HEADLINE: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
President Clinton has ordered the Departments of Defense, State and Justice to devise plans for the arrest and trial of Pol Pot, the shadowy Khmer Rouge leader responsible for the death of perhaps a million Cambodians in the 1970's.
Clinton Administration officials and Western diplomats said that the Khmer Rouge appeared to be near collapse as a result of mass defections and internal fighting. Pol Pot and other Khmer Rouge leaders are said to be in hiding in the Cambodian jungle only a few miles across the border with Thailand. 
 The Thai Government, diplomats said, has suggested it would be willing to take Pol Pot into custody as long as the United States agreed to spirit him out of Thailand within hours of his capture.
Senior American military officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that intelligence reports from Southeast Asia showed that the Thai military had actually taken Pol Pot into custody late last week but then freed him.
The Thai military, the officials said, may have feared that his capture would antagonize China, long an ally of the Khmer Rouge, and would complicate the foreign policy of Thailand's recently installed Government, which is already struggling with an economic crisis.
Spokesmen at the Thai Embassy in Washington had no comment. Other American officials described the intelligence reports as sketchy and said it would be unfair to criticize the Thai military on the basis of such fragmentary evidence.
While Administration officials cautioned that there was no guarantee that the ailing Khmer Rouge leader would be apprehended, they said that recent developments along the border were so significant that President Clinton issued a written order Monday to organize logistics for Pol Pot's capture and trial.
Under one plan being discussed within the Administration, an American military plane would take Pol Pot from Thailand to a third country, possibly the Netherlands, where international tribunals are prosecuting war crimes carried out in Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia.
A military official said the Pentagon had drawn up a list of interim sites where Pol Pot might be held until a location for the trial was selected. These include the Northern Marianas Islands and Wake Island -- both American territories in the Pacific -- or the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
"We've had many false alarms before with the Khmer Rouge, but this may be our best chance to get Pol Pot," said a Clinton Administration official who is involved in the planning. "We're not going to be caught unprepared if he's made available to us."
Another American official said that "if we don't get Pol Pot this time, he may die before we ever have the chance to bring him to justice."
The official said that despite the reports of Pol Pot's capture and release by Thai soldiers last week, the Thai Government "is being cooperative, and their cooperation will be essential if we're to pull this off."
Under President Clinton's order, officials said, the State Department has been directed to oversee negotiations with Thailand, the Netherlands and other nations that might be involved in the apprehension and trial. The Justice Department has been asked to review the legal authority that would be needed under international law for the United States to become involved in the detention of Pol Pot.
Western diplomats said prosecutors at the international tribunals in The Hague had already tentatively agreed to organize a trial for Pol Pot for crimes against humanity, as long as the United Nations Security Council empowers them to oversee the prosecution. The diplomats said the United States, France and other nations had already begun drafting a Security Council resolution to deal with such a trial.
From 1975 to 1979, Pol Pot, who is now in his 70's and in poor health, turned Cambodia into a vast labor camp. Millions of Cambodians, especially city-dwellers, were driven from their homes and forced to work in the fields under primitive conditions. Pol Pot labeled anyone with money or education an enemy of the revolution, and much of the middle class was killed during his four-year reign of terror or starved to death.
The Khmer Rouge were toppled by a Vietnamese invasion in 1979. They resumed their guerrilla struggle in the jungle, where they have remained for two decades. They have armed and fed themselves with the proceeds of the sale of gems and timber harvested in areas of Cambodia under their control.
The movement began to fall apart last year, when the followers of Pol Pot turned against him, apparently over his decision to order the assassination of the Khmer Rouge defense chief, Son Sen, and 14 relatives, including his grandchildren.
After the killings, Pol Pot's former comrades tried him and sentenced him to house arrest. He is reported to be under the control of his former top military commander, Ta Mok.
In interviews last year with an American reporter who observed portions of the trial, Pol Pot said that "My conscience is clear."
"I came to carry out the struggle, not to kill people" he explained. He insisted that estimates that millions had died during the Khmer Rouge reign were overstated. "To say that millions died is too much," he said.

The body of Muhyiaddin al-Sharif, the bomb-maker, was found at the scene of an explosion in the West Bank last month. Hamas blamed Israel for the death, but an investigation by the Palestinian Authority found that it was the result of a power struggle within the militant organization. (AP)

Mr. Jospin told the National Assembly that the expulsions were a result of case-by-case studies based on legislation passed by Parliament. He said they would be applied humanely but firmly. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Indians Striving to Save Their Languages

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: HOOPA, Calif.

 BODY:
At the age of 88 and blind in one eye, James Jackson Jr. keeps a crystal clear memory of a tiny linguistic skirmish in a continental campaign that has brought most of North America's Indian languages to the brink of extinction.
"The teacher at the Indian school grabbed my friend by the arm and said, "You're speaking your language -- I'm going to wash your mouth out with soap," Mr. Jackson recalled. "That's where we lost it." 
 Eight decades later, Mr. Jackson told his story, in English, to a small circle of Hupa language students at the Hoopa Community Center. Although the tribe has about 2,000 members, the room contained the four people who make up about half of the world's fluent Hupa speakers: Mr. Jackson, his younger sister, Minnie, and two elderly friends. Two others died in February.
Despite five centuries of population decline, assimilation and linguistic oppression, most of North America's Indian languages have survived to the end of the 20th century. Of the approximately 300 Indian languages that existed when Europeans first arrived in what is now the United States and Canada, 211 are still spoken today.
But with the impact of television and radio and increased mobility among Indians, North America's native languages are suffering their sharpest free fall in recorded history.
Of the 175 Indian languages still spoken in the United States, only 20 are still spoken by mothers to babies, said Michael Krauss, a linguist at the University of Alaska who surveys native languages. In contrast, 70 languages are spoken only by grandparents, and 55 more are spoken by 10 tribal members or fewer.
"This is a major American tragedy that people are generally in a state of denial about," Dr. Krauss said.
Noting that the Federal Government spends only $2 million a year to save endangered Indian languages, he said that under the Endangered Species Act, "we are spending $1 million a year per Florida panther to save the species."
Belonging to 62 language families, American Indian languages are as dramatically different as German, Chinese and Turkish.
With the rise of a global economy and increased communications, about half of the world's 6,000 languages are expected to disappear over the next century. Among American Indians, that process is unfolding today.
"We just gave a grant to study Klamath," said Douglas H. Whalen, a Yale University linguist who directs a new nonprofit group, the Endangered Language Fund. "When the proposal was made, Klamath had two speakers. Now, it is down to one."
Rapid erosion is also affecting the largest tribes.
In Arizona among the Navajo, the most populous tribe in the United States, the portion of native speakers among first graders has dropped to 30 percent today from 90 percent in 1968.
In Montana, the 9,300 enrolled Crow members display a classic Indian linguistic profile: 77 percent of Crow Indians over 66 years of age speak the language, while only 13 percent of preschoolers do.
On paper, California has the most linguistic diversity in the nation: 50 Indian languages are still spoken there, down from 80 before Europeans arrived.
"But not a single one of those languages is now being spoken natively by children," said Leanne Hinton, a linguistics professor at the University of California at Berkeley. "We are heading toward a state where we will have no native speakers of any of the California languages in 10 or 20 years. We are entering an age when speakers of the California languages will be learning in school, or as adults, rather than at home."
As the language circle at the Hoopa Community Center suggests, however, there is a belated movement among American Indians to rescue their languages from extinction.
"It's part of our culture," said Daniel Ammon, a Hupa high school teacher who is one of several dozen adults studying the tribe's complex language. "It contains how a Hupa person views the world. To lose the language would be to lose our identity. I will talk to my kids all the time in Hupa."
At the regional high school in Hoopa, a town of 1,000 people on a bend of the Trinity River in northwestern California, classes started last fall in the three languages of Indians in the area: Hupa, Karuk and Yurok.
"I want to know Karuk because it is my language, because I want to teach it to my children," Nisha Supahan, 15, said after class as her twin sister, Elaina, giggled in assent.
Their 27-year-old Karuk teacher, Susan Smith, contrasted their attitude with her detribalized upbringing.
"I never heard my language as a child," Ms. Smith said. "I didn't even know how to pronounce my tribal name."
Mr. Ammon and Ms. Smith learned their native language through an innovative effort to stave off linguistic extinction. Since 1992, the Native California Network, a nonprofit group in Visalia, in the state's south-central region, has sponsored 50 "apprentices" to undergo intensive language immersions, sometimes for up to 500 hours, with "masters," tribal elders who speak the language.
The language revival effort is taking many forms. Last year the Crow Tribal Council adopted resolutions declaring Crow the official language of the reservation, honoring fluent speakers as "tribal treasures" and encouraging all tribal members to speak the language.
Elsewhere in Montana, the Northern Cheyenne are offering tribal children a summer language camp, taught by the five elders who still speak Cheyenne fluently. In Missoula, summer language classes are offered in Blackfeet. Across Montana, a recent state decision to ease the certification of Indian language instructors has led to a surge in language instruction.
Idaho State University now offers Shoshoni for foreign language credit.
"At least one quarter of the 30 tribal colleges now require language study," David Cournoyer, a director of the American Indian College Fund, said in Denver. "Today, 25 different languages are taught, plus Plains Indian sign language."
In Connecticut, the Mohegan and Pequot are studying written records in their languages in an effort to revive languages that have not been spoken since the early 1900's. Thanks to the work of missionaries and anthropologists, virtually all of the Indian languages in North America have dictionaries and written texts.
While official language extermination policies have stopped, the main threat today, said Dr. Krauss, the University of Alaska linguist, is "the cultural nerve gas of television."
Putting electronic communications to work, the Hopi of Arizona have expanded Hopi language radio broadcasting, the Choctaw of Oklahoma have produced native language video dramas, the Sioux of South Dakota maintain a Lakota language Internet chat room, and the Skomish of Washington have produced a Twana language CD-ROM.
"There has been an almost total inversion in attitudes toward the native language," said Victor Golla, a linguistics professor at nearby Humboldt State University, who started visiting here 30 years ago. "Before, people were unconcerned about their native language. Now there is a very strong feeling among almost all the people that the loss of their language would be a tragic and very damaging thing."
Indians interested in reviving traditional ways say they cannot pray to their ancestors in English.
"A number of people have learned how to pray in their language," said Ms. Hinton, the Berkeley linguistics professor, who runs a summer program for Indians in California seeking to revive their languages from recorded field notes and tapes. "They are starting to reinvent their languages so they can pray at ceremonies and funerals."
Linguists caution that the language revival movement may only delay inevitable extinctions. But here in Hoopa, a change can already be felt.
"Before, on the bus, I used to say to my sister in Karuk, 'Look at that guy's shirt,' and nobody knew what we were talking about," Nisha Supahan said. "Now that's not true anymore."

HEADLINE: Nurses Put on Fast Forward In Rush for Cost Efficiency

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif.

 BODY:
Click, click, click, click. Heidi Jowett, R.N., snapped her fingers in describing the speed with which she and the nurses she supervises in the new 21-bed short-stay unit of the Kaiser Permanente hospital here perform their tasks. They are what Kaiser, the nation's biggest health maintenance organization, calls accelerated-care nurses: they move patients from suture to discharge in under 48 hours.
When Miss Jowett was a hospital nurse, there was a specialist to draw blood. "In the short-stay unit now, I do it," she said. "I never knew how to do an EKG; now I do it. Pharmacists taught patients about medication; now I do it. It's faster. It's faster when you can do it all. For me, it's almost more fulfilling." 
 Almost. Like many nurses who have been swept into the nation's rush to cost-efficient managed care, Ms. Jowett, 37, has mixed feelings now that the essence of the work that nurses love -- the nurturing of nursing -- is vanishing. A registered nurse for 16 years who wears a button that says "Quality begins with me" and a brooch that says "Nurses have heart," she relishes the challenge of accelerated care but misses giving patients baths and back rubs.
"I was always a nurse who loved to sit at the bedside and ask how they were," she said. "My passion was getting to know my patients, their identity, their hearts, their souls. I would rather know a few patients well than fragments of many."
But in the crucible of managed care, the Florence Nightingale school of nursing is giving way to team systems that get the work done faster and cheaper -- and, managed care organizations maintain, better. The nurse is still accountable for the care of the patients on a hospital floor, but she is now a team leader and coach. Aides give baths. The back rubs have stopped.
"This is happening all over the country," said Delores Jones, Kaiser's director of nursing for California, "and it's extremely difficult for nurses to deal with."
At Kaiser and in many other hospital systems, nurses with advanced degrees and training often welcome the new management responsibilities, the opportunity to assume more of the role of doctors and the higher pay that often goes along with that. But many traditional nurses say they are appalled by having more patients to watch, relying on aides to take up the slack.
They worry that managed care, without restraints, leads to what they call hit-and-run nursing and to mistakes, abuses and oversights. Patients are discharged sooner, and so they need more vigilance, not less, said Kit Costello, president of the California Nurses Association in Sacramento. "Does it make sense to go to less skilled care when patients are sicker?" she asked.
In California, nurses' frustration over managed care's new ways came to a boil over the last year, when six strikes of one and two days were called by the 7,500 members of the California Nurses Association who work in Kaiser's Northern California region.
In March, hours before the start of a seventh strike, Kaiser reached an unusual agreement with its nurses. Kaiser agreed to let the union select 18 members to serve as "quality liaisons," authorized to investigate accusations of poor care and to force a management response.
"They're going to be an unmuzzled voice," said James Letchworth, 47, a Kaiser cardiac rehabilitation nurse in San Francisco. "One of the big frustrations with nursing," he said, "is we see problems, and when we point them out, they say, 'Well, we can't do it today.' "
For all the fury of the dispute, Kaiser Permanente, one of the few nonprofit health maintenance organizations in the United States, regularly ranks near the top of the more than 1,000 H.M.O.'s in the country, both in the satisfaction of its nearly 9 million subscribers and in the quality of its care as measured by the National Committee on Quality Assurance, the leading monitor of health organization quality.
Kaiser has also broken with most of the industry by supporting White House proposals to institute more patient protection laws.
But like any H.M.O., Kaiser operates under extreme pressure from its subscribers' employers to keep costs down, and from stiff competition among health organizations for more subscribers. In the process, Kaiser lost $270 million last year, its first loss in its 53 years.
While both the nurses and the Kaiser management say they are dedicated to the pursuit of quality care, their perspectives often differ. Dr. David M. Lawrence, a former Peace Corps doctor who is Kaiser's chairman and chief executive, wants more computerization of patient records. He also wants knowledge of the best treatments and procedures shared more widely.
Repairing errors, Dr. Lawrence said, costs more than treating patients appropriately in the first place. "Superior quality means lower cost, almost always," he said. "We're trying to move away from a religion, to something that has some scientific base in terms of what we're trying to do for people."
To track down poor and ineffective care, Dr. Lawrence needs advanced computer systems to monitor patients. But that can intrude on a conviction by nurses that quality care requires the intuition and expertise they bring to the bedside.
Asked how her work has changed over a long career, Cecelia Baker, 58, another nurse in the short-stay unit, replied in one word, "Time." She is always rushed. "I have great faith in Kaiser," she said, "but I think the people making the decisions sometimes are accountants."
The accusation of hit-and-run nursing arises from the shift among health maintenance organizations from relying for most care on registered nurses, who have completed two to four years of college, to using what the organizations call team nursing, with nurses supervising workers with less expertise.
Trande Phillips, a Kaiser hospital nurse, said that a unit with 12 patients once would have been assigned three registered nurses, based on the severity of the patients' conditions. Now, she said, that unit has a team of one R.N, a licensed vocational nurse and a nurse's aide. The saving for Kaiser is substantial: Three nurses cost $30 an hour each, or $90, while the team costs about $60 an hour.
"But no matter how many aides I have working with me," Ms. Phillips said, "I have to do everything that's strictly R.N. work -- patients vomiting, patients with severe pain, patients needing changes in their IV medication. So one patient is going to get treatment immediately. The others are going to wait their turn."
And delegating work like baths to aides deprives nurses of an opportunity to detect changes in their patients' condition, nurses say.
"When they're buck naked, it's a bonding, teaching experience, a time to teach as well as to physically assess the patient," said Barbara Lambarida, a union officer and weekend nurse in the intensive care unit at the Summit Medical Center's hospital, a Kaiser rival in Oakland.
"In bathing you detect limits in the range of motion, muscle weakness, muscle tetany, where muscle freezes up," Ms. Lambarida said. "I'm looking at his skin to see if there's any breakdown. When I'm taking care of a patient who has fouled himself, I'm using my nose, I'm smelling that stool. There is a byproduct of bleeding into the gastrointestinal tract -- melanin -- that has a very distinct odor, so even if you can't see blood, you can smell it."
In many respects, however, the interests of nurses and Kaiser in the quality of care converge. Four years ago, Kaiser's ambulatory care clinic in the Western Addition neighborhood of San Francisco opened a cardiac rehabilitation office. Mr. Letchworth has been the nurse operating it for two years.
He monitors 100 to 120 patients who have had heart attacks, bypass surgery or angioplasty, calling them at home periodically to ask about their diets, exercise and success in stopping smoking. Once each week, he reviews the cases with a doctor.
"I'm doing secondary prevention, keeping them from having another event," Mr. Letchworth said. "The computer tells me what I have to talk to them about."
He said only one patient had died while he has managed the program. "The economics are very favorable," he said. "If we prevent one bypass surgery, that's my salary."
And, he said, "I love my job."
The economics of managed care can also expand opportunities for registered nurses. For 20 years, Ethel Nakamura, 58, managed the sigmoidoscopy room at Kaiser's San Francisco clinic, scheduling appointments and maintaining the two-foot-long snakelike scope that doctors use to detect colon cancer.
"Then they decided to train me to do it," Ms. Nakamura said. Last year she began performing the exams herself, and two medical assistants took over management of the sigmoidoscopy room.
"We're called 'R.N.'s in expanded roles,' " she said. "I get to do a lot more. We used to do what doctors told us to do. Today we have our own agenda. We do our own thinking."

Companies Vow to Drop Support for a Tobacco Deal
The chairman of RJR Nabisco, followed by officials of other big tobacco companies, said that his company would no longer work for comprehensive legislation to regulate tobacco and would instead adopt a policy of full-scale advertising and litigation.
The industry asserts that legislation approved by the Senate Commerce Committee would drive companies into bankruptcy. The bill would not give the companies the protection they want from lawsuits based on smoking-related illnesses. Page A1. 

Founder to Depart At USA Networks
Kay Koplovitz, the founder, chairman and chief executive of USA Networks, said that she was leaving the cable television company. Barry Diller, whose HSN Inc. has acquired the company, is expected to assume control. D3.
A Ford to Step Down at Auto MakerEdsel B. Ford 2d, once considered a candidate to lead Ford Motor, will step down as president of the company's auto lending unit and will not take another executive position. D4.
 
Dow Drops, but Nasdaq Rises
Blue-chip stocks fell, led by telephone, oil, drug and bank issues. The Dow industrials fell 65.02 points, to 8,891.48. But the Nasdaq composite index gained 8.30 points, to 1,807.01, its first gain in three sessions. Treasury securities prices fell, with the yield on the 30-year bond rising to 5.89 percent from 5.84. Richard H. Walker, general counsel at the S.E.C., will become the commission's top enforcement officer, investigating wrongdoing in the nation's securities markets. He will succeed William R. McLucas, who will join the prominent Washington law firm of Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering. D2.
 
G.E. Earnings Rise 13 Percent
General Electric said first-quarter earnings rose 13 percent, reflecting the company's successful efforts to cut costs and find new markets. Eleven of the company's 12 main businesses improved profits. Though the results matched expectations, the stock price sank. D5.

The Internet directory service Yahoo, saying traffic on its World Wide Web pages was up sharply, reported earnings that exceeded expectations. D2.

French-U.S. Air Pact
The United States and France agreed to expand access to each other's aviation markets, a move that could drive down fares as competition increases. D4.
 
Trading on Auto Sales
Investors eagerly await the monthly release of sales data from auto makers, a market-moving gauge of the industry's health. But some wait longer than others because of the way the sales figures are distributed, giving a select group of people a profitable trading opportunity. Market Place. D7.
 
Privatized Social Security?
The privatization of Social Security, which once seemed like a far-fetched notion, has become a very real possibility. But getting from here to there will be tricky. Economic Scene: Peter Passell. D2.

HEADLINE: A Revered Relic Stolen From France Is Going Home

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 8

 BODY:
For more than 1,200 years the story of young Maxellendis, a seventh-century Frankish noblewoman who preferred the pious life of a Roman Catholic nun to an arranged marriage to a pagan prince, has been part of the local lore in a string of small agricultural towns in northeastern France.
According to the legend, the jilted prince killed Maxellendis for her impertinence and was instantly struck blind. His sight returned three years later after he begged forgiveness at her grave. That miracle spurred her early beatification, and parts of her body -- a bone fragment, a piece of skin -- became venerated relics. 
 Since its founding in 1635, the Church of St. Martin at Le Cateau, a town of 8,000 in the province of Nord, has cherished a tiny bone fragment from St. Maxellendis. But on Dec. 9, 1996, the ornate 19th-century monstrance, which held the bone pillowed on a red satin liner and set off by a bejeweled brooch, was stolen along with two other gilded monstrances from a glass case suspended six feet above the church floor.
Today in a Newark courtroom, obscure medieval hagiography and the modern market in stolen religious objects came together as a Pennsylvania man pled guilty to smuggling the three objects, valued at $130,000, into the United States.
"The people of the town are shocked and troubled by this affair and they want to know who committed this theft," Maj. Jean-Marie Jumez of the Le Cateau Police Department said in a telephone interview tonight. "You'd have to be very agile and athletic to get at them. We suspected that young boys did it."
Standing before Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise of Federal District Court, the smuggler, Sebastian Zegrean, 23, pled guilty to one count of making false statements to Customs officials when he attempted in December 1996 to send the three objects to his Reading, Pa., home by Federal Express after, he said, they were stolen by others.
The United States Attorney for New Jersey, Faith S. Hochberg, said that Mr. Zegrean, a Romanian citizen who is a legal immigrant living in the United States, had cooperated with investigators after being arrested more than a year ago. As a result, the French police today arrested one of his alleged accomplices -- a Romanian national living in France -- who they said they believe stole the objects from St. Martin Church.
"We believe he was going to attempt to sell them here in the U.S.," said Mrs. Hochberg, when asked why Mr. Zegrean acquired the sacred objects. "There was an agreement to remit funds to the thieves once the objects arrived in the U.S. for sale. Mr. Zegrean was a link in a fairly short chain."
Joel Perrine, an official of the French Directorate of National Heritage, said that such thefts had become more frequent in recent years at small rural churches, such as St. Martin's, where there was no security or guards. In the last seven years, the United States Customs Service has seized more than $30 million in stolen religious objects that were being smuggled into the country in violation of the Cultural Properties Act of 1990, said John C. Varrone, special agent in charge of the service's New York office. Prior to the act, in the 1980's, he said, the estimated value of all seized stolen art was $10.1 million.
"It is one of our fastest-growing categories of crimes," Mr. Varrone said, "and with the disintegration of Eastern Europe we have seen more and more of these objects and religious icons coming in."
Experts said that the market for such items was among auction houses that attracted private collectors as well as museums.
Customs officials said that Mr. Zegrean, a security guard, described the contents of a 18-by-24-by-14-inch box as "a picture frame, candlesticks and Christmas gifts valued at $275" when he shipped them by Federal Express from Lille, just north of Le Cateau, to his home in Reading on Dec. 17, 1996.
When Customs inspectors here X-rayed the box, they became suspicious because it appeared to contain something other than the items Mr. Zegrean had described and because the contents were wrapped in aluminum foil -- a common maneuver by those trying to thwart X-ray detection.
Armed with a description of the items sent out by French authorities, investigators opened the package, seized the contents and focused their attention on Mr. Zegrean.
American officials are working with French diplomats in the United States on plans for "repatriating" the artifacts, but it could not be too soon for Major Jumez and others in Le Cateau.
"The relics belong to the people of Le Cateau and there is a strong religious sentiment here," he said. "The general sentiment is to get them back as soon as possible. We want to know how and when the objects will be brought back."
The story of St. Maxellendis, said Anne-Marie Bouche, an assistant professor of medieval history at Princeton University, is a classic of medieval syncretism, when the Roman Catholic Church was trying to bridge the chasm between pagan beliefs and Christian theology. Those stories were to the common people's devotional life what the illuminated scriptures were to the Scholastics, who labored over translations in hundreds of monasteries.
"It's your basic Merovingian era woman's story," said Ms. Bouche, suggesting that it was the folkloric equivalent of today's romance novels. "There weren't many scripts for women's lives for that day. Marriages were arranged and there weren't many alternatives but to run away and become a nun."
These stories are more "pious fictions" than actual truths, most experts said, but they nevertheless spawned local cults whose adherents venerated the saints as a way of impressing outsiders with the power of the protective spirits that watched over them. It was likely, Ms. Bouche said, that saints like Maxellendis were viewed as a talisman to ward of attacks by roving bands.
Jerrilynn Dodds, an art historian and medievalist who teaches at the City College School of Architecture, said that the monstrance containing the tiny bone fragment from Maxellendis was the key to this protection. Having a "really hot relic," she said, was also an economic benefit because it attracted pilgrims. "It was like having the Super Bowl or the Olympics in your town," she said.
The other two stolen items are formal monstrances, said Msgr. Richard Groncki, rector of the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark, and date to the late 17th and early 18th centuries. They are used with their hinged glass display doors to show the host, or the wafers representing the body of Christ to be venerated in church services. One monstrance had a gilt bronze and enameled facade featuring the four evangelists and the four rivers of paradise, and a filigree base of four cherubs clutching lapis lazuli globes.
Major Jumez said that beyond the spiritual significance of the monstrances, no one in the town overlooked their artistic value. "These things are objects of art -- treasures," he said, sounding eager for their return.

It was one of three monstrances stolen in France and recovered in Newark. (Associated Press)(pg. B1)
 
Map of France shows site of Le Cateau: The town of 8,000 has cherished a bone fragment of St. Maxellendis. (pg. B6)

HEADLINE: California Voters Face New Canvas for Electoral Politics

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 8

 BODY:
In just two months, California voters will begin sifting a pile of options to choose a new governor for the most populous state, decide on whether to retain Senator Barbara Boxer and set statewide law and policy on issues like bilingual education and the use of union dues in political campaigns.
The process will start in the highly unpredictable new arena of the state's first "blanket" primary election, on June 2, in which the names of all candidates for each office will be on the same ballot and voters will be able to select from among all the choices without regard to party. In Los Angeles County, nearly 800 candidates have qualified for various offices, posing a huge challenge to the fortitude of the voters and the capacity of the voting machines. 
 "It's changed the picture," said Bill Carrick, a veteran California political consultant who is advising the Democratic campaign for governor by Representative Jane Harman, who represents beach communities on the south side of Los Angeles. "Instead of operating in a climate that just includes registered Democrats, you have to operate in a climate that includes everybody."
The stakes are high. At the top is replacing Gov. Pete Wilson as head of the world's seventh-largest economy. Mr. Wilson, a two-term Republican, is barred from seeking a third term. The battlefield is giant. When Senator Boxer announced her re-election campaign, she did so by visiting 13 California cities.
And the cost is astronomical. One Democratic contender for governor, Alfred A. Checchi, the former co-chairman of Northwest Airlines, has already spent some $20 million in the effort, more than double the old statewide record for a primary.
The governor's race is the most closely watched and probably the most important single race in the nation this year. For the Democrats, it is a chance to reclaim the office for the first time since Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. left it in 1982, and to elect only the state's fourth Democratic governor this century. For the Republicans, it is a chance to continue their recent dominance through the Congressional redistricting of 2000 by electing Attorney General Dan Lungren, a former Congressman who faces only token opposition for his party's nomination for governor.
So the attention is on the hotly contested primary between Mr. Checchi, Ms. Harman and Gray Davis, the Lieutenant Governor and a Democrat. Mr. Davis, a 20-year veteran of state politics, was Mr. Brown's chief of staff in Sacramento but has seen his long-cherished plan to run for governor challenged by a pair of rich political newcomers. Buffeted by intense television advertising from Mr. Checchi and Ms. Harman -- which Mr. Davis cannot yet afford -- Mr. Davis, 55, has slipped from first to dead last in the Democratic field in statewide polls.
Ms. Harman, 52, a lawyer and an aide in the Carter White House, entered the race in February only after Senator Dianne Feinstein, who for a year had flirted with running, decided not to. California Democrats have nominated women for governor and United States senator in every election since 1990, and in just three weeks of campaigning through televised advertisements, Ms. Harman edged ahead of Mr. Checchi in at least one statewide poll.
"It's going to be a competitive race all the way till the end," said Robert Shrum, the longtime Washington Democratic media consultant who is advising Mr. Checchi.
Mr. Checchi, 49, whose holdings in Northwest Airlines and other investments make him worth more than $700 million, has been traveling around the state for a year in pursuit of the statehouse. He has lately been running about $1.5 million worth of advertisements a week promoting his plans for a cut in automobile insurance rates and improvements in education, among other issues, said aides for rival campaigns.
But in a sign that he feels threatened by Ms. Harman's candidacy, and despite an earlier pledge not to run negative advertisements, Mr. Checchi has also begun broadcasting commercials attacking the Congresswoman, accusing her of such things as voting to raise Social Security taxes. In fact, Ms. Harman voted to raise taxes on only the wealthiest Social Security recipients as part of President Clinton's 1993 budget plan, a major test of party loyalty that passed with no Republican support.
Ms. Harman, who was elected in 1992, has responded with an advertisement in which she says, "Mr. Checchi can waste his money attacking me," and adds: "Leadership is about attacking real problems, not each other."
The new primary system was passed as a ballot initiative two years ago in an effort that its sponsors said would open up the electoral process and make it fairer. But most party professionals worry that it will cause mostly headaches and perhaps be subject to mischief-making.
Given the realities of the new system -- and of the state's preference for Republican governors even though 1.5 million more voters are registered as Democrats -- Ms Harman and Mr. Checchi are emphasizing their centrist appeal. Mr. Checchi never identifies himself in television commercials as a Democrat, and Ms. Harman, who represents a heavily Republican district, once boasted that she was "the best Republican in the Democratic Party."
Ms. Harman, whose husband, Sidney, is the founder and chief executive of Harman International, the stereo and audio equipment manufacturer, has so far spent $5 million of her family's personal wealth on the race. Local political experts predict that she and Mr. Checchi will together shatter all state spending records, and probably national ones, too. Ms. Harman has also won the endorsement of national women's fund-raising groups like Emily's List and the support of much of Ms. Feinstein's state political network, which could help in getting out the vote.
For his part, Mr. Davis has been hard pressed to get any traction since his rivals' spending war began, and he is saving his own $5 million war chest for an advertising blitz just before the primary.
On the Republican side, Mr. Lungren, a staunch abortion opponent whose father was a personal physician to Richard M. Nixon, has largely held his fire. As a result, some Democratic strategists say, Mr. Lungren risks losing voters to Mr. Checchi or Ms. Harman in the June primary who may never return to the Republican ranks in the fall.
Mr. Lungren also unsettled some Republicans with a recent speech laced with religious references, including the assertion that "we have to be a religious people," that some strategists say will not play well in live-and-let-live California.
In the Senate race, Ms. Boxer, 57, who won office six years ago with 48 percent of the vote, had once been thought vulnerable. But her Republican opposition is shaping up as fractured and unsensational. State Treasurer Matt Fong and Representative Frank Riggs are competing against Darrell Issa, a millionaire car-alarm maker who has already spent more than $6 million of his fortune, most of it on television advertisements.
Mr. Issa, 44, has a personal wealth estimated at $200 million, but he, too, is a political novice who has been dismissed by Mr. Riggs as a "glib, fast-talking Ross Perot eccentric." Mr. Issa has committed a novice's share of groaners, saying this week that his wife had described President Clinton as a slut and adding, "I will not disagree with my wife in public."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Investors Snap Up Korea Bonds in a Big Vote of Confidence

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
South Korea, financially destitute just four months ago, won an enormous vote of confidence from investors around the world yesterday with the successful sale of $4 billion in Government bonds.
It was the first time South Korea had attempted to sell i.o.u.'s to foreign investors since the worst of its economic crisis in December, when the Government's largest state-owned bank had to scrap a bond sale because of investor resistance. 
 By contrast, the huge demand yesterday represented a bet that South Korea, which has taken important steps to strengthen its economy and ease a severe debt problem over the last four months, will surge back to prosperity in the next few years.
A welcome reaction to the bond sale was evident this morning in South Korea, where the stock market jumped 3.69 percent. The Seoul Government also was pleased with the outcome and announced today that it would sell a further $1 billion in bonds next month.
To some extent, the successful bond sale also showed investors are increasingly confident that Asia's economic malaise has eased, diminishing the risk of a contagion that has troubled global financial markets since last summer, when the unraveling economies of Thailand and Indonesia touched off the Asian crisis.
"One of the concerns was whether or not what was going on in Asia would cascade into other countries and damage their ability to finance themselves," in regions like Eastern Europe and Latin America, said Joyce Chang, an emerging-markets debt strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "But a real liquidity crisis has not happened."
Viewing South Korea's bond offering as a lucrative opportunity, investors snapped up the $1 billion in five-year notes and $3 billion in 10-year bonds. They are wagering that South Korea's credit rating, which had been severely downgraded to below investment-grade status as its financial health deteriorated last year, will improve as its economy strengthens. An investment-grade rating would make the bonds far more valuable.
Investment bankers at Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Smith Barney, which managed the bond sale as advisers to South Korea's Government, had spent the last two weeks talking to more than 500 investors in 15 cities around the world about the deal. They were ebullient yesterday because customer orders totaled $12 billion.
"In 20 years in the business, this is the largest book for a subinvestment grade or sovereign credit I have ever seen," said Carlos Cordeiro, a managing director and head of Asian debt capital markets at Goldman, Sachs. "People are convinced that Korea is coming back."
Crippled by a plunging currency and tens of billions of dollars in short-term debt, South Korea teetered on default in December, when the International Monetary Fund provided a record $57 billion emergency assistance package.
Since then Seoul has made several significant changes demanded by the I.M.F., including the closing of money losing banks, less Government control over business and fewer restrictions on foreign ownership of South Korean companies. More than $20 billion in short-term bank loans owed to foreign banks have been repackaged into longer-term debt, further easing the pressure.
"South Korea has made substantive progress in reforming its economy, particularly in the financial sector," said Sem Karacadag, a sovereign debt analyst at the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In recognition of the improvement, Standard & Poor's upgraded its credit rating to BB+ Feb. 18, up from B+.
That is still below investment grade and well below the double-A rating South Korea enjoyed before the Asia crisis, when yields on South Korea bonds were only about one percentage point higher than yields on comparable United States Treasury bonds.
By contrast, the yields on the securities priced yesterday are consistent with the higher risks associated with bonds sold recently by other emerging-market nations.
The five-year securities were priced to yield 8.953 percent, or 3.45 percentage points over the prevailing yield on comparable five-year United States Treasury securities. The 10-year notes were priced to yield 9.084 percent, 3.55 percentage points over the prevailing yield on comparable 10-year Treasuries.
About two-thirds of the bonds were sold to investors in the United States, Mr. Cordeiro said. The remainder was split between European and Asian investors.
Demand for the bonds remained strong after the sale, and prices moved higher.
By late yesterday, the five-year notes were quoted at a spread of 3.35 percentage points over five-year Treasury securities; the 10-year notes were quoted at a spread of 3.45 percentage points over Treasury securities of comparable maturity.
The enthusiastic reception for the new South Korea debt partly reflects eased investor anxiety about debt issued by all emerging-market countries. That stands in sharp contrast to the anemic appetite for these securities in December, when worries about the cascading effect of the Asian crisis were at their peak. At that time, only $1 billion in new emerging-market bonds were priced, Ms. Chang said. That figure crept up to $3 billion in February.
Since early March, nearly $18 billion in new deals from countries like the Philippines and Brazil have been offered, including yesterday's sale by South Korea. Another $10 billion worth of securities from emerging markets are in the pipeline, she added.
Proceeds from yesterday's bond offering will become reserves of the South Korean Government, Mr. Cordeiro said.
Despite the improved outlook, it remains instructive to see how far South Korea has fallen in the last year. There is also some risk that South Korea could falter again.
Last summer, before the crisis hit, the country's investment-grade debt was trading at 85 basis points over Treasury securities of comparable maturity. In the last two months of 1997, its credit ratings dropped as much as nine notches.
A record 17,000 South Korean companies went bankrupt last year; corporations there have yet to renegotiate what could be $300 billion in domestic and foreign debt, and Japan's apparent inability or unwillingness to invigorate its own economy could hurt its Asian neighbors.
"The South Koreans admitted there is still a good deal to do, and were willing to admit their problems," said Phil Bennett, a managing director and head of international capital markets at Salomon Smith Barney. "Early on in the process, investors were skeptical, and needed to be persuaded. But the South Koreans did a terrific job in that regard."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasuries Weaken
 Prices of United States Government securities sagged yesterday, hurt by a weaker dollar and lower-than-expected demand at the Treasury's first auction of 30-year inflation indexed bonds.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond dropped 23/32, to a price of 103 9/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.89 percent, from 5.84 percent Tuesday.
Heading into the Treasury's $8 billion auction of inflation-indexed bonds, traders considered the issue attractive. But the dollar's decline in currency dealings made investments in United States securities less attractive to foreign investors. Demand for new, high-yielding South Korea debt may also have diminished demand for United States bonds.
The inflation-pegged securities were introduced in 1997 with the sale of five-year and 10-year maturities. They are designed to protect investors from inflation by paying a predetermined yield plus the rate of inflation. Following are results of the auction:

HEADLINE: Morocco Finds Fundamentalism Benign but Scary

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: CASABLANCA, Morocco

 BODY:
A group of students at the University of Casablanca were comparing notes about how they were being courted by militants of an Islamist movement.
One month the recruiters offered cultural visits to Marrakesh. Another time they volunteered to distribute free photocopies of text books, which are expensive and scarce. Last year, another student recalled, the recruiters offered karate lessons and special coaching for exams. 
 "They all pretend that they just want to help us," said Amina Maadi, a second-year economics student. "They really want us to get involved in their causes."
Militant Islamic groups have been mobilizing and expanding in Morocco, as they have in other Muslim nations. By assisting the sick, the widowed and the unemployed, they have gained followers in the shantytowns in Tangier, Rabat and Casablanca. Their charities run blood banks and help people organize funerals. On feast days they offer lamb or mutton to the poor.
The groups have been steadily reaching into the educational system, enlisting high school teachers and university students, both men and women. Until a recent crackdown, most student leaders of the country's 14 universities belonged to Justice and Charity, the larger and more radical of Morocco's two main Islamic movements.
The Islamists have made inroads at schools because they seize on the frustrations of the students with the lack of job opportunities and the shortage of classrooms. But estimates about Muslim militants who are hostile to the Government are imprecise.
"It is very difficult to measure the impact of these organizations," said Mohammed Tozy, a political scientist who has written extensively on religion and Islamic politics in Morocco. "There are many claims, going from 50,000 to 500,000 members. They are a minority, but they are very motivated, very determined.
"As in much of the Arab world, they grow because of the great malaise, the social injustice, the harsh life in the cities, the generation gap."
In practice, most Moroccan youths are not anti-Western. But many who do not belong to the ranks of the rich resent the lack of jobs and a culture of corruption.
A recent opinion poll that startled the Establishment said almost 90 percent of Moroccans between the ages of 20 and 29 want to leave the country. Among university graduates, 70 percent want to settle abroad. The poll did not say so but for most young people, "abroad" means Western Europe or the United States.
By the standards of Algeria across the border, where Islamists are fighting to overthrow the Government, the Moroccans are low key and moderate and have avoided any suggestion of violence.
But the example of Algeria, with its continuing blood baths and massacres of civilians, has shaken many Moroccans. People here insist that such havoc cannot happen in this stable nation, where for 37 years King Hassan II has demonstrated his considerable political skills. Moreover, the argument goes, Morocco is already an Islamic state with a King who is both the political and the spiritual leader and claims to be a descendant of Mohammed.
But the Justice and Charity movement refuses to recognize the King as the religious leader, which is tantamount to blasphemy here. Abdessalam Yassine, the movement's founder, once mocked Hassan, calling him "my dear nephew of the Prophet." The movement maintains that Islam and its rites have been eroded and corrupted and must be returned to a purer state.
In interviews, the King and palace officials dismiss the importance of fundamentalism, but its rise keeps prompting the question: Does militant Islam pose a threat to Morocco?
"Morocco is basically conservative and pacifist," said a Middle Eastern diplomat with long experience here. "Militant Islamists are not now threatening the stability of the country, but they are clearly preparing for the future."
The clearest signal that the militants are taken seriously among the 28 million Moroccans is the Government's response: Justice and Charity wants to be recognized as a political party and to take part in elections, but the palace has refused. Mr. Yassine, who is close to 70 and has been in and out of jail, is under house arrest and barred from making public statements. The Ministry of Religious Affairs and the ubiquitous police closely watch members and clerics, even inside the mosques.
At the same time the Government has urged another, more moderate Islamic group -- Reform and Renewal -- to join a small political party that won nine parliamentary seats in December. Some people see this as a deft move to divide the Islamists, who have already begun to criticize one another.
There have been tensions at the universities, above all in Casablanca, a gritty industrial city. With 34,000 students, Casablanca's university is Morocco's largest and serves as a political barometer. It used to be a center of Marxist activism until the Muslim militants took over the student organizations.
At the large campus on the edge of town, there are no posters or banners, and students in jeans and sweaters mingle easily with those in long Arab robes and head scarves. In interviews, though, students and teachers said that while a few years ago students had practically stopped covering their heads, there had been a noticeable rise in the use of scarves, which can be either a religious symbol or a political banner.
Ms. Maadi and her friends, nibbling a lunch of dates and almond pies, said many students are frustrated. "I feel I'm living in the middle of a traffic jam and I cannot get out," said one young man.
As a result, students have held strikes and demonstrations organized by the Islamists at several universities. The Government blamed Islamic activists for the unrest but also said that the university authorities were too passive. Rectors have been replaced at eight universities, as have dozens of faculty members.
Among the replacements is El-Bachir Kouhlani, dean of the faculty of law and economics here. In a recent interview in his office, he explained that he had begun to organize sports events, excursions and cultural activities, and had set up an office to help students in need. His program resembles the agenda of the Islamist student groups but "we are creating a very different atmosphere," he said.
Out on the lawn, students on their lunch break had a different explanation for the new calm: the number of police plainclothesmen on campus has more than doubled, they said. The policemen are meant to keep out of sight, but the students see them as lumbering spy planes and "we call them Awacs," one said.

HEADLINE: One in Every 8 Plant Species Is Imperiled, a Survey Finds

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
At least 1 of every 8 plant species in the world -- and nearly 1 of 3 in the United States -- is under threat of extinction, according to the first comprehensive worldwide assessment of plant endangerment.
The assessment, which required more than 20 years of work by botanists and conservationists around the globe, added nearly 34,000 plant species to the World Conservation Union's growing Red List of imperiled organisms. 
 The survey, made public yesterday in Washington, found that among the plants most at risk were 14 percent of rose species, 32 percent of lilies, 32 percent of irises, 14 percent of cherry species and 29 percent of palms. Many species of coniferous trees, and many plant species found in island nations, were also judged especially vulnerable.
While endangered mammals and birds have commanded more public attention, it is plants, scientists say, that are more fundamental to nature's functioning. They undergird most of the rest of life, including human life, by converting sunlight into food. They provide the raw material for many medicines and the genetic stock from which agricultural strains of plants are developed. And they constitute the very warp and woof of the natural landscape, the framework within which everything else happens.
The census of imperiled plants should be taken not as an exact measure of the situation, leaders of the survey said, but rather as a first, rough approximation.
And some acknowledged that the majority of species were "secure and widespread," in the words of Dr. Bruce Stein, a botanist who is a senior scientist with the Nature Conservancy, one of nine scientific and conservation organizations that participated in drawing up the list. Furthermore, Dr. Stein said, some plants were placed on the list simply because they are rare, not because their numbers are declining or their habitat is threatened.
Nevertheless, of the world's 270,000 known species of plants, the 12.5 percent found to be at risk is a huge proportion, said David Brackett of Ottawa, chairman of the World Conservation Union's Species Survival Commission. Moreover, he said, the figure is probably an underestimate, since data from most places in the world -- including some species-rich tropical nations where the countryside is being rapidly cleared -- are fragmentary.
The list of imperiled plants fills more than 750 pages of a large red-bound book. Nine of every 10 plants on the list are native to only one country, making them especially vulnerable to national or local economic and social conditions. Many species are found only on a few islands, and countries like Mauritius, the Seychelles and Jamaica consequently have disproportionately high numbers of threatened plants.
Scientists generally cite two main reasons plants become endangered: destruction of large swaths of wild countryside by agriculture, logging or development, and invasions of plants from one part of the world that run riot and crowd out native species in another part.
The new listing of threatened plants is one more piece of evidence that "a whole chunk of creation is at risk," said Dr. Stuart Pimm, an ecologist at the University of Tennessee, who was not involved in producing the report.
While 1 plant in 8 may not seem like much, Dr. Pimm said, "that's what's threatened now, as a consequence of what we've done so far; but all the evidence is that the destruction is continuing at an accelerating pace."
With 4,669 of its species judged to be threatened to one degree or another, the United States ranked first, by far, among all nations in total number of plants at risk. That is 29 percent of the country's 16,108 plant species.
But Dr. Stein said the United States' situation looked comparatively grim only because plants were probably better surveyed here than elsewhere.
"I don't believe the U.S. is worse off than other countries," he said. "If anything, I think the U.S. has taken a more active interest in plant conservation."
Dr. Stein's group, the Nature Conservancy, maintains what is widely regarded as one of North America's most comprehensive databases on endangered plants. Other major American participants in drawing up the Red List were the New York Botanical Garden and the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History.
The conservation union, also called the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, is based in Gland, Switzerland. Many governments and scientific organizations are among its members. Since 1960, it has been maintaining and adding to its Red List of threatened species. The list has no official effect but is widely regarded as an influential guide for conservation policy makers.
Two years ago, the union placed nearly a quarter of all known mammal species and 11 percent of birds on the list. It also added a number of marine species for the first time.
The Red List establishes five categories of organisms: species not seen in the wild in 50 years and presumed extinct; species suspected of having recently become extinct; endangered species, those likely to become extinct if the causes of endangerment continue; vulnerable species, those likely to become endangered if the causes of vulnerability continue, and rare species, those with small worldwide populations not yet endangered or vulnerable. Of the total number of plants on the Red List, 43 percent are classified as rare, 24 percent as vulnerable and 20 percent as endangered.

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International;
The World Car Wears New Faces

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
IN the early years of this century, Henry Ford had a notion that he could sell the same car everywhere in the world, and he was right: Some 15 million Model T's -- built at plants in North and South America, Europe and Japan -- were sold worldwide during that seminal model's 20-year run.
But Ford's concept of a simple, low-cost, unchanging car for the masses was relegated to the scrap heap as a wider variety of models emerged from various countries. The one-world, one-car formula no longer worked.
 
 Recently, though, the idea for a world car has resurfaced as a way for manufacturers to achieve vast economies of scale. Successes have been few so far, although Toyota has hit a home run with its Corolla, which is sold worldwide in various body styles built on a common platform -- the basic architecture of a vehicle, primarily the chassis. The Corolla now ranks as the best-selling car of all time. (The Ford Motor Company's F-Series pickups are the world's best-selling vehicles over all, and their platforms also serve as the basis for the Ford Expedition and Lincoln Navigator sport utilities.)
Now Ford, the pioneer of the original world car concept, is searching for the right new formula with some intriguing experiments. Rather than offer one car like the Model T for all nations, Ford's approach this time is to use one basic platform to create a variety of vehicles that can be tailored to individual markets, including low-volume niche models that can be built in a cost-effective way.
 Among Ford's first efforts toward a modern world-car strategy was the Ford Mondeo, developed in Europe and sold in the United States as the Contour and Mercury Mystique sedans. A $6 billion undertaking, which included the development of a platform as well as engines and transmissions, the Mondeo program had mixed results.
Although the compact car sold well in Europe, Americans considered its counterparts too small and, initially, too expensive, The company was forced to reprice the cars and reposition them in the United States.
Ford has taken the Mondeo platform out for another spin, using it as the basis for a new, sporty Mercury Cougar coupe, which goes on sale this spring in the United States and Europe. The 1999 Cougar will be on display at the New York International Auto Show, which opens to the public tomorrow and runs through April 19 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.
The Cougar's styling is an example of New Edge, a type of design developed within Ford's American operations, in which sharp creases add definition to an otherwise softly sculptured body. But the car's firm ride and responsive handling characteristics are thoroughly European. The Cougar will be built at Ford's joint-venture plant with Mazda in Flat Rock, Mich., south of Detroit.
But Ford's world car planning is not confined to just one platform. It is using another chassis, one currently used mainly in Europe and Brazil, to create a host of unusual and varied small cars. Already in production are three small, successful and critically acclaimed front-drive vehicles -- the Fiesta subcompact, the innovative Ka city car and the sporty Puma coupe -- as well as a small Brazilian pickup truck, the Courier.
The latest variation on this platform is the Libre, a concept car that is also on display at the New York auto show. The Libre (pronounced LEE-bray) is an innovative four-passenger convertible that could be marketed to couples who would like to own, say, a Mazda Miata, but need more than two seats. The Libre has four doors, but they are configured like those on some new four-door pickups: the back doors are hinged at the rear and latch into the front doors. To unlatch a rear door, the front door must be opened first.
Despite the common genes of these small Fords, the design concepts behind each -- none of them are sold in the United States -- are completely different. The Ka (pronounced cah), a tiny, high-mileage city car, was among Ford's first products to wear New Edge lines. The swoopy, sporty curves of the Puma coupe, which is also a New Edge design, are quite different from the Ka. In contrast, the Libre has soft and flowing lines.
 Although Ford has not made the Libre available for test drives, its driving characteristics are likely to be similar to those of the agile Puma, with which it shares most of its components, save for engines. (The Libre's 1.25-liter, four-cylinder engine is considerably smaller than the Puma's 1.7-liter four-cylinder power plant.)
Ford will not confirm whether it is seriously considering offering any version of its small platform, including the Libre, in the United States. But J. Mays, Ford's vice president for design, said a strong business case could be made at least for the Libre, since the shared platform would go a long way toward making such a niche vehicle cost-effective.
If successful, Ford's modern-day approach could offer the best of both worlds: proving the worth of Henry Ford's notion that low-cost cars could be built around the world, and offering consumers in various countries the models that appeal to local tastes and demands.

HEADLINE: A Feisty Cat For Europe

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
ONE of the most interesting and entertaining cars I have driven lately is one you cannot buy in the United States: the Ford Puma.
Ford began selling the small and very sporty coupe in Europe a year ago. At a price of just over $18,000, the German-made car is aimed at European auto enthusiasts on a modest budget. 
 The Puma's appeal, and its fun, begin with its styling. A prime example of Ford's New Edge design, the Puma has pronounced lines and a short back end that gives the car a swoopy, speedy look.
Inside, the large gauges have black numbers on white dials. Brushed aluminum is used as accents -- on the shift knob, on the door, around the gauges and across the center of the instrument panel.
In a weeklong test drive in Michigan, the Puma grabbed attention everywhere it went, prompting questions from the teller at my bank's drive-through window, getting stares from hairdressers through the win dows of the beauty shop, and inspiring a couple of 20-something guys in a pickup to pull alongside, signal me to roll down the window and ask about the car.
The Puma's performance neatly meshes with its fun appearance. Its very direct steering responds immediately to the slightest movement of the wheel, reminding me of a go-cart I drove as a child. The Puma is not simply agile, it moves with razor-sharp precision, tempting an ordinarily reticent driver to dart in and out of traffic. Its five-speed shifter has extremely short throws between gears for quick shifting. The Puma zips away from stoplights thanks to its lightweight 1.7-liter, four-cylinder engine, and the brakes are decisive.
The comfortable, body-hugging seats held me in place through quick maneuvers. I found the firm ride comfortable, although I suspect it is too stiff for most Americans.
The Puma shares its front-drive architecture with the Ford Fiesta and Ka, both of which are also sold only in Europe. Sharing a platform makes it easier and more cost-effective for Ford to create fun niche models like the Puma. Still, the economies of scale may not be enough to prompt Ford to import the Puma to the United States. The American market for sporty coupes has collapsed, and the car would have to be reworked to meet safety and emissions standards. That's too bad, for this is one enjoyable car. MICHELLE KREBS

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
When a Lone Voice Can Fill a Stage

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS

 BODY:
Brian Cox and Danny Hoch. The names almost sound as if they were designed to mesh, in a Cole Porter lyric, perhaps. And yet one would be hard-pressed to find two performers of more divergent style and pedigree: Mr. Cox, the redoubtable Scottish actor, an accomplished interpreter of Shaw and Shakespeare; Mr. Hoch, the hip-hop chameleon from Queens, inspired as much by the scrawls on subway walls as by anything on paper.
It's hard to imagine the excuse that would land them in front of an audience together. But in their separate spheres, each alone on a bare stage, they create the same magic. Not so much in terms of diction or mannerisms, nor in the messages they impart. They share what one might call leadership ability, that reservoir of self-belief and innate fortitude from which certain gifted souls draw powers of persuasion and turn the rest of us into willing followers. Each is currently the captain of his own one-man show in Manhattan, Mr. Cox in "St. Nicholas," a shaggy-dog monodrama by Conor McPherson about a boozing theater critic, and Mr. Hoch in "Jails, Hospitals and Hip-Hop," an evening of bristlingly funny sketches of his own devising. 
 Never mind the low overhead and lonely-looking curtain calls; they're among the sharpest, most theatrical and, yes, character-rich productions in town. Content is of course a key; both performers have ripping yarns to tell. But solo shows are peculiarly personality-driven, and it's the force of personality that draws us into "St. Nicholas" and "Jails," no matter what other dazzlements these works may provide.
Mr. Cox and Mr. Hoch are leaders in another respect. They are offering new creative rationale for the one-person show, a format so frequently rolled out in playhouses these days that the New York stage sometimes seems an imitation Speakers' Corner.
Who would have thought that some of the most compelling theater of the season, works of some of the most expressive language and subtle construction, would have emanated from stages practically empty of scenery, by actors standing up there, talking directly to us?
From a hypnotist, Paul McKenna, at the Roundabout, to a mind-reader, Marc Salem, at the Westside Theater; from Tyne Daly, playing five different women in "Mystery School," to John Cameron Mitchell, as a surgically engineered one in "Hedwig and the Angry Inch," theaters all over town are filled with entertainers flying solo. Sandra Bernhard's superb, acerbic hit, "I'm Still Here . . . Damn It!," has come and recently gone. Along with John Leguizamo, who continues to play to sold-out houses on Broadway with his autobiographical "Freak," and Eddie Izzard, who has arrived from London with a new stand-up show, "Dress to Kill," in the West Village, many of these performers are proving that in noisy times a lone voice still has the texture and the power to open up worlds, even without a chorus to back it up.
Only it has to be the right voice. Let's face it: The only thing more unbearable than a large cast muddling through a boring play is the sound of one man droning. Reflect for a moment on that college lecturer who made the battles of the Civil War sound about as exciting as the items on a grocery list, or that after-dinner speaker who induced narcolepsy with a discussion of the intrigues on the House subcommittee on intercoastal waterways, and you have a good idea of the squirm fest that awaits you at the Wrong One-Man Show.
There are way too many of these in New York. Impersonations of marginal historical figures who are obscure for good reason; witnessings of triumphs over distasteful medical conditions that should only be discussed long before a meal; colorful travelogues about parts of the country you would never want to visit: this is the stuff of bad monodrama, the sort at which the ushers would be kinder to pass out pillows than programs. In a profession with rampant unemployment, it's no wonder that actors develop their own material as a means of filling the gaps between jobs. But the pieces so often seem to be little more than time-killers.
Of course, the theater of the sole practitioner has numerous success stories. The genre breaks down broadly into two categories, one-person plays and personal monologues. From "Krapp's Last Tape" to "Full Gallop," there is a history of rewarding theater written for one person (and in the radical case of Samuel Beckett's "Not I," for one mouth) and a trove of great performances to go with them. Fiona Shaw's amazing translation of Eliot's "Waste Land" into a theater piece was a high point last season; yet to come this season is Edward Petherbridge's eagerly awaited rendition of "Krapp's Last Tape" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
The field of first-person monologuist is generally more crowded, and more heavily abused. In this compulsively tell-all era, everyone, for better or worse, wants 15 minutes at center stage. Still, out of the mouths of veterans like Spalding Gray and Lily Tomlin and newer entrants like Claudia Shear and Dael Orlander smith, the monologue can be given a shape and meaning beyond the purely personal. With artistry it can be made to transcend the exclusive "me."
In all its forms, the one-person show continues to proliferate. Here's a fly-by of the most memorable of the talking heads now playing in New York City, the Big Soapbox:
Plays with large casts have the luxury of providing villains. But short of "An Evening With Benito Mussolini," the one-person show almost always involves a character with whom you're meant to empathize. In this regard, first impressions are crucial, and at "JAILS, HOSPITALS AND HIP-HOP" the affection you'll feel for Mr. Hoch will be instantaneous. Forget the dreary title: the 90 minutes spent with this perceptive performer and his seemingly inexhaustible wit will erase any memory of the drabness of your day.
Mr. Hoch, a 27-year-old New York product who spent some court-ordered time on Riker's Island, carries on the tradition of such solo-show veterans as Whoopi Goldberg and Mr. Leguizamo. He shifts in and out of characters with astonishing precision. Among the best of his thoroughly original creations are a break dancer in Cuba trying to impress an American visitor and a young man showing the brain-damaging effects of a mother who took cocaine during her pregnancy. Not a moment passes at Performance Space 122 when Mr. Hoch doesn't come across as potent and authentic; he has put together one of the most dynamic solo shows since Claudia Shear's "Blown Sideways Through Life."
Mr. Hoch's theatrical peer, the far better known Mr. Leguizamo, has an even more exhilarating hold on an audience in "FREAK," his coming-of-age tour de force at the Cort Theater. The show, which has just been extended through July 4, is an exuberant blend of impressions and confession; whether or not some of his tales are exaggerations, Mr. Leguizamo's dead-on impersonations and powers of observation convey with a welcome bite a childlike grown-up's view of a turbulent immigrant family.
Verbally adroit ("We were trying to recreate the inside of a papaya," he says of his mother's style of interior decorating for their Jackson Heights apartment) and physically virtuosic (how does he, in milliseconds, so perfectly capture the body language of an Irish street tough?), Mr. Leguizamo takes the sounds and scenes of his youth and in a miraculous feat for a one-man band, plays them back in a veritable symphony.
In contrast to the dysfunctional family circus of "Freak," Mr. Cox performs subtler stunts in "ST. NICHOLAS," at Primary Stages through April 25. While Mr. Leguizamo takes us boisterously up on the high wire, Mr. Cox works closer to the ground, taking us quietly into his confidence. It's a more concentrated kind of performance, requiring a conservation rather than explosion of energy. By evening's end, you've learned precious little about the actor, and only slightly more than that about the man he plays. The effort here is almost exclusively in the casting of a spell.
Mr. Cox's voice is as elastic as Mr. Leguizamo's body, an invaluable asset in a 90-minute play that celebrates the ancient art of narration. In Mr. McPherson's piece, Mr. Cox, as an embittered hack who spent years as a Dublin drama critic, spins a mordantly funny tale about a drunken night in which he fell in with a houseful of vampires.
Only an actor with a highly developed sense of irony could pull off this material, and in Mr. Cox the playwright has an ideal interpreter. He seems to inhabit the body and soul of a storyteller tired of everything in life except the sound of his own story.
In "MYSTERY SCHOOL," at the Angel Orensanz Foundation on the Lower East Side, Ms. Daly is doing the storytelling in five distinct movements. She plays an array of characters in Paul Selig's collection of monologues about women and the manifestations of faith, and while her work is proficient, the overall effect is rarely more than mechanical.
At the other end of the spectrum, Mr. Izzard plays only himself in "DRESS TO KILL" at the Westbeth Theater Center, and the results are a lot more satisfying. Unlike the writers of the other pieces, Mr. Izzard, a cross-dressing comic who sends up such lampoonable staples as television commercials and movie stars, makes no attempt to impose much structure on his musings. The delight here is in contrasts. He is a walking, talking paradox, a heterosexual decked out as outlandishly as Boy George but whose ordinary-guy insights are closer to the sensibility of Bob Newhart.
Mr. Izzard is so successful because he was born for stand-up: he and his material are one. No one gets more of a wicked charge out of his observations than he does, and that's O.K. It all goes back to that ineffable skill, to stand before a crowd and demand that it see the world as you do.
In the category of nervy star turns, however, Mr. Mitchell, of "HEDWIG AND THE ANGRY INCH" at the Jane Street Theater, is in an elite class all his own. Though technically not a one-person show -- in addition to a band, Cheater, a supporting player, virtually mute, shares the stage with him -- "Hedwig" is essentially a monologue with music, the story, narrated and sung by Mr. Mitchell, of a transsexual rock singer divided against himself.
Perched tenuously between manhood and womanhood, Hedwig is a soul of outward confusion seeking inner peace, and Mr. Mitchell delivers a spectacularly visceral portrait of an identity in tatters. His work here sums up the appeal of the best in solo performances. It's the naked ego on display, in all its rawness, humanity and frailty.
