HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Linking a President's Personality and His Policies

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

FLAWED GIANT
Lyndon Johnson and His Times, 1961-1973
By Robert Dallek
Illustrated. 754 pages. Oxford University Press. $35.
 In light of the current White House sex scandals, renewed attention is being paid to the character question. Just what bearing does the character of a President have on his ability to govern? Can personality be separated from policy; morality and temperament from governance? 
 In the case of Lyndon Baines Johnson, the scholar Robert Dallek argues, the private and the political were inextricably intertwined.
In "Flawed Giant," the second and concluding volume of his monumental life of Johnson, Mr. Dallek suggests that the 36th President's outsize, conflicted personality -- at once grandiose and insecure, idealistic and self-serving, visionary and petty -- played a major, perhaps even pivotal, role in shaping both his achievements and failures in office.
Mr. Dallek, professor of history at Boston University, suggests that Johnson's ambitious Great Society programs and commitment to civil rights were firmly rooted in his own sense of self as an underdog, a "poor boy from Texas struggling to emerge from the shadows and win universal approval." "As with all the major reforms he backed throughout his political career, he was most ardent and effective when he could see a public problem as an enlargement of a personal concern," Mr. Dallek writes.
He continues: "A war on poverty, Government programs to eliminate individual and family need, resonated with his own memories and enduring feelings of deprivation; equal rights and opportunities for minorities were an indirect assault on prejudice against a Lyndon Johnson, the Southerner or Southwesterner from rural Texas whose regional identity partly kept him from a Presidential nomination in 1960; Federal aid to education meant increased opportunity for the schooling Lyndon had used to pull himself up the economic and social ladders."
Yet if Johnson's domestic reforms owed a debt to his own identification with the disenfranchised, Mr. Dallek also suggests that his tragic mishandling of Vietnam stemmed from his need to see the war as a personal test of his judgment. Even as Johnson's "lifelong compulsion to be the best, to dominate and win" made him reluctant to become "the first American President to lose a war," his deep-seated insecurities (combined with his competitive mistrust of Robert F. Kennedy) compelled him to demonize critics of his Vietnam policy and cut off reasoned debate.
"Though no one can say with certainty what Johnson's fundamental motives were, including Johnson himself," Mr. Dallek writes, "it is not too much of a stretch to conclude that the Johnson personality was inhibiting him from a more realistic and sensible resolution of a war policy that seemed certain to lead to more losses, more domestic divisions and greater limitations on his capacity to lead at home and abroad."
Drawing upon hours of newly released White House tapes and dozens of interviews with people close to Johnson, Mr. Dallek has created, in this volume, a minutely detailed portrait of Johnson as a contradictory and larger-than-life figure, a Shakespearean character: needy, driven, devious, magnanimous and explosive. There is little about this portrait that is really new; in the last six months alone, Michael R. Beschloss's "Taking Charge" (an annotated collection of Johnson's White House tape transcripts) and Jeff Shesol's "Mutual Contempt" (an analysis of his rivalry with Robert F. Kennedy) have given us similar portraits of Johnson. But Mr. Dallek most persuasively shows how Johnson's personality informed his policy making and day-by-day decisions.
His book may not be as fluently written, or dramatically engaging, as Robert A. Caro's continuing biography of Johnson ("The Path to Power" and "Means of Ascent"), but it's considerably more evenhanded. We are left with a picture of a man who is less evil than fatally flawed, and less hateful than erratic, self-deluding and troubled.
Because Johnson, his Presidency and his prosecution of the Vietnam war have been dissected so frequently, much of "Flawed Giant" is devoted to retracing familiar ground. Once again, we are treated to discussions of Johnson's efforts to establish his Administration in the shadow of John F. Kennedy's assassination. Once again, we are treated to a chronicle of Johnson's legislative prowess in getting his Great Society bills passed. Once again, we are treated to an extended account of his escalation of the war in Vietnam and the growing protest against his Administration.
In Mr. Dallek's opinion, Johnson could not have walked away from Vietnam in 1963-64, given existing assumptions about the cold war and his own unproven record as an unelected President. He also argues that Johnson made two crucial mistakes in his later handling of the war. By failing to discuss his policy of escalation openly, Mr. Dallek contends, Johnson failed to "build the necessary consensus for the fighting"; and by late 1967, when he could have used antiwar sentiment at home and political developments in Vietnam to cut his losses and get out, he instead "stayed the course," having become blinded by his own rhetoric and wishful thinking about the progress of the war.
There are tidbits of news scattered throughout "Flawed Giant." Mr. Dallek contends that Johnson seriously considered getting back in the Presidential race in 1968, after the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy; that he was reluctant to support his vice president, Hubert H. Humphrey, against Richard M. Nixon because of Humphrey's doubts about the war, and that he declined to damage the Nixon-Agnew campaign with accusations about their campaign financing because he wanted to have some political ammunition in the bank for possible future use against Nixon.
In the end, Mr. Dallek's most serious charge against Johnson is that his paranoic tendencies raised "questions about his judgment and capacity to make rational life and death decisions."
"Who then is to say when a President has passed the bounds of rational good sense?" he writes. "Certainly in Johnson's case, for all the cranky nonsense he espoused about his enemies, he remained largely in control of his faculties and more than capable of functioning as President. Still, no one should make light of how much his suspicions and anger toward his domestic critics distorted his judgments in dealing with Vietnam. It may be that he would have pursued the war as avidly even without his personal antagonisms. But it is clear that his personal quirks in dealing with war opponents contributed nothing constructive to the national dialogue on a failing war."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Under growing pressure: President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1967. (Associated Press); Robert Dallek (Alan Braus/Oxford University Press)

HEADLINE: SPARE TIMES

 BODY:

ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites
 
AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. "The Nature of Diamonds," an exhibition exploring all aspects of the mineral, from its geological origins to its popularity as an adornment to its modern uses in technology and research. Through April 26. Admission is by timed ticket only. "Africa: Explorations and Expeditions," featuring firsthand accounts of European and American exploration from the 18th century on, as depicted in selections from the museum's rare-book collection. Through Sept. 30. Weekends through April 19, "Indigenous Peoples' Celebration," featuring theater, video, music, dance and art. Tomorrow and Sunday: at 1 P.M., three videos: "The Spirit of TV" (1990), "Video in the Villages" (1989) and "Signs Don't Speak" (1992); at 2 and 3:30 P.M., "The Electronic Arrow," featuring Erica Wortham, from the National Museum of the American Indian, who talks about the three videos shown at 1 P.M. and explains how Indians in Brazil and Mexico use video as in their efforts to gain political recognition; at 2:30 and 4 P.M., "Piano and Drums," featuring Esiaba Irobi, who uses European and African music, dance, masks and songs to explore the conflicts with Western culture. Free with museum admission. Permanent displays include the dinosaur and fossil halls and the Imax films "Cosmic Voyage," "Whales" and the recently opened "Titanica," which chronicles the construction, sinking, exploration and excavation of the Titanic. In the Imax Theater on Fridays and Saturdays at 9 P.M., "Led Zeppelin in 3-D" and "Pink Floyd's 'Dark Side of the Moon' " in 3-D. Tickets: $9. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M. Suggested admission: $8; students and the elderly, $6; children 12 and under, $4.50. A combination ticket including museum admission and one film: $12; students and the elderly, $8.50; children 12 and under, $6.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100; to buy tickets by phone: (212) 769-5200. 

AMERICAN NUMISMATIC SOCIETY, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. The society has the most extensive coin collection in North America; its library is open to the public. A retrospective of the work of Helder Batista of Portugal, including sculpture, graphics and medals from the artist's collection, will be on view through April 19. On permanent display is "American Numismatic Design, 1892-1922," which includes all coins issued during this period. Also on view is "The World of Coins," a history from 600 B.C. to the present. Free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 4 P.M. Information: (212) 234-3130.
HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 1600's to the 19th century, restored and furnished. This village and outdoor museum depicts the history and life of Staten Island and the surrounding region. The exhibition "Toys!" will be open through the end of the year. A Saturday night tavern concert series continues tomorrow night with Stout, an American-music trio, whose music ranges from sea chantey, work and tavern songs to more recent tunes. Performances at 7:30 and 9 P.M. Tickets: $8; reservations required. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Regular admission: $4; the elderly and those 6 to 18, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.
INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A converted World War II aircraft carrier with two full decks of displays, including four themed halls: United States Navy Hall, Pioneer Hall, Technologies Hall and Intrepid Hall. "Remember the Main," an exhibition that looks at the Spanish-American War, including six models of warships, archival photographs and a hand-carved, wooden bow ornament from the U.S.S. New York. Through July 1999. "The Spanish-American War" is an exhibition featuring pieces of ships that fought in the war, models, photographs and nautical charts. Through July 1999. "Proudly We Serve," an exhibition about the service of black veterans, with photographs, uniforms, artifacts and models, is on view through February 1999. Also on view is a 1950's French naval fighter jet, the Etendard IV-M, given to the museum by the French Government. Visitors can feel what it's like to fly a tactical mission over the Persian Gulf by using a flight simulator, which recreates five minutes aboard an F-18 Hornet fighter jet. A ride on the simulator is $5; $3 for school groups. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; closed Mondays and Tuesdays. Admission: $10; the elderly, veterans, reservists and ages 12 to 17, $7.50; ages 6 to 11, $5; 5 and under, $1; under 2, free; wheelchair patrons, half price. Information: (212) 245-0072.
LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM, 90 Orchard Street, at Broome Street. A look at the urban immigrant experience on the Lower East Side. The museum includes a partly restored tenement at 97 Orchard Street. An apartment, once home to a family named Confino, allows children to explore the premises and interact with an actor playing a 13-year-old family member. Tours of the Confino apartment are on Saturdays and Sundays at noon, 1 and 3 P.M. The museum's two other apartments, which housed the Gumpertz and Baldizzi families, can be viewed only through guided tours. Also: "Hamilton Madison Settlement House: 100 Years of Images," an exhibition that celebrates the centennial of one of New York's oldest neighborhood settlement houses, including works by the Lower East Side photographer Ed Schwartz. Through May 31. Tomorrow at 1:30, the museum celebrates Passover with a two-hour tour of points of interest relative to Eastern European, Yiddish-speaking Jews who arrived in the neighborhood between 1880 and 1920. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Free. Tour times vary. Tour prices: $8; $6 for students, the elderly and children over 5; children 5 and under, $3 (weekends, ages 5 and under free). Information: (212) 431-0233.
THE MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, 1220 Fifth Avenue, at 103d Street. The museum collects, preserves and presents materials related to the history of New York City. On view through June 21, "Berenice Abbott's Changing New York, 1935-39," with 125 of her New York City photographs on view. Sunday at 3 P.M., "Berenice Abbott: A View of the 20th Century," a documentary by Kay Weaver and Martha Wheelock, made during Abbott's 91st and 92d years, includes the only filmed interviews to which Abbott ever consented. Current exhibitions include "A Float for All Seasons: New York's Ethnic Parades," with handmade objects and color photographs by the photographer Martha Cooper. On view through Jan. 10. "The New Metropolis: A Century of Greater New York, 1898-1998," which examines the people and places of the city during the last century as it celebrates the centennial of the consolidation of the five boroughs. Through Jan. 3. "Bridging New York," an art exhibition that explores the role played by bridges in the consolidation of New York. Through June 21. The exhibition "New York From Above: An Aerial View," with aerial paintings derived from maps, photographs and satellite images, through June 14. Hours: Tuesdays, 10 A.M. to 2 P.M., for registered groups only; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; closed holidays. Suggested admission: $5; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $10. Information: (212) 534-1672.
MUSEUM OF TELEVISION AND RADIO, 25 West 52d Street, Manhattan. A collection of taped radio and television broadcasts as well as exhibitions of other media, including drawings, posters and photographs. Through June 25, "Lucy Takes a Cruise to Havana," an original, uncut, 75-minute version of the first of the "Lucille Ball-Desi Arnaz Show" specials, not seen in its entirety since the original broadcast in 1957. Screenings, through June 25: Tuesdays and Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays, at 2 P.M.; Thursdays at 6 P.M.; Fridays at 7 P.M.. Through April 30, screenings of "Gideon's Trumpet," a 1980 Hallmark Hall of Fame production starring Henry Fonda. Screenings: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays at 2 and 4 P.M.; Thursdays and Fridays at 6 P.M. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, noon to 8 P.M. On Fridays, the theater is open until 9 P.M.; closed Mondays and holidays. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 12 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.
NATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN, Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House, 1 Bowling Green, lower Manhattan. Current exhibitions: "Memory and Imagination: The Legacy of Maidu Indian Artist Frank Day," including paintings and drawings accompanied by personal items, Maidu artifacts and paintings by artists influenced by Day's work. Through May 3. "Creation's Journey: Masterworks of Native-American Identity and Belief," artifacts from 3200 B.C. to the 20th century. Through May 12. Also, "All Roads Are Good: Native Voices on Life and Culture," an exhibition with more than 300 objects. Hours: daily, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays until 8 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 514-3888.
NEW YORK CITY FIRE MUSEUM, 278 Spring Street, SoHo. In a renovated 1904 firehouse is a collection of fire-related art and artifacts from the 18th century to the present, including a firetruck, hose wagons, hats, toys, paintings and hand-drawn pumpers. Also, an exhibition, "Fire Marks: Emblems of Insurance," features a selection of 18th- and 19th-century British and American fire marks from the museum's collection. Insurance agencies would give bonuses to firefighters when they saved the premises of a policyholder. The decorative emblems were used to distinguish policyholders from the uninsured. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Suggested admission: $4 for adults; $2 for students and the elderly; $1 for children under 12. Information: (212) 691-1303.
NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 2 West 77th Street, Manhattan. On view through July 12, "Paul Robeson: Bearer of a Culture," an exhibition about the athlete, singer, actor and outspoken pioneer for racial and economic justice, on the centenary of his birth. "New York City and the Spanish-American War," about the city leading the United States into international conflict, is on view through July 12. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $3; 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 873-3400.
NEW YORK TRANSIT MUSEUM, Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street, downtown Brooklyn. "Six Bridges: The Making of a Modern Metropolis," an exhibition on the six major bridges that helped transform New York City into a world center for commerce, finance and culture. On view through May 24. "Steel, Stone and Backbone," a display tracing the construction of the subway system from 1900 to 1925, with photographs, construction tools, films and other objects; "Ceramic Ornamentation," a look at the mosaics, tiles and terra cotta used to adorn subway stations from 1904 to the present, and "Here to There: Signs for Moving Around Underground," a display of more than 100 subway signs, continuing. Also on view are 19 restored subway cars dating from 1903 to 1960. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; closed Mondays and holidays. Admission: $3; the elderly and ages 6 to 17, $1.50; 5 and under, free. On Wednesday from 12 to 4 P.M., admission is free for the elderly. Information: (718) 243-8601.
SOUTH STREET SEAPORT MUSEUM AND MARKETPLACE, South and Fulton Streets, lower Manhattan. The 19th-century port district has restaurants, shops and bars. The museum has three gallery spaces, a children's crafts center and a boat-building center. Exhibitions include "By Appointment to the King: Becken of Cowes, Marine Photographers," yachting images. "Sun Ships: Photographs by Barry M. Winiker," 40 images of contemporary cruise ships and ocean liners, on view through June 21. Also, "Traveling in Style: 20th-Century Ocean Liners." Museum hours: Daily, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays until 8 P.M.; stores in the marketplace: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission to museum: $6; the elderly, $5; students, $4; children 12 and under, $3. Information: the museum, (212) 748-8600; the marketplace, (212) 732-7678.
STATEN ISLAND INSTITUTE OF ARTS AND SCIENCES, 75 Stuyvesant Place, St. George. Cultural museum and library with artistic, scientific and environmental collections. "Moles, Voles and Mastodons: Mammals of Staten Island" traces the history of mammals through mounted specimens, skulls, photos, fossils and murals. Through July 2. Also on view: "In Celebration of the 850th Anniversary of the Founding of Moscow," an exhibition of Russian stamps, icons and enamel boxes. Through April 27. The Family Gallery Hands-On Exhibit features specimens, art, artifacts and activities. And four sections, dedicated to the graphic arts, mammals, fabrics and tugboats, will be updated to highlight concurrent exhibitions. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Suggested admission: $2.50; students and the elderly, $1.50. Information: (718) 727-1135.
 
Gardens
 
BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. More than 12,000 kinds of plants from around the world are displayed on 52 acres, including the Fragrance Garden, the Japanese Hill and Pond Garden and the Bonsai Museum, the largest collection of dwarf potted trees in the country. Through April 25, thousands of daffodils are in bloom. Art teachers and students of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden have an opportunity to showcase their works through April 26 in the Steinhardt Conservatory Gallery. The gallery is open Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Admission: $3 for adults; $1.50 for students and the elderly; 50 cents for children 6 to 16; free for children 5 and under. Admission free on Tuesdays except holidays. Free guided tours are offered at 1 P.M. on weekends. Garden hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the garden grounds. Information: (718) 622-4433.
THE CHARLES A. DANA DISCOVERY CENTER, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue, Central Park. On display: "Vital Signs in Central Park," which focuses on the similarities between the human body and the ecosystem, and how they relate to one another. Through May 3. Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Information: (212) 860-1370.
NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx. The grounds include 27 specialty gardens and plant collections and a 40-acre forest, one of the last remnants of the forest that once covered New York City. Through May, the acres of flowering bulbs include daffodils, anemones, irises, tulips and scilla. Through May 20, "Conservatory Flower Show: Gardens of Charleston," gardens inspired by the Old South. In the conservatory, on permanent display, is "A World of Plants," an ecotour of the world, from tropical rain forests to African deserts. Visitors can get close-up views of the rain forests, the deserts of Africa and the Americas and the tropics. Weekend activities include a bird walk with a naturalist, Debbie Becker, on Fridays at 1:30 P.M. and on Saturdays at 12:30 P.M. On Saturdays and Sundays at 1 P.M., visitors can see tropical orchids on a tour of the orchid terrarium in the main building. Garden hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., closed Mondays and holidays, except Monday holidays. Grounds admission in spring: $3; $1 for students and the elderly and children 6 to 16; children under 6, free. Conservatory admission: $3.50 for adults; $2.50 for students, the elderly and children 6 to 16; under 6, free. Grounds admission free for everyone on Wednesdays and from 10 A.M. to noon on Saturdays. Parking: $4. Information: (718) 817-8700.
QUEENS BOTANICAL GARDEN, 43-50 Main Street, Flushing. More than 39 acres devoted to woodland, bees, birds, herbs and flowers. Seasonal flowers through this weekend include Cornelian cherry, crocus, Siberian squill, forsythia and daffodils. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to noon, a free talk on backyard composting. Hours: Tuesdays to Sundays, 8 A.M. to 6 through oct. 31 P.M. Admission: free. Children's program: $2. Information: (718) 886-3800.
STATEN ISLAND BOTANICAL GARDEN, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The garden has 83 acres of parkland, with neo-classical buildings that were once home to retired seamen. Hours: daily, dawn to dusk. Free. Information: (718) 273-8200, extension 10.
WAVE HILL, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. Gardens, greenhouses and woodlands are part of this 28-acre public garden and cultural institution overlooking the Hudson River and the Palisades. Tomorrow at 1 P.M., the naturalist Jeff O'Handley will point out birds making their seasonal migration. Visitors 14 and over can help foresters preserve Wave Hill's 10-acre Abrons Woodland and neighboring 58-acre Riverdale Park by pruning and clearing excess vegetation, planting trees and shrubs and repairing woodland trails. Work will go on every Saturday from 1 to 4 P.M. through May 30. Sundays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. through June 7 in the Glyndor Gallery, an exhibition of quilts by the Manhattan Quilters Guild inspired by nature. Every Saturday, tai chi chuan, 10 A.M. for beginners; 11 A.M. for intermediates. Fee: $7; $5, members. Grounds hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Admission: $4, adults; $2, students and the elderly, Wednesdays to Sundays. Tuesdays are free all day; Saturdays are free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200.
 
Zoos
 
BRONX ZOO, Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road, Fordham. Special areas in the zoo include Jungle World; African Plains, which features lions, giraffes, cheetahs and the Arabian oryx; the Baboon Reserve; the World of Birds; the Great Apes; the Aitken Sea Bird Colony (with daily penguin feedings at 3:30 P.M.) and Big Birds, with ostriches, emu, rheas and cassowaries. The zoo also offers classes for adults and children. Information and registration: (718) 220-6854. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Admission; $6.75; the elderly and children 2 to 12, $3; under 2, free; free for everyone on Wednesdays. Parking, $6. Information: (718) 367-1010.
NEW YORK AQUARIUM, West Eighth Street and the Boardwalk, Coney Island, Brooklyn. Exhibition areas include Sea Cliffs, featuring sea otters, seals and wave machines; Discovery Cove, a look at the aquatic world with a water tank, photographs, interactive videos and games; the Hudson River; Native Sea Life and the Shark Tank. There are also an oceanic tank, a touch-a-ray tank and beluga whale pools. Daily feedings of sea lions, sharks, walruses, dolphins and penguins. Hours: daily, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $7.75; the elderly and children 2 to 12, $3.50; under 2, free. Parking: $6. Information: (718) 265-3474.
PROSPECT PARK ZOO, 450 Flatbush Avenue, near Empire Boulevard, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. The zoo is geared toward children, with sea lions, baboons, farm animals and a discovery trail; sea lion feedings daily at 11:30 A.M., 2 and 4 P.M. Also a series of weekend activities and crafts. Hours: daily, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Admission: $2.50; the elderly, $1.25; children 3 to 12, 50 cents; 2 and under, free. Information: (718) 399-7339.
QUEENS ZOO, 53-51 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Animals include American bison, prairie dogs, pumas, elk, coyotes, cranes and bobcats. Hours: 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. daily. Admission: $2.50; the elderly, $1.25; children 3 to 12, 50 cents; 2 and under, free. Information: (718) 271-1500.
STATEN ISLAND ZOO, 614 Broadway, off Forest Avenue, West Brighton. Among the highlights are a serpentarium with turtles and a large collection of rattlesnakes. The zoo also has a rain forest; the "African Savanna at Twilight," with leopards, baboons and antelopes, and a children's petting zoo. Free with zoo admission. Fee: $8, registration required. Hours: daily, 10 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. Admission: $3; children 3 to 11, $2; under 3, free. Free on Wednesdays after 2 P.M. Information: (718) 442-3101.

"LOWER EAST SIDE I: RADICAL JEWS." HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Missile Business

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
"I, WILLIAM J. CLINTON, President of the United States of America, find that the proliferation of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons ('weapons of mass destruction') and of the means of delivering such weapons, constitutes an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security, foreign policy and economy of the United States, and hereby declare a national emergency to deal with that threat."
Mr. Clinton's order outlined the diplomatic, economic and export penalties that could be used by the U.S. against proliferation.
 
 That was on Feb. 12, 1994. Almost ever since, a handful of reporters on a handful of newspapers have exposed cases of the U.S. ignoring or rationalizing sales of missile technology -- "the means" of delivery -- or getting into the business itself.
 The public and most of the press pay almost no attention. American business is annoyed when anybody makes a fuss about such matters.
Two recent cases:
On April 4, 1998, The New York Times reported that a Federal grand jury was investigating whether two U.S. companies, Loral Space and Electronic and Hughes Electronic, illegally gave space expertise to China that significantly advanced Beijing's ballistic-missile programs.
But the reporters, Jeff Gerth and Raymond Bonner, wrote that while the inquiry was under way Mr. Clinton dealt it a serious blow by quietly approving export to China of similar technology by one of the companies under investigation -- Loral.
On March 18, Bill Gertz of The Washington Times reported that the Administration would offer China access to missile technology barred under human right sanctions.
The sales, made and planned, permit China to lengthen the range of its missiles and sharpen their accuracy. The Gertz article says the U.S. will ask China not to sell the technology to countries like Iran and Pakistan that are developing nuclear weapons. U.S. intelligence says Beijing has made that promise before and broken it.
And the Administration offers no explanation why it is in American security interests to help China build missiles that will fly farther and hit more accurately. After all, a top Chinese general already has boasted they could pulverize Los Angeles.
In other cases, Mr. Clinton has not used his powers to punish China's sales of chemicals to Iran or Russia's transfer of complete intermediate-range missiles to Iran. The Administration permitted U.S. export to Russia of U.S. supercomputers that can be used to simulate nuclear explosions and are 10 times faster than the Russians made.
Some members of Congress pay attention. The majority members of the Senate Subcommittee on International Security and Proliferation issued an even-tempered but deeply critical report on Administration policy. The report said that about two dozen countries had or were working to develop long-range ballistic missiles, and added:
"It is time for the Administration to announce that America will no longer be endangered by ballistic-missile-delivered destruction from rogue states. The time for debating whether to deploy a national missile defense is over."
But on proliferation or missile defense nothing much happens. Congress calls for more reports or adds to the 60-odd government offices that deal with proliferation.
Henry Sokolski, executive director of the Nonproliferation Policy Education Center in Washington, writes in The National Interest that when you tell Washington insiders that your work focuses on preventing the spread of strategic weapons, they figure you can't hold down a real job. He says business generally views such work as being as bad as promoting human rights. U.S. diplomacy "engages" proliferating nations with "handouts or bribes" to such as China, Russia and North Korea.
All right. American business made foreign trade its ideology, overriding human rights -- not even a contest. The public did not mind. Making trade his own guiding star, Mr. Clinton broke his promises to fight for the victims of China's police-terror. The public didn't mind.
But I did think Americans would mind when Washington began absolving proliferators and getting into the business itself. But, who knows, maybe one day they will awake. If they do it will be because a handful of reporters won't fall asleep.

HEADLINE: Polaroid Posts Bigger Loss Than Expected

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Polaroid Corporation, saying it was hurt by the strong dollar, a weak Asian economy and much lower orders in the United States, reported a far bigger loss for the first quarter yesterday than analysts had expected.
Polaroid lost $17.4 million, or 39 cents a share, as sales were down 15 percent, to $390.6 million. A year earlier, it earned $15.8 million, or 35 cents a share. 
 Though analysts had expected a loss of only 5 to 10 cents a share, investors apparently were not disheartened. Polaroid shares slipped a couple of dollars in light trading after its announcement, but it quickly recovered, and then some. The stock closed at $42.875, up 93.75 cents.
"Wall Street is viewing this as a one-quarter problem," said Charles Hill, research director of First Call, which tracks analysts' earnings estimates.
Apparently, investors see Polaroid as a temporary victim of a push by retailers to slash inventories. Polaroid said that Wal-Mart, for example, had decreased its inventory of Polaroid products by 20 percent from the corresponding quarter last year, but that its sales of the products were 10 percent above last year's rate.
"What's important is what moves out their front door, not what moves out our back door," said Robert L. Guenther, a Polaroid vice president.
Moreover, last year Easter, a popular picture-taking time, fell on April 3, so retailers stocked up on film in March. This year, some Easter-related sales have moved into April because the holiday does not occur until April 12.
"The retailers will have to start restocking soon," predicted Ulysses Yannas, an analyst with Mercer, Bokert, Buckman & Reid.
In talks with analysts and reporters yesterday, Polaroid executives tried to sweeten the quarter's bitter news. Mr. Guenther said that retailers were "very enthusiastic" about Polaroid's new films and cameras.
Polaroid is also on a cost-cutting binge. It has promised to eliminate about 1,800 jobs before the year 2000. It has already sold some land and some underused plants.
"We've been planning for a good year, and we are not changing those plans," Mr. Guenther said.
But while most analysts are giving Polaroid the benefit of the doubt, some worry that its weakness could persist. They are concerned, for example, that retailers, armed with electronic systems for micromanaging inventories, will never again order huge amounts of film or cameras at a time. Others worry that Polaroid's new products may fail in the marketplace.
"I buy their story to some extent, but they'll really need some phenomenal improvement in earnings to meet their own numbers for the year," said Peter J. Enderlin of the First Albany Corporation.

HEADLINE: Observer;
A Poverty of Stardom

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
We of the Media are desperate for stars. That's why the nation and President Clinton can expect no relief from you know what. Boy, don't we all know what!
If we abandon the story, dear mass audience, what have we left to serve you? In all the Congress there is not a single star, not one person whose name is known to any but game-show contestants boning up for appearances on "Jeopardy." 
 Among the Capitol unknown, I include Speaker Newt Gingrich. A year or two ago he approached Mr. Clinton in star magnitude. Today, like Bernarr Macfadden and Jack LaLanne, he is grist for those where-are-they-now pieces in which newspapers remind us who's dead and who's not.
As for the Cabinet, it has been so bereft of stars for so long that no one would know it existed but for occasional news of some wretched cabinet secretary hounded by another special prosecutor for being all too human.
Washington once abounded in what the press calls "colorful characters." There was the great gushing Senate star, Everett Dirksen, "the wizard of ooze," as Time magazine called him.
The Senate also had three Kennedys, Hubert Humphrey, Gene McCarthy and, for color, Olin (Olin the Solon) Johnson, William (Wild Bill) Langer constantly chewing on cellophane-wrapped cigars, and Harry Byrd the Elder clad always in suits as white as vanilla ice cream. The Senate glittered with star power.
Look at Congress now: hordes seemingly groomed, clipped, dressed and color-coordinated by the same television makeup cosmetician, and not a star on the landscape.
Washington is filled with serious people engaged in serious business, some of it alarmingly serious. Right now, while the media fret about the President's character, Senate and President are quietly colluding in a dangerous and costly expansion of NATO, and nobody gives a hoot.
Probably more Americans know who Linda Tripp is than which three countries will extend NATO up to the borders of Russia. Except for a few newspapers, the media don't dare bore us with stories like that.
TV can't risk it. (Death to the ratings.) The tabloids couldn't care less. ("Where's the sex angle?") To put it another way, it's competition that keeps us dumb, that very competition that is said to underpin our greatness.
Competition means there isn't time to introduce minor characters unless they garnish tales of the star's latest adventure. Competition means pursuing the biggest possible audience, which means catering to the lowest common denominator.
The mass audience doesn't readily suffer long-winded dawdling over NATO or stories about who's sabotaging the latest health-care plan. We want stars, not details. This probably explains why the television networks' Washington coverage concentrates so intensely on the White House.
The Presidency offers a rich variety of TV entertainment themes: the family sitcom, soap opera, eye-popping spectacle, tales of intrigue and foul play, and lots more. Government, which is a nuts-and-bolts kind of business, goes unreported because it is not entertainment.
In the early days of television, producers used to respond to criticism of cheesy programming by saying they were "just giving the slobs what they want." From this came the current belief that television is powerless to affect audience tastes and shouldn't try to.
The printing press, desperate to hold its share of the mass market, is under economic pressure to go with the garish flow. Hence this endless Presidential-gossip story.
"It goes like this, Jack: The star has got himself into a titillating sexual pickle. Heavy-breathing enemies are out to ruin him. His wife and pals declare 'war.' There is enough dirty pool all around to compete with a mini-series about the Borgias."
And the beauty part? The beauty part is that a story this entertaining generates a raft of new stars: dedicated Inspector Starr, ladies of various ages with juicy stories to tell, cunning lawyers -- "the full catastrophe," to quote Zorba the Greek.
Meanwhile, who cares what's happening about taxes, all those corporate mergers, Social Security reform, health care, monopolies, the asphalting of America? When the entertainment is this rich, who can be bothered with such drearinesses? We'll scream later.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
The Bronx Is Up but He Parties Downtown

BYLINE: By JOYCE WADLER 

 BODY:
JIMMY RODRIGUEZ, who started out selling fish in the street and now owns Jimmy's Bronx Cafe, the hottest joint in the Bronx, has been running with a new crowd lately.
Last week, accompanied by his ever-present right-hand man, Richard Turley, who used to work with Andy Warhol, he attended the New York magazine party, the Armani show and a book party at the Mercer Hotel in SoHo whose hosts were Anna Wintour and Tina Brown. 
 On Saturday night, Sandy Hill, the socialite and adventurer, is having her birthday party at Jimmy's Bronx Cafe.
"You should also get into the story that Jimmy is sticking his toe even further into East Side society, serving as chairman of the entertainment committee for the May 14 benefit party at the Hispanic Society Museum," Mr. Turley says calling in, sounding suspiciously as if he is reading a news release. "All the other committee members, most of whom work at Sotheby's or Christie's, were amazed Jimmy managed to get friend Tito Puente to perform."
"That's true," continues Mr. Turley, now seeming to depart from the script. "You will get Robert Isabell somehow in the story? He introduced Jimmy to Sandy Hill and Barbara Howard. He's a longtime Latinophile. He loves Latins."
You don't know Jimmy's Bronx Cafe? It's off the Major Deegan, at the foot of Fordham Road: a white building with architectural echoes of a car dealership, which it used to be.
Inside, past the framed silver satin tuxedo of Tito Puente, the legendary band leader whom Jimmy Rodriguez calls the king, and ballplayers' jerseys, there's a Caribbean-style seafood restaurant, a sports bar and a nightclub. You might see the Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, or a major leaguer.
You will also certainly come across 35-year-old Jimmy Rodriguez, six foot three inches of charm, which is a whole lot of charm.
When Jimmy (everybody calls him Jimmy) went to Cuba and met Fidel (another first-name kind of guy) and asked Fidel for a shirt for his uniform collection, Fidel gave Jimmy the whole khaki suit.
"I was so happy! Oh, my God! I couldn't believe it," says Jimmy, in the whispery, singsong voice he does when he's thrilled and delighted, which is almost always. "The whole uniform. I'm thinking, 'How am I gonna get this into the United States?' "
When Jimmy makes the rounds of his club with his rum and Coke, making sure everyone's having a good time, the men light up and the women follow like honeybees.
"The Latin Toots Shor," the newspapers call Jimmy. His story is journalistically irresistible. Jimmy dropped out of high school, sold lobsters under the Bronx River Parkway and expanded into his first restaurant, Mariscos del Caribe.
FIVE years ago, he opened Jimmy's Bronx Cafe. It's a success, everyone agrees, because of Jimmy. He walks the club and when he sees a man or a woman alone he introduces them and next thing they're dancing and Jimmy is chuckling like a proud papa. He sponsors 40 Little League teams and allows a church to meet in the restaurant on Sundays.
Now, under the aegis of Mr. Turley, Jimmy is expanding south, to Park Avenue and SoHo. He's been to Paris and to the Delano Hotel. ("The chic-est hotel in Miami Beach," Mr. Turley says. "He'll learn a lot.")
Jimmy also attended the Duke of Windsor auction at Sotheby's in February, paying $22,000 for three outfits, including lederhosen the Duke wore in Austria in 1937.
Why would Jimmy want something owned by an unemployed Englishman who was thought to be soft on the Nazis?
"I'm gonna frame it and put it downstairs next to Tito Puente," Jimmy says. "It's like the king next to another king. The king of Latin, the King of Windsor. He's got everything and he gives up the throne for a woman. To be as simple as he was. Tito Puente, he's the king of Latin and he's always amongst us."
"I just had to have something of his on the wall," he said, referring to the Duke. "He's such a sharp dresser. It's history."
Mr. Turley puts in quickly, "A lot of historians feel it was not clear the Duke was a Nazi sympathizer."
"It was like Lotto," Jimmy says. "This woman has the King. He just gave up everything. The power of a woman is an amazing thing."
Jimmy's Bronx Cafe grosses $5 million a year, Jimmy says. The subject doesn't interest Jimmy. Money is just a tool, he says. What he wants to do with that tool is to make people happy, let everyone know the Bronx is back.
"I had to put the name Bronx in," he says of his cafe. "It could have been Jimmy's. You have to be proud of the Bronx, proud of the change."
So given that, what does Jimmy need with all those East Side society people, the Armani fashion shows?
"Knowledge," Jimmy says. "Friends. Knowledge. The space talks to you, the way the furniture is laid out."
Jimmy does the low whispery thing: "It's amazing, it's amazing. How they spent two or three million dollars for a 25-minute show. I walk into an Armani fashion show, I can't wait for that to happen in the Bronx."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jimmy Rodriguez, the owner of Jimmy's Bronx Cafe. (Librado Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton, Visiting Tobacco Country, Tries to Win Over Farmers on Legislation

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: CARROLLTON, Ky., April 9

 BODY:
President Clinton vowed today that he would continue to fight for tobacco legislation despite the intransigence of the cigarette manufacturers, and he promised the residents of this tobacco-growing community that their livelihoods would not be threatened by the bill.
"We don't have to wreck the fabric of life in your community," he declared in a speech in the Carroll County High School gymnasium. "But even in tobacco country, we can't deny what the scientists have told us or what has been done to market tobacco to children." 
 Mr. Clinton's visit here, a rural area about an hour southwest of Cincinnati, was scheduled long before the leading American cigarette manufacturers announced on Wednesday that they had cut off discussions with the White House and Congress about legislation to regulate tobacco because they could see that the direction the political process was heading was unfavorable to the industry.
The President seemed undaunted today by the companies' announcement. "I am going to do my dead-level best to get legislation passed this year," he said.
One reason for Mr. Clinton's visit, aides said, is to exploit a widening rift between tobacco growers and cigarette manufacturers and to convince the farmers that the companies' legislative interests were not theirs. The settlement the tobacco companies reached last June with state attorneys general did not address what would happen to tobacco farmers and their communities if fewer people smoked and the demand for tobacco dropped.
Mr. Clinton, however, has made this a priority from the beginning. With his support, the bill approved last week by the Senate Commerce Committee would set aside money and have other protections for farmers and their communities. To the displeasure of the manufacturers, bill includes provisions to keep the price of tobacco high.
Part of Mr. Clinton's route to the high school was lined with protesters carrying signs like "Tobacco pays my bills." Many, if not most, of them said they had been organized and bused here by the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, which is based in Louisville and makes Lucky Strike and Kool, among other brands of cigarettes. Before the speech, the President had a give-and-take with farmers and others at a warehouse where nearly $1 million worth of tobacco was sold on Wednesday.
Bill Sprague, president of the Kentucky Farm Bureau, the largest organization of farmers in the state, said the 60,000 tobacco farmers in Kentucky earned about $1 billion a year, an important element in the state's economy. Tobacco is, by far, the most profitable crop per acre that can be grown here.
"We can't afford to completely dismantle our tobacco industry," Mr. Sprague said.
The most striking remarks came from Mattie Mack, a farmer from Brandenburg, near Louisville.
"My four children did not smoke," Mrs. Mack told the President. "I don't smoke. My husband doesn't smoke. And we are against children smoking, Mr. President, but we shouldn't be penalized on account of children smoking."
She went on: "Tobacco has been good. We paid for our farm off the tobacco. We educated our kids off of tobacco. We paved our old driveway with blacktop on tobacco. We pay our property taxes. We pay the preacher on Sunday morning. We pay for our fertilizer. We overhaul our tractors and our wagons, and we buy tires. We pay our insurance. And we pay the man to help us on the farm. And we pay his Social Security, and we pay his Medicare. And we just try to live right and do right on tobacco."
Despite such emotions, Mr. Clinton was in the kind of setting where he thrives. He looked the skeptics in the eye and seemed to have won many of them over when he offered one of his favorite lines: "We have no interest whatever in putting the tobacco companies out of business. I just want to get them out of the business of selling tobacco to children."
A section of the Commerce Committee bill written by Senator Wendell H. Ford, a Kentucky Democrat who joined Mr. Clinton, would allow the Government to buy out tobacco farmers who wanted to leave the business. Financial aid would be given to those who stayed on the farm and to communities suffering because of a drop in tobacco sales.
The measure would leave in place the Government's tobacco program, which is a target for elimination by many Republicans, including Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican who heads the Agriculture Committee.
The program costs the Government nothing, but by regulating tobacco production, it keeps the price artificially high. That, of course, is good for the farmers. But the program is also favored by the public health authorities. Higher tobacco prices mean more expensive cigarettes, and that in turn, the authorities believe, discourages smoking.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Bonds Turn Downward as Dollar Continues to Weaken

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bonds closed mostly lower yesterday, hurt by further weakness in the dollar and suggestions that the Federal Reserve may be less concerned than previously believed about the impact of Asia's problems on the domestic economy.
The Treasury's 30-year issue ended slightly higher in a trading session shortened by the Easter holiday. Shorter-term maturities ended slightly lower in price. 
 Today the financial markets will be closed for Good Friday and on Monday the European markets will be closed.
Traders said a major force in the market yesterday was the dollar, which had risen to a six-and-a-half-year high against the yen last week but has fallen for four straight days. It was driven down sharply yesterday after the Bank of Japan sold dollars for yen to defend the Japanese currency's value.
Weakness in the dollar tends to dampen the foreign demand for United States Treasury securities.
Additional pressure on the bond market came from remarks by Susan Phillips, a Federal Reserve governor, who was quoted by the Market News service as saying the Fed is less concerned that Asia's weakness will slow the economy, and more focused on the tight labor market, strong growth and risk of rising inflation.
The 30-year Treasury rose 7/32, to a price of 103 15/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, declined to 5.88 percent, from 5.89 percent Wednesday.
The bond market's weakness came despite new evidence that inflation remains benign. Yesterday the Labor Department released its Producer Price Index report on prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers, which showed the index down three-tenths of a percent in March, the fifth consecutive monthly decline. Excluding volatile food and energy, the index was unchanged.
"Inflation performance continues to astound and amaze market observers," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
But Mr. Fine said the market was more focused on the sentiments expressed by Fed governor Phillips, which suggested the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee, which determines interest-rate policy, has grown more vigilant about inflation risks.
Traders said the market will likely focus next week on the retail sales and Consumer Price Index reports, to be released Tuesday, for further clues of possibly higher inflation. But both reports are expected to show a continuation of the same moderate economic growth that has kept inflation low.

HEADLINE: Air Jamaica's American Problem;
A Small Airline Holds Its Own Against a Much Bigger Rival

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

DATELINE: KINGSTON, Jamaica

 BODY:
In 1993, American Airlines gave Gordon Stewart, owner of 10 Caribbean resorts and this island's most celebrated entrepreneur, an award for his contribution to developing tourism in the region.
Three years later, after Mr. Stewart took control of Air Jamaica, the troubled state-owned airline, and began adding routes and improving service, the folks at American gave him something else to remember them by: They slashed fares by 50 percent, driving an already shaky Air Jamaica to the brink of collapse. 
 And that wasn't all. A short time later, Mr. Stewart recalled in an interview at his office here, a spokesman for American implied on a local radio show that Air Jamaica's planes were unsafe. "It was ruthless," he said. "Airline competition is kill and destroy. It is worse than any industry I have ever seen." (American said it was unaware of the incident.)
As it turned out, Mr. Stewart gave as good as he got. Since that near-death experience, he has grabbed market share away from American -- Air Jamaica says it now carries nearly half the air passengers who arrive on the island, more than double the total of three years ago -- and increased revenues to $225 million last year, from $128 million in 1994. He has increased Air Jamaica's reliability and reach, and won over customers with touches like free champagne. And he has survived a drawn-out battle with regulators in the United States and the abrupt departures in the last two years of three senior executives.
For all his doggedness, the airline is still bleeding red ink, losing $145 million in the last two years. But Mr. Stewart, who goes by the nickname Butch and wears his button-down shirts open at the collar, predicts Air Jamaica will soon turn the corner into profitability. And it continues to expand. On Monday, it began an alliance with Delta Air Lines, drawing passengers from that carrier's vast network. Certainly, American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, now regards Mr. Stewart with heightened respect.
"One thing you have to give Butch Stewart, he is going to try everything to make the company work," said Peter J. Dolara, American's senior vice president for Miami, the Caribbean and Latin America, who has known him for years. "The man is a ferocious competitor."
But then, so were a lot of other entrepreneurs who started airlines in the United States and elsewhere and got beaten down by the giants, from Freddy Laker, whose discount Laker Airways collapsed in 1982, to the founders of Valujet Inc., which nearly collapsed after the crash of one of its planes in the Florida Everglades in 1996. Only a handful of such pioneers have survived the punishment that the dominant players have doled out. The most famous of them is probably Richard Branson, an Englishman who founded Virgin Atlantic Airways in London in 1984. Mr. Branson weathered an early dirty-tricks campaign by British Airways, and through penny-pinching, smart marketing and a knack for turning setbacks to his advantage, went on to build an empire of more than 200 companies with $2.5 billion in annual revenue.
Mr. Stewart is commonly referred to as Jamaica's Branson, and in his bid to live up to that title, he enjoys advantages that go beyond the sheer grit that Mr. Dolara talks about. His corporate empire -- which includes trading and manufacturing businesses as well as resorts -- has made him a budding billionaire, giving him vast resources to fall back on in hard times. The hotels and resorts, of course, can only gain from the extra tourists his airline hauls to the Caribbean, as his critics are fond of pointing out.
He also exerts huge political influence in Jamaica, where he is considered by some to be more powerful than the Prime Minister. In any case, the Government is unlikely to let Air Jamaica -- with all its jobs -- fail. It is still a shareholder and has already agreed to extend a $110 million loan guarantee to the airline -- as compensation for its regulatory problems with Washington -- that will enable it to keep more spare parts on the island, decreasing costly delays.
American remains the airline to beat. Over the last 20 years, the competition for the Caribbean market has diminished as Eastern, Braniff, Pan Am and others that offered regular service went under. Today, American flies about 63 percent of the available seats in the region, most of them through its hubs in Miami and Puerto Rico.
Mr. Stewart had a powerful motive to challenge American. Without a thriving national airline, Jamaica, with its tourism-based economy, could be held hostage to the whims of foreign carriers. The islands of Antigua, St. Lucia and Grenada found out last month how serious that risk is; they agreed to pay American $3 million a year to continue jet service after it announced plans to divert the planes to more profitable routes.
Still, Mr. Stewart did not jump at the chance to buy Air Jamaica when the Government put the airline up for sale in the early 1990's. It was only after two other deals fell apart, with no other buyers on the horizon, that he put together an investment group in 1994 that paid $37.5 million for 70 percent of the carrier. His 46 percent stake is the single largest; the Government holds 25 percent and employees 5 percent.
The move was the kind of grand public gesture Mr. Stewart has become famous for. In 1992, when the Jamaican dollar was under pressure, he vowed to spend $1 million to support it, raising confidence in the currency. In 1995, he founded a daily newspaper that forced the venerable Jamaica Daily Gleaner to buy color presses and improve its coverage.
"I never thought I would get rich out of it," he said of the Air Jamaica investment, "but I thought Jamaica and all of us would be poor without it."
Born in Jamaica, Mr. Stewart, 56, never attended college and began his career selling air-conditioners in 1968. His various companies now sell water pumps, electrical generators, cars and auto parts.
In 1981, he founded Sandals Resorts, which offers holiday packages to couples. The company counts 10 resorts on six islands, and plans to open two more, geared toward families, this year. ATL Group, Mr. Stewart's holding company, is the island's biggest private enterprise, its largest earner of foreign currency and one of its biggest employers.
After taking control of Air Jamaica, he set out to improve the airline's notoriously unreliable service. He leased new Airbus wide-body jets and painted them bright yellow, orange, blue and magenta. He gave the flight attendants new uniforms and more training, and he offered coach passengers a choice of hot meals and free champagne, rum punch and beer. He won back many ethnic Jamaicans in the United States and elsewhere who had abandoned the airline with marketing that appealed to their national pride. And last summer, he opened a hub in Montego Bay, expanding the airline's service to other Caribbean islands.
As a result of his innovations, Air Jamaica says that it has increased its share of passengers flown to the island to 46 percent, from 22 percent three years ago. And Air Jamaica says it now carries two passengers for every one on American on Caribbean routes where they compete directly.
There have been setbacks, of course, and the biggest was beyond Mr. Stewart's control. In 1995, in a move to pressure foreign governments to improve their civil aviation bureaucracies, the Federal Aviation Administration restricted the activities in the United States of several foreign airlines, including Air Jamaica.
The action meant that Air Jamaica could not use its new Airbus jets on routes to the United States, and had to lease other planes at high rates instead. Compounding its financial pain, a consortium of banks backed out of a loan agreement, forcing the airline to borrow at much higher interest rates.
Before the restrictions were lifted last fall, they had cost Air Jamaica an estimated $165 million. By that time, though, the carrier had already begun operations at its new hub at Montego Bay. Planes now leave early in the morning from Los Angeles, Chicago, New York and other cities for Montego Bay, fly on to five other islands as well as Cuba and return in the afternoon to take passengers back to the United States.
Robert Booth, an aviation consultant who specializes in Latin America and the Caribbean, said that the hub was a good idea but that it was too small. "A hub works when you have 15 flights coming from 15 different points connecting and going on to other points," he said. Indeed, last month, Air Jamaica announced that it was cutting service to two islands because of a lack of passengers.
Nevertheless, Mr. Stewart insisted that the hub was working better than expected. "It is a building process," he said.
The new alliance with Delta should help. The agreement, under which Delta will sell seats on Air Jamaica flights from New York, Atlanta and Miami, gives Air Jamaica access to 23 million members of Delta's frequent-flier program, who can now use their miles to fly to Jamaica for the first time.
While Air Jamaica's prospects are looking brighter, the pressure of the last two years has taken its toll. Three top executives have left the airline since mid-1996, including two chief executives. In March, Christopher Zacca, 38, a veteran of several of Mr. Stewart's other businesses and acting chief executive of Air Jamaica since January, was named the airline's top manager. Mr. Zacca is in charge of carrying out the "Way Forward" plan to make Air Jamaica profitable by 2000. Mr. Stewart, ever optimistic, called the plan conservative and said the airline could actually go into the black as early as this year.
Just as important, he believes he has finally won admission into the club of established industry players. He recalls how he stopped talking to Mr. Dolara, the American Airlines senior vice president, for six months after the bigger company put Air Jamaica in its cross hairs. Tensions have since eased, and American now seems resigned to letting Air Jamaica have its share of the market. "I like Dolara a lot and respect his talents," Mr. Stewart said, "but I think Dolara likes me a lot more now because he has felt my talents."

HEADLINE: Officials Say Lower Interest Rates Have Cut Cost of Lilco Deal

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, N.Y., April 9

 BODY:
The Long Island Power Authority, which has been pushing to take over the Long Island Lighting Company's electricity service, announced today that the cost of financing a takeover had dropped by about one-third -- nearly $5 billion -- because of lower interest rates.
The projected savings were announced by Gov. George E. Pataki's appointees on the Power Authority. They also unanimously adopted electricity rates that would go into effect after a takeover. The new rates would cut customer bills an average of 20 percent, up from the previously announced 19.4 percent. 
 "It's the largest single across-the-board rate reduction in the history of America," the authority's chairman, Richard M. Kessel, said at the agency's meeting here. Long Islanders now pay the highest electricity charges in North America.
Despite the announcement, opponents seeking to block the plan made new attacks on the credibility of the projected savings.
Although the takeover has cleared several major regulatory hurdles, it is not final. The next battleground may be a meeting on Wednesday of the State Public Authorities Control Board, where Governor Pataki is pressing for approval of the bonds to finance the takeover.
In preparation, the critics are focusing their efforts on Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the State Assembly, who controls a pivotal vote on the control board. The bonds cannot be issued without the board's unanimous approval. The board's other two votes are controlled by the Governor and his ally, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno.
Mr. Silver gave preliminary approval to the takeover last year. But he attached several conditions, and now his representatives are scrutinizing the power authority for its compliance. The Speaker's representatives have asked the power authority to guarantee its promised rate cuts in the bond resolution or bond covenants. So far, the power authority has refused.
Mr. Kessel, in a letter to Speaker Silver's advisers, said that the authority's experts believed that "incorporating this guarantee into the bond resolution would negatively impact the credit evaluation and marketability of L.I.P.A.'s bonds, thus increasing costs for ratepayers."
Larry Shapiro, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, which has filed a court challenge to the proposed takeover, said, "The rate cut guarantee means nothing if it's not in the bond covenants."
Pat Lynch, a spokeswoman for Mr. Silver, said yesterday: "I see no change in our overall position." She declined to elaborate.
Mr. Shapiro also called the projected savings "phony."
Mr. Kessel disputed the criticism. "There was no deception here," he said. "Those are updates on numbers that help the consumer."
He said that when the plan was drafted a year ago, interest rates were projected at 6.8 percent, with a cost of $17.5 billion in interest and principal for the takeover.
Now interest rates are down about 1 percentage point. That savings, plus a new pledge today to pay off the $4.5 billion debt for Lilco's never-opened nuclear plant at Shoreham in 17 years instead of 33 years, would bring the total savings to nearly $5 billion. After Shoreham is paid off, he said, the power authority should be able to reduce electricity rates another 10 percent.
Critics contend that the takeover would not deliver the promised savings and would enrich Lilco stockholders.

HEADLINE: Detroit Council Approves Plan For 3 Casinos

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 9

 BODY:
The City Council today approved a $1.8 billion plan to make Detroit the largest city in the country with casino gambling, despite complaints that blacks were shut out of the project and concerns about its location.
The plan to build three casinos in a warehouse district east of downtown on the Detroit River now goes to the Michigan Gaming Control Board. 
 "We're obviously very happy and very pleased," said Herb Strather, chairman of Atwater group that includes Circus Circus, which won one of the three casino franchises. The other two went to the MGM Grand and the Greektown/Chippewa Indians.
Mayor Dennis Archer pushed the project as a way to revitalize the city's slumping economy, but was criticized after none of the three franchises were awarded to blacks in a city that is 80 percent black.
But Mr. Archer said that blacks had stakes in all three casino groups and would benefit from the creation of 11,000 permanent full-time jobs and the infusion of $180 million in taxes a year that will go to fighting crime and supporting schools.
Casinos will "bring jobs, business opportunities, a new stream of tax revenue and a first-class tourist attraction to the city of Detroit," Mr. Archer said at a news conference, standing in front of the council members who approved the plan.
Don Barden, a black businessman whose casino proposal was rejected by Mr. Archer, emphasized that the state must still approve the plan.
"This is just a first phase," Mr. Barden said. "We could be back to square one in a number of months."
The state gaming board could act within four to six months, paving the way for temporary casinos to open by the end of the year or the beginning of 1999, Mr. Archer said. Permanent casinos would follow two to three years later.
The council approved the Greektown/Chippewa Indians and Circus Circus proposals each by votes of 6 to 3. The MGM Grand proposal passed 5 to 4, after Councilman Kenneth Cockrel switched his vote.
Mr. Cockrel said he voted against MGM because it has approximately 3 percent black ownership, the lowest of the three winning bids.
Mr. Archer also came under fire for moving the proposed casino site from the central business district to the area along the river a few miles away.
Councilman Nicholas Hood 3d voted against the casinos because of their location.
"It doesn't have any economic spinoff for the downtown," Mr. Hood said of the riverfront site.
Some residents disagreed.
"It truly is the right thing for the city," said Brian McDonald, manager of the Soup Kitchen Saloon in the riverfront district. "It will bring a lot of revenue and physical improvements."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Declined for Fifth Month in a Row in March

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
Producer prices fell for the fifth month in a row in March, the Government said today, showing that inflation remains calm amid healthy growth in the eighth year of the economy's expansion.
The Labor Department's Producer Price Index fell three-tenths of 1 percent, a bigger drop than economists had expected. 
 Even when food and energy costs, which fluctuate widely, were excluded, prices were unchanged. In February, the overall index fell by one-tenth of 1 percent, while the core index, which excludes food and energy, rose by that amount.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said the number of unemployed Americans filing initial claims for jobless benefits fell unexpectedly last week by 2,000. Initial state jobless claims declined to 308,000, from 310,000 in the week ended on March 28.
The low level of claims reinforced perceptions that the labor market remained strong despite last week's surprising report that payrolls fell by 36,000 jobs in March. Many economists have dismissed that number as a fluke caused by seasonal variations.
"Despite the moderate tone of last month's employment report, these claims numbers don't tell us that the labor market is necessarily getting weaker," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio.
With the unemployment rate at a low 4.7 percent, many economists have been worried that inflationary pressures might begin to build, particularly in the labor-intensive service sector because of a bidding up of wages, possibly prompting the Federal Reserve to lift short-term interest rates.
So far, that has not happened.
In the goods sector, in fact, prices have been falling, not rising, in a trend many analysts have linked to the economic problems in Asia, which have depressed worldwide demand for commodities like oil.
Economists have repeatedly expressed surprise at the benign inflation data during the current economic expansion. As of February, the Consumer Price Index indicated inflation was running at an annual rate of only 1.4 percent.
In the 12 months ended March 31, the Producer Price Index declined by 1.8 percent.
"The data fit perfectly with the story that Asia's crisis is causing prices to decline," said Chris Rupkey, economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York, who noted that the series of consecutive monthly declines in that index that began in November tracked the acceleration of the Asian financial crisis.
The March decline in producer prices was led by energy prices, which tumbled 1.9 percent and have declined a hefty 10.4 percent over the last year. Last month, food prices slid four-tenths of a percent, while passenger car costs edged up one-tenth of a percent.
The producer index for crude goods, or raw materials, like petroleum and wheat fell 1.6 percent in March. The index for prices of intermediate goods, or items in the middle stages of production, declined five-tenths of a percent.
Many economists warned that the energy and commodity price declines that have helped push the index lower might not continue in the months ahead.
"Oil made its big plunge in mid-February to mid-March and then rebounded," said Joe Ladoga, financial economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
"We are seeing the bottoming out of commodities prices, and they have the base to move higher," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japan Outlines Plan To Stimulate Economy
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan, under pressure from world leaders to do something to reverse a worsening economic downturn that could ripple around the globe, disclosed the Government's largest package yet of tax cuts and new spending.
The package is worth about $75 billion, roughly what Washington has been urging. Nonetheless, it was unclear when, where and how the money would be used. Page A1. 

$300 Million Bid Seen for Court TV
Evercore Partners, a New York investment firm, has made a bid -- said to be more than $300 million -- to buy a majority financial interest in Court TV, which is owned by NBC, Time Warner and Liberty Media. D3.
 
Record Amounts Pour Into Funds
Investors poured a record $37.5 billion into long-term mutual funds last month, according to estimates by a trade group. It said the cash flows were apparently augmented by contributions to retirement plans, including the new Roth I.R.A.'s. D6.
 
Clinton to Pursue Tobacco Deal
President Clinton vowed that he would continue to fight for tobacco legislation despite the cigarette manufacturers' objections to the latest Congressional proposals. He also promised tobacco farmers that their livelihoods would not be threatened by the legislation. A16.
 
With its defiant decision to go on the offensive against the tobacco legislation taking shape in Congress, the tobacco industry has gambled that it can muster enough allies to stop or reshape a legislative process on which its influence had seemed to vanish. News analysis. A1.
 
Solid Gains for Merchants
Many American retailers are reporting strong sales increases, helped by spring fever and feelings of prosperity among shoppers. A Goldman, Sachs index that measures major retailers' sales in stores open at least one year rose 3.4 percent last month. D4.
 
Producer prices were lower for the fifth month in a row, falling by three-tenths of 1 percent in March, as inflation remains calm. In another report, a decline in claims for unemployment benefits last week provided further evidence of healthy growth. D20.
 
Weak Quarter for Polaroid
Polaroid, saying it was hurt by the strong dollar, a weak Asian economy and lower orders in the United States, reported a far bigger loss for the first quarter than analysts had expected. Still, it said it expected sales of its cameras and other products to pick up. D2.
 
Accord in Feud at French Ad Giant
A family feud that threatened to unravel Publicis, the No. 2 French advertising agency company, appears to have been resolved with a settlement between battling sisters that was reached almost two years to the day of the death of their father, who founded the agency. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D3.
 
Profit Up 10% at Abbott Labs
Abbott Laboratories reported a 10 percent jump in quarterly profit, citing strong sales of its hospital and laboratory products. D2.
 
Big Award for Whistle-Blowers
In a rebuke to the Justice Department, a Federal judge has awarded $42.3 million to three men whose whistle-blowing helped expose Medicare fraud at SmithKline Beecham Clinical Laboratories. The Justice Department had argued that its investigations, and not the men's assistance, had resulted in a settlement with the company. D18.
 
Mixed Results in Bond Trading
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was slightly higher, with the yield dropping to 5.88 percent from 5.89, but the prices of shorter-term securities were mostly lower. D6.
 
U.S. Markets Closed
Financial markets in the United States and many other countries are closed today in observance of Good Friday.
