HEADLINE: Kennel Club Recalls Its Dog Bible After Outcry on Profiles

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Serious dog owners tend to share some characteristics of the pets they love: Sensitive. Loyal. Protective.
So it should perhaps have come as no surprise to the American Kennel Club that the latest edition of "The Complete Dog Book," its canine bible, might stir howls of protest. 
 The American Kennel Club has decided to recall the book after complaints that it unfairly maligned the reputation of such popular breeds as dachshunds, Dalmatians and Scottish terriers. Dog fanciers objected to the book's description of dozens of dog breeds as unsuitable for families with children.
The tempest in a dog dish was unleashed by the book's 19th edition, a revision of previous volumes of the 69-year-old classic. The new version describes as "not good" for children some 40 breeds, including toy poodles, Maltese terriers, borzois, Chihuahuas and whippets.
At the same time, the 19th edition pronounces as child-safe some breeds whose popular reputation is more fearsome, including Doberman pinschers and bull terriers.
The book has sold two million copies since 1929, and is a resource for the owners of the nation's 145 registered pure dog breeds. The 19th edition, $32.95 and 756 pages, calls itself the "one reference book for the sport of purebred dogs" in its book jacket copy. The Kennel Club said it would replace the book without charge after issuing a revised edition in June.
The troublesome descriptions are in new "breed profiles" that list dogs' characteristics. For example, the entry for German shorthaired pointer says, "Relationship with children -- not good."
Some 30,000 copies of the book were printed in December, and 10,000 have been removed from distribution. The recall started in January, but the Kennel Club did not publicly respond to the controversy until Wednesday.
In a Jan. 28 letter sent to 500 member clubs and 4,000 affiliates, the Kennel Club said many of the "breed profiles" had been "inadvertently published with incorrect and controversial information."
Yesterday, a Kennel Club spokeswoman, Valerie Geiss, said, "The book does have errors."
In a statement, the Kennel Club, based in Manhattan, said it "sincerely regrets the distress caused to dog owners and breeders." It said the edition's format had been "changed for the first time in recent memory without the proper vetting."
"This has been an expensive and embarrassing lesson for the A.K.C.," it added. "Procedures have been put in place to prevent a recurrence."
While popular wisdom often ascribes varying predispositions to different breeds -- high-strung poodles, temperamental Chihuahuas, valiant collies -- many dog breeders become apoplectic about such stereotypes. For example, owners of Staffordshire terriers, commonly called pit bulls, have long contended that their pets have been unfairly maligned.
It is not clear how the characterizations in the Kennel Club book were arrived at, or to what degree the outcry among dog owners influenced the decision to revise the book. But critics challenged the organization's whole world view.
"The Kennel Club's pronouncements are ridiculous," said Rob Abner, publisher of D.G.N.Y., a magazine for New York City dog owners. "It's a very outdated way of thinking about dogs."
Mr. Abner denied that certain breeds had a genetic predisposition to viciousness, saying: "And even if they did, you can't consider a dog without its environment. It's the nature-nurture question. There is no breed of dog that is more or less compatible with children."
Canine clubs also growled back at the Kennel Club.
"You just can't make such a blanket statement about dachshunds," said Carl Holder, secretary of the Dachshund Club of America. "I've never had any of my dachshunds bite any children. They're very friendly with kids."
Mr. Holder, who lives in Lumberton, Tex., and has seven dachshunds, added: "Dogs are not vehicles stamped out of an assembly line. Each one is an individual."
Sandra Whittle, president of the Chihuahua Club of America in Chesterfield, Va., said: "There is a stereotype of Chihuahuas that they are mean and temperamental. But that is completely wrong."
Ms. Whittle, who has five Chihuahuas, added: "Chihuahuas can be wonderful with children if they are introduced to them in the right way. They should learn to play and trust each other in short sessions under the close supervision of adults."
The Kennel Club would not say how much the recall would cost.
But Albert N. Greco, an associate professor at the Fordham University graduate business school, said, "The organization will take a big financial and public-relations hit."
Professor Greco, an expert on printing economics, said the total loss to the Kennel Club could reach $800,000, considering the cost of the initial and replacement editions, including transportation and warehouse costs.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Investors Shrug Off Forecasts of Lower Earnings

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Investors remain nonchalant about the corporate earnings season, which begins in earnest next week, although stock analysts now expect little or no growth in overall profits.
The stock market has already risen much faster than was expected at the beginning of the year, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 103 points yesterday, bringing its increase to 13.7 percent so far in 1998. 
 The reason for the nonchalance may be that relatively few companies are expected to be poor performers in the first quarter, and they are concentrated in two sectors -- technology and energy. So as long as the overall economic outlook is still strong, investors reason, the broad stock market can continue to rise, too.
"The optimists might say it is better to have the revisions concentrated in a few sectors so the rest of the stocks could do better," said Melissa Brown, the director of quantitative research at Prudential Securities.
Thomas Doerflinger, an investment strategist at Paine Webber, said investors had probably discounted a profit drop at oil companies. A plunge in oil prices caused by overproduction and a drop in demand from Asia is hurting those companies, but it "is not symptomatic of a general weakness in the U.S. economy," he said.
I.B.E.S. International Inc., which collects corporate earnings estimates of analysts, is now forecasting a decline of four-tenths of a percent in the operating earnings for the 500 companies in the closely watched Standard & Poor's stock index in the first quarter, compared with the first quarter of 1997. Just three months ago, I.B.E.S. projected a 9.6 percent increase for the period. The First Call Corporation, another earnings analysis firm, is predicting a scant increase of five-tenths of a percent, down from its 10.4 percent estimate at the beginning of the year.
The collapse in the I.B.E.S. estimates has been concentrated among nine companies in the S.& P 500. Compaq Computer, Intel, I.B.M., Amoco, Chevron, Texaco, Mobil, Atlantic Richfield and Union Pacific account for one-third of the downward revision. And the entire technology and energy sectors account for just over half of the revision.
First Call's list is slightly different because of the analysts included and some other technical factors. But by its count, 25 companies represent half of the downward revision. Among those not in the select I.B.E.S. group are Exxon, Motorola, Boeing, DuPont, General Motors, Silicon Graphics and Amerada Hess.
The big role of technology and oil companies in the revisions is an initial indication of the impact of the financial turmoil in Asia. Mr. Doerflinger said that he had expected the Asian slowdown to be felt most immediately and most strongly by commodity-based companies, which include oil companies and technology companies that sell commodities like semiconductors and disk drives.
Sluggish performance this quarter from these groups could still be troubling, because many investors base their expectations for overall profits on the performance of technology companies like Intel and Microsoft. (Microsoft, it should be noted, was responsible for the biggest upward revision in earnings estimates for the first quarter in the I.B.E.S. data.)
This was clear earlier this week. After closing above 9,000 for the first time ever on Monday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell sharply for two days. Motorola's announcement of lower growth estimates for computer chip sales this year contributed to the slide Tuesday.
But yesterday, investors looked on the bright side, encouraged by stronger-than-expected earnings from Yahoo Inc. and the Chrysler Corporation. The Dow jumped 103.38 points, or 1.2 percent, to 8,994.86, and reached a high of 9,062.12 during the day. The Standard and Poor's 500-stock index climbed 9.02 points, to 1,110.67, while the Nasdaq index jumped 13.23 points, to 1,820.24.
The pessimism of stock analysts that shows up in the earnings estimates is surprising to some economists, in part because the economy has been more robust so far this year than many forecasters thought.
"Yes, Asia is negative and yes, the dollar is strong," said William C. Dudley, the chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, referring to two factors that will depress earnings.
"But the economy grew at 4 percent in the first quarter, so why should profits have collapsed? It doesn't add up to me."
To others, a decline in earnings is not a concern just for the near term. James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, said that the real assessment would be made when it was clear what caused the earnings decline. The earnings downdraft could be a result of nothing more than oil price declines and the sharp price cutting in the computer industry, he said.
Or it could turn out that more Americans are buying cheaper products made abroad and that American exports are falling very sharply, a hint of which appeared in the January trade data. If that is the case, the outlook could be worse for growth here and for future earnings prospects.
Retail sales could be great, he said, but they could be all Asian products. "This would mean that U.S. companies are not doing that well."
So far, earnings estimates for the last three quarters of this year are relatively strong, despite the first-quarter drop-off. "Either the analysts are suggesting that the rest of the year is going to be extremely good," Ms. Brown said, "or they are going to have to bring their estimates down."

HEADLINE: Flush but Crime-Wary Cities Bid Up Pay for Police Chiefs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
When the District of Columbia considered hiring the New Orleans Police Superintendent, Richard Pennington, as the capital's police chief, city officials in New Orleans did everything they could to keep him happy where he was.
That included the offer of a four-year contract with a raise of 50 percent, to $150,000, making Superintendent Pennington New Orleans's highest-paid city employee. Washington, meanwhile, turned to Charles H. Ramsey, second-in-command of the Chicago Police Department, offering him $150,000, which is $60,000 more than Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. is paid and $40,000 more than Mr. Ramsey made in Chicago. 
 "I was really flattered," Mr. Pennington said of the competition for him. "I didn't want to start a bidding war. But when my Mayor said he would match whatever Washington was offering, that made me feel very comfortable."
With crime rates falling dramatically in many places around the country and a strong economy bolstering efforts by local governments to improve services, candidates for police chief with a proven record of success have become municipal superstars. Like free agents in baseball and highly skilled corporate executives, they are intensely recruited and highly paid -- whether by the cities that lure them away or the cities that keep them in place.
Police chiefs are benefiting from the plummeting crime rates, though the reasons for it are the subject of debate. Some experts have cited other factors -- including an aging criminal population and the weakening of the crack cocaine epidemic -- as having had more impact on crime statistics than police work has had.
Nonetheless, a recent survey by the Police Executive Research Forum in Washington, which helps local governments find candidates for police chief, found that 25 percent of chiefs in cities with at least 50,000 people earned annual salaries of more than $100,000. One of the highest-paid chiefs, Bernard C. Parks, who replaced Willie L. Williams last year in Los Angeles, is paid more than $200,000.
Mr. Pennington said he was the first New Orleans police superintendent to be given a contract.
The competition for talented municipal executives is not limited to police chiefs. With the Federal Government shifting more responsibility, and money, to the states to run programs and states giving local governments more leeway in administering them, skilled executives recruited to lead welfare, public works and other municipal agencies are hot properties.
Officials in San Jose, Calif., searched two years for a director of information technology, offering an annual salary of $105,000, but they could not find a suitable candidate for that salary. They finally filled the position in February, hiring Ken Phillips, a computer company executive from Oregon, for about $140,000 a year.
"I've never seen anything like this," Norman Roberts, president of a Los Angeles company that helps local governments identify qualified candidates for senior positions, said of the salaries that leading candidates are winning. "In the last six months, at least 15 to 20 percent of all our recommended candidates have gotten offers, then counter offers." In general, recruiters said, the demand for highly qualified department heads stemmed from the recession of the early 1990's, when many local governments were forced to pare their employment rolls to avoid budget deficits. That often meant saving money by eliminating middle managers.
But those cuts had a longer range impact, depleting future candidate pools in police departments and other government agencies for higher positions. Now, with the economy flush again and local governments eager to restore cannibalized departments, superior candidates for senior positions are widely sought.
Perhaps no candidates find themselves more coveted than a police chief or a second-in-command who can claim that his strategies of community policing helped drive down crime rates. In the early 1990's, when homicide and crack cocaine seemed unbeatable, many big cities fought their way through with strategies devised by their police chiefs.
Now, with murder rates dropping by as much as a third in some cities, like New York and Minneapolis -- although for reasons that remain the subject of heated debate -- police chiefs like Mr. Pennington have become heroes in their cities with popularity ratings as high as any in the local government. In New Orleans, the murder rate has fallen by 40 percent over the last three years.
One of the biggest stars, William J. Bratton, the former New York City Police Commissioner and a former Boston police commander, has written a book, "Turnaround: How America's Top Cop Reversed the Crime Epidemic." Some of his senior disciples have been heavily recruited elsewhere, including John F. Timoney, who was recently named Police Commissioner in Philadelphia for $113,000 a year.
In most places, safe streets and neighborhoods contribute to a strong local tax base and civic pride, but only recently are police chiefs being recognized for the crucial role their programs play in the economic stability of a city or county.
"They have a huge impact on property values, the commercial viability of the community and the eagerness of people to enjoy themselves in public places," said Thomas C. Frazier, the Police Commissioner in Baltimore, where crime has fallen during his four years in charge.
Police officials generally agree that police departments that are running smoothly promote from within when the job of chief becomes vacant. Outside candidates, like Mr. Ramsey in Washington, are usually sought when past policies have failed, or corruption in the department demands that city leaders look elsewhere. The District's previous chief, Larry D. Soulsby, resigned last November amid ethical questions.
The Police Executive Research Forum survey, which polled 358 chiefs in cities with populations of 50,000 or more last September, found that 56.7 percent of them had been promoted from within and 42.2 percent came from outside, a breakdown that has remained relatively constant, said Chuck Wexler, the forum's executive director.
In either case, police chief is no longer the job it once was, simply marshaling forces to respond to one 911 call after another. Policing has changed dramatically recently, from reacting to crime to preventing it through community policing.
For the chief, that means developing programs that involve the department with citizens and community groups to help identify problems, devise solutions tailored to the neighborhood and evaluate results.
Even smaller communities now demand that their chief be well-schooled in community policing. "That was a big thing to us," said Kurt Kimball, city manager of Grand Rapids, Mich., who led a search that ended last month with the hiring of Harry Dolan, the police chief of Lumberton, N.C.
"The more he talked the talk, the more we realized he had walked the walk, albeit in a town one-10th the size of ours," Mr. Kimball said of Mr. Dolan.
Grand Rapids agreed to pay Mr. Dolan an annual salary of $80,000, a 53 percent increase over the $52,000 he was paid in Lumberton.
The higher salaries for chiefs also reflect a wider range of responsibilities. In addition to implementing new policing ideas, many chiefs, particularly those hired to lead departments in mid-size and large cities, are involved more than ever with managerial issues, like budgets, union contracts, grievances, arbitration hearings and computer technology.
"It's a much different emphasis from years ago," said Dan Rosenblatt, executive director of the International Association of Police Chiefs in Washington, noting the shift from the image of chief as crime fighter. "These people are now like C.E.O.'s of major corporations."
With the expanding demands on a chief's time, many highly recruited candidates are far more educated than their predecessors of decades ago. Lee Brown, the Mayor of Houston who was New York City's police commissioner from 1990 to 1992 and Houston's police chief before that, said the first chief he worked under, in San Jose, had only a high school education. Houston's current chief, Clarence O. Bradford, has a law degree from the University of Houston.
The survey conducted by the Police Executive Research Forum found that more than half the chiefs who responded had a master's, doctoral or law degree.
"We always hear the same thing," said Mr. Wexler, the forum's executive director. "Cities want a strong leader, who is a visionary, a good manager, one with impeccable integrity and character and someone willing to move the department ahead. The competition to find them is fierce, and cities that have one want to hold on to him."
But just as the occasional free agent bats only .200 for his new team, some heavily recruited chiefs fail at their mission or do not survive the politics of the city. In New York, Mr. Bratton resigned in 1996 after crime had dropped significantly on his watch but amid tense relations with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over who was responsible for it.
Some Bratton supporters have said the reason for the tension was the former commissioner's popularity, which rivaled that of his boss.
Mr. Williams, who built a strong reputation as Philadelphia's police chief before he was hired in Los Angeles to soothe the civic wounds of the Rodney King beating, was dismissed last year after his five-year contract expired.
The city's police commissioner acknowledged Mr. Williams's "ability to communicate with and reassure the community" but said he had been "unable or unwilling to consistently translate his words into action."
Mr. Frazier, the Baltimore police commissioner, said: "For the city that needs a new chief, there's a huge risk. A police chief is probably the most important appointment a mayor or city manager could make. When there's an opening, 100 people come in and say they can do it, but only five really can. It's like turning around a big ship. You want to turn it as fast as you can but you can't tip it over. That's an art, not a science."

HEADLINE: A Crowd on the Campaign Trail;
159 Days to Senate Primary, 3 Democratic Rivals Hit Hustings

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
With the expanse of Morningside Park at her back, Geraldine A. Ferraro yesterday offered her view of the state of New York's economy -- troubled -- along with some ideas on how to cure it. Ms. Ferraro had barely gathered her papers before Mark Green rose in another corner of Harlem to offer his "Agenda for Children in the 21st Century." By then, the third candidate for the Senate, Charles E. Schumer, had finished outlining his property tax cut plan at a news conference on Long Island.
There may be just 159 days before Primary Day, but the three Democrats seeking their party's nomination to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato took to the hustings yesterday as if it were the day after Labor Day. In the course of three hours, the Democrats unveiled, among them, 30 pages thick with policy proposals, including hiring more teachers to reduce class size and forcing the members of NATO to pay their fair share of the alliance dues. 
 This vigorous display of politicking -- reporters arriving at Ms. Ferraro's speech at Columbia University were met by a Schumer aide handing out copies of the speech that the Brooklyn Representative was giving in Mineola, L.I. -- is unusual this early: phone and E-mail systems are still being installed at the three campaign headquarters. But the confluence of events -- major policy speeches by both Mr. Green and Ms. Ferraro, along with a substantial proposal by Mr. Schumer, directed at suburban voters -- suggests just how intensely this contest will be fought.
In the course of the day, the three candidates clearly looked for ways to distinguish themselves without resorting to the intraparty attacks that proved so damaging to the party in 1992. And although there were many similarities in what the candidates offered to voters in different parts of the state -- all three Democrats are clearly in favor of spending more money -- there were differences as well, which suggested the way the campaign will develop in the months ahead.
Even so, Ms. Ferraro and Mr. Green invoked the same solution in suggesting how to pay for their programs: cutting defense, a proposal that might have particular resonance among the historically liberal Democratic primary electorate.
"We are now spending money we don't have on weapons that don't always work, against enemies that no longer exist," Mr. Green said, speaking at Bank Street College of Education in Harlem. "The enemy of ignorance is a far greater threat to our families and children than any foreign enemy today."
Ms. Ferraro, speaking at a Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce luncheon at Columbia University, offered a similar observation: "The cold war is over," she said. "In a post-cold-war world, we can afford to cut more from the $265 billion we now spend on defense."
This was Ms. Ferraro's first major policy address, and in it, she tried to finesse what has been a difficult task for all recent Democratic challengers: asserting that the economy is not as good as it appears, though not blaming President Clinton for any possible shortcomings.
"The headlines suggest that things have never been better, and in some ways that's true," she said. In truth, she added, wealthy New Yorkers are doing well at the expense of middle class and poor ones.
"It's great to see what's happening on Wall Street," she said. "But it's only fair to ask: When is it going to make it to 125th Street?"
Ms. Ferraro called for lower class size by hiring more teachers, improving teacher training, increasing the use of tax incentives to encourage business development, and forging some portion of student loans for people who become public school teachers. She did not offer an estimate on the cost of her ideas, other than to promise that it would be relatively small.
Mr. Green, who is New York City's Public Advocate, called for universal health care for children, expanded child care programs and hiring more teachers to reduce class size.
"Sixty years ago, this country rightly decided to create a safety net for the elderly who were in trouble," he said. "If we created a system of Social Security to help the neglected elderly 60 years ago, now we have to create a system of social security for our neglected children in the 1990's."
Mr. Green said his "Social Security system for kids," as he termed it, would cost $67.4 billion over five years.
Mr. Schumer offered a single proposal, rather than broad thematic speeches: He said he would introduce legislation in Congress that would mandate that a portion of New York State's share of any tobacco settlement go to reducing property taxes and, in New York City, cutting the state utility tax.
Mr. Schumer said the measure was intended to redress the fact that New York requires local governments to pay half the cost of Medicaid. Reducing property taxes, he said, would effectively reimburse property owners for Medicaid costs incurred because of tobacco-related disabilities.
As it happens, such a proposal would be of particular benefit to suburban counties, where Mr. Schumer is not particularly well known and must do well in order to defeat Mr. D'Amato. Mr. Schumer offered his proposal in Nassau County, and said that one-third of the $2.7 billion tax cut would go to Long Island homeowners, were it to be passed.
One explanation for this unusually early exercise in campaigning is the belief among many Democrats that Mr. D'Amato is vulnerable this year. He is seeking a fourth term, and early polls suggest that New Yorkers are growing weary of the junior senator.
In addition, all three candidates have -- for as much as a decade -- aspired to Mr. D'Amato's position and have given much thought about how to attain it.
The candidates are clearly intent on stoking interest in the race and keeping it going. Mr. Schumer's money, Ms. Ferraro's celebrity and Mr. D'Amato's perceived weakness may suggest that they may have some success in keeping the pace going as briskly as was evidenced yesterday.
Still, the occurrence of the three campaigns competing for attention seemed not an entirely welcome event yesterday, and a few campaign officials seemed irritated at the suggestions that some of the candidates might be looking to steal attention from a rival.
"I told you for a week that we were doing this, right?" said Josh Isay, who is Mr. Schumer's campaign manager.
"This was on Mark's schedule for at least four weeks," said Joe DePlasco, Mr. Green's spokesman.
Ms. Ferraro's campaign manager, David Eichenbaum, in a reference to her high standings in the polls and attention paid to her campaign, just laughed at the question. He said, "Why would we do that?"

All three candidates unveiled major positions yesterday. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times; Jack Manning/The New York Times; Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Play Ball! Now Where Are All the Teams?

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.

 BODY:
Signs in store windows here say that people in this economically troubled old city are "Hooked on the Bluefish," a new minor league baseball franchise. Bluefish hats and T-shirts -- the logo features a tough-looking fish with a bat -- are for sale downtown. A new $15 million stadium, paid for by the city and the state, is under construction on Main Street, which has been rerouted to make the ball park an urban centerpiece.
One little problem, though: The Bluefish do not exist -- nor do the five other teams they are supposed to play against when the season starts on May 21. 
 "A baseball park for a team that is yet to be defined, with a league that is yet to be established -- in some respects, your neck is out to here a little bit on it," said Bridgeport's Mayor, Joseph P. Ganim.
Ganim's neck is not the only one. The Atlantic League, an upstart independent professional association outside Major League Baseball's traditional farm system, has persuaded five of the six cities on its roster to build new 5,000- to 6,000-seat ball parks almost entirely at public expense. A total of $110 million in public financing has been committed altogether -- for teams that, with only weeks to go before opening day, still exist for the most part on paper.
Atlantic City is building a $14 million stadium for its proto-team, the Surf, using redevelopment money from its gambling casinos. Newark has authorized $22 million to build a downtown park for the Newark Bears, who will play in Bridgeport for their first season and do not even have an office yet in Newark. The other franchises are Somerset, N.J., which will play entirely on the road this season; Lehigh Valley, from Pennsylvania, which will play for a year in Newburgh, N.Y.; and Nashua, N.H.
The new league's birth, along with its high stakes -- unheard of in the world of independent franchises, where shoestring budgets, old parks and bankruptcies are more the rule -- has created in its initial cities or locales an interlocking system of hopes, fears and ambitions. Baseball experts say that in a market where there is so much major and minor league baseball already, the Atlantic League's ambitions are testing the limit of baseball both as a recreational drawing card and a spur for economic revitalization.
Within the new league, there are also many different agendas and goals. Everybody's got an angle.
Poor cities like Bridgeport, surrounded by rich suburbs, are hoping for economic development.
Club officials and owners say a period of upheaval and experimentation has begun in the minor leagues as major league owners try to cut costs. The Atlantic League is hoping that the major league clubs will find it a convenient and cost-efficient place to send some of their players under contracts for training and development.
The handful of players signed so far are, for the most part, older veterans of the minor and major leagues, looking either for a comeback or a way to prolong their life in baseball. They are hoping to get noticed, and they are being told by club managers and league officials that major league scouts will certainly be watching them.
Fans are just hoping for some baseball.
"Minor league baseball is great -- it's a cheap date, you bring the kids, people don't get drunk or use foul language," said John Holland, a psychiatric social worker who works in Bridgeport for the Connecticut Department of Mental Health. "It's a nice thing, and not a lot of nice things happen in this town."
So is this a tale of exploited hopes and troubled cities grasping at straws, a practical calculation about how to really make minor league baseball work, or something in between? The new league's chairman, Frank Boulton, a former Wall Street bond trader from Long Island, admitted that it was no coincidence most of the franchises in his league were in cities that had faced hard times and were looking, perhaps even in some desperation, for just the kind of thing he came to sell.
Boulton said his primary vision was that clean new ball parks -- especially the intimate downtown parks that have been hugely successful in places like Baltimore and Cleveland -- are increasingly the key to success in baseball. He said he sought out cities that could not get an affiliated farm team from the National Association of Baseball Leagues because of their location -- too close to a major league club, which could veto any expansion into its territory. Finally, he looked for cities that had access to public money for economic development and stadium construction.
"It was easier to get money to build something in Bridgeport, and it's easier going into a Newark," he said.
He also enlisted some famous names: Bud Harrelson, the former Mets shortstop, is the league's president. Rick Cerone, the former Yankees catcher, is president of the Newark Bears. And Sparky Lyle, the former Yankees pitcher, is field manager of the Somerset Patriots. The Atlantic League is full of major league baseball experience -- and names that could open doors in star-struck city halls.
"I think it was brilliant on Frank's part to go to these places and say, 'Look, territorially you can't have a National Association team, and based on people's perceptions you can't do very much right -- build us a stadium and we'll bring you baseball,' " said Charles J. Dowd Jr., the general manager and part owner of the Bluefish. "And it's worked -- people committed to those stadiums because they wanted some glimmer of hope."
Minor league clubs that are affiliated with major league teams often do well financially. Three of them now play within a few hours' drive of Manhattan: The Trenton Thunder, an affiliate of the Boston Red Sox; the New Jersey Cardinals in Augusta (St. Louis Cardinals), and the Hudson Valley Renegades in Fishkill, N.Y. (Tampa Bay Devils Rays). Independent minor league baseball -- in which the teams have no support from a major league big brother to pay for player salaries and development -- is much different. As a rule, it has lived on hope and little else.
As recently as 1995, for example, there were 11 independent leagues around the nation. This season, including the new Atlantic League, there are seven, said Miles Wolff, the president of the five-year-old Northern League and of Baseball America, a publication that covers the major and minor leagues. One league lasted 10 games, Wolff said. Another went two weeks, until its first payroll came due. One neglected to pay the electric bill and had the lights turned off by the city during a night game.
In the Atlantic League, the pockets are considerably deeper. The mostly local owners -- in Bridgeport's case, the founder of a health maintenance organization and the former chief executive of the local water company and his wife -- will have spent more than $2.6 million by the time the first season starts, including the purchase of the franchise from Boulton, a one-time fee that people close to the league say runs about $500,000.
The Newark Bears will play in Bridgeport this season on dates that the Bluefish do not, while the Newark park is being built. Lehigh Valley will play in an old park in Newburgh. The sixth team, the Nashua Pride, will play in a renovated stadium.
But there are still, in the weeks left before the 70-game season starts, a dizzying assortment of things that will have to come together. The teams are to be formed at a league-wide draft early next month in Florida, and city officials in Bridgeport and Atlantic City say their ball parks will not be completed until probably the week before the season opens, assuming the weather holds.
And while the team and league officials predict that the level of play will be roughly equivalent to perhaps a Class AA minor league level, no one is really sure what to expect. And some people think the very independence of the league -- outside the traditional farm team system, with its rosters of young hotshots dreaming of the big leagues -- will create and convey a different kind of emotion as well.
"I don't mean this in a negative way, but there's a certain wistful quality to this enterprise," said Louis Toscano, a senior policy adviser to Mayor James Whelan in Atlantic City. "It sort of gets you back to baseball's roots, the way it began 150 years ago or whatever."
Players like Al Sontag, a pitcher signed by the Bluefish in March, are humble -- a startling thing in itself in professional sports. At 34, after 14 years in minor leagues, he said he had come to terms with the fact that he almost certainly would not make it to the majors. He hopes to use the Atlantic League as a springboard to playing perhaps in Japan for a final year or two.
"This is probably my last stop," he said. "Guys I've run into over the years always say, 'Whatever happened to you? How come you're not in the big leagues? How come you're not up here with us?' And it's frustrating sometimes, but what are you going to do -- sit back and cry? You just keep plugging away, you keep going on and you hope something good happens."
But you also do not look back. Sontag pitched last year in an independent league, for a team in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. That league quietly folded this spring.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1511 words

HEADLINE: JAPANESE PROPOSE A $75 BILLION PLAN TO SPUR ECONOMY

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, April 10

 BODY:
Under pressure from foreign leaders, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto on Thursday proposed Japan's largest package yet of tax cuts and new spending in an effort to reverse an economic decline that could have ripple effects on other economies around the world.
But the financial markets were not impressed. Even as Mr. Hashimoto was promising to bring about a recovery, the yen slid sharply on Thursday and the Japanese central bank had to intervene in the currency market to stabilize its value. The yen recovered today, but the stock market was down about 1.2 percent late this afternoon. 
 The economic package described by the Prime Minister is large, worth about $75 billion in new fiscal stimulants, or about 2 percent of the total annual economic output, roughly what the United States has urged for the last month. The markets' negative response, however, may have been set off by Mr. Hashimoto's vagueness about how, when and where the money will be spent.
Japan has faced growing criticism from President Clinton and other political leaders about its once-mighty economy, which has been stalled for much of the last seven years. The nation now faces rising bankruptcies, more unemployment and falling export prices. On Wednesday, the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based group of 29 industrial nations, warned that the Japanese economy was on the "edge of recession" and could stagnate for years.
The risk to Japan's trading partners in Asia and to the United States is that this country might try to rescue itself by vastly increasing its exports and reducing imports. That would come at the worst time for the troubled economies of Asia that depend on Japan as a major source of investment and a market for goods. It would also anger the United States, which has pushed Japan to absorb more foreign goods and get consumers to spend more and save less.
Mr. Hashimoto acknowledged in a grim speech carried live on television that the economy was in a "severe situation."
But some private economists worried that the new proposals, while helpful, might not be sufficient to keep the Japanese economy from sliding further. "It's not enough," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo. "The risk of a deflationary spiral remains."
The main significance of Mr. Hashimoto's action Thursday was perhaps that he took it at all. He had been reluctant to cut taxes because he vowed to pursue austerity to contain a growing budget deficit. While American officials have been urging that he abandon that policy for the moment, Thursday was the first time he publicly suggested he was making the break.
The yen, a sensitive barometer of Japan's economic might, tumbled 1 percent just as the Prime Minister was speaking and languished until Japan purchased yen with dollars to increase the currency's value.
The American Secretary of the Treasury, Robert E. Rubin, issued a statement expressing concern about recent weakness in the yen. "In that context we welcome the action undertaken by Japanese authorities in the exchange market to support the value of the yen," Mr. Rubin said.
In afternoon trading here, the yen strengthened to 130.05 to the dollar, compared with 131.19 in New York late Thursday.
The intervention in the currency market appears to have exceeded $1 billion worth of yen purchases, market participants said. Japan's central bank said it sold dollars and bought yen through its accounts at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The Clinton Administration, as such, did not join in the defense of the yen, which it could have done by spending some of the money in a special Treasury fund used to intervene in the currency markets. Senior Treasury officials insisted that American foreign exchange policy had not changed. Despite Mr. Rubin's concern repeated Thursday that the yen is weak, they said he was not backing away from support of a strong dollar.
In addition to the $75 billion program, Japan is making funds available for loans and land purchases, which do not directly contribute to economic output, as part of an overall package of $121 billion of stimulants. Economists agreed that the measures would give some kick to the economy and constituted a step in the right direction.
Thomas S. Foley, the United States Ambassador and former House Speaker, told an audience on Thursday night that the new measures constituted "bold action."
American officials have repeatedly called upon Japan to cut taxes as a way of stimulating broad-based domestic demand. In an effort to get the Japanese people to spend, Mr. Hashimoto said he would put the equivalent of $30 billion into their pockets through tax cuts in equal amounts this year and next -- equivalent to roughly $370 a year for the average household. Some of Mr. Hashimoto's critics had sought more.
Naoto Kan, chairman of the Democratic Party, the largest opposition party, a day earlier had called for $45 billion worth of tax cuts.
In December, the Prime Minister announced a $15 billion tax cut, and part of that has been carried out, though so far with negligible effects.
This proposed tax cut would be a little bit less than the American net tax cut in last year's balanced-budget agreement, which amounted to an average of $20 billion a year over five years in an economy almost 40 percent larger than Japan's.
Part of the problem, though, is that Japan is a nation of savers. So when people receive a tax cut, they may not spend the money.
The last few months of financial and economic uncertainty have only made the Japanese more focused on saving. The savings rate for 1997 jumped as much as three percentage points, according to Tetsufumi Yamakawa, chief economist for Goldman, Sachs here.
"That's never, ever happened in Japan," he said. "So I really do not think that this income-tax cut is going to have a major impact."
In a sign of the enthusiasm for saving, one of the hottest items these days is a home safe, viewed by many as preferable to depositing money in weak banks offering interest rates of perhaps two-tenths of 1 percent.
With ordinary Japanese unlikely to spend all the proceeds of their tax break, many economists are focusing on the direct Government spending in the economic package -- and they do expect that will give a lift to the economy. Mr. Hashimoto said on Thursday that the Government would spend an extra $45 billion, or 1.2 percent of economic output, on public works projects.
But the Prime Minister gave few details, and critics have warned that past public works projects have already equipped Japan with far more remote bridges and dams than the country needs. Perhaps because of such complaints, he suggested that there would be substantial spending in different areas like environmental protection, nursing, care for the aged, science and technology, and fiber optic cables for public schools..
In any case, because of the multiplier effect as the money trickles through the economy, such Government spending could ultimately mean a payback to the economy of as much as 1.5 times the amount pumped in by the Government.
While some economists are more pessimistic, others say that the spending and tax-cut package could reverse the downturn.
Mr. Yamakawa of Goldman, Sachs, for instance, said that because of the package, economic growth in Japan could reach nine-tenths of 1 percent in the current fiscal year.
But economists say long-term recovery is elusive without deregulation and tax reform.
Mr. Hashimoto said on Thursday that the Government would try to lower the corporate tax rate to restore business vitality, hoping to match the rates of other countries in the next three years. More broadly, he called for a profound revision of the nation's tax structure, which currently imposes a top rate of 65 percent on the rich and a 50 percent income tax on corporations.
In an address that seemed to appeal as much to the United States as to his own compatriots, Mr. Hashimoto suggested that he might shift his position on fiscal austerity, which would require amending a law passed last fall to shrink budget deficits. But he was vague on this point, too, and instead emphasized the health of the economy, suggesting that there might not be a sense among top leaders that the economy was indeed in a crisis.
"I would like to stress that Japan's economy is one of the most powerful economies in the world," he said. "There are some people who insist that the Japanese economy has already lost its power to grow. I do not stand for such pessimism."
The nation's economy shrank slightly in the last quarter of 1997, and economists say they expect it to contract again in the first three months of this year, putting the country technically in a recession.
But more worrisome to economists has been the dip in prices, real wages and corporate profits.
"The spiral's gathering momentum; it's beginning," said Russell Jones, chief economist at Lehman Brothers Japan. A buoyant recovery, he added, seems far away.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 264 words

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Gateway to Open Office in Manhattan

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
Gateway 2000, the mail-order personal computer company in North Sioux City, S.D., announced yesterday that it would open its new Web development headquarters in Manhattan.
The office will open within the next few months, and company officials will be scouting locations for the headquarters next week, said Paul G. Roston, Gateway's vice president for global human resources. 
 About 40 jobs will move to New York with the opening of the office. All except for two senior-level managerial positions will be new hires.
Mr. Roston said the company -- known for packaging its computers in boxes that are spotted black and white, like cows -- needed to expand its Internet capabilities. It currently uses its own staff and consultants in South Dakota to run its Web site. Gateway sells about $3 million worth of computers each day from the site.
"We wanted the best talent, and we believe that the bulk of that talent is in San Francisco and New York City, and the best is in New York," Mr. Roston said. "We wanted to attract them without pulling them out of the life style and environment that they are in."
Gateway 2000, a Fortune 500 company, has manufacturing plants in the United States, Ireland and Malaysia and employs more than 13,000 people worldwide.
Russell A. Harding, executive vice president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said, "Gateway's decision to open its Web development headquarters here once again shows that New York City, under Mayor Giuliani, has become the global leader of Internet content and technology." NICK RAVO

HEADLINE: First-Class Travel Is for Rich and Cautious

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Robert B. Reich (Op-Ed, April 5) tries to resurrect class conflict in a prosperous era, pretending to understand the resentment of those in the back of the plane. Most people are pleased to have low unemployment and well-paying jobs. I don't think limousine drivers pine for the factory floor. Most people prefer the convenience of automated teller machines. I think airplane passengers appreciate the opportunity to fly inexpensively, even if the legroom is tight and the cheap fare is subsidized by the business travelers up front. Mr. Reich should stop the forced efforts at appearing compassionate. More affluence and increasing levels of service are good.
 
DOUG FECHTER
Wilton, Conn., April 8, 1998

HEADLINE: Addiction Can Be a Disease and a Behavior;
Tempting the Alcoholic

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Don't Forget the Addict's Role in Addiction" (Op-Ed, April 4), Sally L. Satel notes that researchers have found a link between the amount of alcohol consumed by alcoholics and the cost of it and the effort required to obtain it. She concludes that "alcoholics respond to rewards and consequences, not just to physiology."
The next questions should be: Why is fortified alcohol so inexpensive, and whose economic interests are being served by the low price? 
 What are the conditions in society that might lead someone to use alcohol to numb his pain?
 
PAMELA PETERSEN -CRAIR

HEADLINE: A Star Inspires Young Singers

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
The Young People's Chorus of New York, an acclaimed performance-based choral program that draws some 150 children aged 8 to 18 from all areas, economic groups and ethnic cultures of the city, has sung for some illustrious guests, including the pop singer Celine Dion, the composer Marvin Hamlisch and Hillary Rodham Clinton.
But the chorus's artistic director, Francisco J. Nunez, said few guest listeners had inspired the choristers as much as the mezzo-soprano Denyce Graves, who heard an informal performance by the Concert Choir, the 40 members in the senior division (aged 14 to 18), on Wednesday night in the low-ceilinged, concrete-walled recital room at Maximiliaan's House of Grand pianos on Lexington Avenue. 
 The performance space was bare, but the excitement over Ms. Graves's visit was palpable. The radiant Metropolitan Opera star "really connected with our singers," 32-year-old Mr. Nunez said. Many of them are afraid of the musical world, which can seem rarefied and out of reach, he said. But Ms. Graves, who grew up poor in a tough neighborhood in southwest Washington, is clearly a role model to the young choristers, many of whom also come from disadvantaged backgrounds.
Ms. Graves knows the value of choral groups. During her childhood, it was singing in her Baptist church choir that got her excited about music. On Wednesday night, as the Young People's Chorus sang selections, including a Czech folk song, a selection from Bernstein's Mass and a gospel-inflected piece, "Heaven Bound Train," by the Canadian composer Stephen Hatfield, Ms. Graves sat front-row center, listening intently, swaying to the music and clearly moved.
When Mr. Nunez turned to her for comments, she said little. "I just wanted to be here and see the gifts you have to offer," she said. "You are clearly an exceptional group of singers. Everybody was jazzed and really excited. I really have little to say except, sing some more."
The next selection, however, did provoke some detailed coaching from Ms. Graves. Adrienne Nyamsi, a 16-year-old chorister, sang a solo, the wistful signature song of Billie Holiday, "God Bless the Child," with Mr. Nunez at the piano.
Ms. Nyamsi's performance was lovely but tentative, and Ms. Graves clearly identified with the shy, polite adolescent. "Your voice is gorgeous," Ms. Graves told her. "But I know it can be better. Now what does the song mean to you? Those first lines: 'Them that's got shall get, them that's not will lose.' What does it say to you?"
"Well," Ms. Nyamsi answered, "it seems to be saying that the rich get richer, the poor get poorer, and the Bible tells us it has always been this way and always will be." So, she added, "God bless the child that's got his own." Then she looked expectantly at Ms. Graves.
"There is no right or wrong answer," Ms. Graves said. "There is only what you believe. But look how much more animated your body became when you explained the song to me in words. You must have a reason to make this music happen." Then, she said, to much laughter, "Do you understand where I'm going, or do I just sound like a crazy lady?" When Ms. Nyamsi tried the song again, her singing was noticeably more open and personal.
Mr. Nunez founded the chorus in 1990 under the auspices of the Children's Aid Society of New York. But he wanted the group to reach the outer boroughs, and to "shoot more toward high standards of artistry," he said, "and the kids agreed." So the ensemble became independent. It is now in residence at the 92d Street Y, which provides rehearsal and office space. Its annual budget is over $200,000, and fund-raising is a constant concern.
The chorus performs some 40 concerts a year. Scheduled events include an appearance on April 30 at St. Bartholomew's Church and a "Voices of the World" concert on May 20 at the 92d Street Y.
On Wednesday, after some more music-making, the choristers chatted with Ms. Graves about her own life over cookies and punch. Ms. Nyamsi summed up the mood of everyone when she said: "This whole thing, this whole thing. Wow!"

HEADLINE: How the Antitrust Wars Wax and Wane

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Is the price of airline seats a product of the free market or the result of underhanded business tactics?
This week, when the Clinton Administration accused the major airlines of acting like predators and squeezing their smaller competitors out of business, it entered a century-old intellectual debate on antitrust law and the free market. How these ideas play out could end up influencing how much Americans pay for everything from airline tickets to computer software, from beer to cellophane tape. 
 On one side is the so-called Chicago school, scholars like Robert Bork and Richard Posner who argue that predatory pricing rarely if ever exists and that in the long run, the market will adjust and let in competition. On the other is a group of young lawyers and economists referred to -- not surprisingly -- as the post-Chicago school, who have challenged their predecessors and are providing the intellectual muscle for the Clinton Administration's antitrust assault.
Using game theory and other new approaches to economic analysis, they argue that successful predatory pricing strategies are not as rare and irrational as the Chicago school thought, especially when they are combined with a variety of exclusive deals and other tactics that don't involve price.
Ever since the Sherman Antitrust Act was passed in 1890, rigorous enforcement has ebbed and flowed, an indication of both the ill-defined nature of antitrust law and the ambivalent feelings judges, politicians and the public have had toward big business over the years.
But few Americans would question the existence of predatory pricing. The image of the rapacious monopolist who ruined his competitors or weakened and then swallowed them by using his deep pockets to cut prices below cost has been deeply ingrained in the public mind since the Gilded Age.
The man who helped establish the stereotype was John D. Rockefeller. His Standard Oil Company allegedly employed a grab bag of nefarious practices, including predatory pricing, frivolous lawsuits and bribery, to take over more than 100 companies and amass control over 85 percent of the country's oil refining capacity. The company was broken up in 1911 in one of the first high-profile antitrust cases.
But predatory pricing, much like Justice Potter Stewart's famous observation about pornography, is a lot easier to decry than to define. When the Supreme Court held that Standard Oil had indeed violated the Sherman Act, it neglected to say exactly how. Decades later, John S. McGee, an economist at the University of Chicago, went back and carefully reviewed the case. His landmark article in 1958 concluded that there was no evidence that Standard Oil used predatory pricing to gain its monopoly.
The study had enormous impact on what became the Chicago school, which applied neo-classical economic theory to antitrust cases. What the scholars concluded was that predatory pricing was extremely rare because after driving a competitor out of business and then raising prices, the would-be monopolist would simply attract new competitors into the market. These new theories attacked the conventional wisdom that reigned from the 1930's through the 1960's, often referred to as the Harvard school, that predatory pricing was a common and rational practice.
"The courts had terrible views of economics," says Robert H. Bork, the former Solicitor General and Federal Appeals Court judge, who is a leading exponent of the Chicago school. "It was folk economics. They sort of took antitrust at face value and never took into account the doctrines that were in play, many of which were wrong."
Mr. Bork's 1978 book, "The Antitrust Paradox: A Policy at War With Itself," is considered one of the most eloquent expressions of the Chicago school approach. In it, he wrote, "Unsophisticated theories of predation abound, leading to drastic overestimations of its likelihood."
Since the goal of antitrust law is to protect consumers against unfairly high prices, the courts have long held that anyone claiming to be the victim of predatory pricing must not only prove that the alleged predator is charging prices below cost, he must also prove that the predator can make back the money lost as well as additional profits.
 
The Chicago School Wins One Round
In the view of the Chicago school, this rarely if ever happens. Instead of protecting competition, the Chicago scholars concluded, the courts were depriving consumers of the benefits of lower prices.
"The confusion between a price cut and a predatory cut led to a lot of bad results," Mr. Bork said.
The Supreme Court has agreed. In a 1993 decision successfully argued by Mr. Bork, the court confirmed that a jury was mistaken when it found the cigarette maker Brown & Williamson guilty of predatory pricing and awarded rival Liggett $148.8 million in damages. Even if Brown & Williamson sold below cost, the court held, Liggett couldn't prove that Brown & Williamson would have been able to recoup on that investment.
The Bush and Reagan Administrations were also influenced by the Chicago school and rarely invoked the antitrust laws.
In the most recent swing of the pendulum, the Clinton Administration has stepped up antitrust enforcement. Post-Chicago thinking forms the intellectual foundation behind its decisions to block several mergers as well as some of its most controversial investigations, including that of the Microsoft Corporation. Many of the shapers of post-Chicago thought have held or currently hold key positions at both the Justice Department's antitrust division and the Federal Trade Commission, which share Federal antitrust enforcement. Others, such as Joel I. Klein, the head of the antitrust division, have heartily embraced post-Chicago thinking.
"We regard a predatory strategy as a real possibility," said Robert Pitofsky, the F.T.C. chairman, who describes himself as a member of the post-Chicago camp.
The post-Chicago approach does not reject the Chicago school in the same way Chicago thinkers like Mr. Bork and Mr. Posner attacked the Harvard school. Indeed, some post-Chicago scholars even cite Mr. Bork for inspiring some of their theories. Like their predecessors, the post-Chicago thinkers are firm believers in market forces, but they say the market doesn't always come to the rescue and therefore government intervention may be needed.
"As the economic models have advanced, we have gotten a better understanding of strategic behavior, and that reopens the question of predation," said Steven Salop, a professor of economics and law at the Georgetown University Law Center who has written several articles credited with advancing post-Chicago thought.
In the case of the airlines, for example, the Clinton Administration has said that the major carriers not only cut their prices when they were challenged by small competitors charging lower prices on certain routes; they also wooed away most of the passengers by flooding the routes with cheap flights leaving at more convenient times. When the smaller competitor gives up, the major airline cuts service and raises prices again.
Mr. Bork and the Chicago school argue that this strategy makes no sense because planes can quickly be redeployed into the market once prices rise. Therefore, the major airline could never recover the money it lost by lowering its prices.
But the post-Chicago school counters that the ability of the major airlines to drive out one or two challengers on a few routes has the added value of scaring off new challengers who would expect to get the same treatment. This demonstration effect makes the likelihood of recouping the major carrier's original investment a lot higher. It was cited in a speech last year by Roger W. Fones, the prosecutor leading the Justice Department's antitrust investigation of the airlines.
"There are things that are rational in a game theory model that look irrational from a straightforward neoclassical view," said Garth Saloner, Magowan professor of economics and strategic management at Stanford University's business school and a leading member of the post-Chicago camp.
The post-Chicago school has also examined the predatory nature of a host of exclusive deals in which dominant companies use their power not simply to cut their prices but to raise the cost of doing business for their smaller rivals. For example, the F.T.C. is investigating charges that spice maker McCormick & Company may have gone too far in its efforts to pay supermarkets to give its products prominent shelf space. The Justice Department is investigating Anheuser-Busch for signing exclusive agreements with beer distributors and paying them extra fees if they don't distribute rival brands.
Another theory involves a company using its dominance of one market to force its way into another. That is what the Justice Department claims Microsoft was doing when it forced computer makers who wanted to buy its Windows operating system to load its Web browsing software also. And it is also related to charges that 3M forces distributors eager to get its popular self-stick notes to also buy its less popular cellophane tape.
 
Post-Chicago Group Foresees a Lag
Whether the post-Chicago theories end up having influence as far-reaching as the Chicago school's will ultimately be decided by the Supreme Court. The record so far has been mixed. The court appeared to subscribe to some post-Chicago theories in a 1992 decision involving the Eastman Kodak Company, but the next year it gave a ringing endorsement of the Chicago approach in the Brown & Williamson case. In addition, at least two of the nine justices, Stephen G. Breyer and Antonin Scalia, are known as strong followers of the Chicago school.
But the post-Chicagoans are optimistic that their time may be coming. "The P word is still a dirty word in some antitrust circles," Mr. Saloner said, speaking of predation. "But there is always a lag between the theory and the legal system."

HEADLINE: Photography Sales Set Records at Four Houses

BYLINE: By MARGARETT LOKE 

 BODY:
Manhattan's annual spring week of major photography auctions has concluded with record sales at every participating house and record prices for work by several artists.
Each of the four houses included seldom-seen, pristine vintage prints from major photographers, and collectors said they were impressed by the unusual offerings and buoyed by the strong economy. 
 Swann Galleries, which is better known for its antiquarian book sales, set a world auction record on Monday for a work by Imogene Cunningham when the photographer's transcendent "Magnolia Blossom" sold for $211,500 (the price includes a 15 percent buyer's premium). Around 1929, the print was bought from the artist for $5, about $236 in today's dollars.
At Phillips's single-owner sale of photographs taken in Paris during the 1920's and 30's, an arresting Constructivist photograph by Lee Miller sold on Monday for $145,500, a record for the artist. Phillips has re-entered the photography market in New York after an absence of about a decade.
On Tuesday at Sotheby's, a rare Edward Weston 1924 print showing the abstract lines of the inside of a circus tent sold for $266,500, also a record for the artist. On Wednesday, Christie's set auction records for a photograph by the painter Thomas Eakins ($178,500) and for Pierre Dubreuil ($134,500) and Laszlo Moholy-Nagy ($123,500). With a final tally of nearly $4.6 million, Christie's also set a world record for a photographic auction. Total sales were at all-time highs for the other auction houses, and the aggregate sales for all four houses totaled about $10.25 million.
With many photographs selling at almost giddily high prices, it would seem that two recent scandals roiling the photography market were firmly out of sight and out of mind. One was the revelation that scores of vintage Man Rays made available to collectors in the early 1980's and 90's were skillfully doctored recent prints. The other was the revelation that the provenance of the hitherto unknown, fabulous "Helene Anderson collection," offered by unidentified consignors and sold at Sotheby's in London last May, had been misrepresented. The collection was assembled around 1930 for a German industrialist, Kurt Kirchbach. There were also doubts that the Swiss consignors had clear title.
This week at Sotheby's in New York, a 1922 Man Ray album given by Lee Miller to her brother Erik and containing 12 photographs of the artist's rayographs was bought by the Howard Greenberg Gallery in SoHo for a private client. The price: $244,500. The priciest print at the Phillips sale was also a Man Ray: his famous "Solarized Nude" sold for $156,500.
For weeks before the Phillips auction, there were suggestions that its Maurice Verneuil collection of unknown vintage photographs might be from a missing part of the Kirchbach collection. Notified about collectors' concerns by Nancy Lieberman, the photography specialist at Phillips, the hitherto anonymous Swiss consignor, Gaspard de Marval, a school administrator in Lausanne, revealed his identity and produced two documents establishing that Mr. Verneuil had been in touch with certain photographers represented in the collection.
What the Phillips sale had going for it, said Manfred Heiting, who owns one of the world's premier photographic collections, is that its pictures were "fresh, new and different," a pleasant change from the images appearing again and again at the big auction houses.
Photographs are also appealing when times are flush, he said.
Mr. Heiting cited Cunningham's "Magnolia Blossom" at Swann's as a "unique object." It is, he explained, one of the top five Cunningham images. It is in perfect condition, on perfect matte-finish paper, and has an exhibition label on the back indicating it is one of the earliest prints of this 1920's image.
Rarity is "the overwhelming factor" driving buyers, said Rick Wester, head of Christie's photographs department. A panoramic view of San Francisco circa 1851, composed of five half-plate daguerreotypes, sold for $134,500. The middle half-plate was tarnished, Mr. Wester said, but it didn't matter. "The panoramas that have survived are very rare."
But not everything sold or sold well. A Brancusi photograph sold below estimate at Swann's and another Brancusi did not sell at Sotheby's.
For Denise B. Bethel, director of Sotheby's photographs department, the biggest disappointment was not seeing "Banalite" sell. This 1930 volume of Surrealist poetry and prose illustrated with photos by Roger Parry is, she said, "extremely rare." For his part, Mr. Wester could not explain why Weston's portrait of Diego Rivera or two images from the late 1920's by Hiromu Kira did not sell.

HEADLINE: Feminists Nurture a More Tolerant Christianity

BYLINE: By MICHAEL NORMAN; Michael Norman teaches journalism at New York University.

 BODY:
Mother Church, indeed.
This year marks three decades since Christian women, hundreds of thousands of laywomen as well as theologians and clerics, brought modern feminism into chapels, basilicas and cathedrals and challenged the men running them to rethink the basics of religious practice: their interpretations of the Bible, their liturgical language and symbols, their reluctance to let women join them in the pulpit. 
 That challenge, now commonly referred to as "feminist theology," has matured into a powerful movement. Its leaders have been widely published, and its most formative ideas have helped reshape the curriculums at most major seminaries.
And the reforms that churchwomen have been advocating for three decades -- among them, gender-neutral language in prayer books, a more androgynous view of God and Jesus, special liturgies that address women's experiences, like childbirth and abortion -- have, depending on the denomination, become a major part of Church practice.
Now feminist theologians are asking themselves what's next, and their answers often seem to have little to do with faith, belief, salvation and sin.
These days, for example, when asked what's new, the movement's leaders and scholars are quick to use the word "globalization," a kind of catchall phrase that refers to the way someone's sex and social identity influence worship.
M. Shawn Copeland, a professor of theology at Marquette University and a contributor to the "Dictionary of Feminist Theologies" (Westminster John Knox, 1996) writes that feminists in religion are now focusing on a woman's "social location," or the "acknowledgment of the effect of gender, race, cultural-ethnic background and social-class status on theological practice."
Ms. Copeland and others argue that black women, Hispanic women, Asian women and others all see religion through the lens of their own discrete experience. They may agree on the basic foundations of the faith -- God's grace or holy baptism, for example -- but those ideas and rituals take on different meanings as they are invoked by different kinds of people.
Delores Williams, the Paul Tillich Professor of Feminist Theology at Union Theological Seminary in New York, calls herself a "womanist" theologian. (The term "womanist" was coined by the writer Alice Walker to describe "black feminism." )
To Ms. Williams, womanist theology is concerned with the place and practice of religion in the lives of African-American women. If religion, as Ms. Williams maintains, should embrace matters of "race, gender and class," then in the African-American community religion must deal with the ubiquitous "issue of violence," and that includes the "violence in the crucifixion of Jesus."
To Christians, the murder of Jesus represents the first step in salvation, God's deliverance from sin and victory over evil, but to Ms. Williams and her ideological kin, it is also a sobering echo of the frequent murder in the streets and abuse of children, particularly in homes distressed by poverty.
"How do you teach these children that a loving father sent his son to be murdered?" she asks. "How do you teach them that this amounts to love? We do not need theories of atonement that focus on the blood and murder of Jesus."
Ms. Williams does not want to excise the crucifixion from religious practice. She simply wants it reinterpreted. "I want to give it a meaning less consistent with and supportive of the violence that is so endemic to our society," she says. What this means in practice is a shift from emphasizing the cross as the symbol of salvation to emphasizing Jesus's life as the vehicle for Christian deliverance.
"The ministry of Jesus is what brought salvation to humankind," she said. "The cross represents only the results of that."
Women, of course, have been confronting the church for centuries, but in America, women's organized opposition to ecclesiastical leadership and practice dates from the 19th century, when social critics like Elizabeth Cady Stanton began to challenge the status quo with the publication of "The Woman's Bible," in 1895, a text attacking the scriptural suggestion that sin and death were introduced into the world by a woman.
The most recent surge in feminist theology grew out of the social upheaval of the 1960's. A radical Roman Catholic theologian named Mary Daly built on Stanton's work with two books, "The Church and the Second Sex," 1968, and "Beyond God the Father," 1973. Daly soon left the church and seemed to retreat from the fray as well, but her ideas and arguments, and those of two other important writers, Rosemary Radford Ruether and Elisabeth Schussler Fiorenza, helped inspire a series of reforms in most major Christian denominations, including Catholicism.
Daly provoked the religious establishment and rallied the feminists in American religion by insisting on a simple subjunctive: "If God is male, then male is God." In other words, gender, as it is represented in religious metaphors, symbols, art and iconography, is critical to a reading of scripture, an understanding of Gospel and the practice of the liturgy. To put it more dramatically, Daly was suggesting that if God is a man, then God is a lie, and the church, the patriarchal church, is philosophically, morally and socially bankrupt.
The effect of all this across the last three decades has reshaped much of the religious landscape in mainstream Protestant religions, and to lesser degrees in the Catholic Church and in liberal synagogues and the worship groups of other religions.
Religious texts, hymnals and prayer books are increasingly gender-neutral or gender-free. More women are in the pulpit than ever before and enrollments at five of the largest divinity schools now approach 22 percent women, according to the Association of Theological Schools. In some denominations, women are moving into leadership posts. The Episcopal Church reports that 20 percent of its bishops, priests and deacons are women. Meanwhile, feminist scriptural scholars say they have uncovered evidence in ancient Gnostic and Coptic texts suggesting that women were, in effect, ordained in the early church, and that the texts include women in the doctrine of the Holy Trinity and suggest an equality between Adam and Eve in the Creation story.
The work of scriptural scholarship continues, as does the effort to make sure the language and structure of the church include women. But now a second generation of feminist theologians have expanded the movement's agenda, in large part by adopting some concerns of liberation theology: economic disparity, the "economic colonialism" of large nations and corporations, and environmental and health concerns, particularly AIDS, birth control and abortion.
"This idea of interpreting the culture in terms of feminist theology is as important as interpreting the Bible," says Letty M. Russell, a professor of theology at the Yale Divinity School. As an example, Ms. Russell cites the biblical example of Ruth's devotion to her mother-in-law, Naomi.
"Reading the story of Ruth and Naomi is quite different in Korea, for instance, where women have problems with mothers-in-law," she says. "To Korean women, therefore, they are not sure it's a liberating text," while "in America a lot of lesbians are interested in Ruth and Naomi because they are so close in terms of their survival."
Thus, feminism and theology have many meanings and many applications. What is more, women in each religion and in each culture have different priorities. Catholic women, for instance, still face the formidable challenge of breaking male hegemony in the priesthood, an issue less important to Methodist women.
In religion, then, feminism has come to be a call for tolerance. "Feminists have helped people become more comfortable with a variety of answers to basic religious questions," said Mary E. Hunt of the Women's Alliance for Theology, Ethics and Ritual in Silver Springs, Md., an organization that works on feminist issues in religion.
"I like to call this getting people involved in the theological chorus," she said.
And yet this concept of "inclusion," as diversity is sometimes called, still does not, for all its inherent democracy, include all points of view, particularly conservative ones. "We still have work to do," says Elizabeth Bounds, associate professor of Christian theology at the Candler School of Theology at Emory University in Atlanta.
Ms. Bounds believes that feminists should engage and think more about "the evangelical and fundamentalist forms of Christianity and their reaffirmation of the more traditional roles of women." She argues that feminist theologians cannot afford to "write off" as fundamentalist backlash those women who talk about "family values."
With so many cultural concerns and social agendas in play, it would seem that feminist theology is less concerned with theology than with feminism, more political than spiritual. But almost everyone, especially the movement's founders, insist that is not the case.
"Feminist theology as theology speaks from within a religious community but not just about a religious community," said Ms. Schussler Fiorenza, the Krister Stendahl Professor of Scripture and Interpretation at Harvard Divinity School and one of most respected voices in the field.
"For me," she says, "it would not be such a sharp distinction between social concerns and religious concerns. If you understand religion as more part and parcel of social life, then the cultural and social issues that feminists raise are always religious issues. Elizabeth Cady Stanton argued that religion, like education and the law, is an area of society, and you either reform all areas of society or you will not be able to reform any of them."
