LENGTH: 2167 words

HEADLINE: Washington's Stake in the Arts

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRENSON; Michael Brenson, a freelance art critic and curator, is preparing a study of the visual-artists' fellowships awarded by the National Endowment for the Arts.

 BODY:
THE National Endowment for the Arts has been described as embattled for so long that it now probably assumes this word is part of its name. Since 1989, when it financed exhibitions that included the infamous photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe and Andres Serrano defying conventional religious beliefs and sexual behavior, this agency has been hammered by politicians and pundits eager for a soapbox from which they can bemoan declining national values and inappropriate uses of Government money.
The N.E.A. has been relentlessly attacked by conservative critics who believe that financing a broad spectrum of American artistic activities, including crafts and art made within communities that do not feel welcome in art museums, is emblematic of the erosion of quality and ambition in an increasingly multicultural, relativistic America. If only the N.E.A. would disappear, many opponents believe, the free-market system would do its thing, the cream would rise to the top, and art would once again look like the paintings of Richard Diebenkorn and Claude Monet. 
 As Bill Ivey, nominated by the White House to be the next chairman of the N.E.A., awaits confirmation hearings, what the endowment has been and can be are once again urgent issues.
If the N.E.A. disappears, the pressure on the art world to see itself as part of a larger American picture will be sharply diminished, and the entire fabric of American art will be weakened.
The endowment is the only agency in the United States whose mandate is to build and maintain an arts infrastructure and to secure the place of the artist in society -- a society that before the agency was founded in 1965 was reluctant even to acknowledge that artists were real Americans. It is the only agency that has been concerned with the totality of American art, including difficult and experimental work that challenges mainstream thinking. In an American art world still largely identified with big institutions that can effortlessly slide into insularity and rampant self-interest, the endowment is the only agency whose existence argues for the importance of art to the creativity and dynamism of the nation.
Anyone who believes the endowment can be excised from the art world without seriously damaging American art should consider the repercussions of the radical changes within the agency in January 1996. After the Christian Right campaigned against the endowment and members of Congress promised to vote it out of existence, appropriations were cut from $162 million in 1995 to $99 million in 1996. Laying off roughly 45 percent of the staff meant that the endowment could no longer deal with the number of applications it had been receiving each year in disciplines like painting, sculpture, media arts and photography.
Individual artists' grants, which had been the source of much of the punitive wrath that threatened the agency's existence, were eliminated. The endowment now awards grants in only four general categories: heritage and preservation, creation and presentation, education and access, planning and stabilization.
THIS restructuring has had far-reaching ramifications. Once the endowment stopped giving grants to individuals, many small and large arts institutions stopped exhibiting any living artists who might make someone, somewhere, angry, and who were not widely acclaimed and collected.
After the endowment was publicly excoriated for having the temerity to award some of its money to art that addressed changing views of gender and race, many institutions lost the will to show any art that was rambunctious or edgy. When the agency was deprived of its ability to accumulate comprehensive information about entire disciplines -- for example, 5,000 applications in painting alone were received each year -- arts professionals became less willing to take responsibility for art as a field. The will to think big, to ask uncomfortable questions and to test informed and strongly held convictions is now largely absent.
The mission of the endowment was conveyed through the medium of public financing of the arts, with which the endowment remains largely synonymous. To what and whom it awarded grants, and the political reception of these grants, inevitably influenced how state agencies used their money and how these agencies were treated by local politicians. (As of January, 40 percent of the endowment's funds go to the states in block grants, as opposed to 20 percent between 1975 and 1990.)
Not only does the endowment now have much less money to give, but the very idea of public financing of the arts is now tainted by the microscopic scrutiny by Congress and the news media and by the specter of right-wing intimidation. When arts professionals who came of age after 1989 think of public support for the arts, they do not think of the endowment's 1965 mandate to "help create and sustain not only a climate encouraging freedom of thought, imagination and inquiry, but also the material conditions facilitating the release of this creative talent." For an entire generation, private sponsorship is the only option.
Private support cannot meet this mandate. The difference between private and public support was succinctly defined in a 1995 report to the President's Committee on the Arts and the Humanities by Alberta Arthurs, then director of the arts and humanities division of the Rockefeller Foundation. "Private foundations, corporate and family foundations," she wrote, "do their funding by guidelines and goals which are special to their interests and institutional purposes; they fund to advance their corporate ideas."
In contrast, Ms. Arthurs continued, the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities (a more scholarly, academically oriented agency, also founded in 1965) "must support the whole, the diversity and debate of sectors, of ideas and talents, across the democracy. . . . They reach across disciplines; they mobilize and leverage other resources."
In "The Illusion of Private Giving," in The Washington Post last summer, Robert Storr, a widely respected curator of contemporary art at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, expressed his alarm at the current imbalance. "My work," he wrote, "has taught me to have no illusions about how inadequate private giving -- however generous and at whatever level -- is to the great demands confronting cultural institutions." After writing about the ferocious competition for funds in art museums and the increasing difficulty small and midsize institutions have raising private money, he concluded: "There are no substitutes for Government's contribution to cultural affairs . . . . The coalition of support that has helped the arts to thrive in America is dangerously out of kilter."
It is important to keep in mind that there is no model for private support in the United States that indicates that it, by itself, could meet the demands of this or any future artistic moment. Before the 1960's, when private patrons felt little or no pressure to consider the impact on art of public money, art was a significant but peripheral activity in the United States, and American art was almost entirely unknown abroad. The market system ignored exceptional artists earlier in the century, including many African- Americans, and it still gives little support to many exceptional artists, particularly those who prefer to work outside galleries and museums.
Furthermore, private support is unreliable. Corporate giving, which has been so crucial to the development of art institutions and blockbuster exhibitions, decreased between 1984 and 1994; its willingness to support difficult contemporary art can never be counted on.
To get a sense of the dangers of the current imbalance between public and private support, look at what has happened since January 1996. Arts organizations and museums have turned more to private foundations, many of which have been awarding large sums to programs that encourage arts institutions to engage audiences outside the familiar constituencies of these institutions. At the same time, museums have come to rely on corporations more than ever. Indeed, most big museums are so eager to attract and keep wealthy corporate board members that they are reluctant to do anything that might challenge corporate values and interests. So even as museums are becoming, in theory, more democratic, they are looking and acting more corporate.
What is now largely missing from the contemporary art programming of the Modern, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and the Whitney Museum of American art -- not to speak of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which collects contemporary art but wants no part of the engagement with contemporary life that is proof of a genuine commitment to it -- is respect for the courage and imagination of living artists and an awareness of the needs of the field, two defining aspects of the endowment's mission.
The widespread institutional fear of artists and of conflict, combined with the wish to please all present and future members and donors, helps explain why so many museums have come to seem like satellites of the entertainment industry, in which success is measured by popular appeal.
CLEARLY, private support, however visionary, cannot persuade museums to fight for ways of thinking that challenge their immediate social and economic interests, and it cannot persuade arts professionals to consider the art world as an ecosystem in which every part is connected.
Public support for the arts is also limited. While the new endowment structure is responsive to art that fell through the cracks before, like projects designed to develop art programs in schools, hospitals or community centers, the new categories only reward art that promises to realize some kind of quantifiable social or institutional good, thereby keeping the agency out of trouble. They do not allow it to support artists who want to explore technology, or their own psyches, or the relationship between the earth and the stars.
Just as important, the endowment cannot liberate itself from self-censorship. In 1990, Congress voted to allow the National Council for the Arts, the endowment's advisory committee -- whose members are political appointees -- for the first time to reject grants recommended by peer panels composed of experts. Last December, Congress voted to include six of its own members on the council; there were none before. Self-censorship now infects the peer-panel selection process and indeed the entire endowment system. It also infects the thinking of small and large arts organizations across the country. For the health of American art, this weight must be lifted.
No solution is possible without reinventing the very American partnership of private and public support for the arts that has been a model other countries have envied. It was indispensable to the flowering of American art in the 1960's and to the emergence of that art as a force on the international scene, communicating to the rest of the world that American culture had arrived. This model must not be dismantled.
THE endowment can continue to attend to infrastructure. It can convene panels in which arts professionals from many disciplines and corners of the country work together. With more money, it can be far more imaginative in the ways it approaches its broad and democratic mission. It must trust artists again, perhaps by commissioning individual and also teams of artists -- including controversial ones -- to tour the country and speak with audiences, town-meeting style, about their ideas of artists and art.
The endowment can work to bring together rich patrons, whose tastes and interests are so instrumental in defining private support, with arts professionals from other social classes who may have very different ideas about what art is and who it is for. All these interactions should be considered research and published. In these and so many other ways, the endowment could help define as well as support the manifold meanings and possibilities of art in this country.
The private sector could establish and endow a private agency that gives grants to individual artists, as well as to the kinds of adventurous and experimental projects the endowment is now so reluctant to support. This agency doesn't have to be on the East Coast; it could be based in Chicago, perhaps, or in Los Angeles or Houston. It could give grants in both individual disciplines and interdisciplinary categories. Like the endowment's system, the awards could be made by peer panels of 8 to 12 arts professionals from across the country, or it could invent another selection system. These public and private agencies would always be aware of what each is doing and join forces at crucial moments -- at international exhibitions, for example, when American artists need to feel that their country is behind them.
Now is the time for the private sector to act.

PUB-DATE: April 12, 1998

SECTION: Section 11; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1381 words

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Updating the Residential Space at a Y.W.C.A.

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
IN Lillian Beckford's youth the residences that the Young Women's Christian Association ran in urban centers mainly provided temporary housing to young women living in unfamiliar surroundings after a relocation from out of town.
In time, they would move out, preferring more conventional housing to the Y's dormitory-like rooms, which had no individual cooking facilities or bathrooms. The residents used shared bathrooms and group kitchens down the hall. 
 Now 71, retired and living in a brownstone next to the Y.W.C.A of Brooklyn near Atlantic Center on the edge of Boerum Hill, Mrs. Beckford is hoping that the Y will resume that role once a major renovation, currently under way, is completed. One by one, the five residential floors at the top of the 11-story building are being renovated and the kitchens and bathrooms rebuilt, without any change in room sizes.
"If it's upgraded and more attractive, then women coming into the city would live there," said Mrs. Beckford, who has been active in the Y over the years, and retired from its Board of Trustees two years ago.
The work now under way is an unusual example of a moderate rehabilitation at an old single-room-occupancy Brooklyn building -- with small or even tiny rooms with neither kitchens nor baths -- done with private as well as public financing.
In recent years public financing has been almost the exclusive source of funds for modernizing single-room-occupancy buildings outside prime locations. When the financing doesn't come from the city's S.R.O. loan program, it comes from grants from the New York State Office for Mental Health or from the Federal tax-credit program, which allows the state to finance a limited number of low-income projects with tax-exempt bonds.
But the Y took a different course. First it tried for tax-exempt bond financing, but other projects were deemed to have a stronger claim on this limited resource. On the advice of its real estate consultant, Ronald Moelis, a principal in L. & M. Equities of Larchmont, N.Y., it sought participation financing through the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
In a participation loan, a private lender contributes part of the loan and New York City contributes the rest at a low interest rate. In the Y financing, the loan commitment is $4.4 million -- $1.3 million from Chase Bank and the rest, at 1 percent interest, from New York City. Chase Bank has become the largest private user of the participation loan program on behalf of nonprofit development organizations.
The Y is renovating 210 rooms, modernizing the kitchens and common bathrooms and improving all the basic building features. About 150 tenants are living through the process, moving to another floor while the floor-by-floor work proceeds. Their rent in upgraded rooms will rise gradually to the level that outsiders are to be charged, which will average $95 a week. The three sluggish elevators serving the residential floors will be overhauled.
"Basically, nothing had been done to the residential portion of the building since it was built in 1928," said Donna Ceravolo, executive director of the Brooklyn Y. "In 1989 the fitness floor was gutted and rebuilt, but other than that only the most basic maintenance has been done."
TYPICAL rooms are 8 by 10 feet with a sink and a closet, a pull chain for a single overhead light and one electric outlet. Renovation will bring new windows, new sinks with vanities, electrical outlets and optional air-conditioning. The existing common kitchens will be overhauled, but their dimensions will be unchanged. The architect is Leslie Feder of Manhattan.
For many tenants, Y living has become a comfortable longterm way of life. Some expected to be short-termers when they move in, but then stayed on amid what came to be their "family."
One example is Cora Holliday, a retired schoolteacher who has lived at the Y for more than 25 years. She came to New York in the 50's from Memphis and worked as a dietitian in a nurses' residence on Welfare Island, where she also lived. Later she took a teaching job, and found the Y as a residence through a New York City booklet on places for single women to live.
She retired in 1993 after teaching for 15 years at Junior High School 136 in Sunset Park, but she stays on at the Y. "You're never lonely here, and it's safe," she said. "And if you're sick, you have friends to take care of you. We're like one big family."
Sonia Grobman, 55, who works as a receptionist, moved into the Y two years ago when she was getting ready for a divorce, and stayed on. "I made a few friends, and I feel safer here than I did in an apartment, and I use the gym downstairs," she said. The building has a health club and swimming pool on the fourth floor.
Although tenants will have the benefit of an on-site housing manager, Yvette Williams, and her small staff, they will not have available the high level of social services that are budgeted within the government-subsidized S.R.O. renovations geared largely for a dependent population.
Loans under the city's S.R.O. loan program have produced about 5,000 units of upgraded housing for singles citywide. The program is financed at about $30 million a year.
Current or one-time Y's frequently have the type of residential space that can use these loans. And often it is the only type of financing available to them for building and housing improvements they direly need.
In Brooklyn, one Y.M.C.A. currently benefiting from an S.R.O. loan is on Ninth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues in Park Slope, known as the Prospect Park Y. It has a $6.1 million loan for the rehabilitation of its four residential floors, where the 236 rooms are being rebuilt as 138 rooms for men and women. Every four rooms will share a bath, and some of the rooms will have kitchenettes. Each floor will have two large "lounge kitchenettes" for the tenants without kitchenettes. There will also be a rooftop dining hall serving cafeteria-style meals at a modest cost.
"The tenants will have an extra that many S.R.O.'s can't provide -- the use of a gym, pool and Nautilus room in the Y," said Adrian Tenhor, housing director at Lutheran Social Services, which is in charge of the rental program and will provide social services to tenants. The Y will continue to run its physical education and aquatic programs on the first two floors.
Monthly rents will range from $472 to $525, but the project received a $7 million Federal award under the Section 8 program. Low-income tenants will therefore have to pay only 30 percent of their income as rent, rather than the full "economic" rent. But about two-thirds of the tenants are expected to be able to afford the economic rent.
Lutheran Social Services will also operate Muhlenberg House, a renovation of the former Nevins Hotel at 510 Atlantic Avenue, currently in construction with a $9 million S.R.O. loan and $6 million in equity raised under the tax-credit program. The rehabilitation will produce 201 rooms in what was a seriously rundown 415-room hotel. Muhlenberg House will also have lounges and outdoor patios.
A THIRD current project in Brooklyn has been done with an $8 million grant from the New York State Office of Mental Health, and a supplemental $400,000 Federal grant, providing 150 rooms for a partially dependent population at what was long ago the Boerum Hill Y.W.C.A., at 50 Nevins Street. The Institute for Community Living, a Manhattan-based nonprofit operator, will run it as Stepping Stones, providing longterm housing for formerly homeless people with psychiatric problems.
In contrast to these three projects, the Y.W.C.A. of Brooklyn intends to look to the private market, rather than the city's pipeline of dependent or homeless households, for its new tenants. Most of these new tenants are nevertheless likely to be similar in income to those in the subsidized projects who are employed.
"We will advertise in the local papers and do special marketing to local colleges," Ms. Ceravolo said. "I think we will get a new crop of young women, but we'll continue to serve more mature women who are moving to New York."
The rules do not permit the women to have male visitors, however. "If we catch them, we get grumpy about it," Ms. Ceravolo said.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Confronting Social and Political Issues

BYLINE: By Helen A. Harrison 

 BODY:

Nils Norman/Christopher Whittey
Amelie A. Wallace Gallery, State University of New York College, Route 107, Old Westbury. Through April 30. 876-3056. 
 With this two-person installation, the recently reopened Wallace Gallery is continuing its tradition of presenting art that confronts social, economic and political issues.
Mr. Norman's drawings and scale models are proposals for grass-roots approaches to urban redevelopment, while Mr. Whittey's sculpture and graphics contrast utopian idealism with the realities of manual labor.
Neither artist bludgeons the viewer with overt propaganda, but both send messages that aim to counter mainstream notions.
Of the two, Mr. Whittey is the more complex in his examination of the disparity between theory and practice -- or perhaps the subtlety lies in his adaptation of Suprematist art as a vehicle for his critique.
Using Malevich's "White Square on White" as a template, Mr. Whittey ironically subverts the idealist vision of the artist as worker by studding an enlarged version of the painting with 16,000 plaster casts of his own fingers. The figure is not arbitrary; it is the number of digits lost in industrial accidents in the United States each year.
On the gallery walls, one set of diagrams illustrates how reconstructive surgery may restore function to damaged hands, while another reconstructs Malevich's esthetics. A set of ersatz safety warning signs amplifies Mr. Whittey's admonition, couched in manual-labor imagery but aimed equally at the art world, to play it safe.
Mr. Norman's schemes for kiosks and portable stalls are small monuments to community-based agitprop. His solar-powered "Eco/ Civil Disobedience Bookmobile," designed for Tompkins Square Park, would distribute literature on alternative survival strategies, and his LETS newsstand would serve as a clearinghouse for bartered goods and services.
Computer-generated plans and handsomely detailed models give the offbeat projects just the right aura of plausibility.
 
18th Annual Juried Photography Exhibition
Freeport Memorial Library, West Merrick Road and South Ocean Avenue, Freeport. Through April 29. 223-2522.
 Sponsored by the Long Island Arts Council, the show was selected by the noted photographer Harvey Stein. From 346 entries, Mr. Stein chose 45 images, many of exceptional quality.
One only wishes that the hanging space were less cramped, allowing each picture some breathing room. Notwithstanding its physical limitations, the show offers plenty of visual and conceptual scope.
The best-in-show award went to John Michaels for "Birch Velum," a textural montage incorporating, as its title implies, fragments of bark and suggestions of membrane.
More an all-over abstraction than a nature study, the modest black and white print makes imaginative use of photographic techniques to fuse reality and illusion.
In the black and white category, first place was taken by Jennifer McMillan for "Brooklyn Bridge," although not the one you would expect. It is in fact the Manhattan Bridge, which crosses to Brooklyn and, in this incarnation, looks as if it is literally on the move.
Its ominous silhouette seems to pulse with the shock waves of traffic -- vibrations that the camera has arrested, highlighting the mighty structure's disquieting flexibility.
Several other notable images are concerned with ambiguity, including Bill Stengel's "Cherub," a sensuously lighted portrait that looks alternately angelic and seductive, and Karen Dombrovski-Sobel's "Eve's Apple," an honorable mention winner, which has disturbingly anatomical overtones.
Another honorable mention, Kasmira Mohanty's "Metamorphosis," uses a six-print serial format to reveal and conceal an emerging figure.
Among the color entries, "Apples Nouveau," an elegant still life by Jeanne Lentz, manipulates the fruit's tonality to give it the sheen of burnished copper. Maria Moricca-Calvey took an honorable mention for "A Day at the Beach," an example of photography's power to isolate the extraordinary in the commonplace.
 
Dee Shapiro/Harriet Stanton
Great Neck Library, 159 Bayview Avenue, Great Neck. Through April 21. 466-8055.
 Best known as a "pattern painter" whose grid-based images of the 1970's resembled mosaics of high-key colors, Ms. Shapiro has abandoned nonillusionistic formalism for what she describes as "pictorial magic realism." The current selection features work from the last decade, including small oils on board that presaged her recent series of large canvases.
The small paintings, with strong intimations of Kandinsky filtered through Stuart Davis, retain the flat field and unmodeled forms of textbook modernism. This is not a put-down, for Ms. Shapiro handles these devices with authority, unifying a surprising array of disparate elements in each lively composition. Like Davis, she can inject humor into Cubist-inspired formalism, as in "Red Square With Change," alluding to geometry and the Moscow landmark, both of which she has fragmented.
Like Russia's, however, Ms. Shapiro's own change has come at the expense of unity. Her latest paintings introduce perspective, architectural elements and naturalistic motifs interspersed with geometric patterns and quotations of earlier work. "Screened Memories" crams them into a disjointed scrapbook of images. The effect is confusing. Whereas the illogic of the small works is playful and intriguing, here the flight of fancy is grounded by excess symbolic baggage and compositional overload.
Ms. Stanton has undergone an even more extreme shift in direction, from moody Abstract Expressionism to lyrical nature study. Although the show emphasizes landscapes and flower pieces, a few of the earlier canvases are also included, perhaps to illustrate that her artistic energy is undiminished.
The idea, alas, was not a good one. For all their gestural vigor, the abstractions look gloomy and earnest next to Ms. Stanton's light, airy pastels and monotypes. And in comparison to the earlier work's ambitious, even harsh, subjectivity, her recent efforts seem rather timid and safely pretty.

HEADLINE: Assisted Living: An Option On the Edge Of a Boom

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: BRIARCLIFF MANOR

 BODY:
BENJAMIN TYRA may no longer be the brash young fire captain he once was, but his take-charge attitude still serves him well. "I finally decided I needed a place to rest my weary bones," the 84-year-old Mr. Tyra said, reflecting on his recent move "away from the hustle and bustle and strains of the big city" to an assisted-living community here in northern Westchester.
In recent years, Mr. Tyra's dignity -- along with his stamina and health -- have suffered more than a few blows as even everyday tasks like hauling laundry to the basement of his Yonkers apartment or carting groceries from the supermarket tired him. Now the lanky octogenarian and his wife, Anna, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease, relax by a marble fireplace, eat with peers in a full-service dining room and toss their clothing at the end of the day into a hamper to be washed, folded and returned to them the next day. 
 "Life could be better if we won the Lotto," Mr. Tyra said. "But next to that, this is pretty good."
As residents of Senior Quarters at Briarcliff Manor, the Tyras have tapped into the surging assisted-living housing market, which is finally arriving in Westchester. In many ways, the rush to capitalize on the county's graying population has turned into a free-for-all, as developers hustle to meet the needs of the frail elderly, a rapidly growing group, which is demanding more options than nursing homes.
"Until now, consumers have had few choices, but that's all changing," said Mel Gamzon, president of Senior Housing Investment Advisors, a national investment consulting concern based in Newton, Mass. "Not only is the assisted-living market big today, it's going to boom tomorrow."
But many developers have seen the New York market as daunting, which is why they have been busy building such housing in the rest of the United States but have only lately come to Westchester. The state has complex regulations governing housing for the elderly. Land prices in the county are steep, and many communities have no zoning for assisted-living units.
"Those were critical impediments, and as a result, the development community in Westchester is just waking up to the potential," Mr. Gamzon said. "Now there are a whole slew of assisted-living operators perusing options."
Despite the drawbacks, many developers are forging ahead. In this upscale Westchester community, for example, Kapson Senior Quarters, one of the largest owner-operators of assisted-living quarters in the state, has completed a 102-unit complex, Senior Quarters at Briarcliff Manor, with 16 units for people like Mrs. Tyra, who as victims of Alzheimer's disease need extended care.
"The zoning is tricky and the area expensive, but it's still worth it," said Evan Kaplan, president and chief operations officer for Kapson, based in Woodbury on Long Island, which has developed housing in many East Coast areas. Glenn Kaplan, Kapson's chief executive officer, said the company aims its marketing at the middle-aged children of its potential customers. Mr. and Mrs. Tyra's son helped them find their new home in Briarcliff, near where two other grown children and young grandchildren live.
Offspring often want their parents close by in a living arrangement that offers meals, housekeeping services, social activities, transportation and built-in health care, the chief executive officer said.
Sometimes a reverse migration takes place a decade or more after older couples retire to the South. In time, as they age and one or the other dies, the remaining spouse, often frail, is left alone. "At 85 years old, you're probably not playing too much golf or too much tennis, and your physical activities are limited, so therefore you might as well be home closer to the kids and closer to the family," Glenn Kaplan said. "Instead of traveling back and forth to care for the parent, the adult children decide to bring mom or dad back to a retirement community close by."
In Ossining, the publicly held Care Matrix Corporation of Needham, Mass., is completing the 122-unit Cambridge House-on-the-Hudson, Michael Zaccaro, executive vice president of operations, said. Sharing a model that many builders of elderly housing in New York have adopted, Care Matrix builds the rental units and offers a package of services -- like laundry and meals -- for its customers. But health care is offered separately by outside providers (in this case Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in Tarrytown and the Dominican Sisters Family Health Service in Ossining), thus circumventing the labyrinth of confusing state regulations governing private developers of assisted-living quarters.
Care Matrix is also planning 168 assisted- living units in Rye Brook.
"The cost of land kept most of the larger players out of this marketplace, but we couldn't continue to ignore the demographics here," Mr. Zaccaro said. "Westchester is one of the most affluent, underserved markets in the United States."
The county's Planning Department reported that nearly 20 percent of Westchester's population is 60 or older. In 1990, there were 170,971 people 60 or older, an increase of 8 percent since 1980. The oldest residents, those 85 and older, continue to have the highest rate of growth -- "increasing the need for services and care for the most vulnerable members of our elderly population," a 1994 study by the county's Office for the Aging said. According to the 1990 United States Census, the 85 and older population numbered 14,200 in Westchester, up 36 percent since 1980.
Dr. Audrey S. Weiner, a senior vice president and the administrator at the nonprofit Sarah Neuman Nursing Home in Mamaroneck, said that by age 85, "many seniors are starting to lose their peer groups and their siblings and suffer from isolation." The nursing home, in conjunction with Westchester Jewish Community Services and the Jewish Home and Hospital, has formed Westchester Seniors Housing to expand services at Sarah Neuman, which is responding to the changing market and will include assisted living, adult day care and subacute care for rehabilitation after hospital stays, Dr. Weiner, a social worker, said. Two solariums and a pavilion have already been built in anticipation of accommodating assisted-living residents.
Another existing community for the elderly, the Osborn in Rye, is also planning to expand to meet the growing demand and offer what Mark R. Zwerger, chief executive officer, called "a continuum of care as people age" -- from independent living to assisted living and full nursing care. The 56-acre campus is undergoing a $100 million expansion, adding a four-story, 54-unit apartment building, 13 two-family houses and an 84-bed nursing home.
In White Plains, Marriott Senior Living Services, a division of Marriott International, the hotel giant, and New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center are planning to build 180 rental units for seniors on the hospital's campus-like setting. The Marriott, based in Bethesda, Md., will provide housekeeping services, and the hospital will provide medical care and diagnostic services.
Connie Hildesley, a spokeswoman for the hospital, said the plan affords a less costly alternative to nursing home care, offers residents help with daily living and avoids the regimentation of medical settings. "The trend is to deinstitutionalize," she said.
Another hotel chain, Classic Residence by Hyatt, based in Chicago, had planned to convert the former Kraft building in White Plains to a community for the elderly but dropped its plans. Philip Anderson, a senior vice president for the company, said another project in New Rochelle has also not moved forward. Mr. Anderson would not say why those projects were canceled.
"We're being patient," he said. "Land's in short supply in Westchester, but we see it as potentially a very solid market." Classic Residence is developing a 300-unit assisted- living residence for the elderly in Yonkers near the Riverdale border.
Also in White Plains, a bankrupt hotel has been converted to an assisted-living residence called the Esplanade, which offers a package of services, including kosher meals.
But all of these assisted-living options come at a price. About the least expensive quarters for one person are $2,200 a month, and the most expensive are $4,000 or more a month -- for room, meals and services. If extended medical care is needed, that increases the monthly fee by about $500. The developers generally concede that assisted-living units are aimed at the middle and upper-middle class.
At the Osborn, where some units go for $4,000 a month, paying an entrance fee can reduce the monthly rate. Mr. Zwerger said the Osborn tapped various markets -- "some upscale."
Mae Carpenter, director of the county's Office for the Aging, said: "That's one of the concerns we have. There's very little interest in housing for the moderate-income senior, but considering land and construction costs, that could be a problem."
Ms. Carpenter said many elderly residents, for economic and other reasons, still prefer to remain in their homes or move in with their children. Many receive care in their homes, and the adult day-care industry is also growing to meet their needs.
For all the elderly at all economic levels, Ms. Carpenter said, a nursing home is "a last resort."
As Mildred Bohrer, a 90-year-old resident of Senior Quarters here, explained: "When you've outlived most of your doctors, you know that you're getting on. My children worried about my living alone, but that didn't mean I wasn't functional anymore and belonged in a nursing home. It shouldn't have to be an either-or proposition."

HEADLINE: Creative Women at Work in a Century Past

BYLINE: By ALBERTA EISEMAN 

 BODY:
A GALLERY of women greets the visitor to the Connecticut River Museum in Essex these days. The exhibition, "Extraordinary Yankees: Women of the Connecticut River Valley in the Arts and Literature," presents biographies of writers, painters, sculptors, musicians and actors, each with period photographs and samples of the subject's work.
"The show is the culmination of a three-part series on women," said Emily Stearns, the museum's curator, who was instrumental in creating the exhibitions. The first part, mounted in 1994, focused on social and political activists, while the 1996 show was devoted to women in business. "The current exhibit fills in the spectrum with a close look at women who have excelled in creative fields." 
 Ms. Stearns said the series was designed to show how the Connecticut River Valley defines a culture that transcends state boundaries.
"Through the lives of selected women in various fields," she said, "we have tried to demonstrate that a town like Springfield has a greater cultural and economic affinity to Hartford than it has to Boston, which is in the same state."
The earliest works in the exhibition are in a section entitled "The Needle" and they include a magnificently embroidered memorial quilt, crafted by Massachusetts resident Henrietta Lambie to express her grief at the loss of her children.
The section on the written word is the most plentiful and it shows women's creativity going public in the middle of the 19th century.
"Within the last 50 years more books have been written by women and about women than all that had been issued during the preceding five thousand years," wrote Sarah Josepha Hale, editor of Godey's Lady's Book, during the 1850's.
"Not all are big names," Ms. Stearns admonished, as a visitor made a beeline for a photograph of a youthful Harriet Beecher Stowe (1811-1896), writer, feminist, abolitionist and author of the epoch-making novel "Uncle Tom's Cabin." Stowe, a Hartford resident who helped support her large family with her writing, is said to have been greeted by President Lincoln in 1862 with the words: "So, you're the little woman who wrote the book that started this great war!"
The other big name writer in the exhibition is Emily Dickinson (1830-1886) of Amherst, Mass. For her, fame only came after death, in our own century. During her lifetime she was almost a recluse, writing poems inspired by what she could see from her window and by her own intelligence and sensitivity.
One of the first American women to succeed at a literary career was Lydia Sigourney (1797-1865), a poet known as the "Sweet Singer of Hartford." Today, she is best remembered for a street named after her, but in her time publishers competed for her poems, pious verse that often spoke of death and religious devotion. An illustrated copy of her "Poems for the Sea" is on display in a glass-enclosed case, along with a page from the manuscript of "Uncle Tom's Cabin."
A woman with the intriguing name of Wealthy Buckley Tiffany (1820-1890) was known as the poet laureate of Essex. Her verses, written to mark births, deaths and marriages as well public occasions, were printed in the local newspapers and still serve as an important record of the town's social history. The scrapbook in which she kept her work, illustrated with her own decoupage, is on exhibit.
A theme that emerges in several biographies is the conflict between work and family obligations. The musician Amy Marcy Cheney (1867-1944) of New Hampshire was forbidden by her husband, Dr. Henry Harris, from using his last name, and had to shift her emphasis from performing as a pianist to writing music. As Mrs. H. H. A. Beach she became one of the country's leading composers.
Although all well-bred girls were taught to draw, do watercolors and needlework, none was expected to earn her living as an artist during the 18th and the 19th century. A rare exception was Laurilla Smith (1789-1857), one of five Glastonbury sisters, each creative and headstrong for their day. Throughout her life, Smith taught drawing and watercolors, created her own work in a variety of media and kept a sketchbook of pen and ink drawings of her town, one of which is displayed in reproduction.
The forceful face of artist Mary Knollenberg (1904-1991) beckons the visitor, as do photographs of her figures sculptured in stone, marble and clay, and later cast in bronze. Working in her studio in Chester, the artist focused on the female body, working, she said, "over the whole stone so that all parts of the figure can eventually emerge at the same time." The most familiar face in this parade of gifted women is that of the actress Katharine Hepburn, who was born in Hartford in 1907. Hepburn is seen in a refreshingly unglamorous photograph -- bandana over her hair; wet, sandy pants -- as she attempts to repair damage done by a hurricane to her beloved summer home in Fenwick, a section of Old Saybrook.
Concurrent with "Extraordinary Yankees" is a small display of "Extraordinary Miniatures" featuring a recent gift to the museum -- a scale model of a ship captain's home authentic in all details. Exhibited for the first time, the Federal period house with its three chimneys, leaded fanlight and lion-head door knocker was crafted by Robert Lyon, a former Essex resident whose family still lives in town.
As for the main exhibition, Ms. Stearns and the museum's new director, David T. Guernsey Jr. are making plans to take it on the road.
"By this fall, we hope to have all three parts of the series prepared and available to historical societies, high schools and colleges throughout the valley area," said Mr. Guernsey, who recently took the helm of the museum. "We are also thinking of publishing a short book on the biographies of these women, so the information and the themes we have gathered will not be lost."
"Extraordinary Yankees" will remain at the Connecticut River Museum, 67 Main Street, Essex, until May 3. The museum is open Tuesday through Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $4, $2 for children.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Katharine Hepburn looking at storm damage in Fenwick. Far left, a visitor looking at Essex doll house in "Extraordinary Miniatures" at the Connecticut River Museum, exterior shown above. Harriet Beecher Stowe, author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin." The sculptor Mary Knollenberg focused on the female body. (Photographs by Gale Zucker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Airlines Scramble To Add Flights to Japan

 BODY:
Despite the economic softening in Japan, United States airlines have been quick to jockey for permission to fly there more frequently and on new routes since the Jan. 30 signing of an airline agreement between the United States and Japan ending most restrictions on travel between the two countries.
 American, Continental and Delta, which had been restricted to 46 round trips a week, were granted up to 90 additional weekly trips under the accord, and they wasted little time asking the Department of Transportation to approve new routes and new frequencies.
 
 American will begin daily nonstop service between Chicago and Tokyo on May 1. It has also received approval for daily nonstops between Tokyo and New York, Tokyo and Boston, and Dallas-Fort Worth and Osaka. Service on all three of those routes is expected to begin no later than Nov. 1.
 Continental has received approval to fly a total of seven round trips a week between Tokyo and both Newark and Houston, and expects to begin flying from Newark in November and from Houston in December.
 Delta has received approval for daily nonstops between Atlanta and Tokyo, which will start June 3; for daily nonstops between Portland, Ore., and Osaka, which will start Oct. 28, and between Portland and Fukuoka, beginning Oct. 29. It received approval to increase the number of its Los Angeles-Tokyo flights to seven a week from six, and will begin that service by this summer.
Hawaiian Airlines has received approval to fly daily nonstops in the year 2000 between Kahului, Maui and Tokyo, a route not served by a scheduled carrier.
 United, which like Northwest was given automatic authority to fly additional routes or frequencies, will start new daily nonstop flights between Chicago and Osaka in July.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Harlem;
Around 125th Street, New Interest and Optimism

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
IF your mother had a fur coat, the chances are that it spent its summers in Harlem. The brick building at Amsterdam Avenue and 126th Street was a fur-storage center for almost 50 years, with armored trucks carrying the coats from retailers across the city for storage during warm weather months.
Unoccupied for the last decade, the building, built as a brewery in the middle of the last century when the area was home to a large population of German immigrants, is being offered for conversion to loft office space, movie studios, or another use that can take advantage of the high ceilings and sturdy floors of the old factory. 
 The developer, Scott Metzner of the Janus Property Company, is clearly hoping to participate in what he sees as the remarkable resurgence of Harlem, which is being stoked by Federal, state and city financial incentives and by rising rents in other once-industrial parts of the city.
"This neighborhood has the feel of SoHo and TriBeCa before they changed," Mr. Metzner said. "It has an industrial feel and it is low-rise, so there is plenty of light and air."
Mr. Metzner's project comes at a time when the area centered on 125th Street is drawing more commercial attention than any time in recent years. The Fairway supermarket under the Henry Hudson Parkway is crowded on weekday midafternoons and a 60,000-square-foot Pathmark supermarket is being built on the East Side at 125th Street and Lexington Avenue.
Recently, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced plans to redevelop the long abandoned Washburn Wire factory on the west side of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive into a three-block retail complex from 116th Street to 119th Street that will be anchored by Home Depot and Costco stores. State economic development officials said they expected construction to begin early next year.
After years of delays, Drew Greenwald of Grid Properties said he was weeks away from putting a shovel in the ground for Harlem USA, a 290,000-square-foot retail-entertainment complex that is to include a nine-screen, 2,700-seat Cineplex Odeon movie complex, HMV Records, Disney and Gap stores and a Chase bank branch.
Other retail tenants are coming, as well, Mr. Greenwald reports. "They are not ready to announce until we actually break ground, but we are 75 percent leased at this point," he said.
He said national retailers had begun to recognize that Harlem is a densely populated, relatively underserved part of the city. "This has been a neglected portion of the American population," he said. "Retailers are realizing they can sell more products if they are located there, and banks know that there are deposits there and loans to be made."
MR. GREENWALD said he had been involved since 1992 in the Harlem USA project, which will occupy most of the block on the south side of 125th Street between St. Nicholas Avenue and Frederick Douglass Boulevard. He said he anticipated beginning excavation by May 1, with the complex scheduled to open in time for the Christmas 1999 shopping season.
The decisions by Disney and AMC to participate in the Harlem USA project are making subsequent development in the area easier, real estate executives say. Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty Services, which is marketing the old fur-storage building at 1361 Amsterdam Avenue, said the nearby Harlem USA project helped educate corporate decision makers to the potential of the Harlem market.
"Northern Manhattan has a huge population," he said, and commercial rentals "are very favorable compared to other parts of the city." He said there was virtually no retail space available on 125th Street, one of the major east-west arteries of the city.
"The vacancy rate on the ground floor is two to three percent," said Barbara Askins, executive director of the 125th Street Business Improvement District, which provides cleaning and security services and adds amenities to aid businesses on the street. She said the discovery of the area by national retailers such as Rite Aid, Duane Reade and Blockbuster had stimulated interest in the upper floors of buildings on 125th Street, which she said had been vacant or underdeveloped for a long time. However, some existing merchants have complained that the arrival of national chains is driving rents to levels that strictly local businesses cannot sustain.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, compared what is happening on 125th Street to the transformation of 42d Street, which is changing from a sleazy, depressing neighborhood to a glittering office, entertainment and retail area.
"We committed $100 million to the empowerment zone," he said, referring to the state funds that were added to the Federal and state incentives already available to businesses in the zone, which extends from 116th to 132d Street. "We made public money available and we are beginning to see the results," Mr. Gargano said. "The developers appear to watch what we do and then follow us with their own projects."
Mr. Fox estimated that the combined Federal, state and city incentives could be worth as much as $6 a square foot initially, in an area of town where annual rents for industrial properties range in the mid-teens. The incentives include a Federal credit of as much as $3,000 for each employee who is a resident of the empowerment zone, $1,500 from the state per employee and $1,000 from the city for corporations who relocate above 96th Street or to boroughs other than Manhattan.
Among the major developers arriving in the area are Bruce Ratner of Forest City Ratner companies, who is undertaking a entertainment and retail project on 125th Street between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and Malcolm X Boulevards in conjunction with the Abyssinian Development Corporation, an affiliate of the Abyssinian Baptist Church. Mr. Ratner, who built the Metrotech office center in downtown Brooklyn, is a major player on 42d Street with a development on the south side of the street that will include a huge movie complex and Madame Tussaud's wax museum.
ALSO getting involved on 125th Street is Jerry I. Speyer, the president of Tishman-Speyer Properties, who is proposing a 500,000-square-foot retail-entertainment complex that would anchor the eastern end of 125th Street between Second and Third Avenues. Tishman-Speyer partially owns and manages Rockefeller Center and won the bidding to control the Chrysler Building in midtown Manhattan.
Brokers familiar with the area said that now that various government programs have helped restore much of the housing stock in the Harlem area, commercial development is less of a risk than it is in other areas of the city.
"Metrotech was more of a risk than this area because downtown Brooklyn does not have the resident population you have here," said William M. Shanahan, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield. Mr. Shanahan, who is attempting to sell a building at 55 West 125th Street, said the Harlem area was a "Cinderella story" about how to rehabilitate a neglected part of the city with a combination of public and private investment.
In addition to the big names, there is a multiplicity of small names opening business in the Harlem area, people familiar with the neighborhood say.
"The big story in Harlem is that on almost every block small businesses are opening up," said Mr. Greenwald. He said the large number of immigrants coming to the area was adding energy to the commercial sector.
Mr. Metzner, whose building is under consideration for landmark status, said that whoever occupies it would add to the economic health of upper Manhattan by hiring local residents because of the incentives. He said the facade and roof of the structure had been stabilized after years of no maintenance, but that further work would need to be done once a deal has been consummated and the tenant's needs were known.
He said no zoning issues stood in the way of development of the building. "We are as-of-right," he said. "We can build almost anything anyone wants." He said his structure would be called the Mink Building, in a reference to its history as a fur storage vault.
Mr. Fox said the other developments in Harlem were providing a level of comfort for corporate executives who might have been reluctant to base operations in the area in the past, and the low rentals should be a lure. "Corporations are looking at Harlem in economic terms these days, not in racial terms," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Former fur-storage warehouse, left, is now being marketed. (Kevin Woest); At right, Mink Building as it might look after conversion to suit whatever tenants are acquired. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 5; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2779 words

HEADLINE: Vacation Home Sales: Water Adds Heat

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

 BODY:
THE house on Shore Road in the Cape Cod community of Chatham, Mass., wasn't selling at $500,000. Rather than fix it up, the owner tore it down and is building something new. "He feels there's a better market at $1 million for a new house," said Marie Connolly, owner of Connolly Real Estate in Chatham.
Driving by the new-house-in-progress, Ms. Connolly agreed with his assessment. "It needed work," she said. "Somebody who could afford $500,000 would go to another part of town and buy a better house."
It may be shaping up as another record year for vacation-home sales in beach communities in the Northeast, but even in this sellers' market, buyers are looking for the most for their money, Ms. Connolly said. "Buyers are very intelligent and very market savvy," she said. "They're looking at everything."
At many destinations -- particularly near the ocean -- they may not have much to look at. In the third year of strong sales for vacation properties, with a strong economy, a soaring stock market and low interest rates, inventory is diminishing or has vanished completely.
"We are back to the early 80's," Ms. Connolly said.
Not only back, but in many areas -- particularly those with the cachet of old money, trendiness or close proximity to the water -- beyond. Brokers selling in beach communities said that record prices were being paid for waterfront properties and that in many instances sales this year were outpacing record totals for 1997.
"Our sales market has gone through the ceiling," said Timothy G. Davis, a principal with Allan M. Schneider Associates on the East End of Long Island, which had over $200 million in sales in 1997.
For many other companies the story was the same. But the impact of the sales differs from area to area. While prices of luxury properties have soared, houses in the more moderate price ranges are holding steady or increasing at a more reasonable rate, brokers say. Buyers leaning toward a country home or mountain property may even find that prices have not fully recovered from the dip in the early 1990's.
Unless the homes are on water. Whether the body of water is the Atlantic Ocean, an Adirondack lake or the Hudson River, a close proximity to water is going to increase price.
Perhaps nowhere is the strength of the waterside market so dramatic as in the rarefied heights of waterfront homes in the Hamptons. So in demand are oceanfront estates that one owner is asking a breathtaking $19.5 million. For that a buyer can have a 13,600-square-foot contemporary home on Further Lane in East Hampton with 288 feet of Atlantic Ocean frontage included in its 11 acres.
"Is it wishful thinking?" said Frank Newbold, head of the Sotheby's International Realty office in East Hampton. "No it's not. It's got to the point of literally knocking on doors on the ocean and in the estate area. We'll have a customer who says, 'I want to be on this particular street, and price isn't a problem if you find me the right house.' "
Not all buyers, of course, can afford such insouciant attitudes toward price. For many would-be buyers, increases in the market have been intimidating.
"A lot of buyers are coming to me saying the market is too high and a lot of people don't want to buy right now," said Susan Davis, a real estate broker with Pat Schultz Associates in Provincetown, Mass.
But others are willing to take their chances.
Jack Fallon, who recently reached agreement to buy a house in Osterville, Mass., for about twice the price of his home in neighboring Cotuit, is moving into one of Cape Cod's most exclusive areas, where inventory is low and record prices are being paid for prime properties.
Mr. Fallon, who moved to the Cape after retiring from the chairmanship of an electronics business in Boston five years ago, had been looking for two years. He had watched as prices rose and inventory tightened. Still, he said, he wasn't worried about making a mistake in price because he felt he had been well informed about the market.
"We feel in the worst instance prices will stabilize or perhaps decrease, but not like eight or nine years ago," he said.
Paul E. Grover, a broker and partner in Kinlin Grover Properties in Osterville, said that while record prices were being paid for waterfront homes and demand was high in Osterville, it was possible to get more for your money in nearby areas.
IN Centerville, just minutes away from the village of Osterville, a two-bedroom bungalow with 900 square feet just a block from Craigville beach is listed for $135,000. In West Hyannisport on an inlet of Nantucket Sound, a quaint Cape Cod beach house with views of the water is $299,000.
Buyers willing to go north of Route 28, where there are more year-round houses, can do even better since prices there have not completely recovered from the softening of the market earlier this decade.
In New Jersey, brokers in shore communities are also finding prices rising with increased demand. "One of the things I've been saying is, 'How do you spend $180,000 for a $170,000 house? -- just wait 30 days,' " said Jack Waters, regional vice president for Weichert Real Estate for Ocean and Monmouth County. "That's how prices are moving, and that's in all markets, not just our beach markets."
Aside from water, another factor that will boost the price tag is being close to a charming (or trendy) village.
Melanie Ross, president of Cook Pony Farm Real Estate on Long Island, used the example of a village home in East Hampton that was on the market this year at $350,000. The house, which did not have a lot of extras, was expected to sell in the $340,000 range.
"It sold in about two weeks for $15,000 over the asking price," she said, attributing the increase to location and lack of inventory.
While there are still some houses around East Hampton and Southampton for sale under $200,000, those prices are generally closer to what is being paid for land alone.
"There's a lot of building in the potato fields," Ms. Ross said.
Location and lot size are the biggest factors determining the price of new construction, said Bob Immacolato, owner of Twin Pines Realty in Wainscott. For from $300,000 to $500,000, buyers can get a new home north of Montauk Highway in Bridgehampton, Sagaponack and Wainscott, he said. The bulk of the $300,000 homes, which would have three bedrooms, two baths and a pool, would be in Wainscott on a half acre, he said. The same house in Bridgehampton or Sagaponack would be on an acre or more and start at $400,000.
"Land is the fueling factor," Mr. Immacolato said. "Once you cross the highway to the south the same thing works."
He said that a year ago a lot south of the highway on an acre or more would have cost in the low $300,000 range -- in Hamptons real-estate shorthand, "the low threes." "Now you've got to be thinking five and up," he said.
While sales are strong across the board on the East End of Long Island, which includes East Hampton, Southampton, Amagansett, Bridgehampton, Sagaponack, Wainscott and Water Mill, other ocean enclaves are finding that some price ranges are hotter than others.
In Bar Harbor, Me., Kim Bennett-Swan, a broker with the Swan Agency, said the market was strongest in the mid-$200,000's and at the high end. "I just listed a house at $895,000," she said. "There have been more showings on that, probably five times more, than on something at $350,000."
Kathy Burton, a broker with American Real Estate on Martha's Vineyard, said she was seeing the same thing. "The high $300,000's are not moving as swiftly as anything that comes on the market under $200,000 or just over, unless there's an issue with the location," Ms. Burton said. "The rare and unusual waterfront properties are selling immediately."
While she said inventory was the lowest she had seen in the last five years, there are still a variety of properties available. "You can actually get something for $150,000, but not a heck of a lot," she said.
Among her listings are a two-bedroom condominium near Oak Bluffs at $113,000 with access to tennis, clubhouse and fresh-water pond. At $169,000 there's a Vineyard cottage near Lagoon Pond outside Oak Bluffs. In the $200,000's there's new home with four bedrooms and two baths a short drive from South Beach and Edgartown Village. The mid-range is a mix of new construction, older farm houses and traditional Capes.
At $1.75 million there's a recently renovated 1929 Georgian-style house with attached guest wing. The secluded property in Edgartown has views of Nantucket Sound and is "a minute away" from the harbor and shops. At $3.5 million there's a seven-bedroom house on the water with views of Katama Bay, a three-bedroom guesthouse, a boat house and deep water pier.
Ms. Burton said that there was a lot of speculative building on the Vineyard, and "much of what you'd see is things of that variety."
ON neighboring Nantucket, inventory is extraordinarily low, with only about 300 homes for sale out of a housing stock of 8,400, said Penny Dey, a vice president and broker with Congdon & Coleman Real Estate. Although there is something available in every price range, prices are up, she said, noting that the average sale so far this year was $571,000, compared with $475,000 last year and $230,000 in 1992. To some extent those numbers are skewed, she said, by the high number of sales over $1 million.
"What's driving this market is waterfront -- stable, non-eroding waterfront," Ms. Dey said, adding that a record $7.85 million was paid last year for a turn-of-the-century waterfront home on just over an acre. "Basically we've got this chasm between average sales and extraordinarily expensive sales," she said.
The number of sales over $1 million never exceeded 20 in a year until 1996, she said, when 29 properties were sold above that price, representing 24 percent of the dollar amount in sales that year. In 1997, 52 properties were sold for over $1 million.
A small two-bedroom cottage in Nantucket town on a small lot would have sold for $120,000 in 1990, Ms. Dey said; the same house today would go for about $189,000.
However, she said, the biggest change in the market -- a trend reported in several areas -- is that people are increasingly buying property just for the land and removing or demolishing the house. That was just done recently, she said, with a 12-year-old house overlooking Nantucket's inner harbor that sold for $1.6 million.
The market is a bit more settled in Chatham, a quaint village in the elbow of Cape Cod. Ms. Connolly described inventory as "healthy," with prices starting at $94,000 for a two-bedroom saltbox with access to Oyster Pond, and going up to $1.65 million for a stately four-bedroom home overlooking Chatham Harbor and the Atlantic Ocean.
"Right now prices are not escalating," she said. "What we're seeing is the customer buyer base starting to build up."
Overall, it appears that prices on the Cape are going up. According to the Cape Cod and Islands Board of Realtors, the average residential sales price in the first two months of 1998 was $219,000, with 515 sales. In January and February of 1997 the average sales price was $171,000, with 454 houses sold. Also, there are fewer listings -- 2,879 this year compared to 3,267 at this time last year.
Shoppers looking for a home in the country or mountains will fare better when it comes to price, brokers say, and buyers not tied to a particular location have a better chance of controlling the price they pay.
 "I think we have a better value and better supply than we've had in the last four or five years," said Marilyn Spaulding of the Woodstock Corporation in Vermont. "In the early 90's prices were still way up. People were dreaming. People are now much more realistic about price and ready to sell." Around the picturesque village of Woodstock, prices for three- to five-bedroom homes range from $250,000 to $400,000, she said.
Jim Insinga, owner of North Country Property Management in Rutland, Vt., said sales around the Killington ski area had been flat in recent years but were beginning to pick up. Two- and three-bedroom condominiums that would have sold for $130,000 to $160,000 in the 1980's are now selling for between $90,000 and $120,000.
In the rolling hills of Columbia County two hours north of Manhattan, a visitor need look only as far as Main Street in Hudson to gauge the market. "In the last five or six years, about 60 antique shops have opened, and there are now eight cappuccino machines in town," said Stephen Kingsley, president of Hudson Michael Realty.
Even before Wall Street started reaching new highs, New Yorkers in search of second homes were picking up bargains in Columbia County. Although prices are much higher than they once were in this former whaling community, which boasts a rich array of antique homes, "you can still buy what would be a palace in New York for $150,000," Mr. Kingsley said. He estimated that prices in Hudson had gone up 30 percent in the last two or three years.
Out in the countryside stretching toward the Catskill Mountains, a small house with an acre or two of land will start at about $100,000. For that price, a neighbor will probably be visible. With more land and privacy, the figure moves up to about $200,000 to $300,000.
Houses along the Hudson River or property with views command higher prices, Mr. Kingsley said. For example, an early 1700's shingle house on 10 acres in Germantown right on the river is listed at $695,000. Along with the house come a guest house and a studio above the barn.
In contrast, a Victorian farmhouse on eight acres on Wire Road in Livingston, N.Y., Columbia County is on the market at $100,000. For $375,000 there's an 1860's colonial on 30 acres in Germantown with a small pond and red barn. The top of the market is a $3.75 million turn-of-the-century Stanford White creation on 85 acres of an old Astor estate in northern Dutchess County near Rhinebeck.
The market in Columbia County peaked in 1987 and 1988, Mr. Kingsley said. After that, prices dropped 30 to 40 percent until sales began picking up two years ago. "The year of the Gulf War nobody bought a house in the county," he said.
While speculative building has not taken off in the area, Ancram in Columbia County is the site of a development called Long Lake, a 220-acre recreational community at the foot of the Berkshire Mountains. The developer, Samson Management, has started work on the first phase of the project, which will include 68 homes ranging in size from 1,800 to nearly 2,300 square feet. Prices are to start at $250,000.
The company is seeking to capitalize on the town's location near Berkshire County, just across the state line, and nearby Litchfield County.
BOTH Great Barrington and Litchfield are County seeing strong sales. "We all said it will be hard to top last year, but we're doing it again," said Carolyn Klemm, a sales representative in the luxury division of Klemm Real Estate in Litchfield County, Conn.
While Litchfield County has its share of luxury listings -- which have recently included a stone castle built in the 1920's on 300 acres listed at $8.5 million -- the market has also been sprinkled with a wide variety of homes, including a four-bedroom colonial with pool on 11 acres for $349,000; a lakefront two-bedroom home with dock for $495,000; a large colonial on 125 acres with pool and "killer views" for $995,000, and a 1920's fully furnished estate for $2.75 million.
"The market is great," said Mary Mawn White, president of Barnbrook Realty Corporation in Great Barrington. "We have buyers in all price ranges, and the demand is higher than the supply."
While houses are available in the mid-$100,000's, Ms. White said that realistically a home with three bedrooms and no view would cost $250,000 to $300,000. Properties with views and a fronting on a lake are "almost nonexistent," she said.
While the current market in the Northeast is being likened to the heady days of the 1980's, brokers say, there are some differences. Much of the buying then was done on borrowed or leveraged money. Properties were being purchased and then resold after a few years.
Today buyers are often coming in and paying significant amounts -- 50 to 100 percent of the price -- in cash. They are treating the homes more as an investment in the future and spending longer periods of time there as telecommuting makes doing so possible.
Brokers agreed that the Wall Street boom and the strong economy, along with record low interest rates, were fueling the current market. "People are just confident in general," said Ms. Ross of Cook Pony Farm.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 14; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 912 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
A Cool, Clear Vision From a Distant Land

BYLINE: By BARRY SCHWABSKY 

DATELINE: LAWRENCEVILLE

 BODY:
LOUISA MATTHIASDOTTIR'S paintings include still lifes, landscapes, animal studies and portraits, but amid all these traditional motifs, there is another recurrent, underlying theme to her work: the color blue. Just as it sometimes seems as if the secret goal of the painters of the Venetian Renaissance was to put the appropriate admixture of red in their paintings, so as to lend each one the pulsating warmth of circulating blood, Ms. Matthiasdottir seems inclined to endow everything she paints with the cool, refreshing clarity of a cloudless sky.
More than anything else, that ever-present tincture of bluish atmosphere separates Ms. Matthiasdottir's mature work from what came before. Among the pictures on view in her retrospective at the Rider University Gallery, the leap can be located somewhere in the years separating "Temma" (1962-63) from "Self-Portrait With Umbrella" (1966). Not that blue is literally absent from her earlier work, of course; it's there, for example, in one of the child's toys in "Matti (Child Playing)," from 1937, or as the spine of a book in "Matthias Einarsson Reading," circa 1946. Yet with the benefit of hindsight, it may not be insignificant that in those cases, the color embodies the toy not played with, the book not being read. It's as if the artist had already recognized in this color a resource she did not yet know how to handle. 
 What is missing from these early works is precisely this cerulean atmosphere that unifies her later canvases. Otherwise, the elements of her style were pretty much in place 60 years ago, especially the deliberateness of her formal construction, her careful pressing into place of the blunt, sometimes almost awkwardly blocky shapes into which she has codified her quotidian subjects. Ms. Matthiasdottir lays her paint down in a get-the-job-done kind of way. The bristles left stuck to the surfaces of many of these paintings suggest that those broad zones of color were hardly brushed in with dainty, delicate strokes. There's no obvious fiddling with contours, yet their placement feels well-weighed.
Sometimes the reign of blue occurs quite subtly, as in a 1983 "Still Life With Ketchup Bottle,"' in which the hue is mostly displaced into some casually placed shadows yet still manages to inflect the whole painting, so that the slightly odd tone of the red bottle and a red dish can be understood only as if their color were being viewed through a blue filter.
But more often, Ms. Matthiasdottir's blues dominate her paintings overtly, as in her 1982 "Self-Portrait" or a small 1995 "Still Life" and despite a wealth of brilliantly contrasting color notes. But why is blue the keynote to her palette? It's a painting like "Reykjavik Harbor" (1991) that really explains it, although I might not have realized it without having seen the place. (Ms. Matthiasdottir was born in Reykjavik in 1917. She studied in Denmark and Paris before settling in 1943 in New York, where she continued her studies under Hans Hoffmann. But she still spends a good deal of time in her home town, as many of these paintings attest.)
Visiting Reykjavik last year, I happened to take with me a copy of "Independent People," the great novel by Halldor Laxness, Iceland's 1955 Nobel Prize-winning author. The book's cover featured a reproduction of one of Ms. Matthiasdottir's landscapes. From almost the moment I stepped off the plane, I realized that much of what I had taken for the painter's stylistic mannerism -- notably her way of transmuting spatial recession into horizontal color strata, somehow without losing a sense of real spaciousness -- was straightforward reporting of what Iceland looks like: there is no sky so clear and all-permeating as Iceland's, no place where distant vistas seem to loom so near.
THE people in Ms. Matthiasdottir's figure paintings always stand separate, and even the objects in her still lifes most often keep their distance from each other. Except where portraiture is the point, faces are only vaguely sketched: expression is not an issue. Yet these are not allegories of estrangement, as some critics have seen Alex Katz's paintings to be. These people and things are separated from one another and from their viewers, but what separates them -- this cool, luminous atmosphere -- also joins them. The distance always feels just right, at least for these taut, solid paintings, this tough-minded sensibility.
The English title of Laxness's epic is a translation of the Icelandic title, "Sjalfstaett Folk." As the writer Brad Leithauser (who has almost singlehandedly been responsible for reviving interest in the book in English) points out, the expression literally means "self-standing folk." It's a phrase hard not to remember when looking at the austere, bolt-upright figure who presides over the four wonderful self-portraits (a fifth, in pastel, is weaker and could have been left out), in which Matthiasdottir's resistance to psychology itself becomes a psychological motif. An unreconstructed insistence on empirical reality over emotional drama dominates these paintings, in which an unspoken love of home nevertheless surrounds things with crisp northern air.
