HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Chasing Michael, or, How to Corner a Corporate Nemesis

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:
HE'S back.
Michael Moore ambled irrevocably onto the scene with his 1989 documentary "Roger and Me," which chronicled his often comic effort to ask Roger Smith, then chairman of General Motors, why he was laying off so many people. 
 Now he has a new movie, "The Big One," in which he tries to ask various chief executives the same thing. So it seemed high time to shove a microphone -- a notepad, at any rate -- at Mr. Moore himself.
For a while, this quest was shaping up almost as "Michael and Me." Mr. Moore gives the sense of someone who moves his jovial bulk casually through life, a man you call up and, 10 minutes later, meet for a beer.
But over several days, with Mr. Moore in the midst of a not-at-all-casual blitz of promoting the movie, calls poured in from no fewer than five people -- some in public relations, some with Miramax, the film's distributor. Yes, there should be some time on Monday. At 1 P.M., in midtown Manhattan. No, make that 1:30. No, at Miramax's office, downtown, at 3:15. No, still 3:15, but at Mr. Moore's office across from Carnegie Hall. Whew!
An assistant opened the door to a warren of small rooms, the hallways stacked high with file boxes. Michael Moore Central. Four or five people bustled about, one making travel reservations, another keeping tabs on Mr. Moore's site on the World Wide Web (www.michaelmoore.com).
What to expect? Half the new movie is Mr. Moore as (quite funny) stand-up comedian, the other half Mr. Moore as shining crusader.
In person, he was as imposing as on film, a great mass of denim-shirted man hunched over his computer, his back to the door. After finishing his work, he plopped down on an overstuffed couch, put his feet up and burst out, "I was kidding about O.J.!" (In his book "Downsize This!," published by Random House, he has a tongue-in-cheek chapter titled "O.J. Is Innocent.")
So it was to be Mr. Moore the comedian? Not at all. To the suggestion that with all the comedy, "The Big One" is less political than "Roger and Me," he responded seriously and emphatically: "No, it's more political. The outrage is stronger. But I'm a film maker, not a political activist. We are all citizens in a democracy. That alone implies we are all political activists. Plus there's nothing wrong with giving people who work hard all week 90 minutes of a good cathartic laugh at the expense of the powers that be."
And his message is clear: "It's no longer about just making a profit. Corporate America is now running on pure greed. This whole economic recovery is financed on the backs of overworked and underpaid people."
In his films, his book, and his series "TV Nation," he has hammered away at the economy's inequities -- the rich getting richer, the rest clawing along on two or three jobs. Does he believe that some new economic cycle is brewing, in which workers will assert their rights to a bigger slice of the American pie?
"Yes, I do," he said firmly. "That's why I ended the movie with the kids at the Borders bookstore in Des Moines organizing a union -- to end on an optimistic note." Soon, across the nation, "you'll see a rise in unions," he said.
Surely things are not as bad as in his hometown of Flint, Mich., in the 1930's, when it was the site of a pivotal auto strike. For workers to rebel, he conceded, "things have to get pretty bad."
But he quickly added: "For some people, it doesn't have to get too much worse. Unions were born when people had to work 60 or 70 hours a week. But today, a lot of people are working two jobs." Unions, he added, also were born in reaction to child labor. "But in the Midwest, I see 14-year-olds working at McDonald's, not so they can buy Nikes but because they need to help pay their family bills."
At a Borders store in Philadelphia, Mr. Moore had come across striking workers and asked them to speak out at a book signing. Mr. Moore says Borders later banned him from its stores, while Borders says that only one event was changed, because of overcrowding and a fire hazard.
"After finishing the movie, I talked to the head of Borders Inc. and told him: 'The workers didn't need a union organizer. You've organized the union by doing things like withholding money from their paychecks for an H.M.O. that had no doctor in their city.
"It is short-range thinking to downsize, to make one person do the job of two," he went on, growing animated. "If you wear your workers down, they get sick more often, and because you've shoved them into these worthless H.M.O.'s, they don't really get help."
To Mr. Moore, the "old days" loom large. "My dad used to work from 6 A.M. till 2" at G.M., he said. "He'd be home by 2:30, before we were even home from school." It was clear that he treasured this memory. "Workers were encouraged to make suggestions on making cars better," Mr. Moore continued. "These days, if you're suddenly forced to do the jobs of two people, the creative part of your mind turns off. What does that do to society? Great inventions come from those moments of 'Aha!' And often it's from people with little or no formal education. I wonder if people in factories now will have the time, energy and desire to do that."
But isn't this just nostalgia? Isn't change inevitable? Absolutely, he said: "When you come from the working class, the way I do, you don't romanticize hard labor. You welcome advances like robots."
Other changes he doesn't welcome. "There's a shift to making money from money, not from labor," he said. "What new ideas aren't being explored because everyone's logging onto the Internet to find out how their stocks are doing?"
Mr. Moore, 43, who lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Kathleen Glynn, and teen-age daughter, Natalie, has made money -- plenty of it -- but he keeps it in a savings account. "My accountant probably thinks I'm a little strange," he said. "I don't own stock partly for political reasons. But I'm not making a judgment on people who do. It's partly just the way I was brought up.
"We did put a little money into a Broadway musical -- I don't want to say which one -- that's starting a road company. That's our total investment."
In his films, Mr. Moore is concerned -- one might say obsessed -- with job losses in Flint, where for a decade he ran a newspaper. What about opening a business there now?
"No," he said quickly. "But since 'Roger and Me,' I have given away $520,000 in grants, and a fifth of that has gone to Flint, for things like scholarships and job training."
THE 45 minutes was nearly up, and an assistant poked her head in. "Two-minute warning," she said, then closed the door.
So, a last question: Do any chief executives have a conscience?
A blanket condemnation would have been no surprise, but Mr. Moore resisted that. Rather, he mentioned an auto executive: Alex Trotman, chairman of the Ford Motor Company.
"Last year, there was a strike at Johnson Controls -- they fired the strikers and hired replacement workers," he said. "But Trotman refused to buy car seats made by replacement workers. And his action forced Johnson Controls to settle with the union. It may be because he grew up in Scotland. There's a different tradition over there -- even conservatives believe in fair play and a social safety net."
As does Mr. Moore, all joking aside.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Trash Hauler Fined

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
Suburban Carting, one of Westchester's largest private trash haulers, was sentenced in Federal Court late last month to five years' probation and ordered to pay more than $5 million to the Government, John L. Kase, the lawyer for the Mamaroneck-based company, said. Suburban will also have to pay Westchester about $800,000.
The money owed to the county stems from an illegal profit-sharing scheme involving Suburban and another carter, I.S.A. of Middletown, N.Y. Combined, they are paying roughly $17 million in back taxes, fines and restitution under plea agreements they accepted in September. Mr. Kase said that Judge Jed S. Rakoff at sentencing in Federal District Court in Manhattan in March described Suburban Carting as a mob-controlled "shadow economy." 
 But Mr. Kase, whose offices are in Garden City on Long Island, said last week that Suburban was no longer influenced by organized crime and that three trustees were managing the company. In turn, the trustees are being overseen by a Federal monitor. The carter's president, Thomas Milo, will begin a three-year jail term this spring.
Mr. Milo -- along with his companies, 11 other companies and 5 other people -- pleaded guilty to various roles in an antitrust, organized- crime conspiracy, which spanned 10 years. The goal was to control the carting industry in the Hudson Valley, said John L. Pollok, Mr. Milo's Manhattan lawyer.
The county has a contract with Suburban and a subsidiary, Trottown Transfer, for trash hauling through August.

HEADLINE: Teaching the Teachers About Investing

BYLINE: By CAROL MARIE CROPPER 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
THE Texas securities commissioner stood before 200 schoolteachers here recently to warn about emu scams (the wingless birds, not the European currency units) and the wily Ohio teen-ager who raised millions from other kids for a fraudulent ticket-scalping enterprise.
The official's goal wasn't necessarily to keep Texas educators from getting taken -- although for teachers like Trudy Dossett of San Antonio, who complained of her husband's fervid stabs at money-making, that was undoubtedly a side effect. ("He is notorious for wanting to invest in everything that comes along," she complained.) 
 Instead, the appearance of the commissioner, Denise Voigt Crawford, was part of a year-old Texas initiative to prepare tomorrow's investors for the complicated financial questions that lie ahead by educating the teachers who educate them.
With 401(k)'s replacing traditional retirement plans, Social Security's future under question and more Americans investing in stocks, high school graduates are quickly facing financial choices that their parents didn't dream about. "Unlike past generations," Ms. Crawford said, "the next generation is going to have to plan for themselves."
And so, armed with $275,000 -- paid in a 1996 settlement by a securities firm that put the funds of unknowing investors into high-risk derivatives -- the Texas Securities Board set out to give basic investor information to high school teachers.
Ms. Crawford said she had spoken to 400 to 500 teachers around the state so far. The program will last another year.
The Texas initiative is one sign of the new attention that educators are giving this topic nationally. At the heart of the Texas Investor Education Project is a 180-page guide, "Consumer Approach to Investing." Teachers who attend the state's conferences receive a copy of the guide; Rosella Bannister, director of the National Institute for Consumer Education, walks them through it.
In Dallas, Ms. Bannister used slides and tossed out questions to her audience, raising such issues as whether a single person needs life insurance (probably not) and how long it takes to double your money at various interest rates: Just divide 72 by the rate; at 8 percent interest, for example, it would take nine years.
One of the most surprising slides showed how long it would take to pay off a $2,000 credit card debt, at 19.8 percent interest, if you made the minimum 2 percent payment each month. The answer: 32 years.
The guide contains worksheets that the Texas Securities Board hopes teachers will distribute to students. One explains how to calculate a family's income and expenses; another tests students' ability to interpret stock and bond quotations.
"We teach drivers' ed. We teach P.E. in our schools," Ms. Crawford said. "It's time that we teach the investors of tomorrow how to manage and protect their money."
Mrs. Dossett, the San Antonio teacher, said that even her fifth-grade students would benefit from what she learned at the conference. Children that young are already falling prey to questionable deals offered over the Internet, she said. "They go get in mom's and dad's purse and get a credit card," she explained.
But the teacher seemed especially excited at the prospect of showing the materials to her husband, Mike, who works in telemarketing. About four years ago, Mr. Dossett bought 10 candy vending machines at $2,000 each as a way to make money, his wife recalled; these days, she said, the machines are sitting in the garage.

HEADLINE: VIEWPOINT;
Keeping a Safety Net Under a Budget Surplus

BYLINE: By CHARLES J. ZWICK and PETER A. LEWIS; Charles J. Zwick and Peter A. Lewis were director and assistant director, respectively, of the United States Bureau of the Budget in 1969.

 BODY:
IN 1999, the Federal budget is projected to show a surplus for the first time since 1969. But if we do not want to run into another long string of deficits after that, we must recognize that the nature of Government programs has changed drastically, making it infinitely more difficult to maintain a balanced budget now than it was 30 years ago.
Consider the budget in 1969, in the midst of the Vietnam War: Military spending and other traditional functions of Government -- areas that had no private alternatives, including the Treasury, Justice and State Departments -- absorbed 74 percent of the budget before interest on the Federal debt. Social programs represented only 26 percent. 
 Today, the situation is reversed. Seventy-two percent of the budget is for programs for individuals, programs that substitute for or supplement private insurance and other private spending. Our population is growing older, and these programs will grow faster than the economy, as they have for the last 30 years.
If we wish to hold the Federal budget in check or provide for lower taxes, we must deal with these Government insurance programs. Although health insurance and retirement programs could be shifted from the Government to the private sector, the resulting cost to society would be the same unless the benefits or the numbers of people covered were reduced.
When the budget existed primarily for the military and other traditional programs, a cutback meant a cutback for the overall economy; offsetting expenditures for those activities did not reappear in the private sector. But expenditures for health care and retirement do not stop at the budget's edge. Cutting back insurance spending at the Federal level most likely will mean increasing that spending at the private level.
It is argued that the number of people covered will fall when insurance is shifted to the private sector. This conclusion would be accurate if insurance were an option that consumers could forgo. We must recognize, however, that lack of coverage is what created the Government programs in the first place. Alternatively, if we were to make these private programs mandatory, they would be no different than a tax -- albeit a private one, and hardly less expensive for taxpayers.
Some people also assume that private health insurance is more efficient and ultimately less expensive. In fact, private medical costs have been increasing at the same rate as Government health costs.
YET there remains a great temptation to shift public expenditures to the private sector and declare victory on behalf of the Federal budget, forgetting that all of us have private budgets, too. In today's society, the public and private sectors are difficult to separate, and the overlap is not the exception but the rule. This overlap is what conservatives would like to remove and what the industrialized world is reluctant to sacrifice. And it is where the safety net is found.
President Clinton recognized this when he tackled health care. But simply recognizing the issue did not help. The new Congressional commission on Social Security will confront the same question.
The debate should not be about balancing the Federal budget and what to do with the projected surplus, but about what level of health care and retirement benefits the nation wants and will pay for. Relieving the public sector by shifting an equivalent burden to the private sector does not constitute a saving, and the public senses this. Having a balanced Federal budget is a welcome first move. But dumping expenditures on the doorsteps of nervous citizens may not prove to be an easy next step.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 2417 words

HEADLINE: First Lessons in the Power of Money

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
THE eighth graders at Macopin Middle School in West Milford, N.J., a rural town about 40 miles northwest of Manhattan, are learning some basic lessons about economics.
First, they sold candy and magazine subscriptions to their families and friends. Then, instead of pooling the money in an activities fund, as had been the custom until this year, the school set up individual accounts for each student, reflecting how much each had raised. Until they graduate, they will be able to draw money out of their accounts to use for school trips, like one last month to the theater district, where they ate cheeseburgers at Comedy Nation and then took in a matinee of "1776." 
 What did they learn from all this? "If you do something, you're going to get paid for it," said Jamie Riegler, an eighth grader who has about $100 in her account.
Some classmates have far more, some have less and others nothing at all.
"That's America," declared the school's vice principal, Ray Johnson, a husky man with a Clintonesque hair style, as he stood surrounded by the hubbub of 130 adolescents crammed into Leatherette booths for their pre-theater lunch. "It's a good lesson in economics and capitalism. In America, you're supposed to reap what you sow, so to speak."
Such lessons are among the many that the nation's children are being taught about what drives the mighty engine of the American economy. Some school systems start as early as kindergarten; others wait until junior high or high school. And the formats can range from formal, comprehensive courses about supply and demand, profit and loss, incentives and opportunity cost, to real-life experiences like balancing a checkbook or interpreting the fluctuations of the Dow.
Many schools have also become choice marketing sites for companies, from standbys like the Scholastic Corporation, which pitches books to children starting in kindergarten (and lately has been selling videos and toys, too), to more recent arrivals like the Microsoft Corporation, whose software programs are installed in thousands of classrooms and libraries.
In some areas, school gyms are bedecked with corporate logos, offshoots of school-solicited advertising or partnerships between the schools and companies. Cafeterias serve McDonald's fries or Pizza Hut slices, and soft-drink companies are signing exclusive contracts with school districts, often getting an advertising presence at schools as part of the deal. In some towns, even the school buses have ads on the sides.
Yet as the line between education and business grows fuzzier, there is little agreement about the best way to teach economics. The informal message -- that money is power -- is often delivered more emphatically by ads in schools, for example, than by the economics curriculum, if there is one.
What is being sown by educators, moreover, seems to have trouble taking root. A test conducted last year by the nonprofit Jumpstart Coalition for Personal Financial Literacy found that graduating seniors knew a "dismal amount" about how to manage their money.
"The teaching of economics at the pre-college level is quite confused," said Mark Schug, director of the Center for Economic Education at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. "A lot of people think of economics as the writing of checks, the importance of savings, how to manage your financial affairs. That's all very good stuff and kids should know that. But when we talk about an actual program, it's about how kids can learn about economics as a discipline. It's a great analytical tool, the discipline of economics, with its focus on costs and choices and incentives."
MR. SCHUG'S center is one of 200 financed by the National Council on Economic Education, a Manhattan-based organization started in 1949 by business leaders who were concerned that postwar youth knew nothing about what made markets tick, or even what a market was. The council, which said it reached about 7.5 million students in the last year, works primarily with teachers, supplying materials like a stock market game and suggestions for tying economics into existing subjects like government or the environment.
"There are still not very many schools that teach economics as such," said Robert Duvall, president of the council. "Our goal is to reach every kid in the country. When people say 'reading is fundamental,' we want to add to that 'economics is essential.' "
Last year, the council published a list of 20 principles that it believes all graduating high school seniors need to know to be economically literate. For example: "When individuals, regions and nations specialize in what they can produce at the lowest cost and then trade with others, both production and consumption increase." And: "Federal Government budgetary policy and the Federal Reserve System's monetary policy influence the overall levels of employment, output and prices."
True, many parents may admit that they do not understand either of the above. But, Mr. Duvall noted, "people are called upon more and more to manage their own retirement plans. And when people go into the voting booth and are asked to decide on fast-track trade legislation, or they read that financial problems in Hong Kong are going to impact this country, they haven't got a clue. We want to do something about that. And you start with the kids."
Mr. Duvall says a third-hand story about a second grader in Timberville, Va., illustrates the advances his group is making. The little boy was asked in Sunday school to define "prophet." His reply: "It's what is left over after the costs of production are taken out."
EAGER to show educators that economics can be incorporated into the average classroom, the council has published some teachers' successful lesson plans, including one for a Little Rock, Ark., kindergarten. Called "Ginger Town Economics: A 'Runaway' Success," it expanded upon the story of the Gingerbread Man to teach scarcity and "the need to make allocation decisions." The students collected taxes in Ginger Town and used the money to buy classroom equipment.
Another lesson, first used by junior high school students in Casselberry, Fla., revolved around the students' setting up a food concession. They did everything from designing a logo (for "The Breakfast Club") to interviewing workers and learning "the importance of social and business skills in a restaurant."
Still, only 14 states have agreed to make formal economics a part of their school curriculums, Mr. Duvall said. Much of what the others teach seems to focus on practical applications: the use of money, the effect of sales taxes, the budgeting of hard-earned cash to pay for things you want.
Yet even these lessons in personal financial management may not be having much impact. For the 1,509 graduating seniors who took the Jumpstart Coalition's 31-question exam -- on subjects from money management to savings and spending -- the average score was 57 percent, a failing grade in many classes. Most said they learned what they knew from relatives, not at school, and the scores were slightly higher for the ones who learned at home.
"This implies that the schools that are teaching tools of money management may need some strengthening of their curricula," the coalition's report states, or understates.
Extracurricular activities teach their own brand of financial wisdom, but as in school, it is sometimes hard to tell if the intended lessons stick.
Girl Scouts, for instance, work on an incentive plan, collecting prizes like T-shirts and plastic mugs if they reach certain cookie-sales plateaus. Sarah Baker, a 10-year-old fourth grader from Summit, N.J., recently sold 100 boxes of cookies and got a shirt.
A victory for capitalism? "A couple of my friends thought it was too much work," Sarah said.
Teaching kids the art of self-defense against commercialism is a priority for the National Endowment for Financial Education, a nonprofit group based in Denver that has issued teaching materials to the Girl Scouts and other groups. "We will ask: What are the alternatives to buying something at the full retail price?" said Brent A. Neiser, the endowment's director of collaborative programs. "And we ask: Do you have to have that right away?"
At the sole public school in Haledon, N.J., just north of Paterson, fourth graders are busily learning how to stay within a budget. An assortment of empty cereal, juice and detergent packages are lined up on a table, suggesting a grocery store. Teachers take math principles and apply them to real-life situations, usually involving shopping and similar experiences.
"I have kids who have a real problem with math," said the principal, John R. Dunay. "But if you put a dollar sign in front of it, they get it right away." The school serves a mostly working-class mix of longtime residents and recent immigrants, many from the Middle East.
Mr. Dunay's emphasis on practical applications has brought about "Supermarket Math," in which the fourth graders use what they know about addition and rounding off numbers to figure the cost of a basket of groceries -- selected by the children and heavy on Pepsi and Lucky Charms.
"If we're working within a budget, what does that mean?" asked the teacher, Dennis Elliot.
"You're not supposed to go over the budget," answered one girl in the group of 19 children.
"That's right," Mr. Elliot said. "We can't spend more money than we have."
LaToya Williams, a 14-year-old eighth grader at the school, has already had a variety of experiences with the economy. These include an unsatisfying part-time job and the introduction of fast-food companies to her school's "closed-lunch" program, where every child is served a cafeteria meal, rather than brown-bagging it.
"We have Pizza Hut and Domino's Pizza a couple of times a month," LaToya said. She also glimpses corporate America in the "Labels for Education" program in which the school participates. Labels from Campbell Soup Company products, like canned soup and Pepperidge Farm cookies, can be redeemed for equipment ranging from basketballs to desktop computers. It's a slow process; for a Gateway 2000 Multimedia desktop computer, a school needs to turn in more than 223,300 labels. Then there's the 15-passenger van with automatic transmission and power brakes, which requires almost 1.1 million. Let's see, at 59 cents a can for soup, that would mean more than $649,000 in Campbell's sales to get the van, or $131,747 in sales to get the computer.
LATOYA is the only girl in the Haledon School's stock market club; she said she joined because her mother works at a company that lets her buy shares, and LaToya figured it would be good if she understood the market, in case the same opportunity presented itself to her.
Club members make simulated investments in stocks and track their performance week by week. At the start of the year, LaToya bought 132 shares of Lucent Technologies at $94.6875 and 158 shares of Microsoft at $79. Her gains in March totaled $2,293.75 -- a respectable sum but still far behind the club's leader, Nahim Ahmed, an eighth grader who was up $6,758.75 on his basket of stocks.
LaToya's job at the Checkers Drive-In down the hill from school taught its own lessons in real-world economics. She started in January and quit last month. "I was putting tomatoes on the buns and working on a cash register a little," she said. "They only trained me for two weeks, and they expected me to know it in two weeks. They were only paying me $5.15 an hour, and I was the youngest. They thought they could push me around." So, LaToya downsized Checkers.
Like the students at Macopin Middle School, the seventh and eighth graders at Haledon have their own accounts, fattened with money from school fund-raisers. Every dollar's worth of wrapping paper, candy, fruit and magazine subscriptions translates into 50 cents for the students, Mr. Dunay said. (There is probably at least one lesson in the economics of that arrangement: an unpaid work force is a great way to generate cash.)
The individual accounts "teach us to be responsible," LaToya said. Her own account, she said, contained enough money to let her attend the eighth-grade dance recently. "In this school, they treat the eighth graders like young adults," she said.
MARKETERS look at schoolchildren as young adults, too, aiming advertising messages at them in every way imaginable. Ira Mayer, publisher of Youth Markets Alert, a Manhattan newsletter, said commercialism in schools was clearly on the rise. "I've seen an increase in the sophistication and the order of magnitude," he said, mainly because "kids are increasingly influential in decisions and purchases."
Ads are clearly influential, too. Marianne Manilov, whose Center for Commercial Free Public Education, based in Oakland, Calif., has kept close watch on the growth of advertising in schools, said studies had shown that children could not separate the authority of their school from that of ads they saw there. "They think their school sponsored the ad," she said.
Mr. Dunay hopes to bring more corporate partners to his school, where he became the principal last fall. Haledon is somewhat off the beaten track, and so far, there have been no offers of equipment from I.B.M., say, or Microsoft. But Mr. Dunay is optimistic that this will change.
"I have friends in the corporate world that I plan to approach," he said. "They're very anxious to do it, too, because they see a potential market here." Besides, he added, "the kids learn that there are companies that are reputable and provide a good product, and others that don't."
Haledon, though, will have to compete for attention with other schools in the state and around the country. Skeptics contend that many corporations put their energies into schools where they are likely to get the highest return, in visibility and in the dollars that may flow their way as a result.
And those priorities may be the strongest lesson that students are learning about economics -- either directly, in the classroom, or indirectly, from the world around them. It is all about whether they are considered an important part of the picture, or out of the picture altogether.
Economics could explain that.
"The important thing to understand is that there are scarcities in the world," said Mr. Schug, the Milwaukee economics educator. "You have to understand that people are self-interested. Not to be confused with selfishness."

Chart: "Need to Know"
Here are 20 economic principles that the National Council on Economic Education considers essential for high school graduates to understand.
 
1. People cannot have all the goods and services they want. They must make choices.
 
2. Making choices means weighing costs and benefits and thinking in terms of more and less, not just all or nothing.
 
3. One kind of choice facing individuals and their government representatives is how to divide up goods and services among those who want them. There are many different methods.
 
4. People respond predictably to positive and negative incentives.
 
5. Generally, trading happens only when everyone involved expects to gain by the trade.
 
6. For people and for countries, concentrating on what one does best and cheapest, and then trading with others, brings greater overall prosperity.
 
7. When buyers and sellers interact, they form a market; the trading they do determines market prices.
 
8. Prices are signals that people use to learn about supply and demand in the market.
 
9. When sellers compete, prices fall and costs are cut. When buyers compete, prices rise and goods and services go to the buyer willing to pay the most.
 
10. Institutions evolve to help market economies function. Banks, corporations, labor unions, a legal system and property rights are examples.
 
11. Money makes it easier to trade, borrow, save, invest and compare the value of goods and services.
 
12. When interest rates rise or fall, they balance the amount of money saved and the amount borrowed, changing how people choose among saving, investing for the future or spending today.
 
13. Income for most people depends on the market value of the work they do or of the goods and services they sell.
 
14. Entrepreneurs set up businesses and take risks in hope of profit.
 
15. Investment in factories, machinery and new technology or in the health, education and training of people can raise future standards of living.
 
16. Government's role in a market economy includes things like providing for national defense and making and enforcing laws. Most government policies have the effect of redistributing income.
 
17. Costs of government policies sometimes exceed benefits, often because they are aimed at a goal other than economic efficiency, or because those who benefit have more say than those who pay.
 
18. Over all, income, employment and prices are determined by the combined effects of all the choices made by people, businesses, institutions and government.
 
19. Unemployment imposes costs on people and nations. Unexpected inflation imposes costs on many people but benefits some others. When inflation leads people and organizations to use resources to protect against uncertain future prices, the economy can suffer.
 
20. The Federal budget and the Federal Reserve's interest-rate policy broadly influence the economy. (pg. 10)

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Investors Seek Sale Of Nuveen

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
IT is, undoubtedly, a quixotic quest: A little-known analyst at an even less-known money management firm tries to get a giant fund group to put itself up for sale.
But in tilting at the John Nuveen Company, Mario Cibelli of the New York money manager Robotti & Company has some formidable backers in the role of Sancho Panza. 
 At Nuveen's annual meeting on May 7, Mr. Cibelli plans to introduce a shareholder resolution asking Nuveen's board "to immediately initiate discussions with possible purchasers" of the company, according to Nuveen's proxy statement, filed on April 3.
Mr. Cibelli acknowledges that the outcome of the vote is all but certain. "I expect to lose," he said, noting that the St. Paul Companies, the big Minnesota insurer, owns 77 percent of Nuveen. A St. Paul spokesman said the company planned to vote against Mr. Cibelli's proposal, and Nuveen's board also opposes it.
Rather than an outright victory, Mr. Cibelli hopes to capture the votes of a significant portion of the minority holders of Nuveen's 7.5 million publicly traded class A shares. "I think it would send a strong message to management if a majority of them supported the resolution," he said.
One portfolio manager who intends to send that message with his proxy is Martin J. Whitman, who runs the Third Avenue Value fund. He has owned about 163,000 Nuveen shares for several years. "It's obvious Nuveen's results have been disappointing," he said.
Other shareholders agree that Nuveen's shares have long lagged behind its fund industry peers. While many publicly traded fund companies have soared in value the last five years -- more than tripling, in the case of Franklin Resources, or rising fivefold, as at T. Rowe Price -- Nuveen's shares rose a mere 8 percent.
Nuveen occupies a relatively lonely corner of the fund business. At the end of last year, roughly 91 percent of its $11 billion in mutual fund assets were in fixed-income funds, mainly of the municipal bond variety. And most of the rest of its $50 billion in total assets under management were in closed-end funds and unit investment trusts, many of which also specialize in municipal bonds.
That gives above-average stability to Nuveen's assets because closed-end funds and unit trusts are less susceptible to redemptions.
But investors lately have had little interest in municipal bonds, which suffered when interest rates spiked upward in 1994 and again during the flat-tax debate in 1996. Instead, Americans have flocked to stock funds the last five years.
Nuveen started offering equity mutual funds in 1996, and its equity fund assets recently topped $1 billion. But its stock funds ranked in the bottom quarter of their peer groups in the year ended March 31, according to Lipper Analytical Services. And while the company's fund assets grew by 50 percent last year, after stagnating for four years, most of that growth came by acquisition.
John P. Amboian, Nuveen's chief financial officer, said Mr. Cibelli's comparisons of the performance of Nuveen to other companies were unfair because its asset base was so different. "We are in the process of building the company to another level," he said. "That will result in significant wealth creation for the company and its shareholders."
MR. CIBELLI and Mr. Whitman complain, however, that the people receiving most of Nuveen's wealth are its executives. "Their compensation is off the wall," Mr. Whitman said. "For what they're getting paid, there ought not to be any excuse."
Nuveen's top two executives each received an average of $3.2 million in salary, bonus and stock for each of the last three years, Nuveen's proxy statement shows. That was double the average annual compensation earned by the top two executives at Franklin Resources, manager of the Franklin Templeton funds.
Nuveen says its total compensation costs, as a share of revenues, are about even with the industry average. "We believe we will generate more value for shareholders by building our businesses than by squeezing them," Mr. Amboian said.
Even investors still undecided about Mr. Cibelli's proposal can sympathize with him. Nick Truitt, an investment analyst at Conseco Capital Management, which has bought about 195,000 Nuveen shares the last six months, said, "If I had bought a mutual fund company several years ago and it had barely budged, I'd be frustrated, too."

HEADLINE: Spotted in New York: Shiny Cars

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
THE New York International Auto Show arrives each year with the Easter lilies, and for the 35 car makers with exhibits, it holds all the promise of a perfect spring day. This year's show, which opened yesterday and runs through next Sunday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, is no exception. The New York economy is booming, gas prices are at record lows and Wall Street bonuses were exceptionally rich last year.
With the sales forecast generally sunny, auto makers are eager to plant seeds of interest in models that are new, improved or not even available yet. While the Ford Motor Company used the show to showcase luxury sedans that will not go on sale for a year, competitors displayed a crop of vehicles that will make it to market sooner. Here are some of the most significant: 

HONDA MINI-VAN -- Honda goes after mainstream mini-van buyers this fall with a new, yet-unnamed mini-van. Replacing the relatively small and marginally successful Odyssey, the new van is sized and designed more like models sold by Chrysler, Ford and General Motors. Powered by a V6 engine (the Odyssey has four cylinders), the new Honda will seat seven and will be the first van with dual power-operated sliding doors. The third-row bench seat folds completely into the floor, like that of the Odyssey. The new van will be built at Honda's recently expanded plant near Toronto.
 
INFINITI G20 -- Nissan's luxury division has brought back a new version of the entry-level car it briefly discontinued. The 1999 G20, which goes on sale this summer, will start at $25,000 to compete against some versions of the BMW 3-Series and the Audi A4. Built in Japan, the G20 is based on the Nissan Primera, already on sale in Europe and Japan. The G20 is powered by a 140-horsepower four-cylinder engine and comes in standard and more sporty touring editions.
 
CHEVROLET TRACKER, SUZUKI VITARA AND GRAND VITARA -- The Geo Tracker is now a Chevy, and the Suzuki Sidekick will soon be gone. Both Suzuki and General Motors introduced redesigned versions of their small, very similar sport utility vehicles as 1999 models, with the Suzuki models getting new names: the four-cylinder Vitara and the V6 Grand Vitara. Basic versions come as two-door convertibles or four-door models with solid roofs; the fancier Grand Vitara comes with four doors and a new 2.5-liter, 24-valve V6 engine. Starting at less than $20,000, the truck-based, Canadian-built vehicles are aimed at the Toyota RAV4 and Honda CR-V.

AUDI A6 AVANT -- Audi begins selling this station wagon version of its successful A6 sedan in June. Like the sedan introduced last fall, the A6 Avant is powered by a 2.8-liter V6 engine. Quattro all-wheel drive is available, making the A6 Avant an alternative to four-wheel-drive sport utilities. The Avant starts at about $37,000.
 
PORSCHE 911 CABRIOLET -- An open-top version of the new 911, the first redesign of that legendary sports car in 34 years, arrives in showrooms this month. The cabriolet has an electronic soft top that raises or lowers in 20 seconds. The coupe starts at about $65,000, the cabriolet at about $75,000.

HEADLINE: There, on the Autobahn, Could It Be a Lincoln?

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to American-style excess, Lincoln has had its share. And as baby boomers rebelled against the overwrought, softly sprung land yachts of their parents and grandparents, the luxury-car division of Ford faltered.
Now, Lincoln is playing catch-up, with some success: Sales are up 63 percent this year, thanks to the popular Navigator sport utility; a new, sleeker Town Car, and a restyled Continental. And for its next act, it wants to slim down, tone up and slip into a sleek European suit. 
 Last week, at press previews for the New York International Auto Show, Lincoln unveiled its most ambitious weapon for wooing affluent boomers, in the United States and abroad, who are entering their peak earnings years: the LS series of medium-sized, understated, German-inspired luxury cars.
In his introduction of the LS, Jacques A. Nasser, president of Ford automotive operations, said it was "designed to travel beyond the borders -- beyond the design borders, beyond the geographical borders and beyond the pscyhological borders -- that Lincoln has traditionally operated in."
The two LS models, with either V6 or V8 power, will go on sale in about a year as 2000 models. They will join one of the most competitive segments of the auto market: the "entry luxury" category of cars priced from roughly $30,000 to $40,000.
Total luxury car sales have held steady despite a strong economy, and they are expected to remain stagnant into the next century, at about a million vehicles a year in the United States. But the lower end of this market has been growing here and around the world, with continued expansion likely. To defend their ground and preserve their pride, every auto maker of global significance has entered the fray, and Detroit's Big Three are among the last to show up.
For the 1997 model year, Cadillac introduced the European-built Catera, based on the Opel Omega. In May, Chrysler brings out the 300M, a performance-oriented sedan based on a newly redesigned platform, which it shares with the Chrysler Concorde, Chrysler LHS and Dodge Intrepid.
The lower-luxury market is dominated by Japanese and German cars like the Lexus ES 300 and BMW 3-Series. In contrast to Cadillac, which essentially put a new grille and its venerable crest on an Opel from Germany, Lincoln engineers started from scratch to develop the LS6 and LS8. The sport sedans ride on an all-new rear-drive platform, which will be shared with a midsize Jaguar that also arrives next year. The new platform is complemented with new engines, transmissions and suspensions.
"We looked at the platforms we had available to us and didn't really find anything we were looking for," said Robert F. Widmer, luxury vehicle line director for Ford.
The LS6 is aimed at the ES 300, the 3-Series and, though Ford officials will not actually speak its name, the Catera. The Lincoln's V6 engine is a more powerful derivative of the Duratec engine in the Taurus. The LS8 is equipped with a new 3.9-liter V8 derived from the V8 used by Jaguar.
Both the LS6 and LS8 are available with a new five-speed automatic transmission, which can be ordered with a feature that allows the driver to shift, though there is no clutch. The LS6 will also come with a five-speed manual transmission, a rarity in this class and the first stick shift in a Lincoln since the early 1950's.
The LS models also come with other luxury-car features like anti-lock brakes, side air bags, all-speed traction control and a yaw control that helps to eliminate fishtailing and otherwise maintains stability.
The LS sits on a relatively long wheelbase but has short overhangs, especially in the front. The car's total length is five meters, or about 16.5 feet, which is considered an international standard.
The two models look identical, except for their wheels. The LS6 is expected to be priced in the low $30,000 range; the LS8 is likely to start at less than $40,000, or below the BMW 5-Series that Ford sees as a primary competitor to the V8 model.
The LS's understated look is a departure for Lincoln, but is typical of European sport sedans, with a clean, conservative profile and wide, solid stance. One styling touch that sets it apart -- and an American one at that -- is the extensive use of chrome. The car's prominent grille is chrome plated, as is the trim around the rear license plate; a wide chrome band runs across the front bumper. (Body-color moldings will substitute for chrome on cars sent overseas.)
Until now, Lincoln has been a brand only in North America. This car, however, will be sold in 30 countries as the "Ford Lincoln," in right- and left-hand-drive versions.
Lincoln does not expect a lot of BMW and Lexus trade-ins immediately, though it has grander long-range plans. Initial buyers are likely to be people moving up from family sedans, said Jim O'Connor, the Ford vice president in charge of Lincoln. First-year sales are expected to total 25,000 -- roughly equal to Cadillac's 1997 Catera sales. Susan Jacobs, an independent auto industry analyst who specializes in the luxury car market, said Lincoln's marketing plan and sales projections were on target.
"This is the best offering from any of the domestics, including the Cadillac Catera and Chrysler 300M," she said.

HEADLINE: VICARIOUS CONSUMPTION;
Making Short Work Of Long Commutes

BYLINE: By ERIC HUBLER 

 BODY:
IF you think you have a long commute, consider where a typical day may take Richard Jacobs. From his home in Nantucket, Mass., it is down to Washington to meet with fellow officers of the Futures Industry Association; then to Charlottesville, Va., where he lectures at the University of Virginia; then back to Nantucket or, if needed the next morning at the Manhattan headquarters of CTC Fund Management, where he is director of business development, to his pied-a-terre in Englewood, N.J.
Living this way has its complications -- Mr. Jacobs has 11 phone numbers -- but he makes it work with a special business machine: his airplane. In the seven years that Mr. Jacobs has been flying on business, he and his single-engine Mooney 231 have become almost like partners. "I'm well known now in our industry as a pilot, and I don't think at this point anyone would offer me a job and say, 'And you can't fly,' " he said. 
 Mr. Jacobs is part of a small fraternity of business people who use personal aircraft as other people would use a car: to get to work, to accept out-of-town consulting jobs, to take clients to ball games. Like Sam Walton hopping around the country looking for Wal-Mart sites, they attribute much of their success to their ability to wrest control of their travel schedules from the airlines.
And, as fellow business flier Joseph Buscemi puts it: "It's a hell of a lot more fun."
Which is not to say that this type of travel is universally accepted. The first time that Mr. Buscemi, production director for Lyons Lavey Nickel Swift, a New York medical-advertising firm, flew a rented Piper from Long Island to Boston to check a print run, he "forgot" to tell human resources at the parent company, Omnicom Group. When he put in for expenses, he received his reimbursement -- along with a finger-wagging.
"The next time I have to sign a waiver, which I think is kind of ridiculous," Mr. Buscemi said. "The risks everyone takes driving a car and riding a motorcycle and everything, nobody crimps your style about that. But as soon as you get into a single-engine airplane, everyone panics and thinks you're going to kill yourself."
Like investors, aviators say there is a difference between danger, which cannot be controlled, and risk, which can. "There's an expression in flying: 'There are old pilots and there are bold pilots, but there are no old, bold pilots,' " says Ken Bardon, president of the RF Electronic Sales Company on Long Island, who has flown for 30 years.
Flying one's own plane is certainly convenient for business. Although unprofitable airports have been closing at the rate of one a week for a decade, according to the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, there are still 5,400 public-use airports in the United States, only 366 of which offer commercial service -- and half the commercial service is concentrated at just 21 airports.
Personal flying can be such a time-saver, Mr. Bardon said, that he sometimes rents a plane at Republic Airport in Farmingdale, on Long Island, to visit clients in New Jersey. "Sometimes," he said, "it's more efficient to fly across the Hudson River than drive it."
Cost, on the other hand, is endlessly debated among pilots. For Mr. Jacobs, the cost of maintaining a small plane, estimated at as much as $100 an hour flown, compares favorably with what his friends spend on pleasure boats.
Step a rung down the economic ladder, though, and it can become difficult to tell whether a pilot flies to work or works to fly.
Because playing jazz vibraphone is not the most reliable route to wealth, Craig Peyton -- who describes himself as a professional musician who's always had a strong attraction to flying-- concocted a circle of opportunity by mounting video cameras in the cabin and on the wing of his Mooney 201.
Now, as owner of Earth Flight Productions, Mr. Peyton sets his music to aerial scenes for use in business videos. Every time he flies from Dutchess County, N.Y., to a meeting with a client, he collects new material for the next project.
"It's called survival," he said. "On a typical trip across the country, fuel alone is going to cost you $1,500, so you'd better have a way to recoup some of it."
For James Wynbrandt, a writer in Manhattan, flying is both a means and an end. He flies and reviews planes for aviation magazines but also uses his Mooney M20-E to get to assignments that have nothing to do with aviation. He has flown to San Francisco for a job writing the "Merry Christmas From Walt Disney World" radio program, to Nova Scotia to see his co-author on a reference work on genetic disorders and to Baltimore to visit a dental museum for a coming book, "The Excruciating History of Dentistry: Toothsome Tales and Oral Oddities From Babylon to Braces" (St. Martin's Press).
"Beyond the utility, there's a certain satisfaction that you really can't put a price on," Mr. Wynbrandt said. "The things that one sees from the air, the Zenlike calmness that one experiences while flying, is in marked contrast to being squeezed six across in an airliner."

HEADLINE: Correspondence/Uncompetitive in Tokyo;
In Japan, Nice Guys (And Girls) Finish Together

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
MY intention, honest, was not to scar these Japanese kids for life. I just wanted to give them a fun game to play.
It was the fifth birthday party last year for my son Gregory, and he had invited all his Japanese friends over from the Tokyo kindergarten that he attended. My wife and I explained the rules of musical chairs, and we started the music. 
 It was not so awful for the Japanese boys. They managed to fight for seats, albeit a bit lamely. But the girls were at sea.
The first time I stopped the music, Gregory's 5-year-old girlfriend, Chitose-chan, was next to him, right in front of a chair. But she stood politely and waited for him to be seated first.
So Gregory scrambled into her seat, and Chitose-chan beamed proudly at her own good manners. Then I walked over and told her that she had just lost the game and would have to sit out. She gazed up at me, her luminous eyes full of shocked disbelief, looking like Bambi might after a discussion of venison burgers.
"You mean I lose because I'm polite?" Chitose-chan's eyes asked. "You mean the point of the game is to be rude?"
Well, now that I think of it, I guess that is the point. American kids are taught to be winners, to seize their opportunities and maybe the next kid's as well. Japanese children are taught to be good citizens, to be team players, to obey rules, to be content to be a mosaic tile in some larger design.
One can have an intelligent debate about which approach is better. The Japanese emphasis on consideration and teamwork perhaps explains why Japan has few armed robbers but also so few entrepreneurs. The American emphasis on winning may help explain why the United States consistently racks up Olympic gold medals but also why its hockey players trashed their rooms in Nagano.
The civility that still lingers in Japan is the most charming and delightful aspect of life here today. Taxi drivers wear white gloves, take pride in the cleanliness of their vehicles, and sometimes give a discount if they mistakenly take a long route. When they are sick, Japanese wear surgical face masks so they will not infect others. The Japanese language has almost no curses, and high school baseball teams bow to each other at the beginning of each game.
One can go years here without hearing a voice raised in anger, for when Japanese are furious they sometimes show it by becoming incredibly formal and polite. Compared with New York, it's rather quaint.
The conundrum is that Japan is perhaps too civilized for the 1990's. To revive its economy, mired in a seven-year slump, the country now needs an infusion of economic ruthlessness, a dose of the law of the jungle. Japan desperately needs to restructure itself, which is to say that it needs to create losers -- companies need to lay off excess workers, Mom-and-Pop rice shops need to be replaced by more efficient supermarkets and failing banks need to go bankrupt.
But Japan is deeply uncomfortable with the idea of failures or losers. The social and economic basis of modern Japan is egalitarianism, and that does not leave much room for either winners or losers. In Japan, winning isn't everything, and it isn't the only thing; in elementary schools it isn't even a thing at all.
When Gregory and his brother Geoffrey went to Sports Day at their Japanese kindergarten, everybody told us that this was the big event of the year. So my wife and I went to cheer, but it wasn't really necessary. There were three-legged races and team basketball shoots and all kinds of games, but somehow at the end of the day no one won and no one lost. There were no blue ribbons, no prizes for the fastest runner, no cheers for the best basketball shooter, or anything else; instead, every child got a small prize.
The point of Sports Day was not to divide students by recognizing individual excellence but to unite them by giving them a shared experience. Likewise, schools do not normally break up children into "fast reading classes" and "slow reading classes," because that would stigmatize the slower ones. During recess or phys ed, there is no system of having a few captains take turns picking teams, because the last-picked might be upset; instead kids divide by class or by the Japanese equivalent of alphabetical order. When drama teachers select a play to perform, they choose one in which there is no star, just a lot of equal parts -- which makes for first-rate student harmony and second-rate drama.
Of course, competition is inevitable in any society, and in Japan it is introduced in junior high schools, when children must compete intensely to pass high school and college entrance examinations. But the emphasis remains on "wa," or harmony, on being one with the group.
Ask a traditional Japanese housewife what she wants for her child, and you will sometimes hear an answer like: "I just want my kid to grow up so as not to be a nuisance to other people." Hmmm. Not a dream often heard in America.
Even in business, the obsession with egalitarian wa goes to astonishing lengths. One Tokyo bank executive told me how he envied the Japanese subsidiary of Citibank, which waives certain fees for customers who keep a large minimum balance. That would never be tolerated in a Japanese bank, he said, because it would be regarded as discriminatory against the poor. Likewise, he said, his bank cannot easily close unprofitable branches in remote areas, because then it would be criticized for abandoning the people there.
THE emphasis on wa perhaps arises because 125 million Japanese, almost half of America's population, are squeezed into an area the size of California. How else could they survive but with a passion for protocol and a web of picayune rules dictating consideration for others? If 125 million Americans were jammed into such a small space, we might have torn each other to shreds by now.
Building teamwork in Japan starts from birth. When our third child, Caroline, was born in Tokyo last fall, the hospital explained that the mothers were to nurse their babies all together in the same room at particular meal times. So on her first day of life, Caroline was effectively told to discipline her appetites to adjust to a larger scheme with others.
THIS civility and egalitarianism shape just about every aspect of life. When the Japanese translation of a book that my wife and I wrote was published, we were pleased that the first reviews were positive. But we were frankly surprised when every single Japanese review was positive, and I remarked on that to a Japanese friend. "Oh, that's the only kind of book review there is in Japan," he explained. "There are no bad book reviews. Just nice ones."
And insipid ones, of course. Indeed, Japan itself is so polite as to be a bit bland, rather like "Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood" on a national scale. And of course Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood was never known for its hustle or economic vibrancy.
So now, Japan is trying to become nastier. Workers are being pushed out of their jobs, occasionally even laid off. Employees are no longer being automatically promoted by seniority. Pay differentials are widening. Companies are becoming more concerned with efficiency and share prices, less concerned with employee welfare.
All this will make Japan a more prosperous country, but perhaps a less civil one. The changes certainly rub against the grain here, particularly of older people.
They rub just a bit against my grain, too. I bought a long scroll of calligraphy with the character "wa," in hopes that my kids will learn harmony, instead of clubbing each other over toys. Yet on the other hand I still want them to win -- at musical chairs and everything else.
That is getting tougher, because young Japanese are adapting to greater competition, and they seem to be a bit more aggressive and individualist than their parents. Some young Japanese are even getting pretty good at musical chairs.
And little Chitose-chan, Gregory's girlfriend -- well, she may be polite, but don't underestimate her generation's ability to catch on quickly. Thirty minutes after the game of musical chairs, Chitose-chan and her friend Naoko-chan got into an argument over a party favor. Chitose-chan slugged Naoko-chan in the mouth and grabbed the toy.
Perhaps that's globalization.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1382 words

HEADLINE: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;
Arming Yourself (Financially) for Armageddon

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN 

 BODY:
IT'S a fact that 99 percent of all species on earth have become extinct. And because man is a species, the question is not "if" so much as "when." Anyway, if, like me, you grew up a few radioactive Day-Glo orange puddle-jumps away from Love Canal, the upstate New York town turned toxic dump site, you're entitled to think that if some natural force doesn't get us, we'll probably just do ourselves in.
When people in my neighborhood said, "You look radiant," they weren't necessarily being complimentary. 
 So musing over doomsday does not mean that you're crazy or cranky or that you gave up hope for Lent instead of Haagen-Dazs. And you're certainly not alone. In a recent Gallup Poll, 61 percent of adults and 71 percent of teen-agers said they believed that the world would come to an end or be destroyed. It did not help to find out last month that an asteroid might be crashing into the planet, even if the next day's headlines read, "Whoops, just kidding!"
A short catalogue of potential calamities: nuclear accidents, environmental devastation (ozone layer, greenhouse effect), plague (resistant new strains of tuberculosis, Ebola virus, H.I.V.), doom prophesied by religious groups, and the latest cause for collective concern, the year 2000 computer glitch, or Y2K.
Given all this, some people want to prepare for whatever tribulation they envision. In these days of do-it-yourself investing, that means girding your finances, as well as the usual apocalyptic tasks like building a bunker or putting your soul in order.
Consider Y2K. The predictions for Dec. 31, 1999, range from simple bank errors, disappearing stock certificates and Social Security checks to a Government shutdown, mass social unrest and global economic collapse. The alarums are not just conjectures in Internet chat rooms but the genuine fears of techies charged with finding a solution before the gong strikes midnight.
Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in New York, says there is a 60 percent chance of a global recession from Y2K problems. He advises having cash on hand, putting money in Treasury bonds and steering clear of airline stocks. The reason for the last is that today's air traffic control computers are not ready to handle the change, he believes.
"No one knows what's going to happen, but it's a systemic problem" that Y2K poses, says Robert Forrester, managing partner of the Forrester Network, a consulting firm in Norwalk, Conn. His advice: Collect six months' worth of hard copies of all financial statements and bills. Make sure you have written copies of your birth certificate, college transcripts and insurance policies. And get a letter from Social Security stating your benefits; most experts believe that the Government is less likely to ready its computers for Y2K than is the private sector.
Bert Dohmen, president of Dohmen Capital Research in Honolulu, advises steering clear of stocks like Boeing, Lockheed Martin and other companies with substantial Government business. He also worries about Washington's computers crashing.
Howard J. Ruff, publisher of The Ruff Times, a newsletter, writes about the silver lining in this computer cloud, although he agrees that the Y2K problem may be dire. He recommends investing in ZMAX, a venture that prepares companies for the transition, and Home State Year 2000 (800-232-0224), a mutual fund that invests in businesses working on the Y2K problem. Gold is also a good bet, Mr. Ruff said.
What about those like Donald S. McAlvany, editor of The McAlvany Intelligence Advisor, who worry about drug-resistant viruses, germ warfare and anthrax attacks? Mr. McAlvany suggests that, for survival, people study up on nutrition, alternative medicine and the like. For investments, analysts would look into the same areas.
Stephanie Ackler, a financial counselor at Tucker Anthony in Manhattan, does not herself fret much about these dangers, but those who do might explore companies like General Nutrition, Celestial Seasonings and Lincare, a provider of respiratory therapy, she said.
INSURANCE, the next stop on our financial doomsday tour, offers something for everyone. Although most homeowner and business policies cover any objects that fall from the sky, for instance, the especially fearful can buy anti-asteroid insurance as well. For a one-time premium of $19.95, the St. Lawrence Agency in Altamonte Springs, Fla., sells a policy paying up to $10 million for asteroid damage. Reimbursement for treatment of cirrhosis of the liver resulting from panic-induced alcoholism is included. Honest.
If your mind turns to those 10 or 12 Chernobyl-type nuclear reactors in the former Soviet Union that have not yet been decommissioned, you may want mushroom-cloud coverage. The three primary insurers of nuclear risks are Mutual Atomic Energy Liability Underwriters, Nuclear Electric Insurance Ltd. and American Nuclear Insurers, which paid out $60 million in claims related to the 1979 accident at Three Mile Island.
Indeed, nuclear-reactor perils are one reason that Mr. Dohmen advises steering clear "of any investment in the former Soviet Union unless you like playing Russian roulette with five cylinders loaded."
Douglas S. Land, a venture capitalist with the Chesapeake Group in New York, says he is not himself convinced that the end will come with a nuclear blast, but he has investment advice for those who do. Go with Bausch & Lomb and Sunglass Hut International (eye protection), Brookstone (back-to-the-earth garden tools) and Glaxo Wellcome and other drug giants (sun screens). Or, because retailing may be wiped off the face of the earth, invest in Orbital Sciences, a satellite maker, he says.
Back on the insurance front, the spiritually optimistic may be interested in a reincarnation policy. The St. Lawrence Agency offers one that reimburses holders for lost property when they return after death.
Also, several companies sold "rapture insurance" over the years but, after a concerted effort, the industry successfully vanquished such coverage a few years ago. In the rapture, some Christians believe, the living faithful will be spirited to heaven, leaving others behind to face the Antichrist on earth. The policies granted the faithful the same status as deceased clients, with the moneys duly paid out to the beneficiaries.
Do religious groups that believe in apocalyptic doom as prophesied by the Bible invest only, say, in precious metals? The answer for many is no. The Mormons, Seventh-day Adventists and others are as stock-oriented as any large institutions.
"Though this could easily be considered a contradiction, realistically it isn't," said Milton Erhart, a stockbroker in Boise, Idaho, who advises the Adventist church. "Most religious organizations realize they must be in the equity markets if for no other reason than to fund the pension liabilities."
Of course, in thinking about the financial implications of doomsday, don't overlook stockpiling and other standard Armageddon preparations. It is always prudent to have food and water for emergencies, said Mr. Ruff, a Mormon, who suggests living off what you have in the house for a week right now, just to get an idea of your stockpiling needs. Having myself survived a few noteworthy Buffalo blizzards, I would agree that you can never have too many cans of creamed corn in the pantry.
True, the apocalypse may never come. But remember that preparing for it has yielded numerous contributions to society. It was the Adventists' interest in alternative diets and millennial bodily perfection, for instance, that led them to invent three food pillars of modern life: peanut butter, graham crackers and cold breakfast cereal.
So it's not all gloom and doom. Many prophecies are very optimistic. Just ask the pastor of the First Church of Elvis. This "Presleyterian" denomination predicts that the singer will make his second coming at the end of the millennium.
 
Questions about investing, careers and personal finance can be sent to Minding Your Business, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York 10036. Or they may be sent by E-mail to yourmind@nytimes.com. Questions can be answered only in the column, not by mail, E-mail or telephone.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
In the Megamerger Parade, Banks May March in Front

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
DESPITE the breathtaking size and scope of the proposed merger of Citicorp and the Travelers Group, the deal merely punctuates a reality of the financial services industry: The urge to merge is real, and will remain that way for some time to come.
For investors in bank, brokerage or mutual fund stocks, the consolidation wave is the ultimate payoff for backing businesses that in the main have been outstanding performers for much of the 1990's. 
 But because the industry's fundamentals continue to look so good, it is hard to predict who may merge next.
"For an investor, it is sort of a futile activity, because every major transaction has surprised the market," said Sallie Krawcheck, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
But speaking broadly, many analysts say banks will be doing the bulk of the buying.
"They have the size, the money, the customers, the branches and the technology," said Michael W. Blumstein, an insurance company analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. "They are coming to the party with much more than most of the other players."
Moreover, while the Citicorp-Travelers deal signals that virtually all financial services businesses are fair game, some sectors may see less takeover activity. While some analysts disagree, for example, many say that banks are unlikely to want to buy insurers.
"I don't think a lot of commercial banks have the appetite to get into the insurance underwriting business," said David Berry, research director at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a bank-stock research firm in New York. "There is a lot of volatility in areas like property and casualty. Selling insurance is one thing. Underwriting it is something else."
Even if a big bank wanted to buy an insurance company, many of the biggest are off limits because they are owned by policyholders, not stock investors. (A number of these mutual companies, however, including John Hancock Mutual, Metropolitan Life and New York Life, are considering public offerings.)
Even as they acknowledge that more mergers are coming, analysts said the pace could slow early next year, as possible year-2000 computer problems approach.
"Many banks we talk to suggest that by year-end or early in 1999 they would not feel comfortable making an acquisition because of the time needed to integrate computer systems," said Frank J. Barkocy, a managing director at Josephthal & Company.
What about insurers as buyers? At the moment, they seem content to pursue mergers within their own industry in order to increase market share and economies of scale, and to shed businesses in markets where they lack a major presence.
Beyond citing these general patterns, Ms. Krawcheck, Mr. Blumstein and other analysts declined to predict who might merge with whom. But some, including Mr. Berry and Mr. Barkocy, were not quite so shy.
Here are the companies they like.
 
James K. Schmitt
Portfolio manager, Hancock Regional Bank fund and Hancock Financial Industries fund
Mr. Schmitt, whose funds have assets of $7.5 billion and $3.4 billion, respectively, buys stocks he sees as both solid performers and sensible takeover targets.
"There will be consolidation in two directions," he said. "Banks will combine in what I call battleground states like Alabama, Tennessee and California, where a few banks have significant market share and the superregionals are not omnipresent. And we will see banks buying the remaining brokerage firms."
His regional bank fund owns Alabama institutions like Regions Financial and Amsouth Bancorp. His holdings among Tennessee banks include First Tennessee National, Union Planters and First American of Tennessee. In California he owns several smaller institutions like City National and the Westamerica Bancorporation.
Brokerage firms with underwriting capability, like Lehman Brothers and Donaldson Lufkin Jenrette, would be particularly attractive to banks, he said. So, too, would regional brokerages like Legg Mason and Raymond James.
Mr. Schmitt, whose Regional Bank and Financial Industries funds were up 56.4 percent and 58.5 percent, respectively, for the last 12 months, said he does not turn over his holdings much.
"In the last few years, there have been few fundamental reasons to sell a bank stock," he said.
 
David Berry
Research director, Keefe, Bruyette & Woods
Mr. Berry said he was intrigued by the possibilities of three big superregional bank deals: US Bancorp with Wells Fargo, First Chicago with Banc One and Nationsbank with BankAmerica.
"From our perspective, Wells Fargo looks like a seller," he said. "They have disappointed investors since the First Interstate deal, they have no forward revenue momentum and, notwithstanding their problems, they are very shareholder-friendly."
Mr. Berry likes First Chicago as an acquisition target because of its prized assets: a strong credit card business, a leading presence in Chicago and a solid middle-market banking business in the Midwest.
Because of its location, Banc One is the most logical buyer for First Chicago, he said. But he would not rule out Nationsbank or BankAmerica as potential buyers.
Finally, "if you want to get really big, a combination of BankAmerica and Nationsbank would meet that criteria," Mr. Berry said. "It has a lot of the same characteristics as the Citicorp-Travelers deal."
Referring to the acquisitive chairman of Nationsbank, Mr. Barry added that "if you are Hugh McColl and are interested in being a major player in the consolidation of American banking, a merger with an institution like BankAmerica has to look interesting."
 
Frank J. Barkocy
Managing director, Josephthal & Company
Like Mr. Schmitt, Mr. Barkocy said the shrinking number of prize properties in certain parts of the country was likely to accelerate consolidation in the banking industry. The same logic applies to brokerage firms and investment banks, he said.
Among banks, he said, he likes Summit Bancorp in New Jersey, Mercantile Bancorp in Missouri and Hibernia in Louisiana.
"They are the largest independent banks remaining in those states," he said.
Closer to home, he said, a number of Long Island savings institutions are having difficulty in increasing revenues because of "fairly compact" customer bases. These institutions are likely to be acquired by larger ones, he maintained.
"Greenpoint Savings, Dime Savings and some other New York banks will be looking at names like Rosyln Bancorp and Haven Bancorp," he said.
