SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 915 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
At the Bull-Market Party, Distributions Cause a Hangover

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
APRIL is a month for cruel surprises. And if you're a late tax filer just getting ready to tear into your mutual fund's distributions statement for 1997, you may very well be in for a big one.
Mutual funds paid out a record $334.1 billion in distributions for 1997, mostly from capital gains, and shareholders whose holdings are not invested through tax-deferred accounts will pay the I.R.S. accordingly. But not all of those billions flowed to long-term investors who had earned them over the years. Some were nasty side effects -- a result of changes in fund administration. 
 The Berger 100 fund, for example, paid out 34.1 percent of its assets to shareholders after a new portfolio manager cleared out many of his predecessor's holdings. GE Mid-Cap B, created out of a predecessor mutual fund through a merger and reorganization, distributed an even higher portion of assets -- 45.2 percent. And both Delaware U.S. Growth and HSBC Growth and Income realized gains of about 40 percent when they had to sell stock to meet huge redemptions.
The bottom line is that investors could have lost much of their profit to taxes. A $10,000 investment in a fund that delivered total returns of 15 percent would have lifted its owner's assets to $11,500. But if the fund distributed 25 percent of those assets, or $2,875, as capital gains, the tax bill for an investor could be as much as 28 percent, or $805. That would slash the return by more than half.
In fact, nearly 50 mutual funds paid distributions in 1997 equal to 25 percent or more of their assets. For investors who bought their shares during the year, the results were basically a return of their capital, but with Uncle Sam taking a bite.
"A lot of mutual funds are a lot less tax-friendly than most people would think," said Amy Arnott, editor of the Morningstar Mutual Funds newsletter.
No kidding. Last year's distributions were mammoth. Stock and bond funds paid out $130.5 billion in ordinary dividends, up from $73.7 billion in 1996, according to the Investment Company Institute, the industry's trade group. Capital gains payments more than doubled, to $203.6 billion from $101.1 billion the previous year, itself a record.
Of course, 1997 was no ordinary year. It was the third consecutive year of double-digit growth in capital gains, meaning funds had plenty of them on hand. It was also a time of continuing consolidation, when funds acquired one another and merged portfolios to make them more economical to manage.
To make matters worse, the market happened to correct in October, just before the end of many funds' fiscal years. "Some funds had to sell securities to meet redemptions, which made them end up realizing more gains than they otherwise would have," Ms. Arnott said.
Often, shareholders learn well in advance that their funds will reorganize, usually because of a change in management.
Berger 100 had fallen from industry leader to also-ran over a period of years under Rod Linafelter, an iconoclastic manager who left the fund early last year. Berger recruited Patrick Adams, a growth-stock manager formerly with Founders Funds, to overhaul the portfolio. It was no surprise that Mr. Adams would make plenty of changes.
In the case of the Investors Trust Value fund, shareholders had to approve the portfolio's acquisition last fall by GE Funds of Stamford, Conn., which subsequently merged it into a new portfolio, GE Mid-Cap, and installed a new manager.
"We went on a very aggressive campaign to notify shareholders of impending capital gains distributions," said Mary Stone, manager of shareholder services for GE Investment Management, the fund's adviser. "Normally we have very low turnover on our funds."
Shareholders also had to approve the conversion of a closed-end fund, Quest for Value Dual Purpose Fund Capital Shares, into the open-end Oppenheimer Quest Capital Value. When they did, "more than half of the portfolio securities were sold to meet shareholder redemptions," said Greg Stitt, a spokesman for Oppenheimer.
But a huge tax bill can be a quite unexpected side effect. After the Lincoln National Corporation bought Delaware Investments in 1995, it put the Delaware name on its own Lincoln U.S. Growth Portfolio. In 1997 Lincoln withdrew roughly $18.2 million, representing funds it had used to seed that portfolio several years earlier, as well as investment profits. Shareholders were stuck with the tax bill when a third of the fund's portfolio was sold to meet the redemption.
Taxes are an inevitable consequence of successful investing, and many mutual funds have built up very significant unrealized capital gains. Some investment advisers recommend unmanaged index funds because they seldom distribute big gains, but such funds are just as vulnerable to redemptions as actively managed portfolios.
"The tax liability built up in these funds is huge," said Cindy Bohlen, a research analyst with Marshall Funds in Milwaukee. "If you ever start to see money exiting those funds, watch out."
What is a tax-sensitive investor to do? Peter Brown, a principal of Evensky, Brown, Katz & Levitt, a financial planning firm in Coral Gables, Fla., said the best protection against being blindsided by oversized capital gains distributions is to buy funds that have just made them. "They've probably wiped out all the puff in their portfolios, and going forward it's going to be a long time before investors get hit with taxable distributions," he said.

HEADLINE: A Land Giant Is Stirring. Will Florida Ever Be the Same?

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.

 BODY:
REAL estate development in Florida conjures up visions of Eden gone awry. Over the last century, the state's subtropical environment has been battered by an onslaught of tourist attractions, billboards, strip shopping centers, beachfront condominiums and featureless subdivisions that have drained the wetlands and scarred the landscape. Planning has been haphazard and sometimes completely absent.
Now, the St. Joe Corporation, the quirky public company that is Florida's largest private landholder, insists that it intends to break with that pattern as it develops a million acres in the panhandle, some of the last pristine tracts in this state. 
 The stakes are high, both for Florida's future and for St. Joe shareholders -- the latter primarily a duPont family trust that supports clinics for the elderly and disabled, though Wall Street, too, is beginning to take an interest in a company that it long could comfortably ignore.
For decades, St. Joe was an undermanaged holding company with assets in timber, transportation and banking that fed the trust in dribs and drabs. But all that changed a year ago when Peter S. Rummell was hired away from the Walt Disney Company to become St. Joe's chief executive, chairman and in-house rabble-rouser.
"I felt a little like I'd stepped into a time warp," said Mr. Rummell, who was head of Disney's theme park and real estate development divisions. When he first asked for an overview of St. Joe's holdings, Mr. Rummell recalled, he was given a yellowed Esso gas-station map so old that it did not show Interstate 95, the main highway down Florida's east coast. Today, a large studio on the ground floor of St. Joe's headquarters here houses a research and development center with huge satellite photos delineating the company's land.
"You don't see this quantity of assets that have been maintained so conservatively for so long," Mr. Rummell said.
After a year spent assessing those assets and importing a team of outside managers, Mr. Rummell has begun to carry out an ambitious plan with social implications that could ripple across Florida -- and perhaps beyond.
In the coming decade, St. Joe intends to open up resort and residential development not on the east or west coasts of the state but along the panhandle, which despite its white-sand beaches on the Gulf of Mexico has lagged behind in growth and prosperity.
The company's holdings in the region include 30 miles of frontage on the gulf and 250 miles on inland waterways and lakes. The centerpiece of the proposed development is a series of planned communities, resorts and retirement centers that would transform not only St. Joe's vast tracts but also the panhandle itself.
Rather than the high-rise beachfront condominiums and bland retirement villages that are the hallmarks of Florida, St. Joe wants to build places that are more walkable and human-scaled -- shaped around the environment instead of ignoring or damaging it. The models are not Miami Beach or Fort Myers but the more recent communities of Seaside and Celebration. St. Joe's towns are intended, too, to reshape Florida's demographics, by appealing to families and job seekers, not just the retirees who have been the primary targets of Florida developers in the past.
All this is risky, of course. Undeveloped land is the most volatile of real estate assets, and Merrill Lynch -- which recently began following St. Joe -- estimates that 35 percent of the company's value is in vacant land. So any significant downturn in the state or national economy could poke a big hole in Mr. Rummell's balloon.
Plus, there are good reasons that the panhandle has been slow to develop. Transportation into the region is weak, making it difficult to attract visitors beyond a day's drive away. There are few hospitals or clinics -- vital for the second-home and retirement markets -- and not enough of the good schools essential to attracting permanent residents. To outsiders, the area is probably best known for replacing Daytona Beach as Florida's No. 1 destination for hard-drinking college students on spring break.
But Mr. Rummell has assets beyond his own experience and St. Joe's vast acreage, which is only slightly smaller than the state of Delaware. The company's balance sheet is debt free. The trust has given him a green light to shake up St. Joe's stolid status quo. He has already made a key acquisition -- a controlling interest in the Arvida Company, which built Boca Raton and many of Florida's more uncharacteristically charming planned communities and will build most of the houses on St. Joe's panhandle lands.
"If we are smart about it -- if we are methodical but aggressive -- it is a huge opportunity," Mr. Rummell said. "We have an opportunity to create a very special kind of region."
 
Roots in Rebellion
St. Joe may have been a sleepy business for decades, but Mr. Rummell is not its first rebel.
The company was founded by Alfred I. duPont, the black sheep of the Delaware family that grew rich selling gunpowder in World War I. He battled other family members for control of the business and caused a social ruckus in 1921 when, at 57, he married Jessie Ball, who was 21 years his junior.
But it was not social ostracism that drove Mr. duPont south; it was business. A cousin and rival, Pierre duPont, became Delaware's tax commissioner and promised to make the rich pay their fair share. When a tax deputy came calling to review Cousin Alfred's accounts, he was turned away.
"I'll be damned if I'm going to have Pierre going over my books," Alfred duPont snapped, according to a published family history. Instead, he transferred all his assets into Florida corporations and, with his bride, moved to Jacksonville in 1926.
While the rest of the country was enjoying prosperity that year, Florida was suffering from the effects of a devastating hurricane and collapsed real estate prices. Mr. duPont, with a personal fortune of $70 million to $200 million, took advantage of the situation and bought large tracts of land for just a few dollars an acre, particularly in the panhandle.
In a single transaction in 1933, he bought 240,000 acres, including virtually the entire town of Port St. Joe on the gulf. The deal included two railroads, some telephone companies and a paper mill that eventually gave the whole enterprise its name: the St. Joe Paper Company.
Mr. duPont died in 1935, leaving the bulk of his holdings in trust for the benefit of his wife; after her death in 1970, the proceeds of the trust were designated to help disabled children and the elderly.
Through the trust, control of the company fell to Mr. duPont's brother-in-law, Edward Ball, a pugnacious man who ruled with the firm hand of an autocrat. He added to St. Joe's land holdings and expanded its bank, Florida National, into the state's largest.
Mr. Ball acquired the Florida East Coast Railway Company, the historic line that runs from Jacksonville to Key West and defined migration to Florida's east coast.
St. Joe's rich lore contains a story, probably apocryphal, about an encounter in the early 1960's between Mr. Ball and Walt Disney. As part of his quiet search for land to build a new theme park in the wake of Disneyland's success, Mr. Disney supposedly inquired about the possibility of buying a chunk of St. Joe's panhandle holdings.
"We don't deal with carnival people," Mr. Ball is said to have replied -- forever altering the course of Florida land development and leaving intact the domain now being prepared for development by Mr. Rummell, the former executive with Disney.
Mr. Ball died in 1981, but control of the company remained with the Alfred I. duPont Testamentary Trust, which as recently as 1990 owned 86 percent of St. Joe. (Its holdings now amount to about 55 percent of the company.)
The beneficiary of the trust, the Nemours Foundation, was allotted 3 percent of the trust's market value each year to run clinics in Florida and Delaware.
Only in the early 1990's, after representatives of the trust, Florida officials and outside investors began to demand that it produce more income, did change begin to shake St. Joe.
To focus on real estate, the company put other assets up for sale, including the namesake pulp and paper mills, container plants and most of the phone business. A deal is pending for the Federal Government to buy a sugar plantation in the Everglades as part of a conservation program.
In 1996, the company was renamed the St. Joe Corporation, and a headhunter was hired to find someone to run it.
 
Real Estate Man Returns
Peter Rummell was 51 when St. Joe came knocking. As chairman of Walt Disney Imagineering, he oversaw the development of a wide range of Disney projects, from Euro Disney outside Paris to Celebration, the company's new planned community in central Florida. He had an especially strong relationship with Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of Disney.
Mr. Rummell started out as a developer in the early 1970's, working on Amelia Island Plantation near Jacksonville for the Sea Pines Company. He also worked for Arvida and spent two years as vice chairman of the Rockefeller Center Management Corporation in New York before returning in 1985 to Arvida, which had been acquired by Disney. He soon moved to the Disney side of the corporate aisle; Arvida was eventually sold.
At heart, though, Mr. Rummell is a real estate man, he says, and Disney is an entertainment company. So in January 1997 he accepted the invitation of the St. Joe board to try to reinvent the company -- and real estate development in Florida.
Besides the acquisition of Arvida, his early moves have included deploying stock options and bonus incentives, previously unheard of at the staid St. Joe, to attract a new team of senior managers. Charles A. Ledsinger Jr. was brought in as chief financial officer from Harrah's Entertainment Inc.; he recently became president and chief operating officer. Two former Disney executives, Robert M. Rhodes and Michael F. Bayer, also took senior management positions.
Mr. Rummell got a good deal for himself, too. His base salary in 1997 was $600,000, with a performance-based incentive bonus that added $300,000. He also received $5 million worth of St. Joe stock to compensate him for the value of stock options he forfeited by leaving Disney. Plus, he received stock options that, if the company's stock rises an average of 10 percent a year for the next decade, would be worth $123 million. (Since Mr. Rummell signed on, the stock is up about 60 percent; St. Joe shares ended the week at $33.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.)
His immediate task, though, is to start enough real estate projects fast enough to satisfy Wall Street that St. Joe has the cash flow to be a good investment now, not just years from now when its big developments come on line.
Toward that end, the company, borrowing a page from Disney, has branched into the entertainment business. Its most significant deal is with the National Football League, to develop interactive entertainment centers that will include technology-based games, retail stores and restaurants in an atmosphere similar to that of a football stadium. Tentatively called NFLX, the first of the 7 to 10 ventures is expected to open late next year in New York, possibly in Times Square.
But the real test for St. Joe will be developing its hundreds of thousands of acres in northwest Florida over the coming decade in a way that provides long-term value for its shareholders and long-term benefits for the state.
 
Expanding a Beachhead
One model for what Mr. Rummell has in mind sits squarely in the midst of some of St. Joe's most valuable land. St. Joe did not build Seaside and will not duplicate it, but the company's plans are taking some of their inspiration from the 240-home village surrounded by St. Joe's panhandle real estate.
Seaside, about 20 miles west of Panama City, is the beachhead for neotraditional town planning. Probably no other 80-acre strip of land in America has been so scrutinized and analyzed in the last decade as its picturesque collection of homes, built since 1981.
The houses are, by regulation, wood-shingled and clapboard, with deep front porches and whimsical cupolas. But the changes exemplified by Seaside are more fundamental than architecture. They go to scale and to the way people live. The streets are narrow, putting a premium on walking. The town is organized around a center with shops and galleries. While there are a few houses directly on the gulf, which is across the road from the main part of town, walkovers and other devices are intended to open the beach to all residents.
A stroll through Seaside uncovers the real gold mine envisioned by St. Joe. It is largely a second-home community, and the signs outside most houses are hand-lettered with the names and hometowns of its residents: Atlanta; Memphis; New Orleans, Birmingham, Ala. These are the population centers, all within a day's drive, that St. Joe hopes will provide vacationers and second-home buyers for its first large development, tentatively called Seagrove.
"There is this wide arc that goes into Texas, up to Memphis and north of Atlanta, and the people within that arc are used to coming here," said Timothy D. Edmond, the Arvida vice president who is supervising the planning for Seagrove. "And, looking at Seaside, we know they have money to spend on second homes."
Seagrove has 1,400 feet of beautiful beach frontage on the gulf and 500 acres that wrap around Seaside. The first phase calls for a resort hotel more expensive and luxurious than anything in the region, some retail space and a beach club on the gulf side of the property. Vacation and retirement homes will follow on the other side of the road, winding along a freshwater lake and behind Seaside.
Master planning has already begun, and Mr. Edmond said the process of receiving governmental approvals was expected to be completed next year.
But that may be optimistic. Florida's development rules have become tougher in the last decade; here, as in other places transformed by breakneck growth, environmental concerns can cause delays in even the most environment-friendly projects.
"Some people don't like to see big, beautiful tracts of land developed," noted Paul F. Bryan, the Orlando-based president of LaSalle Partners Development, a unit of a Chicago real estate firm.
St. Joe's long-range plan is to get people to come to Seagrove for a vacation or convention, like what they see and decide to return, first in a vacation home and then as retirees. The theory is that once the place finds its center of gravity, services will follow that attract permanent residents.
Mr. Rummell acknowledges the work ahead. The region, for example, needs better medical services. "If you are 65 years old and you've started going to a cardiologist routinely," he said, "we have to make you comfortable that you can get quality care close to your home."
There are also plans to expand at least one runway at the nearby Panama City airport, which now can handle only short-hop aircraft, and discussions about a major feeder highway.
Local government is quite welcoming. Seagrove is in Walton County, a thousand square miles stretching from the Alabama border to the gulf. Except for the beachfront, the county is sparsely populated and generally eager for the jobs and prosperity promised by new development.
"A lot of the most valuable land has been purchased for preservation by the state, so it's off the tax rolls," said Tom Powell, executive director of the nonprofit Walton County Economic Development Council. "The county government realizes that its salvation is in the development of the remaining existing land."
Nowhere is the warmth of St. Joe's relationship with government more evident than southeast of Tallahassee, the state capital, where the company is planning Southwood, which it envisions as a neotraditional community of 12,000 people and 6,000 new homes on 3,200 acres of rolling land now covered with pine trees and dotted with lakes and ponds.
In a speech early this month in Tallahassee, Mr. Rummell offered free land for a future medical school under consideration by state legislators and promised to help improve roads in the surrounding county. "Others may build developments," he told the Economic Club of Florida. "We build towns."
The first public hearing on the project is scheduled for July. Already, though, the company has been meeting regularly with state and local officials and citizens groups.
State officials praised the willingness of St. Joe management to negotiate over the most sensitive issues, including affordable housing -- something that its predecessors never did in previous stabs at developing the land and a far cry from the days when Ed Ball dictated terms to Florida lawmakers.
"The old St. Joe categorically rejected providing affordable housing, and that's why they left town and never did the development," said Jim Murley, secretary of the Florida Department of Community Affairs. "The new management is doing education and housing and all the things that are important, not only for Southwood but for the region."
Mr. Rummell is convinced that there is money to be made in Florida with a kinder, gentler type of development. He says he does not foresee a Disney-like theme park or an Orlando-like megalopolis in western Florida. Instead, he envisions a series of towns and communities where people of all ages and economic means live in proximity. Rather than cutting off beach views with high-rise condominiums, he wants to build low-rise hotels and beach clubs that offer permanent access to residents who do not live on the beach.
"I think it's the right location at the right time," he said. "We can change the story of Florida development if we do it right."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1517 words

HEADLINE: The World: East and Eden;
America Is Prosperous and Smug, Like Japan Was

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
COMPARING Japan's raw hubris in the late 1980's and America's in the late 90's has become the latest international parlor game. To economic forecasters, dispensers of global-sounding sound bites and nervous investors -- and who isn't nervous? -- the eerie similarities are a reminder of what can happen when boom times beget a boom psychology. First, Americans were sounding more and more like the Japanese did in late 1989, just before they reached the mountaintop and blindly stepped into the void. Now, by some measures, Americans are beginning to act like them too.
The Japan of 1989 was not only a place of booming Ferrari sales and lavish corporate entertainment, it was a place where expectations of limitless economic success washed over serious discussion of the economy's weaknesses. Bigger was always equated with "more global" -- and size alone was thought to be enough to immunize businesses, and the country, from bad decisions. Now Japan's biggest banks own the world's most globalized collection of bad debt, which has crippled the country's economy. 
 The America of 1998 is similarly a place of boundless confidence and rationalizations for ever-rising markets. It is also a place where many economic red flags -- in this case, low savings rates, income disparities, rising trade deficits -- are often lost in the din of the boom. And when Citicorp and Travelers Group explained the merits of their mega-merger last week, there were echoes of Japan's old logic -- bigger, the new partners said, meant more global.
 
Myths
 Of course, comparisons between the Japan of a decade ago and America today, however tempting, must be made with considerable care. Japan's boom created national myths like the one that the land under the Imperial Palace in Tokyo was worth more than all of Florida. It's a matter of debate whether America's boom is inflating such a bubble of overconfidence. But as anyone who lived in Tokyo then and lives in America now can testify, this country's economic strengths today run considerably deeper than Japan's ever did.
In the 80's and 90's, the United States endured a wave of downsizing, job-shifting and retooling that the Japanese put off and put off, convinced they could muddle through. "The structural differences, the sophistication of the American financial markets, are now so great that the economies are no longer easy to compare," said Jeffrey Garten, the dean of the Yale School of Management. But he warned that "every country at the top of its economic cycle grows enamored of its own system."
There is a lot of that in the air. As the Dow toyed with the 9,000 milestone last week, even one of the President's economic advisers found himself repeating the old saw that "the four most dangerous words in an ever-rising stock market are, 'It's different this time.' " And like Japan in the 80's, the United States has an astounding capability to preach the need for economic reform abroad while missing opportunities to do exactly that when times are prosperous at home.
Remember America's low personal savings rate, one of the favorite explanations for why rich Japan was lending money around the world and America was mired in debt? It's gotten worse: Americans saved 5.5 percent of their disposable income a decade ago, and 3.8 percent last year. The Japanese, astounding as it sounds, are actually saving more than ever, fearful that tomorrow morning that "lifetime job" could turn into very early retirement. (Tellingly, though, more Japanese are putting the money in personal safes, because they doubt the solvency of their own banks.)
 
Old Habits
 And remember those evil American trade deficits? This year they will break almost all records. In part, that is because Asian nations have stopped buying American goods, while desperately shipping stuff here to export their way out of their troubles.
But those numbers also suggest that America may not have improved its productivity as dramatically as some believe. Even with the recent rise in the value of the dollar, it's not clear why America should be running trade deficits at all.
To pay for all its imports, America is still borrowing abroad -- even from the Japanese, who would much rather have their money earn 5 percent here than 0.5 percent at home. In 1990, when borrowing foreign cash to buy foreign goods was decried as evidence of national weakness, about $458 billion in Treasury securities belonged to non-Americans. Today, the figure has risen to $1.2 trillion. But in the happy glow of the American boom, this is now interpreted as a sign of global confidence in the American economy.
"This is classic economic euphoria," says Laura D'Andrea Tyson, former head of the national economic council. "In prosperous times we overstate the good and understate the bad."
Her old boss, President Clinton, gingerly began to warn against this tendency last week, saying it's time "to bear down and do more in the good times, not to relax and pat ourselves on the back." But his grand national gab-a-thon about how to save the Social Security system, which began last week, may not be enough to lift Congress out of its ideological swamp.
The Japanese sidestepped lots of tough problems in the 80's as well, back when it was unimaginable that the chairman of Sony would warn, as he did recently, that the Japanese economy is "on the verge of collapse." Perhaps the biggest lesson of Japan's bitter decade is that it's a lot more expensive to fix an economy in recession than when it's running on autopilot.
Just look at the opening of Japan's huge securities and financial services markets to the likes of Fidelity, Goldman, Sachs and Citibank -- the so-called "Big Bang" that was delayed at the insistence of Japan's financial industry back when Japan bestrode the world.
The day finally arrived two weeks ago. But if the Japanese opened the financial market a decade ago, when money was everywhere, they could have spent billions to build software systems and lure world-class talent to take on Wall Street. Now, desperately trying to avoid bankruptcy, they don't have the cash to compete with the arriving foreign hordes.
 
Buying Out Japan
 Worse yet, the foreigners are buying out failed Japanese institutions. Merrill Lynch has snapped up the retail operations -- and the experienced employees -- of the failed Yamaichi Securities Company, a giant brokerage that collapsed last year. Other American companies are now trying to persuade rich, elderly Japanese that the best place for their money is in mutual funds that invest outside their own country. It's a tough sell in small towns in Kyushu, but it's beginning to work.
Amid all the American triumphalism about the demise of the Japanese model, though, there's a lot of politics under way in Washington that sounds familiar to anyone who has hung out in the corridors of the Japan's once-mighty Finance Ministry.
For sheer audacity, it is hard to match the Citicorp-Travelers merger. It is clearly forbidden by the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act, designed to keep financial institutions from mingling federally insured bank deposits with Wall Street trading.
No one doubts that those laws need to be updated; they were designed to build protective walls for small-town banks like the one George Bailey ran in "It's a Wonderful Life," not the 24-hour global behemoths of currency swaps and derivatives. And since 1979, Congress has been frozen in place, sucking in campaign contributions from all the interest groups with billions riding on how the bills are tweaked. Citicorp even helped kill a bill two weeks ago that would have enabled the very kind of merger it is now trying to complete. But by announcing the merger and then insisting that Congress make it legal, Citicorp and Travelers are attempting to make Congress pass a bill that fits the deal.
Maybe that will finally break the logjam. But even Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, noted the irony last week that Congress is under pressure "to weaken our traditional barrier to combinations of commerce and banking, precisely the practice in Asia and elsewhere that we rail against as a major source of institutional weakness."
Japan is a testament to the risks of getting the mix wrong. Its banks rose on their holdings in the Japanese stock market, which emboldened them to lend money for wildly overpriced land deals. Then the stock market collapsed, the real estate market followed, the loans went bad and the banks ceased lending -- putting the Japanese economy into a seven-year-long deep freeze.
The Government is now pumping in taxpayer money to help the banks get rid of $600 billion in bad loans. It spent untold billions last month trying to buck up the stock market, and just announced a $76 billion emergency spending program that is probably not enough to revive the moribund economy.
So maybe, amid Washington's celebrations, it's worth getting some Congressional testimony from a laid-off Japanese bank executive or two. They certainly have time on their hands.

Japan's revered bureaucrats send missions throughout Asia teaching neighbors how to replicate the Japanese model of capitalism. The country's huge banks, awash in cash, extend their global reach with huge loans abroad, and Finance Ministry regulators ease the rules over midnight karaoke with the bankers in Tokyo's hostess bars. Restaurants sprinkle sushi with gold leaf. Japanese leaders warn that America's lazy workers and huge budget deficits are dragging down the world economy.

Citicorp and Travelers announce a mega-merger to extend their global reach -- but first they make courtesy calls to the Treasury Secretary and the President, because the deal violates laws separating banks, brokerages and insurance. The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: April 12, 1998

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3363 words

HEADLINE: Old Places, New Faces

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
SATURDAY is not Nathilee Caldeira's Sabbath, yet she feels a certain reverence for the day. As Orthodox Jews dressed for worship walk to synagogues, she and other blacks in the neighborhood go about their business. They do so with an understanding that it is a sacred day. "Somehow on Saturdays, nobody really gets crazy," she said.
Sunday is Ms. Caldeira's Sabbath. Her West Indian and African-American neighbors dress for church and walk to bus stops. The Orthodox Jews go about their business, she said, but with a similarly respectful air, a certain mutedness. "It is understood between the communities," said Ms. Caldeira, 29, a research assistant at a hospital. 
 She and the Jews in her neighborhood are not friends, she said -- "There is no contact" -- but there is no tension either. "The media make such a hullabaloo about relations between Jews and blacks," she said, "but it actually runs quite smoothly." The focus of that hullabalo, of course, is Crown Heights, but that is not where Ms. Caldeira lives. Since she and her family arrived from Guyana a decade ago, they have made their home in a less scrutinized, more southern pocket of Brooklyn, between Midwood and Flatlands, in a triangle bounded by Nostrand Avenue to the west, Flatbush Avenue to the east and Kings Highway to the south.
Around them, "For Sale" signs sprout like spring daffodils, signposts of a continuing, quiet departure of Italians, Irish and secular Jews over the last decade, reflecting an exodus seen throughout southern Brooklyn. In Ms. Caldeira's neighborhood, their places are being taken mostly by West Indians seeking homes in quiet, stable communities and by Orthodox Jews crowded or priced out of Midwood.
In other neighborhoods, the trail of newcomers is similar, whether the settlers are recent immigrants or Orthodox Jews seeking more space for their growing families. They want housing: affordable starter homes for some, larger upgrades for others. And they end up colonizing new neighborhoods. Even working- and middle-class blacks, still kept out of many neighborhoods by an invisible color line, are settling in previously impenetrable terrain. The result is new ethnic enclaves in some places and new hybrid communities in others.
The old-timers in neighborhoods like Bay Ridge, Bensonhurst and Sheepshead Bay will tell you that the local stalwarts, the Irish and Italians, are departing for other shores -- New Jersey, Staten Island, Long Island or upstate New York. Real estate agents say the same thing. "At this end of Brooklyn," said Anthony Nasti, the president of Coldwell Banker Mid Plaza, "there are not a large number of second-time home buyers."
In the past, blacks most likely would have filled the places left by vacating whites. That is what happened in the 60's and 70's in neighborhoods farther east like Brownsville and East New York. But in southern Brooklyn in the 1990's the immigrants filling the void left by whites are mainly Russian and Chinese; some are Hispanic or Arab. Immigrants, Mr. Nasti said, make up about half the home buyers he sees. Most are Russians, whose ranks grew to an estimated 6.7 percent of the borough's population in 1996 from 3.2 percent in 1991, according to Department of Housing Preservation and Development -- the largest increase among any population group.
Brighton Beach realtors say there are typically five applicants for every empty apartment, and many Russians have left Brighton Beach behind. A swelling middle class is buying homes in Manhattan Beach, Sheepshead Bay, Bay Ridge and Bensonhurst, among other neighborhoods.
"Middle-class working Russian immigrants are probably the hungriest for the American way, and the fastest learners of it," Mr. Nasti said. "They are making investments in real estate."
The Russians are also pushing north into Midwood, where they are filling apartments, buying homes and establishing businesses along Ocean Avenue and Coney Island Avenue, mostly south of where a sizeable Pakistani community has done the same thing. The Pakistanis, too, are buying homes and pushing their boundaries north and east, along Church Avenue.
The Orthodox and Sephardic Jewish communities, who have long had a beachhead in Midwood, are growing rapidly as well. Their close-knit families cluster around synagogues and yeshivas, and their prosperity is evident in real estate. Along Bedford Avenue and on surrounding streets, the Jews are not just buying but building: renovating and expanding already large homes and even tearing down some homes and building bigger ones on the lots.
"Palatial is the only word I can use to describe it," said Alvin Berk, the chairman of Community Board 14, speaking of houses that filled back-to-back lots on Bedford Avenue and on parallel streets. And Orthodox Jews are expanding the boundaries of the neighborhood, pushing westward past Ocean Parkway or eastward past Nostrand Avenue.
All these groups -- Pakistanis, Russians, ultra-Orthodox, Hasidic and Sephardic Jews -- are advancing northward, along McDonald Avenue, Ocean Parkway, Coney Island Avenue and the streets in between. A Muslim center is being built on Cortelyou Road between East 16th and 17th Streets, and Bangladeshi businesses are opening around the intersection of Church and McDonald Avenues. Ultra-Orthodox and Sephardic Jews are moving north on Ocean Parkway as well.
And the ranks of Russian residents in Flatbush and Kensington are growing as well, as the recent opening of a Russian bath on Coney Island Avenue between Cortelyou Road and Avenue C reflects. Slowly, the Russians are diversifying the edges of Caribbean and African-American areas.
"On Church Avenue, you're seeing white faces, and a lot are Russian," said Francois Pierre-Louis, a Haitian-American who directs the Community Action Project, a church-based group in Flatbush. "You never would have seen that a few years ago."
 
Loving Lox but Missing The Italian Butcher
 All over Brooklyn's southern different languages can be heard, and different cultures and customs observed. An Italian baker who has lived in Bay Ridge his whole life, pondering the departure of many longtime customers for Staten Island, struggles to identify just where the "dark people" come from. He is referring to the area's more recently arrived Arabs, and he expresses bafflement at the kinds of breads they bake.
Farther north, Yolanda Lawrence considers the changes that have come since she bought a co-op at the northern end of Ocean Parkway 12 years ago. She moved into a neighborhood whose residents were mainly elderly Jews. No problem. Ms. Lawrence, who is black, said she loves lox and loves having her hair set for $17 with the "little old Jewish ladies" at the beauty parlor around the corner. The mix on her hallway -- elderly black and Jewish people, interracial couples, young white and black professionals like herself -- has been just right, she says.
But the elderly are moving out or dying, and taking their place are immigrants. Many are Russian, some are Caribbean, others are Indian, Pakistani or Bangladeshi; some are from Hispanic groups.
It amuses Ms. Lawrence, for now, that a local store carries birthday cards in Russian but not English. But she misses Carmine the Italian butcher and his gourmet cheeses. Carmine, she said, was replaced by halal and kosher competitors. And she dislikes having to go to Park Slope to buy chives because nearby storekeepers no longer stock them.
When Ms. Lawrence bought her co-op, she recalls, the board of her building examined her finances closely. So she wonders how a family of 12, recently discovered living in one apartment in the building, managed to bypass such screening. She is angry that someone is peeling the wallpaper in the hallways.
Ms. Lawrence, who works in sales in Manhattan, plans to keep an eye on things. She says that if "undesirables" continue to move into her building -- and if more local stores start stocking borscht instead of basil -- she may eventually move out. She is watching for what sociologists call "tipping."
Ms. Lawrence is an example of a new variation on an old phenomenon: a black woman watching to see how people of different ethnic and socio-economic backgrounds reshape her neighborhood.
Yet she knows that in many neighborhoods, particularly to the south, she is still the one who would be watched.
In Brooklyn, moving up the economic ladder has meant in part moving south toward the water. But except for Community District 13, which contains the largely black Coney Island and Marlboro public housing projects, a tiny proportion of blacks have historically breached Brooklyn's southern districts.
"The racial line of black/white has remained much much much stronger than the person-of-color line," said Philip Kasinitz, an associate professor of sociology at CUNY, comparing the relative ease with which Hispanic and Asians have moved into certain neighborhoods with the difficulties encountered by many blacks. The exception, Mr. Kasinitz said, are Puerto Ricans who are treated like "virtual blacks."
Studies have shown that many blacks prefer integrated neighborhoods, which they define as half black and half white, but that they do not want to live in predominatly white neighborhoods they perceive as unwelcoming. "Some neighborhoods are not yet ready for black people," said Cedma Mark, 40, citing Sheepshead Bay and Bensonhurst, "and I don't want to be a hero."
What Ms. Mark and many middle-class blacks want are safe streets, good schools and peace and quiet -- qualities sometimes scarce in impoverished areas, as is affordable, middle-class housing.
"There are a lot of black dollars chasing relatively scarce black housing," Mr. Kasinitz said, explaining that that is why, when a neighborhood settled by new immigrants is perceived as friendly, "you see a huge African-American influx."
"It goes from 10 percent to 50 percent very quickly," he said.
That has happened neighborhods like East Flatbush, and in the last decade in Ms. Mark's neighborhood, Canarsie, as an aging population began selling homes and moving out. As housing opened up, blacks sometimes braved open hostility -- and sometimes paid inflated prices -- to move in. As more did, Irish, Italians, and Jews who had laready fled one black influx moved south or left the borough.
Now Caribbeans and African Americans are moving further south. Some are leaving neighborhoods like East Flatbush. Some are even leaving Canarsie, according to Dorothy Gurano, the district manager for Community Board 18, which includes Canarsie, Georgetown, Flatlands, Marine Park, Mill Basin and Bergen Beach.
They are replaced by what Ms. Guarano called "less-desirables" who sometimes live two or three families to a house. "We are getting a lot of reports of auto repairs being done in the street," she said.
Some of those leaving Canarsie are returning to Caribbean islands; some are moving to the suburbs, and others are going south, to Flatlands, Marine Park, even Mill Basin, "to see if they can get a better life for themselves," Ms. Gurano said. As they do so, once again the whites seem to be leaving.
Jean Chenet, a Haitian who works in the payroll department at the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, moved to the Flatlands area from Flatbush in 1990. He had lived in a suburb of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and wanted a quiet area in Brooklyn. It took him two years to find a place he could afford.
Mr. Chenet, 59, was the first nonwhite on his block; since then, one by one, whites have been moving out. Jamaicans, other Haitians and African-Americans have moved in.
"I was surprised to see that the people coming in weren't very mixed," he said, with a touch of bewilderment in his voice. "Apparently when black people move into a neighborhood, everybody's out." By everybody, he meant the whites.
Estimates from the Department of Housing Preservation and Development for the Flatlands/Canarsie area show a drop in the white population from 64.6 percent to 47.5 percent from 1991 to 1996, and a corresponding increase in the black population from 24.6 to 43.3 percent. Those numbers suggest that yet another neighborhood is being unstitched and restitched.
Susan Field, who has lived a few blocks from Mr. Chenet's home for 14 years, said realtors had actively sought to turn the neighborhood over by encouraging blacks to move in. State officials are investigating charges of block-busting, the use of racial and ethnic scare tactics to prompt residents to sell.
Ms. Field has a "For Sale" sign outside her house, just a few blocks from Mr. Chenet. In part, she wants a bigger house for her three children. But she also said that for people like her, the product of earlier immigrants from Europe, life in Brooklyn was no longer so appealing.
"Immigrants of prior generations are moving up the ladder, moving to Long Island, New Jersey," she said, adding: "It's not like we could look in our own neighborhood" for a new, bigger house "because of the changes."
The changes she meant are the arrival of black, particularly Caribbean, residents. "Real estates," as she calls brokers, show houses only to blacks, she said; the result is that a once heterogeneous neighborhood with a few blacks is turning into a black one. When a white person comes to look at her house, she said, "I know they're an investor, wanting to buy the house way below value and then turn it over quickly" because they know new immigrants will pay higher prices.
The neighborhood is changing in all sorts of ways, she said. Most of the newcomers were two-income families, working so hard that no sense of community congealed. "It is not a bad neighborhood," Mrs. Field said, "but it is a sterile neighborhood."
The local Roman Catholic church no longer has enough children for a baseball league; an interparish league had been formed. White children were leaving the schools, and white families the neighborhood.
"I'm not scared," she said. "I'm not running. I will move when I get my price."
 
Something Ununusual: Whites Replacing Whites
 This pattern has been repeated time and again southern Brooklyn. But in the Flatlands area something unusual is happening: as whites move out, other whites are moving in. They are Orthodox Jews, unable to find houses in Midwood or unable to afford them. Houses to the east of Nostrand Avenue, between Kings Highway and Avenue J, are within walking distance of synagogues, but they cost up to $100,000 less than in Midwood. So Orthodox Jews are "turning" blocks, too.
One woman, who refused to give her name, said that, much like Mr. Chenet, she was the only Orthodox resident, although not the only Jew, when she moved onto her block 12 years ago. "The kids were really nervous, because they had no one to play with," she said. Now they have plenty of playmates.
Mark Colton, 39, is an Orthodox Jew who moved east of Nostrand Avenue four years ago. Since then, he said, nine Orthodox families have bought homes on his block; in somecases, the sellers were secular Jews.
"You typically think of older Jews receding before younger blacks," Mr. Kasinitz, the CUNY associate professor, said of the two groups. "Here they are both young, with similar incomes."
Often, the groups seem unaware of each other, creating mini-enclaves as small as a block. "There are pockets, I suppose," Mr. Colton said of the West Indians in the neighborhood, oblivious to the West Indian man washing his car across the street. Marsha Waltuch, an observant Jew who has lived on her block for 44 years, said the Orthodox influx delighted her. "I don't think so," she said when asked if blacks lived in her neighborhood. "Well, they're on 35th Street, but not on this block." Ms. Waltuch lives on East 34th Street.
For now, such segregation within integration limits direct competition for housing, though some West Indians said they thought they paid more for houses and apartments than Orthodiz Jewish newcomers. A need for different size housing also limits competition. Because they generally have large families, the Orthodox Jews often need larger houses. It is possible that one group will accumulate more money or more residents and buy out the other group, but few people seem to think so.
Brought together by opportunity and necessity, the two groups ar molding a new southern Brooklyn. Nathillie Caldeira pondered Crown Heights and the riots that resulted there in 1991 after a black youngster, Gavin Cato, was struck by an ambulance driven by a Hasidic Jew.
"I don't know if something like that could happen here," Ms. Caldeira said. "I don't think so." Her neighborhood is more affluent, she said, and thus less tense.
And then she pondered the mystery of co-existence without contact. Neither her Orthodox Jewish nor her black and West Indian neighbors greet one another. No one says hello. "If someone were to make the effort," she asked, "would there be tension, or would it go smoothly?"
 
On the Books but Not Always in Practice
Every morning, Phyllis Spiro leaves her Sheepshead Bay apartment and boards a subway bound for SoHo. Her trip takes her through neighborhoods that are models of diversity: mixtures of Russians and Chinese, Pakistanis and Orthodox Jews.
As the train crosses Avenue J and moves northward through Flatbush, the neighborhoods become mostly African-American and Caribbean. Such divisions are so entrenched that many people don't even notice them.
Phyllis Spiro does. Diminutive and raspy-voiced, she calls herself the "old lady of fair housing." The deputy director of the Open Housing Center, a nonprofit group that fights housing discrimination, she has been battling for New Yorkers to be able to live where they please since the 1960's.
Thirty years ago this weekend, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Fair Housing Act, making it illegal to discriminate on the basis of race, color, religion or national origin. The state and city also have fair housing laws. But time has shown that enforcing laws is as crucial as passing them.
It would be a stretch to attribute segregation in southern Brooklyn primarily to discrimination by real estate agents, brokers or landlords. But studies have shown that bias does play a role in housing decisions, whether in redlining or racial steering. In 1989, for example, the Urban Institute conducted 3,800 housing audits, using testers of different races, in 25 metropolitan areas. The study found that 53 percent of black renters and 59 percent of black home buyers could be expected to encounter at least one incident of discrimination.
Yet the number of formal complaints filed in New York City doesn't reflect those results. For example, Adam Glantz, a spokesman for the New York City office of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, said 597 cases citing discrimination on the basis of race or national origin had been filed in the city since 1989; of those, 17 had been found to have "reasonable cause" and 115 were resolved through conciliation; the rest were withdrawn or found to have no "reasonable cause" for a hearing.
Some realtors and city officials point to the small number of complaints as evidence that discrimination is not widespread. It tends to be the product of a "few bad apples," said Jacob Shayovitz, the president of the Brooklyn Board of Realtors.
But fair housing advocates say the low number of complaints reflects the sheer effort required to bring a case and to the fact that real estate clients often did not know they had been discriminated against.
"Discrimination is difficult to detect and prove without testing," Mr. Schill said.
The city does not do systemic testing, said Lorna Goodman, director of affirmative litigation for the Corporation Counsel, unless a complaint comes in. There are currently no investigations under way.
Ultimately, much of the work of fair housing enforcement in the city falls to the Open Housing Center, which receives thousands of complaints each year. In three or four cases, the Center files suit in Federal court. Most defendants settle, with monetary payments to the plaintiffs. AMY WALDMAN

PUB-DATE: April 12, 1998

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1090 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Producer Prices Slide
Producer prices fell an unexpected 0.3 percent in March. The drop, the fifth monthly decline in a row, came amid healthy growth in the eighth year of the economy's expansion, belying fears that low unemployment -- 4.7 percent at present -- might lead to inflationary pressures. Even when volatile food and energy costs were excluded, prices were unchanged. In another sign of a robust economy, retailers reported strong March sales. The Goldman, Sachs same-store index, which measures major retailers' sales in stores open at least one year, rose 3.4 percent, and some stores were even stronger. Wal-Mart reported a 6.2 percent gain. 

ASIA
In Japan, Half a Loaf?
Under pressure from world leaders, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, below, proposed Japan's largest package yet of tax cuts and new spending -- $75 billion, or about 2 percent of total annual economic output -- to reverse an economic decline that could have ripple effects on other big economies. But investors feared the package would be inadequate to avert a recession. The Japanese central bank had to intervene in the currency market to support the yen, and the stock market fell 55.54 points on Friday, to 16,481.12. Still, there was one bright spot in Asia's seemingly unrelenting economic gloom. South Korea, destitute just four months ago, won an enormous vote of confidence from investors around the world with the successful sale of $4 billion in Government bonds.
 
CITIGROUP
Big, Bigger, Gargantuan
Throwing down the gauntlet to Washington, Sanford I. Weill of Travelers Group, below left, and John S. Reed of Citicorp announced plans to merge their institutions, forming the world's largest financial services concern. The deal was valued at $70 billion in stock when it was announced on Monday, and shares of the two companies immediately surged, pushing up the value by $14 billion that day. Some of those gains had been trimmed by week's end as investors began to see potential problems. The big one is the nation's longstanding legal bars to combining banks and insurers. Citicorp and Travelers are gambling that they can use their political muscle and sheer weight in the marketplace to break down the barriers to creating vast financial supermarkets.
 
MARKETS
A Display of Optimism
After flirting with 9,000 a week earlier, the Dow Jones industrial average managed to close above that milestone on Monday, only to back and fill as the week wore on. Still, its close of 8,994.86 after a short trading week, up 11.45 points from the previous week, showed that investors were displaying remarkable optimism in the face of an expected slide in corporate earnings. I.B.E.S. International forecasts a decline of 0.4 percent in first-quarter operating earnings for the 500 companies in the Standard & Poor's index. But two sectors -- oil and technology, which have already been discounted in the market -- account for a large portion of the drop. In contrast, General Electric reported a 13 percent gain and Chrysler exceeded estimates with a 2.9 percent increase.
 
TOBACCO
Coming Out Smokin'
The leading American cigarette manufacturers went on the offensive against legislation approved by the Senate Commerce Committee that would cost them far more than the $368.5 billion settlement they agreed to last June, saying they would no longer work for comprehensive legislation to regulate tobacco. Steven F. Goldstone, chairman of RJR Nabisco, said in a speech at the National Press Club that his company would begin aggressively advertising cigarettes and fighting for its position in court. Philip Morris, Brown & Williamson and Lorillard Tobacco quickly issued statements supporting Mr. Goldstone's position. House Speaker Newt Gingrich lambasted the industry and promised legislation to fight smoking among teen-agers.
 
AIRCRAFT
Rewiring Urged for Safety
The National Transportation Safety Board recommended that thousands of aircraft built by Boeing and other companies be rewired to reduce the risk of a fuel tank explosion like the one that investigators say destroyed Trans World Airlines Flight 800 two years ago. The board said the low-voltage wires that run from the cockpit to the fuel gauges should not be bundled with wires that carry high-voltage electricity; if the wiring is damaged, current could jump from one to the other and ignite fumes in the tank. Boeing said it was working with the board and the F.A.A. to address fuel tank concerns.
 
DEALS
Lenders United
Other financial services companies also announced plans to merge. Beneficial and Household International, which have competed with each other to provide consumer loans for most of this century, agreed to a stock swap valued at nearly $9 billion. Also, two companies known for controversial accounting methods will merge: Conseco, an insurance conglomerate, will acquire Green Tree Financial, which lends money to people who buy mobile homes, in a deal that Conseco says is worth $7.6 billion.
 
AUTO SAFETY
Protection on the Way
More cars will soon have side air bags. The Ford Motor Company, expressing concern about the death rate of people in cars hit from the side, will offer side air bags in the front seats on all of its cars and Ford Windstar mini-vans over the next several years. General Motors already offers side air bags on a half-dozen of its 81 models and plans to add 15 more over the next two years. Chrysler, which offers no side air bags, is reviewing whether to add them. Federal regulators, insurance industry researchers and the auto makers' own safety experts have grown increasingly worried that the spread of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, which ride higher than cars, may mean that more collisions will be deadly.
 
ECONOMISTS
The New Superstars
Perhaps it ought not be surprising that people who study money are demanding more of it for themselves. But more than a few eyebrows were raised when Columbia University lured away Robert J. Barro of Harvard, one of the nation's most distinguished economists, with pay of nearly $300,000 a year and a cornucopia of perks and privileges for his entire family -- a choice Manhattan apartment, tuition for private school for his son and a university post for his wife. The Columbia provost, Jonathan R. Cole, ruefully calls top economists "free agents without salary caps." Still, the university, eager to reclaim its rightful position as a top school for economics, took the action it considered necessary.

HEADLINE: Audits Spread Unevenly Across U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Nothing touches off panic in taxpayers more than the prospect of an audit. But there are such wide disparities across the country in who gets audited that residents in New York City and its suburbs continue to be treated with kid gloves by the Internal Revenue Service while those in California have been hit comparatively hard.
Part of the reason for the difference is that the I.R.S. has been looking harder in California for people who do not file tax returns, but it is also because the agency relies on a decade-old study of taxpayer behavior that critics call obsolete. 
 Newly released I.R.S. data, obtained by researchers at Syracuse University, show that Los Angeles County taxpayers are four times as likely to be audited as those in New Jersey, even though the two areas have roughly the same population and the same average income.
Meantime, under a financial squeeze, the I.R.S. has reduced the number of audits it conducts of suspected fraudulent returns -- as opposed to those that are merely erroneous -- by nearly 75 percent, the data show. But such is the unpredictability of the I.R.S.'s tax-monitoring activity that huge disparities in the number of such fraud investigations have developed in the New York City metropolitan region.
In the highest-income district in the United States -- Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island and Westchester and Rockland Counties -- fraud audits fell to 208 in 1996 from 628 in 1992. In Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island, they declined to 155 from 575, and in upstate New York, they dropped to 142 from 514. In the Connecticut-Rhode Island district, they tumbled to a minuscule 57 from 848.
Such seeming capriciousness in the distribution of both ordinary and fraud audits is certain to fuel the political debate -- heating up again as Congressional elections approach -- about overhauling or even replacing the current income tax system.
The new tax information was obtained by the Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse, a research arm of Syracuse University that for years has pursued lawsuits and other tactics to obtain data from the service. The data disclose another trend that is likely to add to popular disenchantment with the I.R.S.: Back taxes and penalties are increasing for the poor and declining for the rich.
This shift is largely a result of a 1995 directive from Congress for the I.R.S. to monitor the tax returns of the working poor more thoroughly -- not only to collect unpaid taxes but also to make sure people eligible for the earned-income credit, a form of negative income tax, do not get more than they are supposed to.
Between 1992 and 1996, the average increase in the tax bill that I.R.S. auditors recommended for those making less than $25,000 more than doubled, to almost $5,700 from $2,500, while for those making more than $100,000 it fell 14.5 percent, to $19,700 from $23,000.
This year, 174 million Americans must file an estimated 124 million individual and joint returns before midnight on Wednesday. About 1 in 150 are expected to be audited; in 1996, the last year for which figures are available, 760,197 returns out of 115.4 million got the I.R.S. once-over.
The agency bases decisions on which returns to audit on several factors, including suspicions about the integrity of the preparer or information from a related return -- for example, one filed by a business partner caught cheating.
But it also gives huge weight to statistical departures from norms established in a 1988 study -- a study that critics say is outdated because of the huge changes in the American economy since then, from the Wall Street bull market to the explosion in the ranks of the self-employed.
The 1988 research was conducted by picking thousands of taxpayers at random and making them prove each entry on their return.
By gaining such full disclosure from a broad cross section of the population, the I.R.S. was able to determine how much people in various income groups actually gave to charities, paid in state and local taxes, spent on medical care and allocated to other tax-deductible costs. It then devised a statistical formula -- known as the "dif score," for discriminant function -- and focused on taxpayers who deviated the most from the norms.
More than one-third of all 1996 audits were based on dif scores, but there are geographic incongruities, from 1 out of every 110 returns in Los Angeles to 1 in 1,000 in New Jersey and 1 in 1,428 in the Carolinas.
The disparities in overall auditing rates were narrower, ranging from 1 in 62 in the two I.R.S. districts covering Southern California to 1 in 278 in upstate New York and 1 in 294 in Ohio. In the New York City region, the overall rates ranged from 1 in 133 in the Manhattan tax district that includes its northern suburbs; 1 in 172 in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island; 1 in 167 in Connecticut and Rhode Island, and 1 in 238 in New Jersey.
In interviews, three former I.R.S. commissioners all criticized the continued use of the old study. "The taxpayer-compliance measurement data are obsolete," said Donald C. Alexander, a tax partner at Aiken & Gump in Washington and the tax commissioner in the Nixon Administration. Margaret Richardson, who resigned last May, and Fred T. Goldberg Jr., who served in the Bush Administration, said that they agreed, but Mr. Goldberg added the service needed to find new ways to identify citizens who evaded taxes.
In 1995, the I.R.S. planned to update the profiles by putting 93,000 individuals and 63,000 companies through similarly intense audits, but the Republicans eliminated money for the project.
The I.R.S., of course, looks at more than just dif scores. Thomas J. Smith, the assistant commissioner for audits, said that Californians were audited the most because "the characteristics of their returns" indicate a greater likelihood that more taxes may be due. Californians have more income from self-employment and business activities that the I.R.S. has found prone to abuse than do residents of New Jersey, for example, and the super-rich in California are much wealthier than those in New Jersey.
Aside from the cumbersomeness of the tax-collection process, the biggest problem the I.R.S. faces is a budget squeeze. The agency has fewer auditors and agents to examine returns now than in 1988 -- 27,375 today compared with 31,895 then, a 14 percent decline.
Meanwhile the number of individual income tax returns grew to 115.4 million from 103.2 million in 1988, an increase of 11.8 percent.
The Syracuse University clearinghouse collects information from Federal computers, compiles it and posts it on the Internet at http:// www.trac.syr.edu with the aim of improving public understanding of how the Government functions.
"The I.R.S. has such power over the average citizen that people need to understand it," said Prof. Susan Long, the co-director of the clearinghouse. "Taxes are the one area of the law, other than traffic cops, where the ordinary citizen is likely to come into contact with law enforcement, and the most painful area of contact is the audit."

HEADLINE: Aid Groups Are Hands That Help In Bosnia

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: BRCKO, Bosnia and Herzegovina

 BODY:
Every month, the brain trust of the local chapter of Bosnia's "mini-Marshall Plan" -- the military, the United Nations and voluntary agencies known as NGO's -- meets in a revived neighborhood of concrete office buildings and smoky pizza parlors to plan how to spend the next allotment of hundreds of thousands of dollars to rebuild the region.
"We can report that we've seen a school that needs a playground," Capt. Victoria Wolfe, a civil affairs officer in the United States Army, said at one recent meeting. "That's where we coordinate with the NGO's," she said. 
 Three years after the Dayton peace plan committed the countries of NATO and international organiza tions to rebuilding the shattered economy of Bosnia, the $7 billion spent annually for everything from NATO troops to new brick factories is beginning to pay off.
The central goal of the Dayton Plan -- to get the Muslims, the Serbs and the Croats of Bosnia to live together again -- is as elusive as ever. The communities remain partitioned, and most refugees have not been able to return to homes seized by members of other ethnic groups. But the reconstruction of the country is picking up speed.
Fields are being tilled. Abandoned villages are being reclaimed house by house. Churches and mosques have been rebuilt -- more frequently than schools -- and cafes and sausage joints are opening. Roads are becoming navigable, electricity is more common than not and telephone service now connects the entire country.
Those largely responsible for this effort are the NGO's, or nongovernmental organizations. There are nearly 200 here, from 24 countries, and this year alone they will spend some $1 billion, according to Christopher Miller, spokesman for the World Bank in Bosnia.
"You could say that the U.N., the European Community, even the U.S. A.I.D. programs all walk on the legs of the NGO's," said Jim Bishop of Interaction, a voluntary agency based in Washington.
There has never been as large an assemblage of voluntary agencies as here in Bosnia, nor have they ever before been given such broad responsibility. Some economists and bankers fear there are too many, viewing them as an occupation force of foreigners who are smothering the incentive of Bosnians to take over the reconstruction of their country.
NGO projects cover medical, social and commercial rehabilitation: loans for start-up businesses; counseling for widows and angry veterans; reopening of schools and job training programs; repairing of houses; provision of medical care, and establishment of human rights and democratic organizations.
In Sarajevo alone some 16,000 foreigners have taken up residence. They prowl the city's narrow streets in white jeeps with their agencies' acronyms emblazoned on the side. They have regular watering holes like the Internet Cafe. Even the city buses -- painted in the signature blue of the European Union with its gold stars -- are a mobile advertisement for the Europeans who donated them.
When the military, the international organizations and the voluntary agencies hold their coordination meetings in Sarajevo they involve more than donation lists. The military briefs the group on the latest security incidents, flashing computer-generated slides on the walls noting the sites of ethnic clashes. Then the country's fortunes are measured in projects totaling billions of dollars.
"It's far more like being in a James Bond movie than most of our other meetings," a participant said.
While the profile of the NGO's has been rising for years, the movement has come into its own in the last few years. Last year the Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to one of their own: the International Campaign to Ban Landmines.
Now in Bosnia the unwieldy collection of NGO's are being asked to prove their worth in an unusual situation. Most cut their teeth on disasters in Asia and Africa, but their duties were strict disaster relief: providing food, water, shelter and medical care.
"All of a sudden we're in the middle of Europe where we're being asked to rehabilitate infrastructures and rebuild brick houses," said Nick Scott-Flynn of the NGO umbrella group, the International Council of Voluntary Agencies. "We come from situations where there were no solid houses and no infrastructure."
Critics contend that the rest of the reconstruction should be up to the Bosnians now. Mr. Scott-Flynn counters that the foreign NGO's have helped create 177 local Bosnian NGO's, which are being trained to take over the basic tasks now done by the foreigners.
Dismissing the complaints against the NGO's, Amanda M. Fernandez of Catholic Relief Services said: "We do the daily work that has to be done. We have to be here."
