HEADLINE: Political Interests Arouse Raging Debate on Census

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
Two years from the start of the 2000 Census, it is shaping up as the most contentious in 80 years, generating a firestorm of debate and strategizing in Congress and litigation aimed at blocking the Census Bureau from changing the way it does business.
Over the last year, the dispute over the bureau's plans to alter its method of counting the population delayed passage of a disaster relief bill for victims of flooding in the Midwest, prompted Congress and the Clinton Administration to set up an outside board to monitor the bureau and generated two lawsuits, including one by Speaker Newt Gingrich. 
 Congress has ordered the traditionally apolitical Census Bureau to draft two plans for conducting the census -- one the old way and one using the proposed new method, statistical sampling, which is at the center of the dispute.
"This is quite a battle," said Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican, and one of the few members of his party to support the proposed changes.
The fight is the most heated since the 1920 census, when rural lawmakers, aghast that the headcount documented for the first time that more people lived in cities than in rural areas, refused to use the results to reapportion the House of Representatives.
At issue this time is the Census Bureau's plan to forgo its traditional, and some experts say failing, method of trying to physically count every person in the country. Instead, the bureau proposes to try to count all the people in 90 percent of the households in each census tract, which is a geographical area consisting of about 1,700 dwellings.
Using those figures, bureau statisticians would try to determine the number of people in the tract who had not been physically counted. The bureau would then check for accuracy by conducting a survey of 750,000 households nationwide and making any needed adjustments to the final total.
The statistical sampling plan was prompted by the 1990 census, which cost $2.6 billion, a 400 percent increase over the previous headcount, in 1980, even after adjusting for inflation. The 1990 effort missed 10 million people and double-counted 6 million, according to Census Bureau studies and a study by the National Research Council, an arm of National Academy of Sciences.
Most Republicans vigorously oppose the plan for sampling, arguing that it violates the Constitution, Article I, which calls for an "actual enumeration" every 10 years, and that it is much too complex for the Census Bureau to perform successfully.
But the proposal is staunchly supported by many Democrats who assert that it is the only way to get an accurate tally of minorities -- particularly inner-city blacks and Hispanic migrant workers, who are traditionally the hardest to count.
Beneath the assertions about constitutionality and fairness and the discussion over statistical methods lies a raw political fight that is based on race and redistricting. And the outcome, some experts say, could be critical to which party controls the House and state legislatures in the beginning of the next century.
Both sides say the Census Bureau's sampling method would probably help Democrats and harm Republicans, but no one is quite sure.
Sampling may increase the count of minorities, primarily blacks who are the Democrats' most loyal voters, in some Congressional and state legislative districts. Since these districts tend to be safe ones for Democrats, boundaries could be redrawn by state legislatures to shift some of the "surplus" black voters into neighboring white districts, making these districts more competitive for the Democrats.
"The Republicans are very much aware of this," said one Democratic redistricting expert who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "That's why they're fighting it. They're scared they're going to lose the House. Frankly, I don't see that it would make a 15- to 20-seat difference. It might make a 6-, 8- or 10-seat difference. But given the situation we have right now, that's huge."
Indeed, the Republicans are very much aware. Some even argue strongly that the reasons the party has a slim majority in the House have less to do with ideology and more with the fact that the 1990 census was conducted in the traditional way.
In his new book "Lessons Learned the Hard Way"(HarperCollins), Mr. Gingrich described last year's fight over the issue, in which the Republicans tried to force the Census Bureau to scuttle its plan to use sampling, as being "of great importance to the welfare of our party." In a meeting with Republican House members then, he called sampling a "dagger pointed at the heart" of Republican control of the chamber.
Last year, Jim Nicholson, national chairman of the Republican National Committee, sent a memorandum to his state chairmen, urging them to join in the fight against statistical sampling, saying the new method could jeopardize 24 House seats, 113 State Senate seats and 297 State House seats.
"At stake is our G.O.P. majority in the House of Representatives as well as partisan control of state legislatures nationwide," Mr. Nichols wrote.
Most experts contend that Mr. Nicholson and others exaggerate the political consequences of sampling. Still, Amos R. McMullian, president of Flowers Industries and a contributor to Republican candidates, sent out a fund-raising letter in February that used those figures and asked for contributions to help a conservative legal group, the Southeastern Legal Foundation, challenge the constitutionality of sampling.
This lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in the Eastern District of Virginia, in Alexandria, is similar to the one filed by Mr. Gingrich in Federal District Court in Washington. Both lawsuits assert that sampling violates the Constitution's requirement that the Government conduct an "actual enumeration" of the population every 10 years.
Democrats say that using sampling is the right thing to do, but they are also aware of the political advantage the new method could bring them. In 1990, the bureau used a modified version of sampling, conducting a nationwide survey to determine who was missed. The bureau then proposed adjusting the final numbers based on that survey.
But the Bush Administration refused to adjust the census, prompting a lawsuit by several cities, including New York, in an effort to force the Commerce Department -- which oversees the Census Bureau -- to do so. The lawsuit failed. Some members of the Clinton Administration have vowed that the census setbacks the Democrats suffered in 1990 would not be repeated.
The raging political wars have baffled and demoralized the Census Bureau itself. Situated in nearby Suitland, Md., and with only 2 political appointees among more than 10,000 employees, the bureau is one of the most apolitical of all Federal agencies.
Census officials say they came up with the plan for statistical sampling at the behest of lawmakers in both parties to reduce costs and increase accuracy. Now they find themselves in a political maelstrom.
"We have gone about doing our work with the assumption that we should be looking at solutions that produce the best results," said James F. Holmes, the bureau's Acting Director. "The political side is something that we have not given a lot of thought to."
Despite the political ramifications of the census fight, House Democrats have complained that the Clinton Administration has not shown sufficient resolve in the battle.
Two months after Martha Farnsworth Riche resigned as the bureau Director while intense political wrangling was taking place, the Administration has only recently begun interviewing people to replace her. The White House has also just announced its four choices for the eight-member outside monitoring board, which was agreed upon in November. The Republicans announced their four choices in January.
The Democratic appointees, announced this week, are Everett C. Erhlich, former Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs; Tony Coehlo, a former House whip; Gilbert Casellas, former chairman of the Equal Opportunity Commission, and Lorraine Green, former Deputy Director of the Office of Personnel Management.
And, though President Clinton promised House Democrats in November that he would make the census fight a major priority, he has not uttered a word in public on the subject since.
"There has not been the total commitment on the Administration's part to this issue," said Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Backtalk;
An Eminent Voice Pleads for the Soul of Rutgers

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
The struggle for the soul of Rutgers University, which beat Princeton in the first intercollegiate football game in 1869, escalates in a week when its most honored alumnus, the Nobel Prize-winning economist Milton Friedman, officially asks the administration to turn away from big-time sports and return to the academic and intellectual values he cherished.
In a full-page ad in the April 20 issue of The Daily Targum, a student newspaper, Friedman, Rutgers '32, declares that universities do not "exist . . . to provide entertainment for spectators or employment for athletes." This is an attack on the policies of the president, Francis L. Lawrence, who shepherded the Scarlet Knights into the Big East Conference and has helped hire major coaches. 
 Lawrence's position was made clear last year when he wrote in a local newspaper's op-ed page that while "our primary mission is the academic one," the university needed to be competitive at the same high level in athletics. "A successful athletic program, in fact," he wrote, "underlines the university's academic reputation in an especially compelling way."
To Friedman, a senior research fellow at the Hoover Institute at Stanford, "it is not the purpose of a university to generate publicity or to stimulate sports." In a telephone interview last week, he said that "as long as athletes are admitted on lower standards than other students, sports is a corruptive influence on higher education."
Lawrence chose not to comment on a Nobel laureate's unusual and enthusiastic role as spokesman for an informal group of students, faculty members and alumni, conceived in intellectual outrage on the New Brunswick, N.J., campus several years ago and nurtured on the Internet.
The ad featuring Friedman was paid for by the Rutgers 1000 Alumni Council, led by a semiretired advertising executive, Richard Seclow of Easton, Conn., who read a newspaper story about the ad hoc group and suddenly "felt the diminishing value of my academic equity."
"I feel like a dissident shareholder," Seclow said, "especially since the administration is approaching this like a professional sports corporation."
Seclow, Rutgers '51 and a former president of The Targum, sees the campaign as eventually spreading to other large universities trying to gain national publicity and alumni donations through sports.
It was an English professor, William C. Dowling, who several years ago founded the grass-roots campaign that has suddenly expanded beyond the campus. The campaign's purpose was to help Rutgers fulfill its destiny as a "public Ivy" rather than become a "Yahoo U." football factory.
But Pete Bigelow, a senior political science major and the outgoing sports editor of The Targum, argues that the choice is not that simplistic. He thinks Rutgers can use schools like Stanford, Michigan and Northwestern as models. "Rutgers is not an exclusive Ivy," he said. "When it chose to enlarge, it had to make a commitment to making a national name and recruiting more students. In today's sports culture, athletics is a way to do that."
Lawrence has stated that Rutgers's "support for intercollegiate athletics amounts to one-half of 1 percent of the total university budget." But his statistic is less compelling than the Rutgers 1000's Internet "slum classroom contest."
One student described a "classroom that had broken windows, a gaping hole in the ceiling in one corner and toilet smells from a backup bathroom next door so bad that you could hardly concentrate on what the professor was saying." The writer went on to suggest that some of the $700,000 salary of the new basketball coach, Kevin Bannon, might be better spent cleaning up "slum" classrooms and creating comfortable seminar rooms.
This was followed by an excerpt from column in The New York Times in which William C. Rhoden described the "spacious dressing areas and custom-designed handmade cherry wood lockers" in "a room that is part lounge, part study, part theater." Bannon had designed it, and furnished it with 7 television sets hooked up to 2 satellite dishes, 5 videocassette recorders and 23 giant leather seats for his team.
To bolster its position that Rutgers was too Ivy-ish to be associated with the Big East, Dowling's group compared the fourteen conference schools, using the U.S. News and World Report's national ranking of four academic departments. Rutgers was No. 20 nationally in English, No. 22 in history, No. 16 in math and No. 22 in physics. The only other school with all four national rankings was Notre Dame, which had nothing higher than a No. 41 in math. Six of the schools, including St. John's and Seton Hall, had no nationally ranked academic departments.
But keeping company with Miami, Georgetown, Syracuse and West Virginia may well have its advantages; according to Lawrence, student applications and private fund-raising are at all-time highs.
Nevertheless, Friedman looks to the University of Chicago, where he was associated for many years.
"As you no doubt recall," he said, "Chicago was a football powerhouse before Robert Maynard Hutchins dropped the game. And as you know, it hardly harmed the university's academic standing."

HEADLINE: Makeup of American Religion Is Looking More Like Mosaic, Data Say

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
Several mainline Protestant denominations have reported losing fewer members over the last three years, easing a trajectory that once suggested the nation's largest moderate to liberal churches were sliding toward the margins of religious life.
During this same period, the rate of growth has slipped within the nation's conservative powerhouse, the Southern Baptist Convention, whose membership increased so quickly in the 1970's that it emerged as the country's largest religious organization outside the Roman Catholic Church. 
 But the annual figures do not show a clear reversal of fortune within the pattern that took hold among Protestants 30 years ago, when many conservative denominations began to gain and more liberal ones to shrink. Yet the numbers do offer a new indication of the growing complexity within American religion, which is increasingly defined by such trends as immigration, the spread of independent congregations and new religious networks, and the globalization of some organizations.
Church historians and sociologists of religion say the country's religious landscape has become too diverse and multifaceted to be described as a culture war between right and left.
"I think the old liberal-conservative paradigm is a thing of the past," said David A. Roozen, director of the Center for Social and Religious Research at the Hartford Seminary. "Today's religious world is kind of like a mosaic, rather than a nice clearcut set of boxes."
A central trend, especially among Christians, Professor Roozen said, is that energy and innovation have passed from national religious organizations to local congregations, many of which are experimenting with contemporary music and new, expressive styles of worship. Some of that creativity is occurring among Protestants, particularly in the West, he said, adding, "I think that's helping their growth trends somewhat."
Recent statistics reported by Protestant denominations present a more intriguing picture than statistics a decade ago.
For example, the 2.4 million-member Episcopal Church, which lost more than 1 million members from 1965 to 1989, grew by nearly 100,000 from 1989 to 1994. Losses resumed in 1995 and 1996, but church attendance (those who actually go to Sunday services) held stable, then rose in 1996, the last year for which figures are available.
Since 1992, two other mainline denominations, the 8.5 million-member United Methodist Church and the 5.2 million-member Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, have seen their annual membership losses narrow. Membership losses also declined between 1995 and 1997 within the United Church of Christ.
Another denomination, the 2.6 million-member Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), reported losing more than 32,000 members in both 1995 and 1996. But the loss shrank to 22,000 last year, after a surge in adult baptisms, as people without any previous Christian affiliation joined, a spokesman said.
The Southern Baptist Convention, which suffered a fierce internal struggle between fundamentalist and moderate factions in the 1980's, continues to grow. But it has seen the rate dip, to about one-half of 1 percent or less from 1994 to 1997. Still, members put a record amount in the collection plate last year, sending the Southern Baptist budget to a new high, said Herb Hollinger, editor of the denomination's news agency.
Further complicating the picture, one of the most liberal religious groups in the country, the Unitarian-Universalist Association, has been growing. Its membership has risen by nearly 20 percent, to more than 200,000, since 1981.
The Rev. Eileen W. Lindner, editor of the "Yearbook of American and Canadian Churches 1998" (Abingdon), which reported a "flattening" of membership trends among many denominations, said the complicated picture within Protestantism should be seen within the "context of the incredible robustness of American religious life."
Changes in immigration laws allowing greater numbers of immigrants from outside Europe in the mid-1960's have fueled the growth of major faiths, with American Muslims estimated at 2 million to 5 million, and Buddhists and Hindus often numbered at up to 1 million each.
Immigration, too, has helped raise the Roman Catholic ranks, to 61 million baptized Catholics, up from 50 million in 1980. The church has also gained from converts. The United States Bishops Conference recently reported that parishes nationwide would welcome nearly 100,000 newly baptized adult members the Saturday before Easter.
In other broad changes, new networks of Christian congregations have been formed, emphasizing contemporary religious music, informal dress and Bible teaching. Among them are the Vineyard and Calvary Chapel movements, which began among young converts in California and are unaffiliated with any traditional denomination.
And some denominations are undergoing a form of globalization and are no longer solely focused on their American members. In 1980, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints numbered 4.6 million, three-quarters of them in the United States. Last year, the church announced that it had 10 million members, the majority overseas.
The Assemblies of God, a Pentecostal denomination founded in Arkansas in 1914, counts 2.5 million members in the United States and 10 times that many overseas, many in Brazil. The 8.5 million-member United Methodist Church has also expanded abroad. Although it lost 1 million American members from 1980 to 1995, it gained about 500,000 elsewhere, mostly in Africa, according to church statistics.
"American religion is in a state of permanent transition," said Bill Leonard, a church historian and dean of the Divinity School at Wake Forest University. Mr. Leonard cited a growing number of interfaith marriages and a tendency of many people to "shop around" for a house of worship as reasons for a great "flux and fluidity" in religious life.
Tidal changes have been at work on the religious scene before.
In the late 1930's, pollsters reported that 4 in 10 Americans said they attended church or synagogue regularly. That figure spiked, at nearly 6 in 10, during the 1950's, at a time of rising middle-class prosperity and the growth of families in the postwar baby boom. Much of the gain went to the mainline Protestant churches.
The Episcopal Church's statistics show that it grew to 3.3 million from 2.4 million members from 1950 to 1960, a rate of increase achieved by the Jehovah's Witnesses and Mormons 20 years later. Episcopalian numbers, like those in many other mainline churches, peaked around 1965, after the baby boom.
The Rev. Charles R. Wilson, a consultant and researcher of church statistics, said, "We took our hit, and I suspect most Protestant churches did, in the 1960's, when the baby boomers got out of high school, and Pop quit caring about" religious attendance.
The falling birth rate, along with population shifts in some parts of the nation, took their toll, said Thomas E. Frank, director of Methodist studies at the Candler School of Theology at Emory University.
Some Protestant churches were hit hard by economic troubles in America's farm belt, Professor Frank said.
"There are counties in the United States that have lost 75 percent of their population in 15 years," he said. "Well, that's where the Methodists and Presbyterians and Disciples of Christ built their churches. That's where the people were in 1900."
The flip side is that other congregations, particularly those in growing cities and suburbs, expanded along with the surrounding population. Atlanta, Professor Frank said, is home to mainline Protestant "megachurches" with thousands of members.
"Huge numbers of churches are thriving because they're well adapted to where they are," he said.
Speaking of the complexity of American religious life, Professor Roozen at the Hartford Seminary, said: "It's a fun time to be a student of religion, because there are a lot of interesting changes going on. We don't know where they're going to end up."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Striking Back, Especially If the Shoe Fits

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
IN the climactic scene of his film "The Big One," Michael Moore scores a prize interview inside the sanctum of Nike's chairman, Phil Knight. Several months ago, in an achievement Moore could appreciate more than most, a bunch of teen-agers from a New York City public housing project made the sports monolith come to them.
There is no tape of this meeting for Miramax to release, only a three-page memo in which Nike comes off as witless as Knight does in Moore's new film on the subject of exporting jobs. He maintains his "basic belief that Americans do not want to make shoes." 
 Moore goes right back home to Flint, Mich., to round up a posse of jobless locals, who beg for work. Knight concludes that the pleas of the unemployed are essentially a lie.
It wasn't the scruffy-bearded billionaire himself who hurried east from his encampment in the great Northwest, to the Edenwald Gun Hill Houses in the north Bronx last Sept. 10. Leo Johnson nonetheless recognized the presence of a senior public relations manager, Vada Manager, and a regional marketing official, Lincoln Parker, to be a sign of unmistakable corporate fear.
"They came to Edenwald, all the way from Portland, Ore.," Johnson said. "Most people from Fordham Road won't come up here."
Johnson, a 38-year-old father of two from Co-op City, has in the past year galvanized more than 200 young people from the Edenwald Gun Hill Neighborhood Center, as well as a coalition of settlement houses citywide, in a Nike-targeted sneaker give-back campaign. As sportswear and other youth trends often begin in poor urban neighborhoods and spread to wealthier enclaves and suburbs, Johnson and Company have the potential to hit the sneaker king right in its pockets.
"We're at the bottom of the market," he said. "But if the bottom falls out, the whole thing can collapse."
Moore's only real weapon against corporate cruelty is his camera. Johnson, youth director of the Edenwald Center, is fighting back with young, impressionable minds. That makes him a more dangerous man to a company like Nike, which counts on unquestioning, nascent consumers to buy expensive sneakers produced in Asian sweat shops for a fraction of the price.
Not only did Nike come, but Michael Moore also called.
An offer was extended last month for a private screening of "The Big One," in which Knight -- the first c.e.o. to play along with Moore's trademark gag of showing up unannounced and demanding to see the boss -- shoots himself in his $140 Air Jordans. Leo Johnson's recruits hit the phones, filled two buses. They saw the film on March 19, slightly out of focus, similar to Knight's "Big One" defense that Nike does not employ 12-year-olds because the minimum working age in Indonesia is 14.
After the film, the buses rolled on to 57th Street and Fifth Avenue, to Niketown, in the cold rain, where more sneakers were thrown back like fish, while network cameras recorded the event for the evening news. The film director could not have staged it better himself.
"Michael Moore is like an idol of ours," Johnson said. This is Be Like Mike, in a new context, one that does not presume the only effective adolescent stimulus to be sports, and related merchandise. "We got a little sick of people saying we needed to use sports to bring our kids in," said Michael Gitelson, another Edenwald Neighborhood Center counselor. "This has always been a politically active center. We've floated a lot of different issues with the kids. Nike worked."
Johnson added: "Nike is only one issue. What these young people here have to realize, and what they've seen by the way Nike has responded to us, is that they have the power to make these companies speak to them in more honest ways, not just show them Hollywood images of shirtless black men with their chests glistening with sweat."
When the Nike people visited the Edenwald Center on East 229th Street, they obviously were not yet convinced. Michael Gitelson's memo on the meeting said Vada Manager expressed "sincere doubts" about the veracity of the information Johnson's group had spent hours gleaning from the Internet and other news media sources.
One recent stormy night, in the Edenwald Center conference room, Johnson introduced two young disciples, who said having their work questioned made them determined to do more. Christina Burton, 15, and Donte Edwards, 16, insisted that the notion of Nike-as-pariah seemed to be spreading around the 2,500-unit Edenwald Gun Hill projects. The issue, they said, was simple to grasp once put in the context of their own lives.
Their dollars spent on sneakers their unemployed mothers and fathers have no chance to make.
"People want to work," Johnson said. "I could get 1,000 people here tomorrow who would make sneakers." That would be more than Michael Moore found in Flint.

HEADLINE: Glen Frazier Leet Dies at 89; Helped Aspiring Entrepreneurs

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Glen Frazier Leet, who worked to provide financing to entrepreneurs here and abroad and who aided community development programs around the world for more than five decades, died on April 7 at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 89.
Mr. Leet's credentials in self-help and community development date from the end of World War II, when he became involved in antipoverty work in Greece. After that, he was president of Save the Children and the Community Development Foundation and a consultant to governments on their environmental and community development plans. 
 In 1979, he and his wife, Mildred Robbins Leet, founded Trickle Up, a program that has helped an estimated 350,000 of the world's poorest people, many of them women, offering to them the opportunity to build new lives by starting a small business with grants of as little as $50 each. At his death, he was co-president with his wife.
The Leets formed their own consulting firm on social issues in the 1970's. Trickle Up, which grew from that experience, was started with $1,000 of their own money, a few computers on their dining-room table and the help of a part-time assistant. It now operates in 115 countries and estimates that it has spawned about 67,500 enterprises.
The program depends on individual donations and foundation grants and now operates from its West Side headquarters with a staff of 14. Although it was formed to benefit the world's poor, it began to make grants in this country, too, in 1994. The grants are typically about $500, with a $200 follow-up, and are given in conjunction with community-based agencies like the Harlem Business Outreach Center, the Central Vermont Community Action Council or the Institute for Social and Economic Development of Iowa.
Trickle Up reported recently that more than 80 percent of the wide variety of enterprises started since 1994 in the United States have remained in business. These include a caterer, a milliner, a T-shirt printer, a leather crafter, a day-care center, a photographer, a television repairer and a word-processing service.
Glen Leet was born in Brockton, Mass. He graduated from Norwich University in Vermont in 1930 and received a master's degree in public administration from Syracuse University. In 1935, representing the American Public Welfare Association, he helped draft social-welfare legislation for state legislatures.
Mr. Leet began his work as a volunteer for Unrra, the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, in 1944 and led its effort to relieve starvation in Greece in the wake of war and civil strife. That work led to a stint as the United Nations' first chief of community development in the 1950's, when he directed research, training and technical assistance for building infrastructures, mostly in developing countries. He helped governments set up community projects and organize self-help efforts for the poor.
As program director and, after 1971, as president of the Save the Children Foundation, he oversaw programs in urban areas as well as among the Indians of Arizona and New Mexico. In 1973, while engaged in that work, he met the woman who was to become his second wife.
Besides Mrs. Leet, he is survived by two daughters and a son from an earlier marriage, Frederika Leet of Manhattan, Carla Leet of Houston and Glen Jr., of Kingston, N.Y.; two stepdaughters, Aileen Robbins of Manhattan and Jane Marla Robbins of Los Angeles, four grandchildren and two great-granddaughters.
His first wife, Marcia Hatch Leet, died in 1971.

HEADLINE: Rancor Eases As the Koreas Open Talks After 4 Years

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 11

 BODY:
In a basement hotel conference room, North and South Korean officials held their first face-to-face talks in almost four years today, breaking a long, hostile silence with friendly overtures.
The two five-member teams, each led by a deputy minister, met for two hours in a session that a South Korean negotiator later described as "very sincere and friendly." They said they would meet again on Sunday. 
Although the talks had been prompted by a North Korean request for fertilizer to help ease its food shortage, the agenda of the meeting was far broader.
Negotiators discussed everything from large-scale economic investments by South Korea in North Korea to plans for reuniting families separated by the country's division.
The newly elected South Korean President, Kim Dae Jung, has made improved relations with the North a high priority, and this shift in policy has lent the meetings an upbeat tone.
As they filed into the meeting room today, both the North Korean delegates -- wearing red Kim Il Sung lapel pins commemorating their late leader, and their South Korean counterparts expressed hope that some sort of agreement could be reached.
Earlier governmental talks had been suspended at Kim Il Sung's death in 1994.
"The tone of these talks is certainly much more positive than anything since the early 90's," said Selig Harrison, a fellow at the Twentieth Century Fund who is an expert on Korea. "This is an encouraging indicator that the North is responding positively to the new President."
The United States Government has publicly encouraged the talks in Beijing, saying they could prompt progress in stalled four-way talks, which include China and the United States as well as the two Koreas.
However, some Western diplomats hold out little such hope, saying North Korea had been forced to the bargaining table more by a desperate shortage of food, fuel and other supplies than by a genuine desire for reconciliation.
At today's meeting, South Korea's leading negotiator, Deputy Minister of Reconciliation Jeong Se Hyun, told the North Koreans that his country was prepared to offer not only fertilizer but also other agricultural assistance.
He dangled the hope of money flowing North, saying South Korea was "preparing for a gradual expansion of intra-Korean economic cooperation including large scale investments in your territory."
Investment has been discouraged and severely limited in the past.
But the Deputy Minister said the South Koreans wanted economic and financial aid to be part of a comprehensive discussions that would include plans for exchanging envoys, re-establishing the border liaison office from which North Korea withdrew in 1996 and reuniting an estimated 10 million South Koreans with long-separated relatives in the North.
"I would like to emphasize that the aid would be realized vis-a-vis your corresponding measures to improve the South-North relationship," he said.
He suggested that dealing with the separated families, perhaps through a border meeting center or hometown reunions, would make the South Korean public more amenable to further aid to the North.
At the talks, the head of the North Korean delegation, Chun Kum Chul, said his side was also concerned about the issue of separated families, according to South Korean journalists who were allowed to attend the session.
The reporters said, without elaborating, that Mr. Chun had said North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, had sent a letter to South Korea in February that touched on the matter.
The North Korean delegation did not speak with reporters after the meeting, but experts say that their customarily strident statements against South Korea have been muted since Kim Dae Jung's election in the South and that their country's desperate food situation has left them more inclined to bargain.
When the Soviet Union collapsed, Communist North Korea lost its main supplier of fertilizer, fuel and other goods, leaving the country extremely vulnerable. In the last several years, the country has experienced floods and droughts that have left its citizens at short of food and even, some experts say, in a state of famine.
"These talks are a very important turning point," Mr. Harrison said. "But it won't be a quick process."

HEADLINE: Nguyen Co Thach, Hanoi Foreign Minister, 75

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 11

 BODY:
Former Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam, the urbane diplomat who struggled but failed to normalize relations with the United States in the 1980's, died on Friday at the age of 75, foreign diplomats in Hanoi said today.
There was no immediate announcement of his death by the Vietnamese leadership, which removed him in 1991 from his post as Foreign Minister and from the ruling Politburo. 
 He had reportedly been suffering for some time from various ailments, but had recovered enough last year to lead a Vietnamese delegation that met in Hanoi with the former United States Secretary of Defense, Robert S. McNamara, to discuss missed opportunities for peace during the Vietnam war.
Mr. Thach made it clear at that meeting that Vietnam had few regrets over its conduct of the war, which ended in 1975 with a Vietnamese victory and a reunification of the country that had been divided since its liberation in 1954 from French colonial rule.
Mr. Thach, a revolutionary from the age of 14 and a career diplomat fluent in French and English, first made his mark abroad in 1968 as an aide to Le Duc Tho in secret peace talks in Paris with Henry A. Kissinger, who was President Nixon's national security adviser and Secretary of State.
He later played a leading role in the 1973 Paris peace accords, which led to the American military withdrawal from Vietnam two years before Hanoi's final victory.
He became Foreign Minister in 1980 at a time when Vietnam was economically broken and internationally isolated, and put his energies into attempts to improve relations with the West.
He apparently fell from favor when Vietnam's ally, the Soviet Union, collapsed and Hanoi sought to improve relations with China.
His attempts at rapprochement with Washington were stalled by Vietnam's decade-long domination of neighboring Cambodia, from 1979 to 1989. His removal as Foreign Minister came as Vietnam turned its attention to better relations with China.
Mr. Thach retained the respect of many of his colleagues, who saw him as the most liberal and intellectual member of the leadership, and of many of his counterparts abroad, who were drawn to his charm and reasonable approach to problems.
Nguyen Co Thach was born in Nam Dinh province, in northern Vietnam, on March 15, 1923, and left school as a teen-ager to join the resistance against the French.
He was jailed by them for a year in the same prison that later became known as the Hanoi Hilton when it housed American prisoners of war. One of the P.O.W.'s was Pete Peterson, a fighter pilot who is now serving as the first United States Ambassador to a unified Vietnam, after the normalization of relations in 1995.
Mr. Thach rose to the rank of colonel in the Viet Minh resistance and joined the diplomatic service of North Vietnam after the country's partition in 1954. Two years later he became consul general in India.
He served for two decades as Deputy Foreign Minister, gaining an increasingly high profile abroad before being promoted to Foreign Minister. He became an alternate member of the Politburo in 1982 and a full member four years later, the first diplomat to join the ruling circle.
In 1987 he gained the additional post of Vice Chairman of the Council of Ministers, equivalent to the position of Deputy Prime Minister.
Mr. Thach is survived by his wife, Pham Thi Phuc.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nguyen Co Thach in Paris during Cambodian peace talks in 1989. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: In W.N.B.A., Hope for Union Of Their Own

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
A year ago, the women of the Women's National Basketball Association chose to settle for less -- modest money and little power -- for the privilege of playing professional ball in the United States and the greater good of starting a new league.
The league succeeded. Fans poured into arenas, the average 10,000-a-game attendance doubling the W.N.B.A.'s projections. And 50 million viewers tuned in to nationally televised games over the 10-week summer season. 
 Now, with their second season scheduled to begin with games on June 11, the players are wondering whether they need to ask for more.
Under the contracts they signed with the W.N.B.A., players can be terminated at any time, cannot endorse products that compete with the league's 15 sponsors, are not entitled to percentages from sales of team merchandise and receive health benefits only when they play, according to players and their representatives. The average player salary is $20,000 to $40,000 -- substantially less than that of the rival women's league, the American Basketball League. And the language in the W.N.B.A.'s contracts, the players say, is so ambiguous that it is unclear whether players are entitled to be paid if they are injured.
Chafing at the economic limitations and eager to garner greater rewards in light of the league's success, the women of the W.N.B.A. have begun to debate a volatile issue: forming a union. Conducting largely secret discussions -- the women have whispered among themselves at promotional events and talked more frankly at private dinners -- the players are trying to figure out who might represent them and how to get what they want without hurting the league they fought so hard to create.
The questions reverberate deep and wide for female athletes as, with their success and greater popularity, they face the possibilities and plagues that male athletes have grown accustomed to -- multimillion-dollar contracts, lucrative endorsements, free agency, salary caps and labor unrest. For the women, the issue of power is a real, if awkward, one. Indeed, the fear of reprisal on the issue of unionizing is so great that players refuse to be identified by name in speaking about it.
"Everybody was so happy and excited to be playing pro ball -- all the hype, the fans, the big time -- nobody was going to complain," one prominent W.N.B.A. player said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "We're willing to do what it takes to see the league succeed. But we also have to look after our own interests."
Trisonya Thompson Abraham, an agent who represents a W.N.B.A. player, said the players want "what the men have." She added: "They're playing in the same venues as the men, they have the N.B.A. name, its logo. Now they want a players association like the men have."
Unionization and the ability to bargain collectively that would come with it are not ideas that league officials are eager to embrace now.
"We are striving to be a major league sport; we want to be the fifth major league," said Valerie B. Ackerman, the president of the W.N.B.A., which drew 1.12 million fans last year. "That having been said, unionization is likely. We accept its possibility. But in some respects, it does seem premature. We're trying to make decisions that are right for us as a business. Decisions that will help us be viable and profitable in the long term and successful for years to come."
 
Pay From $5,000 To Six Figures
 The W.N.B.A. is owned by the 29 teams of the N.B.A., and the players -- 140 players are scheduled to play on 10 teams this summer -- are signed and paid by the league. The league refuses to release information on how much money it made last year -- its sources of revenue include ticket sales, television money, merchandising and sponsorship fees, although people knowledgeable about its finances say the W.N.B.A., at minimum, took in more than $10 million through ticket sales. Clearly, though, the league's single-entity structure is intended to control marketing and costs, and that desire to control costs has produced strikingly restrictive contracts with the players.
Although star players like Rebecca Lobo of the Liberty, Lisa Leslie of the Los Angeles Sparks and Cynthia Cooper and Sheryl Swoopes of the Houston Comets are being paid in the six-figure range, players on the taxi squad receive as little as $5,000. Agents for several players said their clients were unable to subsist on the salaries paid by the league.
Many players, like Kym Hampton and Wanda Guyton, who briefly thought the deals with the W.N.B.A. would relieve them of the financial need to play overseas to survive, wound up still needing to play in Europe and elsewhere this year. Promotional rewards for most of the players -- the league picks who makes such appearances -- typically amount to fees of from $500 to $1,000.
And unlike the men in the N.B.A., who receive a percentage of sales on team merchandise, the women do not contractually receive any revenues from the sale of millions of T-shirts, sweat shirts, athletic shoes and team banners -- even those bearing images of their faces. In one recent telling moment, in fact, one of the league's athletic apparel sponsors complimented a player about how well her jerseys were selling. When the player asked if the company would send her one or two jerseys to give to family members, the company's representative declined. The player bought her own.
Moreover, the players in the W.N.B.A., whatever the benefits of the league's $15 million spent in marketing last year, say they are in certain ways worse off financially than the women of the A.B.L., which just ended its second season. Those women, on average, are paid more -- $40,000 to $125,000 -- and receive better benefits, including a 401 (k) program. The A.B.L. players also are, through stock holdings, part owners of the league, their contracts are guaranteed and, through a loosely defined players association, they have a say in management decisions.
 
After One Season, Seeking Alternatives
 The W.N.B.A. players' contract negotiations with the league did not result in terms nearly so advantageous.
"We received lots of questions from this first generation of women professional basketball players who found themselves with 'take it or leave it' contracts," said Donna Lopiano, executive director of the Women's Sports Foundation, which has served as a consultant to professional female athletes. "They wanted to know from us what alternatives they had."
One alternative that has growing appeal is a union. Aside from providing higher salaries, improved health benefits, agent certification, guaranteed contracts and licensing revenues, a players union could fundamentally change the way the W.N.B.A. conducts its business. With a union, players believe they could have a say on issues like draft eligibility and the length of the season and also have the ability to contest dismissals or disciplinary action.
The history of female professional athletes and unions is mixed. The Women's Tennis Association, formed decades ago in an effort to gain tournament prize money equal to men's, has generally been regarded as a formidable success. But the three women's professional basketball leagues that preceded the W.N.B.A. and the A.B.L. never had unions and never lasted long.
"A lot of girls are being ripped off by agents," a W.N.B.A. player said. "Right now, there are no rules governing agents because that's what a union does. The N.B.A. players association certifies agents, sets fees and arbitrates disputes between players and agents. We don't have anybody looking out for us, and we really need it because this is so new to many of us."
The informal talk about unionizing has led to various proposals. The N.B.A. players union said it would like to represent the women, and many of the W.N.B.A. players feel it is the logical choice. The Women's Coaches Association, which has 4,500 members in the collegiate and professional ranks, is also lobbying for the job. There are, too, a handful of sports agents interested in organizing the women.
"We began talking to several players last summer with respect to unionization," said Billy Hunter, executive director of the N.B.A. players union. "The great majority were generally receptive. But the first year, most of the women were a bit reserved and conservative, because their main ambition was to insure the survival and success of the league and they didn't want to do anything to impede or jeopardize the league."
Mr. Hunter said it could take two to four years to put together a full-blown union and thus said joining the men made sense. "We've dealt with the league for 40 years," he said. "We obviously have the expertise."
But others, including some W.N.B.A. players, expressed reservations about joining ranks with the men.
"When it comes to choosing who gets the top lawyer, who gets the best representation? Does the union send its top gun to handle Latrell Sprewell or the 10th player on the bench for a W.N.B.A. team?" Paula McGee asked. Ms. McGee helped lead the University of Southern California to National Collegiate Athletic Association championships in 1983 and 1984 and played professionally overseas. She now represents her twin sister, Pamela, a center-forward for the W.N.B.A.'s Sacramento Monarchs.
"Another thing," Paula McGee said. "The men aren't concerned about issues like maternity leave. Some of these women are primary care givers. Normally, when a player is traded, they have to report to the new team within 48 hours. If I'm a man, no problem; the wife stays at home. If I'm a married woman with kids, it gets a little more complicated."
 
What Impact Would a Union Have?
 At this point the players seem uncertain who to choose, perhaps, in part, because they are not quite certain what it is they want to do. Some want to hold off on doing anything until the issue can be further studied.
The Women's Sports Foundation has established a committee that is looking into the needs of professional and amateur female athletes and aims to make wide-ranging recommendations on everything from marketing to money for players in all sports.
W.N.B.A. officials, in their defense, note that the league helps players with housing and transportation expenses during the season, and they say that the addition this season of two franchises in Detroit and Washington has resulted in 28 more jobs for players. The league said it has also increased salaries by 25 percent over last year.
Still, league officials are wary of the impact of a union.
"We have one season under our belt," said Ms. Ackerman, the W.N.B.A. president. "We did better than expected the first year, but does that mean we will have continued success? I hope so. I just don't know.
"We recognize the league will develop and evolve and we are very receptive to input from wherever it comes, be it the teams, players or sponsors," she added. "But we're trying to look at what's right for the W.N.B.A. most of all, and focusing pretty much exclusively on our business interests and business needs, and harmonizing those needs with those of the players."
But Ms. Thompson Abraham, the agent, said the players are interested in, if also nervous about, seeking their own definition of full justice.
"Right now, players, especially those in the W.N.B.A., are powerless," she said. "But they're so happy to be a part of a league where they can stay at home that they're happy to settle, even if it's not perfect. The players want to play, and they know that if they don't take it, there will be someone out there ready and willing to take their place."

HEADLINE: Taxi Conversions Are Another Step In the City's Move to Cleaner Vehicles

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Last week, a Queens taxi garage made news with the announcement that it was buying 100 natural-gas-powered vehicles, but for some time New York City has been laying the groundwork for cleaning up automotive emissions.
The first step has been to build the nation's largest fleet of natural-gas-powered vehicles -- 3,000 in all -- from taxis to delivery vans to buses. The second, and perhaps more important, step is to establish fueling stations to service the vehicles. 
 Industry officials and advocates of alternative fuels say that the growth in fueling stations would encourage the buying and use of natural-gas-powered vehicles, which produce far less pollution than gasoline-powered cars. And the fueling stations could also be used to service vehicles powered by a newer technology: fuel cells, which, in effect, are batteries that never need recharging.
And fuel cells mean that pure hydrogen could supplant natural gas, meaning no vehicle emissions and even better fuel economies.
"When you look around the rest of the country, you don't find the same kind of concentrated forward motion as you find in New York," said Richard Kassel, senior attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Robert B. Catell, chairman and chief executive of Keyspan Energy Company, a subsidiary of Brooklyn Union Gas that has been a leader in the city's natural-gas conversion efforts, said he expects that within a decade more than half the city's delivery vans will be powered by natural gas.
But there are huge obstacles. One is the price of gasoline -- about $1.15 a gallon now -- which city transportation authorities fear may be too low to push car buyers to shift to natural gas. Another is that there are already millions of electrical outlets, which advocates of electric vehicles say can be used to recharge the vehicles. Still another is that the range of natural-gas vehicles is limited and that fueling stations are sparse, particularly in rural areas.
Moreover, to many people, hydrogen power still seems more at home in laboratories than the marketplace.
New York ranks first among cities east of the Mississippi in particulates and ozone, two forms of pollution that can severely damage lungs. Well over half of these pollutants could be removed in New York City by eliminating automotive emissions from gasoline-powered vehicles, Mr. Kassel and other experts suggest.
Buses are a special problem. Despite its leadership in converting delivery vans and taxis, the city has been slow to switch over its bus fleet to natural gas, according to Inform Inc., an environmental research organization.
But advocates of alternative energy draw inspiration from the city's record on encouraging a natural-gas-vehicle market. They point to 1,500 municipal vehicles, from pickups to full-size sanitation trucks; 1,000 vehicles owned by fleets, from United Parcel Service to the Postal Service to milk companies, and 700 vehicles owned by Brooklyn Union and Consolidated Edison, the principal sellers of natural gas in the city.
And taxis represent perhaps the most expansive frontier. On Thursday, the Ford Motor Company announced that it sold Winner's Garage in Queens 100 natural-gas-powered cabs to replace its entire fleet. That brought the city's number of natural-gas taxis to 270.
"I can't think of a city that's making a big push toward natural-gas taxis like New York," Mr. Kassel said.
More than 300 additional cabs are expected to be sold under incentives offered by the state and Ford, totaling more than $10,000 per vehicle, enough to cover the additional expense of such cabs.
In mass transit, the city Department of Transportation has bought 53 buses for the 7 bus franchises it operates. It has ordered 174 more and has said that it will exercise an option to buy 120 others. Its total fleet is 1,100 buses.
The Metropolitan Transit Authority has been less aggressive. Just 39 buses in its fleet of 3,500 are powered by natural gas.
But in total, the converted cars, vans, trucks and buses could begin to form the basis for a hydrogen-powered transportation system. Already, 50 natural-gas fueling stations exist in New York State, most in or around the city. These could be used to directly inject hydrogen into fuel tanks or to inject natural gas, from which pure hydrogen would be extracted in the vehicle.
A fuel cell in the vehicle would combine the hydrogen with oxygen through an electrochemical process, without combustion. This process produces energy, leaving pure water as the only waste product.
"Anything you can do to bring natural gas into the transportation system is paving the way for the hydrogen fuel cell," said James Cannon, senior energy fellow for Inform, the environmental research organization. "Every conquest natural gas makes today will help people down the road get to hydrogen."
Private companies are pushing ahead on both natural gas and the fuel cell. All three big American auto companies -- Ford, General Motors and Chrysler -- are offering natural-gas-powered cars this year for the first time, and all three are developing prototype fuel cells. Brooklyn Union is already demonstrating fuel cells at industrial plants on Staten Island, while a waste-water treatment facility in Yonkers uses fuel-cell technology.
New York State is also working on a number of fronts. One program gives buyers of cars powered by alternative fuels up to $5,000 in an investment tax credit and truck buyers $10,000.
New York is also the only state to require 2 percent of all vehicles sold this year to have "zero emissions," a program that can help in the sale of electric or gasoline cars.
The city, under a 1991 law, is also stepping up its purchase of alternative-fuel vehicles. This year, 80 percent of new municipal cars and trucks must use fuels other than gasoline or diesel fuel. Another city and state idea is to paint some curbs green as free parking spaces for alternative-fuel vehicles.
All this is beginning to add up to pressure for cleaner cars.
"The technology's available right now," Mr. Catell of Keyspan Energy said. "What's needed is a little bit of market pull."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Expos Have Eyes on Downtown to Turn Around the Team's Fortunes

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Claude Brochu, managing partner of the Montreal Expos, expects the club to turn a profit this year. With a $9.2 million payroll, that economic trick should not be hard to execute. But Brochu is looking well beyond this year.
"I've made a commitment to the organization that we're not going to go through what we've gone through," said Brochu, keeper of the major leagues' lowest and most widely discussed payroll. 
 "We either build a competitive team in Montreal or do it somewhere else. We feel we have a very talented group of players and we think we can win with them in a couple years."
The days of shedding players for financial considerations are over, Brochu said. From here on, the payroll goes in only one direction -- up.
"We'll double the payroll next year and again the year after," he said. "Then probably increase by who knows how much the year after that. We have to position ourselves at 90 percent of the industry average or we'll never win."
Integral to the Expos' ambitious long-range plans is a new stadium, making Montreal one of a growing number of cities whose baseball future is linked to a new playground. It is happening in Milwaukee, Seattle, Detroit and San Francisco, where new parks are under construction, and it is a dream of more than half a dozen other teams, including Pittsburgh, San Diego, Minnesota, Cincinnati and Florida.
All of these teams see visions of Baltimore and Cleveland in their dreams because the Orioles and the Indians offer living proof of what new parks can do for revenue. In addition, the Indians are a vibrant example of how a team can be built along with the new park.
The Expos' meager payroll is the lowest in the majors since the Indians paid their players $8.8 million in 1992. The Indians now have one of the highest payrolls but also one of the best teams, having won three consecutive division championships and played in the World Series two of those three seasons.
"We outlined our game plan some time ago," Brochu said. "I figure in this business you better have a $50 million payroll or you won't win. There's no sense being at 40 or 35 or 20. You won't win."
The average payroll, Brochu said, will be in the $65 million to $70 million area in a few years. "If we're going to compete," he said, "we will have to have a payroll that will be at least 90 percent of that average."
In recent years, low attendance has undermined the Expos, who have developed some of the best players in the majors who no longer play for them. From a record of 2.32 million attendance in 1983, the Expos have dropped to a more typical 1.5 million fans, which they drew last season.
"In my estimation," Brochu said, "in 1994, we probably had one of the best teams of the decade, but we wouldn't have drawn two million people. I was concerned we didn't have a baseball town. But I've identified the problem. It's clear we have a stadium problem. If we relocate downtown, we can do in Montreal what was done in Cleveland and maybe what was done in Baltimore. If we go downtown, we'll bring in the business community, which we haven't had before."
The Expos hope to get a $180 million, 35,000-seat park with an umbrella-type roof that will cover the field and the seats when it rains. A downtown site has been staked out and an option taken on the land.
The club's goal is to sell $100 million in personal seat licenses by June 30 as a sign that corporate Montreal wants the team to remain in the city and that the government should formulate a plan to finance construction of the new park.
"We're no longer a small market; we're a micromarket," Brochu said. "We can't afford to take on any debt service. This thing has to be completely financed by the community."
In the meantime, the team will struggle to be competitive with players named Brad Fullmer, Jose Vidro, Javier Vazquez and Trey Moore. "Sure, it's tough," General Manager Jim Beattie said. "Veteran players have a hard time going through it."
But just as the players are frustrated, Beattie said, so is everyone else.
"Our owners are frustrated that they've had to operate this way," he said. "But we're trying to save the club for the city of Montreal. It's not a lot of fun for anybody to be going through, but it's the reality of the game today that puts teams like ours at a disadvantage, and we have to battle at it."
Brochu said he knows he has made himself unpopular by starting at the bottom again. "But you have to look at the bigger picture," he said. "The business community is not concerned about who's playing third base for us right now."
 
Battered From the Start
 The Seattle Mariners lost Randy Johnson's first two starts, in which he gave up 12 earned runs in 11 2/3 innings. The Kansas City Royals lost Pat Rapp's first two starts, both against Baltimore, in which he allowed one run in 14 innings.
Pitchers have had no shortage of awful starts in this young season. The worst of the worst: Jeremi Gonzalez, Chicago Cubs, seven batters, no outs, six runs; Marc Valdes, Montreal, five runs in one third of an inning; Kevin Tapani, Cubs, nine runs in two innings; Jim Bullinger, Seattle, 10 runs in 3 and a third innings; Manny Aybar, St. Louis, 7 runs in 2 and one-third innings.
 
Cubs Put Out and Receive
 The Chicago Cubs decided it was time to make an investment, and it has already paid off. Unlike last year when the Cubs lost their first 14 games, this season they have won 6 of their first 7, and 8 of their first 10.
"The past year and a half or so we didn't do very well," Andy MacPhail, the Cubs' president, said. "I wouldn't wish it on my worst enemy."
Two factors figured in the decision to spend money, MacPhail said.
"We felt we had a more legitimate foundation to build on than we had the past two years," he said. And for the fans' sake, he added, "We felt it was important to turn it around and have a good season this year."
The Cubs signed closer Rod Beck and shortstop Jeff Blauser as free agents and traded for second baseman Mickey Morandini and left fielder Henry Rodriguez. Their payroll, which was $30.8 million at the end of last season, soared to $49.4 million.
The winter spending decisions paid off even before the season began with a six-game winning streak following an opening-day loss.
"Our season-ticket sales are up and our individual ticket sales are up," MacPhail said. "That's no easy feat based on a 68-win season."
 
Ups and Downs for Rosado
 Last July 8, Jose Rosado experienced the biggest thrill of his incipient career. Midway through his first full major league season, the Kansas City Royals pitcher pitched in the All-Star Game and received credit for the victory when Sandy Alomar Jr. hit a tie-breaking home run while he was still in the game.
The next day the Royals changed managers, and Tony Muser is still looking for the pitcher who performed well enough to be named to the All-Star team. Before the break, the young left-hander had a 7-4 record and a 3.39 earned run average. After the break, he skidded to 2-8 and 6.75, doing nothing to impress the new manager. Rosado didn't make a favorable impression in spring training either and lost his job in the starting rotation.
Last Thursday, in his third appearance as a reliever, Rosado gave up an eighth-inning run that gave Baltimore a 2-1 victory.
 
A Lasting Impression
 Kevin Millar, yet another member of last season's Class AA Portland (Maine) Sea Dogs, joined the Class Z Florida Marlins last week, but it was an earlier stop in his minor league travels that added to the significance of his promotion.
The 26-year-old infielder began his professional career with the St. Paul (Minn.) Saints of the independent Northern League in 1993. That is the team owned by Marvin Goldklang. The team has started and revived the careers of a growing number of major leaguers.
"Kevin was different from the others," said Goldklang, who also is a Yankees limited partner. "He was the first player we signed to his first professional contract after he went through the draft undrafted."
A third baseman who had gone to Lamar University, Millar was deemed by scouts to have a slow bat and to be below average defensively.
"I signed him largely on the recommendation of his college coach, Jim Gilligan," Goldklang said. "He came in as the 22d player on a 22-man roster and won the third base job. He was one of the hardest workers I've had on the team. He did not have a slow bat, and he was better defensively than advertised."
In five minor league seasons, Millar batted .313, and with Portland last season he hit 32 home runs and drove in 131 runs and was named the Eastern League player of the year.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bill Has Egypt's Copts Squirming

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: CAIRO

 BODY:
A proposed American law aimed at reducing persecution of religious minorities abroad has aroused anger here, even among the people it is intended to help, and has brought an outcry against American interference in the domestic affairs of other nations.
The Freedom From Religious Persecution Act was approved on March 25 by the House Committee on International Relations by a vote of 31 to 5. It is expected to be submitted to the full House in May. The Senate bill is pending in the Foreign Relations Committee. The bill would mandate sanctions against countries found guilty of religious discrimination. 
 Advocates of the law have made it clear that it is aimed at these situations: China's persecution of certain Christians, Muslims and Tibetan Buddhists; Saudi Arabia's treatment of its non-Muslim expatriate work force, and the alleged systematic persecution of the large Christian populations in Egypt and the Sudan.
But the legislation has been opposed by many Egyptian Copts, the largest Christian minority in the Arab world.
If enacted, such a law could strengthen the demands of those in Congress who want to eliminate American economic aid to Egypt, now at $2 billion a year, which has been a pillar of Egyptian-American relations for nearly two decades -- since Egypt signed the Camp David peace accord with Israel.
The proposed law comes as the Arab world is boiling over with accusations that the United States applies a double standard of justice -- punishing Arab and Muslim countries with sanctions while overlooking alleged Israeli violations of Palestinian rights. The assault on the proposal has been joined by Government and opposition news organizations, members of Parliament and members of the public -- including leading figures among Copts, who feel they are being used as pawns by enemies of Egypt.
"Those who are trying to incite foreigners to interfere in Egypt's internal affairs are, in fact, stabbing Copts in the heart," said Edward Ghali Eldahabi, a Coptic member of the People's Assembly, a consultative group made up of senior jurists and community leaders.
Another Copt, Mounir Abdelnour, chairman of the board of Vitrac, a major exporter of food products, said: "Yes, there are problems. But we are not killed in the streets by Muslims, and these issues can be solved within a framework of a national dialogue."
Copts contend that they are not a cultural or ethnic minority but Egyptians whose ancestors embraced Christianity in the first century. They make up about 10 percent of Egypt's population of 65 million.
Speaking privately, prominent Copts in business, the arts and the professions concede that there are indeed discriminatory measures against Copts.
One is an archaic law dating from the Ottoman Empire era that bans the construction or repair of churches. Another is the general failure of Egyptian schools to include Egypt's six centuries of Coptic influence before the advent of Islam in high school history courses.
Copts are also excluded from much of the country's political life, including senior Government jobs, and from most top-level academic positions. Still, most Copts here maintain that the wisest way to deal with the issue is quietly, and within Egypt.
"We don't have an affirmative action program, if you will, concerning Copts but there is no active persecution," said a high-ranking Coptic official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
One of Egypt's most successful Coptic businessmen, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "Such laws may advance the political agenda of some, but they overlook the harm it could do to all Copts here."
"As the population grows bigger and poorer, Islamic fundamentalism has grown considerably stronger," he continued. "It would be like hitting the wall with your head. The Americans can impose sanctions, but they cannot and will not help us."
On the other side of the divide, those leading the lobbying for the measure are the growing and powerful Coptic populations in the United States, Canada, Europe and Australia -- estimated at well over 600,000. The Coptic immigrants, most of whom have arrived in the last 20 years seeking economic opportunities, have formed powerful lobbies that encourage political activism.
"We did not invent the law," Selim Naguib, a leading activist among Copts in Canada, said in a telephone interview. "This is a matter of sovereign American decisions. But if Egypt practices no discrimination against its Christians, as the Government claims, why do they fear it?"
Mr. Naguib, a retired jurist who lives in Montreal, has co-signed full page advertisements like one that appeared in The New York Times on Feb. 13 and The Washington Post on March 24 contending that Christians in Egypt are treated as second-class citizens by Muslim militants in the Government establishment and that hate crimes against the Copts are not pursued vigorously by law-enforcement officials.
"I love Egypt as much as anyone," he said. "But it defies logic to say there are no problems for Copts when they are getting killed in their churches and shops and excluded from Government except in the most token fashion. Instead of saying everything is fine, what are the solutions our critics are proposing to address these problems?"
The Government's reaction has been to marshal legions of Copts to assert in newspapers, on radio and television that they face no discrimination and to brand those outside as traitors.
"This small minority of fanatical migrant Copts has allowed itself to be a toy in the hands of Zionist organizations opposed to Egypt, spreading these lies in very expensive paid advertisements to provoke foreign nations into pressuring Egypt," said Makram Mohammed Makram, a Muslim who is chairman of the board and executive editor of the Government-owned Al Mussawar. His comments reflected the official view that Christians are doing well in business and professional circles.
A different view has been expressed, though, by many Egyptian Muslims -- particularly among the large liberal elite -- like Saeed Alnajaar, an intellectual and pro-democracy activist who is leader of the New Appeal Club, a liberal forum. He contends that the problems the Copts face are part of "the general political stagnation of the country, which needs to adopt a truly democratic opening in which all issues can be discussed freely and openly."
"On the personal level," said Mr. Alnajaar, "Copts in Egypt have no problems, but it is unquestionably true that on the institutional legalistic level they have something to complain about. The issues are not difficult to solve with some good will -- but above all with a great deal more freedom for all."
