HEADLINE: Can-Do American's Patience Paid Off With an Ulster Pact

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 11

 BODY:
Ask George J. Mitchell why he gave up the comforts of retirement from the United States Senate to spend three years trying to wring a peace agreement out of the feuding political leaders of Northern Ireland and he will tell you about his 6-month-old son.
On the day that Andrew Mitchell was born last October, Mr. Mitchell, the former Senate majority leader, asked his staff to find out how many babies were delivered in Northern Ireland that day. There were 61. 
 "I believe that they are entitled to the same chance in life that I want for my son," he said. "Peace, political stability and reconciliation are not too much to ask for. They are the minimum that a decent civilized society provides."
They are also qualities that have been notably at a minimum in Northern Ireland, where leaders are more accustomed to greeting one another with robust snubs and rebukes. Mr. Mitchell likes to quote David Ervine, leader of the Progressive Unionist Party, who says, "Northern Ireland is the only place I know where someone will drive 100 miles out of his way just to receive an insult."
On Friday, Mr. Ervine joined other political leaders around the negotiating table in praising the former Senator for his stewardship of the 22 months of talks it took to produce that day's peace accord for Northern Ireland. There was general agreement in the tributes that without his guidance and forbearance no accord would have emerged.
As the praise for the self-effacing and indefatigably upbeat 64-year-old chairman continued, Mr. Ervine put it more simply: "I don't know how you stood us all that time."
Lord Alderdice, leader of the moderate Alliance Party, which includes Roman Catholics and Protestants, said: "At various times in this process I have really felt for him. Here the United States sent one of its most able, skilled, talented, humble politicians, a supreme diplomat, and frankly we didn't deserve him."
In his own closing remarks, Mr. Mitchell said he had not had a cross word directed at him the whole time. This probably made him unique in that room, where so much bitterness was continually on display.
Over breakfast recently at the Stormont Hotel across from the drab Civil Service buildings where negotiators met, he theorized that "people here are very nice and friendly -- they're just not friendly to each other." That they remained friendly to him stems from the attribute most often cited for his success: his patience and his willingness to listen.
Since beginning to come here regularly three years ago as an economic adviser to President Clinton, a mission that grew into his assignment as chairman of the peace talks, Mr. Mitchell has become a popular figure in Belfast. On his strolls through the lobby of the downtown Europa Hotel, where he normally stays, he has to pause to shake hands and greet well-wishers.
"Back for more torture?" the piano player in the hotel bar once asked him on one of his more than 100 shuttle-diplomacy trips.
Since taking over the talks in June 1996, his schedule has been to fly to Belfast for the three days of the week that the negotiations are on and then to return to his law practice in Washington and to Heather MacLachlan, the woman he married after leaving the Senate in 1995, promising her that he was also leaving politics.
At the outset of the talks, his widely praised bent for patient attentiveness could be time-consuming. He let Robert McCartney, head of the militant UK Unionist Party, which eventually quit the negotiations, speak for seven hours uninterrupted. He reasoned that just the fact that political leaders of this conflicted society were talking was progress.
Mr. Mitchell said that in more recent months, the pace of the talks had quickened. "When we go in there, we really get down to work," he said.
A member of the Senate for almost 15 years until his retirement in 1995, Mr. Mitchell said his experience there prepared him well for his role here. "I had plenty of practice listening to long debates, seeing people waste time, stall and delay," he said. The big difference in Northern Ireland, he said, was "the overlay of violence," a reminder of which he received at the start of each day in Belfast when an aide would brief him at breakfast on the shootings and mortar attacks and fire bombings that had occurred overnight. Sectarian bloodshed has cost more than 3,200 lives since 1969.
Political parties were admitted to the talks only after signing a commitment to nonviolence and democracy known as the Mitchell Principles. When paramilitary fighters represented by the Ulster Democrats and Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, were linked to killings in January, the two parties were suspended from the talks until the truces were clearly holding again.
Mr. Mitchell's success in establishing those entry conditions demonstrated a talent that was to become essential in the last two weeks: the ability to draft language that Northern Ireland's politicians could agree on. "I once told them that the challenge we faced was having to find a way to come up with words that neither side owns," Mr. Mitchell said.
There are long-nursed bitter hurts in the politics of Northern Ireland, grievances stemming from episodes in history that are recalled and cited as contemporary rationale for holding to unyielding positions. Political leaders have to take soundings of their followers more frequently than public figures do in other Western societies. Missteps can be fatal.
"The political pull in Northern Ireland is not toward the center but away from it," Mr. Mitchell said. "Compromise is a foreign concept. There are no win-wins, only winners and losers, and that's a part of their history, culture, vocabulary and experience."
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain noted this characteristic in his remarks in Belfast on Friday, saying that the agreement should end the tradition. "Put this agreement into practice, and we all win," he said.
Aware that part of the reason for throwing a former United States Senator into the Northern Ireland mix was to inject some American can-do positivism into a nay-saying culture, Mr. Mitchell said he once mused out loud about American history.
"I talked about the drafters of the Constitution where big states wanted representation by population and small states wanted it by states and this fellow from Connecticut jumped up and said, 'Why don't we do both?' Every American believes that compromise can result in a better idea than the beginning ideas."
By February, Mr. Mitchell realized that they would not make the May deadline set by Mr. Blair unless he fixed a firm cutoff point, and with the backing of Mr. Blair and Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland he settled on last Thursday, the last day before the four-day Easter break. He said then that in his days as Senate majority leader he had always found scheduling votes just before the summer break a good way to focus people on taking action.
On Friday night, he reported a further reason for the rush. He said he feared that the splinter guerrilla groups determined to undermine the talks might try to assassinate him or one of the other participants.
Early on Tuesday, he presented all the parties with his synthesis of their arguments, noting commonalities and reducing to clear options the areas of continuing disagreement. It was that document, refined in three days of round-the-clock dealing, that formed the basis for the agreement that emerged on Friday.
The strong possibility of collapse dogged the talks until the very end, and only the intervention of Mr. Mitchell, the two Prime Ministers and President Clinton on the phone from Washington in the feverish last hours held it together.
In the early hours of Friday, Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, said the design of the new council being created to link the governments of the Irish Republic and Northern Ireland was too subject to the new Northern Ireland Assembly, which will have a Protestant majority. A compromise was worked out whereby the council will be set up before the new Assembly is in place to shape it. Sinn Fein appeared to be back on board.
Then David Trimble, leader of the largest Protestant party, the Ulster Unionists, raised deal-breaking objections over the disarmament of paramilitary groups, reform of the predominantly Protestant Royal Ulster Constabulary and how prisoner releases would be treated. Mr. Blair composed a letter giving him the necessary guarantees that he would not be "locked into" an arrangement that could not be broken in the event of a resumption of I.R.A. violence. Mr. Clinton was asked to phone Mr. Trimble with reassurances.
On Friday afternoon, some of Mr. Trimble's party members raised objections to a provision that appeared to make the release of paramilitary prisoners automatic rather than dependent upon conditions at the time. Mr. Trimble withheld his support of the final document until he could quiet the dispute with clarifying language.
"At 4:45 P.M. he said he wanted to go," Mr. Mitchell said Friday night. "At that moment I thought this process is too volatile so we better get it done. I told my staff to tell everyone the meeting was at 5 P.M."
At 5:37 P.M. Mr. Mitchell made his dramatic announcement that a settlement had been reached.
If on flying back to the United States today he is leaving behind what he has described as the most difficult negotiations of his political life, that will not be the dominant memory. In his parting words to the delegates in Belfast, he said, "I have been in politics for 30 years and never have I felt this sense of gratification and responsibility and gratitude that I feel today."

HEADLINE: Evidence Is Scant That Workfare Leads to Full-Time Jobs

SERIES: DOES WORKFARE WORK? First of four articles.

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
Three years ago, when a national overhaul of welfare was still a Republican dream in Washington, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began his own ambitious experiment. At its heart was a vast expansion of workfare -- sending tens of thousands of New Yorkers into parks, city offices and hospital wards to work for their welfare checks.
Since then, 200,000 people have passed through what has become by far the largest workfare program in the nation: more than 34,000 are enrolled today. Mr. Giuliani often hails workfare as a keystone of his mayoralty and a national model for rousting people from a culture of dependency. 
 When he does so, he can point out that the city's welfare rolls have shrunk by nearly a third, in part because workfare has forced out people who used to work secretly while getting public assistance. Workfare, the Mayor often says, has also taught some welfare recipients lessons about the ennobling value of work and the responsibility of contributing to society.
But an extensive examination by The New York Times found scant evidence that workfare has accomplished one of its central goals: moving a significant number of people from welfare to full-time work.
Workfare has provided limited job training for many of the poorly skilled, poorly educated New Yorkers on public assistance. Much of the work is so menial that it offers few, if any, skills that employers demand. Participants receive little help looking for a permanent job; half of them get none at all.
And there is no indication that many people have been able to use workfare as a springboard to a real job: a recent state survey, the first of its kind, found that after three months off the rolls, fewer than a third of those who left welfare in New York City had found full- or part-time jobs on the books.
Where workfare leads is a matter of growing urgency as welfare recipients for the first time face being cut off the rolls under new state and Federal laws. The Federal law, enacted two years ago, places a five-year limit on single mothers; adults without young children, supported by the city and state program formerly called Home Relief, are under a two-year limit on cash benefits.
But many workfare participants say they already knew how to push a broom or pick up trash and are mystified at how workfare will lead them to a permanent job.
Mark Cummings, who is 46 and used to be a handyman and plumber, has picked up trash and done odd jobs in Prospect Park since 1995 in return for public assistance. He enjoys the work, is treated well by his supervisors and has only one real complaint: "I just wish this led somewhere."
The Mayor and his senior aides declined to be interviewed for this article and for most of the others in this series of articles. They would not discuss the history of workfare or even some basic questions of fact. Nor would they talk about its future, although the city has quietly made some recent adjustments, and the Mayor's new Social Services Commissioner has hinted of more to come.
"The feeling here now is they would rather not sit down and discuss these issues," said Mr. Giuliani's deputy press secretary, Jack Deacy. "They feel the program's well known."
Some aspects of workfare have indeed been reported before. But to understand in far greater detail how workfare works, and to assess its effectiveness, four Times reporters visited more than 50 work sites over the last four months and spoke with hundreds of participants and supervisors.
The inquiry showed that workfare had failed to live up to a number of promises:
*The Mayor says workfare participants have not taken the places of regular city employees. But, in seeming violation of state welfare law, many participants, especially those cleaning city office buildings or working as clerks and receptionists, are doing work once performed by civil servants. In some cases, they are working side by side with civil servants, doing the same tasks.
*There is a severe shortage of child care for mothers called to workfare. Although state law requires the city to find safe child care for those mothers, the shortage has left some caseworkers unable -- or unwilling -- to give women the help they need. And while mothers without proper care are supposed to be excused from workfare, caseworkers sometimes threaten to cut off their welfare benefits, pushing them into leaving their children in substandard care.
*Picayune or technical work rules are sometimes rigidly enforced, pushing people off welfare whether it is warranted or not. These punishments have created a sizable churning in which thousands of people are cut off the welfare rolls each month, only to return later. When welfare recipients challenge these sanctions in administrative hearings, they are successful two-thirds of the time.
*Working conditions have improved, but workfare participants are still sometimes denied access to toilets and drinking water or lack basic equipment like raincoats and boots. Some, like Clara Chalk, who sweeps the streets of Brooklyn, have not even been issued winter coats.
Even with such problems, many workfare participants said they were happy to be working, were usually treated fairly and found most supervisors empathetic. "This is better," said Celena Vargas, who was raking leaves at a Bronx housing project. "I didn't do anything in my home."
But critics of workfare, and some proponents as well, argue that if people are to find real jobs, most need to know more than how to report to work on time -- especially in a city where the unemployment rate is 9.2 percent, nearly double the national average. They point out that the welfare population is hardly a model labor pool: many recipients have limited skills and educations, a significant number are addicted to drugs or alcohol and some resist the idea of working.
The critics of workfare are hardly limited to liberal Democrats and advocates for the poor. Across the country, where the welfare caseload has dropped by about a third, local officials rethinking welfare have largely shunned workfare as an expensive program that has not been notably successful at getting people into real jobs. Instead, they have pushed people directly into the private job market, especially in areas where unemployment is much lower than in New York.
New York is the only city to move large numbers of single mothers into workfare. By contrast, Los Angeles County, with the nation's largest welfare caseload and second-largest workfare program, hopes to keep most mothers out of workfare. Officials plan to spend the next two years helping mothers look for jobs, improve their basic education and hone their vocational skills. Only mothers who do not find jobs after two years will end up in workfare.
Mr. Giuliani, though, often does not use jobs as a measure of workfare's success. He emphasizes instead the 31 percent decline in the welfare rolls, to 797,000 last month from 1.16 million in 1995. The core of that decline, he said in a speech in February, "is the workfare program, which continues to be controversial, but it's something that I think is probably the best thing that we've done."
But many participants said the public debate had ignored many daily realities of what is formally called the Work Experience Program. Some said there was often not enough work to fill a shift. Parks workers are often sent home early, especially in winter. Some W.E.P. workers who sweep streets or clean outside housing projects said they finished in an hour or two, then spent their shifts hanging out.
Sometimes, supervisors just make work.
At the Sedgwick Houses, a housing project in the Bronx, a workfare crew finished raking leaves by 10:30 one morning, recalled Yolanda Green, a member of the crew. The supervisor grabbed the plastic bags into which the leaves had been swept, dumped the leaves back out and told the workers to sweep them up again. Ms. Green refused, but before the dispute could be resolved, rain began to fall and the workers and their supervisor went inside.
 
The Mission
A Shift From Training To the 'Work Ethic'
Workfare in New York dates back to the Koch administration in the mid-1980's, when the city began requiring some welfare recipients to choose from a mix of training programs, high school equivalency classes or work experience in city agencies.
Early in 1995, the Giuliani administration started to expand workfare dramatically and to narrow the choices. What it created were essentially two programs.
The first participants were adults on Home Relief, who are required to stay on workfare until they find full-time jobs. Participants typically work 25 to 35 hours every two weeks -- in six- or seven-hour shifts -- most of them for the Sanitation or Parks Departments.
There are no training or educational programs available for W.E.P. workers on Home Relief. The Mayor says he is convinced that most participants need only learn basic work skills to get a job in the private sector.
"In welfare, I think one of the prime mistakes that we made was we put training first and work second," Mr. Giuliani said in an interview with Times reporters and editors four days before his re-election last November. "And therefore when they did that institutionally, millions of people lost the work ethic. Work is hard. Getting up every day, making sure you get to a job, getting yourself cleaned and ready to do it -- there's a certain discipline that's required for everybody in that. And what we were doing in welfare was training, training, training, training."
In 1996, the city expanded workfare again, to single mothers on welfare. Some were forced to leave college or other school programs. By last January, the last month for which complete data were available, there were 17,000 single mothers in workfare, along with 16,000 adults on Home Relief.
Most mothers work five days a week from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M., usually filing papers or doing general cleaning in city offices. After six months, they spend a month in a basic job-search class and are sent out to look for work. Those who do not get a job -- and they are the vast majority -- usually return to workfare.
Today, despite the expansion, the 34,100 people in workfare represent fewer than 10 percent of the adults on welfare. An additional 130,000 adults have been deemed eligible for workfare but have yet to be put to work. City officials declined to explain why.
From the start, the city essentially took a one-size-fits-all approach to workfare. Participants were generally given low-skill jobs, whether or not they had work experience.
For 14 years, Eustacia Ojeda had worked as a cashier in a Brooklyn liquor store. A year ago, the owner retired and the store shut down. She was making $140 a week at the time. Now, she finds herself picking up trash in the parks and feeling bitter that the city is not helping her find a job.
Ms. Ojeda went on Home Relief when her unemployment benefits ran out. She gets food stamps, a rent allowance and $101 a month in cash. In return, she sweeps and rakes five days every two weeks at the Parade Grounds, a complex of baseball diamonds and tennis courts next to Prospect Park.
"We don't learn anything here," she said. "The program says you come here for training, but all we do is pick up paper."
Ms. Ojeda said she had been answering newspaper ads in hope of finding work. Nothing has come through, and she suspects it has to do with her age. "It's hard to find a job now for me, because I'm 56," she said.
Critics of workfare say her predicament shows the futility of the one-size-fits-all approach. Since she already knows basic work skills, they say, the city should be teaching her new skills to make her more marketable.
"It's one thing if all you want to do is to create a permanent workfare work force," said City Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the General Welfare Committee. "But the fact is that we are supposed to go from welfare to work, not from welfare to workfare."
Of course, many, if not most, people in workfare do not have Ms. Ojeda's long grounding in work. But whether the stain on someone's resume involves time in prison or an interrupted education, even proponents of workfare say that kind of personal history is precisely why people need to learn more than basic work habits to get a job.
"Workfare is an essential first component in any welfare reform program," said Suzanne Strickland, a supporter of the W.E.P. program who as a private consultant created a city program on linking welfare recipients with private companies.
Ms. Strickland said it was an important administrative achievement just to have reviewed everyone in Home Relief to determine who was capable of enrolling in workfare and to strip the rolls of people who had used welfare to supplement off-the-books jobs.
But because more than half of those on welfare do not have high school diplomas, she said, work experience has to be combined with education, training and experience in private companies to move people permanently off welfare. Also, many companies require applicants to pass a drug test, "and that's a problem," she said.
"Work experience in a workfare program," Ms. Strickland said, "just is not a credential to get you in the private sector."
 
The Numbers
Hard to Determine Program's Success
Whether many people ever reach the private sector is a central mystery of workfare.
City officials take two approaches when talking about welfare to work. Mr. Giuliani often says work experience is valuable in itself -- whether or not it leads to a real job.
"They clean the parks, they clean the streets, they clean the buses and they clean the sanitation trucks, and they contribute back to the rest of society," he said in a speech in February. "Now what's wrong with that? That is exactly what the social contract is all about."
At other times, though, Mr. Giuliani and his aides say workfare has moved a large number of New Yorkers into real jobs. Asked how many W.E.P. workers had found permanent jobs, Mr. Deacy, the deputy press secretary, said there were 130,000 "documented job placements" between 1994 and 1997. But neither he nor the Mayor's press secretary, Colleen Roche, would respond to questions about whether these placements involved only people in workfare or in welfare over all.
The number of W.E.P. workers specifically known to have obtained permanent jobs is much smaller. Since 1995, about 1,000 have been hired full time by city agencies: 300 by the city's Housing Authority, 200 by the Parks Department, 97 by the Health Department and 451 by the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the city hospitals.
The Parks Department says it helped 750 W.E.P. workers get jobs in private companies over the last three years. An additional 640 found jobs through the city's Businesslink program, created to connect welfare recipients with jobs, during the fiscal year that ended last June, a mayoral spokesman said.
The first broad statistical insights into the question came from the recent state survey, and it found that of those who came off the rolls in New York City from July 1996 through March 1997, 29 percent made at least $100 on the books in the first three months after leaving welfare.
The survey used computer databases to compare lists of people whose benefits had ended against records of wages reported to the state by employers over the following three months. The survey did not distinguish between full-time jobs and part-time or occasional work; nor did it take into account people who were working off the books, were self-employed or had moved out of the state.
Mr. Giuliani highlighted those flaws in publicly criticizing the state study. But the city has not surveyed people leaving welfare or workfare, and has blocked independent attempts to survey former welfare recipients, including those working off the books.
An attempt by professors at Columbia University's School of Social Work broke down in part because the city wanted to review and respond to any report before publication.
And The Times sued the city last fall, seeking the names and addresses of those leaving welfare so it could create a random sample for a scientific survey.
City lawyers contended that the information was confidential under state law. Lawyers for The Times argued that state law requires the city to furnish the information, provided the newspaper does not publish recipients' names and other personal information. The newspaper has promised in writing not to do so. On Friday, Justice Bernard J. Fried of State Supreme Court ruled that The Times was entitled to the information. City officials said they would appeal.
In recent months, while Mr. Giuliani has continued to hail workfare as a great success, the city has quietly begun to make some changes that seem to acknowledge that work experience, by itself, is often not enough to move people from welfare to work.
Six months ago, the city started tailoring programs toward some single mothers' educational and work histories. Those with recent job experience were sent immediately for a four-week job search, instead of first spending six months in workfare.
Many single mothers who lack a high school diploma or English-language skills have been enrolled in programs in which they alternate between a week in workfare and a week of studying. About a quarter of the mothers in workfare are now enrolled in work-study, city officials said.
The Mayor and his new Human Resources Commissioner, Jason A. Turner -- who arrived from Wisconsin in February with a reputation for reconfiguring welfare -- have not said much publicly about other changes in workfare. But there have been hints that they may shift direction.
Speaking to legislators in Albany last month, Mr. Turner said his highest priority would be to route welfare recipients directly into private jobs and into temporary, subsidized jobs in private companies. Workfare should be considered a useful alternative for those who cannot get permanent or temporary employment, he said.
For now, though, three-quarters of the mothers in workfare are still left working in city agencies with occasional breaks for a job search. As for childless adults, they must still figure out on their own how to make the journey from workfare to work.

Does Workfare Work?

HEADLINE: So, How Much Did You Pay for Your Ticket?

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
IT was a typical flight in the era of deregulation: United Airlines Flight 815 from Chicago to Los Angeles, with 204 tickets sold at almost as many prices.
 Deregulation has changed the way passengers are routed and tickets are sold. To illustrate the wide disparity in fares, United provided details of this Boeing 757 flight last Oct. 31 from its hub at O'Hare International Arport. A total of 186 passengers showed up for the trip, 68 of them beginning their journey in Chicago and the rest changing planes there. The flight would end in Los Angeles, but that was the final stop for only 97 ticket holders; most of the others were bound for Australia, on a different plane with the same flight number. 
 But if any of the 33 passengers who held tickets only for the Chicago-to-Los Angeles trip had compared notes, they would have found that they had paid 27 different fares. One paid nothing, using frequent flyer miles; another who bought a first-class ticket on the day of departure paid $1,248.51. And one who bought a coach ticket on the day of travel paid $108.26.
 Illustrating the complexity of pricing, Gregory Taylor, vice president of revenue management at United, said the last passenger was probably an older person flying on a special deal called a Silver Travel Pack, which requires advance purchase of coupons and advance reservations, and then exchange of a coupon for a ticket on the day of the flight.
 In general, people who bought their tickets earlier paid less, but not always. The lowest cash fare paid was $87.21 one way (purchased 29 days in advance), but one compulsive planner bought his ticket before Labor Day and paid $229.60.
 Deregulation is a success, according to both the airlines and Government aviation experts, because average fares are down and travel is up. The Air Transport Association, the big airlines' trade group, says fares, adjusted for inflation, are down 35.5 percent from 1978.
 It has made life complicated, though, with airline pricing completely divorced from cost and, from the passenger's side of the ticket counter, arbitrary. The Transportation Department said last week that it was formulating a policy to determine when pricing crossed the line from arbitrary to predatory, with big airlines squeezing out little ones.
 The big airlines say they are simply more efficient. Cyril D. Murphy, vice president for international affairs at United, said that before deregulation, planes flew about 55 percent full, with only three or four fares offered. Since then, he said, planes are fuller so the costs are spread wider, and the average fare has dropped sharply, allowing a boom in air travel and benefiting both consumers and the airlines.
 In the weeks and even months before a flight, prices fluctuate. Rather than let seats go empty, Mr. Murphy said, airlines will mark down prices if demand is slack. But they also hold out seats until the last moment, for last-minute travelers; the high price charged at that point, airline executives say, is the airlines' reward for taking the risk that the seat might go empty.
 But customers, Mr. Murphy acknowledged, do not always see it that way. "We always assumed we had a happy customer base," he said. "We didn't understand that on a micro basis, that isn't what the customer was seeing."

In the illustration of the Boeing 757, the fares are randomly distributed. (Source: United Airlines)

HEADLINE: The World;
Surprises in the Global Tourism Boom

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
IF those spring holiday airport crowds seem worse than ever this year, think of that suitcase on your foot as merely a harbinger of even bigger things to come. Travel -- yearround and around the world -- is taking off on a phenomenal upward trajectory, with the numbers of tourists growing faster, proportionately, than the population of the countries they come from, or go to visit. Trips closer to home are also on the increase almost everywhere. Spending on travel is expected to grow fivefold in the next two decades.
An industry that moves so many people from place to place -- on as many as six billion trips a year -- and accounts for 10 percent of the world's annual economic growth is bound to have more than just economic effects. Decades ago package tours began laying waste to the Spain's Costa Brava, Caribbean islands and some priceless Himalayan valleys. In the hamlet of Lukla, the jumping-off point for Mount Everest, they started serving muesli and french toast for breakfast and selling nice, soft toilet paper for trails with no toilets. Borneo's jungles got video. Want a picture of a stately African Masai hunter or an Igorot villager in Luzon? Pay up. You take their privacy, and maybe their souls. They take your money. 
 But mass travel has another side. More people are meeting people than at any time in history. In a country like China, where millions are beginning to travel, this exposure could either bind the country or further fragment it as people decide how much alike or different they are. Imagine the earful tour groups from Beijing or Shanghai might get traveling in Tibet or Hong Kong some day. Travel creates jobs and earns hard currency in scores of countries, including the United States, where it is a major export and services industry. Its very destructiveness has sounded alarms, and not just a few countries have awakened in time to save their land and heritage, learning in the process how precious their culture is.
Travel, even group tourism, has been around for centuries. People have long teamed up on pilgrimages, as we know from Chaucer's "Canterbury Tales." Thomas Cook, the father of modern tourism, got his start in the British Midlands taking groups to temperance rallies (tea and sandwiches included). The difference now is scale. Wide-bodied aircraft, deregulation and competition mean more routes and lower fares. With the almost complete collapse of Communism, many barriers have fallen or been torn down, releasing pent-up demand for travel in both directions: visitors out, visitors in. Rudimentary English has become the industry's international language.
Even Americans, still laggards at crossing borders when compared with many Europeans and Asians, picked up a record number of passports -- six million -- in the last year, the State Department says, and there are now more than 45 million American passports in circulation.
In an age of global economics, business travel has pushed up passport applications, not only for the traveling executive. Family members are now nearly three times as likely to be included on business trips than in 1990. Robert Kaplan, who poked around the far corners for his book, "The Ends of the Earth" (Random House) said business travelers are now probably the most savvy tourists. "Look at Forbes, Fortune -- what business people read," he said. "They are filled with articles about the outside world."
Paradoxically, the electronic connections enjoyed by businesses and home computer owners may be encouraging, not discouraging, travel. The Travel Industry Association of America found that six million Americans booked trips online this year, often after browsing through electronic encyclopedias, atlases and the home pages of state or foreign tourism authorities. The association predicts that by the end of 1998 bookings via the Internet may rise to 18 million.
 
Voyages to Granny

Cyberspace can never beat the heat, the smells, the sounds, the sense of Foreign. For Mr. Kaplan, the experience of arrival may be the tipoff to a place.
"Look closely at airports and you can see how a country is doing," he said. "Is the airport safe? Do you have to pay bribes? Airports are quasi-governmental places." Closer to home, he added, "you don't have to leave Penn Station to know that New York is getting better."
As more immigrants become United States citizens, getting to grandmother's house is no longer just a jaunt over the river and through the woods, but more likely a voyage over continents and seas. Immigrant families, fewer of whom have had to renounce all ties to their homelands because of political dangers, are traveling back to keep their children in close touch. Americans with deeper roots here go to take a look at where their neighbors came from.
When Catherine O'Neill, an expert on refugees, and her husband, Richard Reeves, the political writer, went globetrotting with their joint extended family a year ago, she handed out questionnaires at each stop. "I really felt that they are going to live in a global world, and that to understand it only from the perspective of the U.S. and Europe is not really seeing it," said Ms. O'Neill, the author with her husband of "Family Travels: Around the World in 30 (or So) Days" (Andrews and McMeel). "I asked them: In this country do they have jobs that we don't have in the United States? What kind of movies are being advertised? How do people get around the streets? In your life, will this country be important?"
Twenty years ago, when the world's population was 4.4 billion, 287 million people took international trips, according to the World Tourism Organization. By 1996, when global population stood at about 5.7 billion, 595 million international tourists were on the move. In 2020, the tourism organization's experts predict, 1.6 billion of the world's 7.8 billion people will take a foreign trip.
 
Internal Travel
 Billions more will take their first, modest vacations closer to home. For example, a man in Beijing named Wang and his small family recently boarded No. 1 Special Tourism Bus in the Chinese capital for their first trip to the Great Wall, about 60 miles away. Xinhua, the Chinese news agency, which told their story, said that Mr. Wang was one of nearly 77 million people who visited tourist sites in or around Beijing last year. They spent, on average, about $10 a family.
In India, the world's second-most-populous country, whole villages charter buses and occasionally trains to take people with very little expendable income to places that were out of the reach of earlier generations. Tour operators everywhere are finding that standards of living need to rise only marginally for people to get an itch to hit the road. Perhaps even because of hard times -- like the economic stress Asia is now experiencing -- the popularity of short trips continues to rise.
Not every place is automatically threatened by an invasion, said Mr. Kaplan. "Are we messing up the world?" he asked. "I see that more in the Caribbean than anywhere else, where the islands are so small. But the Hyatts and Marriotts in a place like Cairo kind of disappear among the 14 million people."
The widely held view among environmentalists -- who don't know whether to weep or cheer at the news that ecotourism is now one of the fastest-growing travel sectors -- has been that mass international tourism has been the most damaging to natural settings. But as numbers of domestic travelers grow, that assumption cracks. In the case of India, with nearly a billion people, foreign travelers are still very small in number -- not even one-sixth of the 17 million tourists who go to Thailand annually, for example. Indian beaches and mountain resorts, monuments and historical sites are taking a trouncing from short-haul Indian visitors. Similarly, Southeast Asia is experiencing a boom in the construction of clubs and golf courses for the local business class, and it has forever altered rural landscapes.
Countries can respond to environmental and cultural problems imaginatively. The Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan raised prices and limited the number of tourist visas issued; it also developed with the World Bank a trust fund for protecting one of the last pristine mountain environments in Asia. The World Bank and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, have both helped the Mexican state of Oaxaca excavate, preserve and display Meso-American archeological ruins -- saving sites but also making them accessible to tourists in a controlled way.
"Oaxaca is the best example of how you can have cultural tourism enhance the value of a historical site by having a local population very committed not only to conservation but to helping new generations create a new heritage of living cultures," said Lourdes Arizpe, a Unesco cultural official and a Mexican anthropologist. "Otherwise, we turn the world into a museum."
For both tourists and hosts, fortifying cultures as well as buildings is important, said Deborah Luhrman of the World Tourism Organization. "Tourism provides the money to restore local sites and monuments," she said. "It also helps the people who live there to understand the value of what they have."
"Travel is one of the basic human rights now," Ms. Luhrman said. "It is part of what makes the quality of life better. For some people, the right to travel has become part of political freedom."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1242 words

HEADLINE: American Blueprint

BYLINE: By Robert Campbell; Robert Campbell is an architect and the architecture critic of The Boston Globe.

 BODY:

SHAPING A NATION
 Twentieth Century American
 Architecture and Its Makers.
 By Carter Wiseman.
 Illustrated. 412 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. $39.95. 
 This book is about as good a summary of American architecture of this century as anyone is likely to write. It is full and accurate in its facts, wise and fair in its judgments. Carter Wiseman, who for 16 years was the respected architecture critic of New York magazine, states his premise clearly in the introduction: "I believe that serious architecture should be buildable, useful and beautiful." An obvious truth, you would think, yet one that needs affirmation at the end of a century in which architecture has too often been perceived as a sport of clashing verbal manifestoes rather than as the art of designing places for human habitation. Wiseman is comfortable in the world of ideas, but he understands that an idea becomes truly architectural only when it has been embodied in a physical reality.
If you are any kind of fan of architecture, reading a book like this is like visiting the town you grew up in. Wiseman takes you on a long informative stroll among familiar landmarks. Here are the wonderful small masterpieces of the turn-of-the-century Arts and Crafts movement, the great factories of America's industrial heyday, the nostalgia of the Colonial Revival, the soaring Art Deco towers. Then comes the shocking arrival from Europe, in the 1930's, of the modern movement, followed by its triumph and then by a series of reactions against it -- the preservation movement, the urbanism of the indispensable Jane Jacobs and the post-modernist revivals of the 80's and 90's. Finally you arrive at the computer-influenced design of today. Wiseman shows you, too, a scrapbook of photos of your town's old-timers: Frank Lloyd Wright, Mies van der Rohe, Frank Gehry and other architects of an amazingly diverse century.
Wiseman is a challenging guide. His praise is not easily earned, and when it does come, it is usually framed in a "yes, but" format. His strength is the care he takes to step back for a longer look, to sketch the cultural and social background of a career or a building. At his best, he can illuminate an entire reputation in a few words. The pages on the Pop-chic world of Robert Venturi, for example, are definitive, unsparing without being unsympathetic.
There are a couple of standard ways to write a book like this, both of which Wiseman avoids. You can string all your material on the thread of a single idea, making everything into a march of progress. The classic example in architecture books is Sigfried Giedion's "Space, Time and Architecture" (1941), a morality tale about the birth, tribulations and victory of the modern movement. That kind of master narrative, giving shape to history by presenting it, in the manner of Marx, as a tidal trend, is hopelessly out of fashion. But if you can't supply such a plausible fiction to give meaning to your material, you risk producing the second kind of bad book, the one that presents history as encyclopedia: just one thing after another, which in the case of architecture means one style after another, each expressing nothing more significant than boredom with the previous style.
Wiseman skirts both traps by bringing into his story, as much as possible, the writers and theorists who shaped the culture from which the architecture sprang. He refuses to make myth, but by showing us how others did he gives his book a quality of intellectual and social narrative that raises it above the level of merely factual history. He starts by returning to the beginning of the 19th century to find the sources of the architecture of the 20th. You gain a sense of the cultural discourse from which architecture arises, from early copybooks to the theorists of today.
If there is a weakness, it is overcrowding. "Shaping a Nation" covers a lot of ground. It is packed so tight with fact and judgment that there often isn't space for a building or a designer to be fully fleshed out. In 386 pages of text, 190 different architects are discussed, not to mention many people in other fields -- and a lot of those pages are broken up by photographs. Wiseman seems never to have met a fact he didn't want to include. The inevitable result is writing that sometimes stuffs whole eras into a speedy sentence or two, as in this appraisal of the influence of Andrew Jackson Downing and Alexander Jackson Davis in the 19th century: "The stylistic shift promulgated by Downing and Davis away from the neo-classical was abetted by the increasing size and economic diversity of the post-revolutionary population. And that led, predictably enough, to a steady fragmentation of the Colonial heritage." You need to possess some knowledge of your own to fill in the blanks when the writing becomes this skeletal. It is only fair to add that I tested the book on a high school senior with a passionate interest in architecture but no formal study of it, who reported that he understood the book just fine and liked it. Still, it probably isn't at its best as an introduction for raw beginners.
For a book so packed with facts, errors are few and minor. William Rawn did not renovate the Boston Navy Yard and Wright's Larkin Building, despite its importance to architecture, was at no time "one of Buffalo's most prominent landmarks." Perhaps the only slip of any importance is the statement that at Thomas Jefferson's original Unversity of Virginia, one of the nation's greatest works of architecture, the lawn was enclosed on three sides but left open to the west. Metaphorically that is probably true -- the lawn conceived as looking out toward the open frontier -- but geographically the open side is south. And I would quarrel with Wiseman's conventional view that it was a disaster when, in 1896, the opening was blocked with a new building by Stanford White. White's enclosure of the lawn occurred in the same decade as the appearance of the historian Frederick Jackson Turner's classic essay on the closing of the American frontier. Architecture embodies history. But it is exactly this kind of author-reader argument that makes the book fun.
A few gripes: Wiseman's prose is literate but so conventional it sometimes sounds like committee work. He can be loose with words -- "romantic" is one he throws around too much and never defines. Of Louis Kahn, the greatest American architect of the second half of the century (as Wright, far greater, was of the first), the author says he avoided "literal romanticism," whatever that may be. And why is European modernism, with its Cubist abstractions and its ardent, often impractical social utopianism, always described as "rationalist," while Wright, with his fuller sense of life, is "romantic"? Such words need closer examination. The book in general is well produced, but the color reproductions are bad. The numerous large portraits take up too much space -- most architects look like anyone else -- but a few are gems, as is one of Wright in 1915 with flowing tie and long curls, still trying to resemble, at 48, a Wildean esthete.
These are blemishes in a welcome work. Architecture, more even than the other visual arts, must be experienced directly to be experienced at all. You must inhabit its spaces, sense its scale and its materiality, know it in its setting. "Shaping a Nation" should send many people out to do just that.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Chrysler Building in New York City, by William Van Alen, 1930. (From "Shaping A Nation")

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2389 words

HEADLINE: Coalition and Builder Battle in Riverhead

BYLINE: By MARY CUMMINGS 

 BODY:
When the East End's principal business was farming, Riverhead was the commercial hub for both forks of Long Island. But for almost 20 years, while South Fork towns have boomed as chic resorts and second-home havens, and the North Fork has evolved into elegant wine country, Riverhead, a town of 23,000, has been languishing. And for almost as long, the town's preservationists, planners and Main Street merchants have been arguing with large-scale commercial developers over the real key to Riverhead's rebirth.
Now, the forces appear poised for a showdown: earth-moving equipment is already at work on the site of a planned 51-acre megamall that its opponents feel was improperly pushed through the approval process last November. 
 On one side of the battle is East End Properties, the New York City-based development company that plans to build the mall on the corner of Route 58 and Mill Road on the outskirts of town. Called Riverhead Center, it is to be a shopping mecca with twice the retail space of downtown Riverhead. H. B. Gianos, the 38-year-old president of East End Properties, argues that eastern Long Island is a woefully underserved market, with potential profits that Riverhead is ideally located to reap. In his view, Riverhead Center is the solution to the town's economic problems.
"You can see how starved people moving in from the West are," Mr. Gianos said. "They're used to being able to go to a modern supermarket, the cinema."
By bringing in a huge new Waldbaum's, a multiplex theater and stores like Home Depot, Circuit City, Staples and Barnes & Noble, as well as other national and local retailers to the Riverhead Center site, Mr. Gianos insists that he is insuring Riverhead's survival. As he sees it, the town's future is as a shopping venue offering access to large-scale retailers and outlet stores, plentiful space and ample parking. Downtown Riverhead, he feels, can sustain itself with entertainment and eating attractions. Mr. Gianos contends that in serving the needs of consumers who have been deprived of competitive, convenient shopping, Riverhead Center will also provide the jobs and tax revenues Riverhead desperately needs.
To bolster his argument, Mr. Gianos points to the success of the Tanger Outlet Center farther west on Route 58. Having opened in 1994 as a 285,000-square-foot outdoor mall, Tanger is undergoing expansion and is on is way to becoming the largest manufacturers' outlet center in the country.
On the other side of the conflict are the forces whose ideal is to retain the rural character of Riverhead's surroundings while channeling commercial activity back into the moribund downtown district. "Keep Riverhead's Future in Riverhead's Hands" is the battle cry of their newly formed organization, the Riverhead Growth Coalition, whose membership includes local businesses and private citizens.
On March 19, the coalition held a news conference in downtown Riverhead to set forth 11 reasons "why Riverhead Center should not be permitted" and to start an advertising campaign under the banner, "Don't Let Big-City Developers Determine Riverhead's Future."
"Right now, there is a surplus of commercially zoned space along Route 58 and in downtown Riverhead," said Barry Barth, the group's spokesman, who is also the proprietor of Barth's Drug Store and president of the Riverhead Business Improvement District. "There is plenty of room for cinemas, restaurants, building supply stores, supermarkets and other businesses, and we would welcome their addition to our community." Meanwhile, the battle is being fought in the courts as well as in the news media. A series of suits and counter-suits was begun last spring when the improvement district, whose volunteer members are dedicated to strengthening the local business community, joined the Riverhead Building Supply Corporation and several other businesses, including the local hardware and electrical-supply stores, to sue the town of Riverhead, challenging the process by which it had approved Riverhead Center. When that suit was dismissed last December, it was quickly followed by another, which argued that the rezoning in 1997 permitting commercial development on land extending from the Riverhead Center site to the eastern entrance of the Long Island Expressway had been carried out without due consideration of the impact such development would have on the community.
The rezoning, which was widely criticized in the letters column of the local paper as an 11th-hour sellout to developers more interested in enriching themselves than in serving local needs, added momentum to a wave of anti-administration sentiment. Voters ultimately swept the Town Supervisor, James Stark, a Republican, and his two running mates out of office last November. The victors, members of the new Riverhead Party, were led by Vincent Villella, a Main Street businessman and a former Republican.
In a countersuit, Mr. Gianos and his company contended that Riverhead Building Supply's huge new drive-through lumber yard on Pulaski Street, which had its grand opening early last month, was spared the kind of scrutiny from the town that Riverhead Center received.They pointed to the high volume of truck traffic that the site would generate in a neighborhood that includes a day care center and a Little League field. The suit alleges a lack of compliance with the state's Environmental Quality Review Act.
Two months after Mr. Villella took office and found himself "stuck between the two lawsuits," as he put it, he was bracing for more suits from Riverhead Center. They arrived on March 18, when the developer filed suit against the Riverhead Business Improvement District and several of its individual members, contending that the district is prohibited by its own bylaws from participating in lawsuits.
"The funny part of it," Mr. Villella said, "is that before the election I was on the board of the B.I.D. It's getting out of hand, and I'm going to have to meet with both parties."
Describing himself as a "good mediator," Mr. Villella admitted that finding common ground in this case would not be easy.
"It'll never happen," Mr. Gianos said, suggesting that the recalcitrance is all on the side of his adversaries. He described the legal challenges to the rezoning that paved the way for Riverhead Center as nothing more than "vehicles to obstruct competition" and said the suits were financed and orchestrated by Riverhead Building Supply to fend off competition from Home Depot. He contended he was warned at the outset that this would happen.
"Early on I was told I was in big trouble by the most powerful family in town," Mr. Gianos said, referring to the Goodale family, the owners of Riverhead Building Supply, which he called the East End's "monopoly building supply company."
"I was told in no uncertain terms that they would do everything to oppose Home Depot," he said.
Mr. Gianos said he had tried to reason with the family but has had no success. Nor does he appear to have changed any minds among members of the Business Improvement District, whom he charged with adopting "anti-competitive, anti-business tactics to maintain the status quo" in Riverhead after failing to generate new jobs themselves or to complete any of several plans for creating downtown attractions.
In a vigorous public relations campaign, Mr. Gianos has issued statements predicting that Riverhead Center will create approximately 1,200 "permanent, year-round jobs," inject "millions of new dollars into the region's economy each year" and contribute greatly toward the "commercial revitalization of Riverhead." Riverhead Center will also make a significant tax contribution to the town, Mr. Gianos said, citing projected annual real estate taxes of $850,000.
"We are not, as a company, thrilled to have Home Depot come to Riverhead," conceded Jesse R. Goodale 3d, speaking recently for Riverhead Building Supply and his family. But, he added, "we as a company are perfectly prepared for Home Depot to go into any property presently zoned for it. There is plenty of room."
Mr. Goodale insisted that his objection is not to Home Depot, nor even to Riverhead Center per se. What he and the others are challenging, he said, is the decision made by the previous administration to open up a huge swath of land for commercial development on Route 58 without considering the impact the development of miles of megamalls would have on the town.
"It is our contention," he said, "that they should not have done this major rezoning until and unless the town has in place a master plan for commercial development in the town as a whole." Mr. Goodale has little doubt what that impact will be: increased traffic and the continued decline of the remaining downtown businesses.
"The basic thrust," he said, "will be to forever change the nature of this town."
In stressing that he is neither anti-growth nor anti-competition but rather pro-planning and pro-Riverhead, Mr. Goodale advanced themes that the Riverhead Growth Coalition has expanded on in its campaign. At the top of its 11-item list of reasons why Riverhead Center must be stopped is the surplus of vacant, commercially zoned space that already exists along Route 58 and in downtown Riverhead.
In this, the forces against Riverhead Center are powerfully armed with a 1997 report on retail commercial development prepared by the Suffolk County Planning Commission. According to the report, in 1996 the town of Riverhead had an overall shopping-center vacancy rate of 17.1 percent. The vacancy rate in Riverhead's central business district was even higher -- 27 percent -- the highest of any downtown in eastern Suffolk County.
The Planning Commission's director of planning, Stephen Jones, said the existing vacancy rate was a major reason for the commission's decision to rule against Riverhead Center when the project came before the commission for approval a year ago. (Since the commission's role is advisory, the Town Board can override its decisions with a majority-plus-one vote, which it did.)
"For starters," Mr. Jones said, Riverhead Center's application was for "retail square footage that is twice as big as downtown Riverhead, and to say it wouldn't have an environmental impact is inaccurate." It would constitute "a dramatic expansion of retail in a traffic corridor, Route 58, where a tremendous amount of shopping centers exist now," he added.
Mr. Jones noted that "the fierce fighting for the retail dollar" has taken a new twist in recent years. The struggle is no longer between downtown and shopping centers, he said; it is now shopping center versus shopping center. It follows, he said, that the creation of Riverhead Center will do damage not only to downtown Riverhead but, "because it's so large, it will do damage to all of the existing shopping centers on Route 58."
Calling the environmental impact statement that was submitted with the Riverhead Center application "completely faulty," Mr. Jones said the Planning Commission had seen "no evidence that Riverhead or anybody else was looking at the whole picture."
That, Mr. Villella suggested, is one of the tasks he was elected to tackle.
"We are updating it as we speak," Mr. Villella said of the town's master plan, which was developed in the early 1970's but never officially adopted.
If the supervisor has his way, the new plan will reflect what he believes to be valid on each side of the argument over Riverhead's future, a conflict he feels has escalated well beyond reasonable debate.
"We are not against development or growth," Mr. Villella said of his administration. "We are against the way it was done without any planning."
As for Riverhead Center, "there is opposition," he said, "but there are a lot of people for it." He said that since the shopping mall will probably be built, he is preparing to work with everyone involved.
"People want the movies, they want Home Depot, the bookstore and restaurants," he said, "but when you put it all together in one project, it scared them."
To allay those fears, Mr. Villella offered reassurances that capitulating to Riverhead Center will not inevitably mean abandoning Riverhead's downtown, with its core of surviving businesses that still offer a hometown touch; its riverfront, and the handsome brick buildings on Main Street.
"We have to change the mix completely in the downtown area," he said. In the future, he predicted, "there will not be as much retail as there has been." The planned expansion of Swezey's Department Store, a Main Street mainstay, is a good sign, he said, "but there has to be a combination" of retail and other attractions. He noted that his administration is pushing ahead with a long-stalled plan for a large aquarium, and that it has not abandoned plans to create a downtown arts district to lure artists and galleries to upstairs space on Main Street. He added that he hopes to raise the money needed to complete long-delayed renovations that will transform Riverhead's boarded-up Suffolk Theater, an Art Deco movie house, into a performing arts center.
One path toward achieving Mr. Villella's goals for the theater leads straight to Mr. Gianos, who has offered money for the project. Stung by the attacks on him as an "outsider," Mr. Gianos points out that he has a long history of commercial improvement in Riverhead and is as interested in creating a lively, economically viable downtown as anyone. He said his company deserved credit for bringing numerous improvements to the town, among them an elegant Ramada Inn that had formerly been a run-down motel, and housing for the elderly that the company created from a dilapidated apartment complex. In this spirit, he said, he offered to contribute $1 million to complete the work on the Suffolk Theater.
When he first made the offer, it was rejected by the town, Mr. Gianos said. He looks upon the rebuff as more evidence that he will never crack what he sees as an anti-competitive clique that runs Riverhead.
"Everyone went to high school together," he said. "It's really sad, because the victims here are the people of Riverhead."
That is not an outcome that Riverhead's elected protector and self-designated peace-maker, Vincent Villella, is prepared to accept.
"I'm talking with him," he said.

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 4; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1450 words

HEADLINE: Lessons to Be Learned From the Glitter of Broadway;
Duke Students Examine the Business Side of the Arts

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
Though it is certainly a theater district institution, one would hardly call Sardi's an institution of higher learning. But on a recent afternoon, 15 Duke University students assembled beneath the show-biz caricatures on the restaurant walls for a class on leadership and vision.
The day before they had gathered at Wynton Marsalis's apartment to observe the trumpeter tutor a protege, and that evening they saw "Il Trovatore" at the Metropolitan Opera and briefly chatted with Sarah Billinghurst, the assistant manager, about business matters and fund-raising operations. 
 Now, in Sardi's main dining room, Prof. Bruce Payne, a lecturer in public policy at Duke, called the class to order to discuss leadership as conveyed in such divergent artistic forms as Verdi's "Trovatore" and Mr. Marsalis's conducting of the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra.
The students, six men and nine women, are spending a semester abroad in New York, the country's cultural capital, to learn firsthand the place of the performing arts in American life. The program is sponsored by Duke's Terry Sanford Institute of Public Policy and the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Payne, who devised the program and is its director, said it is aimed at undergraduates headed for careers in law, medicine, business and government who may be "very well educated but culturally deprived," as he put it.
"The idea is to get nonfine arts majors to think about questions of leadership and policy in the arts," Mr. Payne said. "Who supports the arts, why it matters and why it makes Jesse Helms so angry."
Their scholarly pursuits include attending 15 operas, 20 plays on and off Broadway, half a dozen dance performances, New York Philharmonic rehearsals and performances, talks with actors, producers, directors and singers and visits to nearly every museum in the city.
"I had to sell my parents on the idea," Meredith Groban, a junior from Rockville, Md., said. "They didn't quite understand how living in New York and going to the theater, the opera and the symphony was consistent with my major in labor relations."
Of course, there is also the required reading -- "The Diary of Anne Frank," "The American Canvas" and many others -- and the writing. Students must produce a short paper every other week and a term paper. Not to mention an independent studies project on a topic of their choice with New Yorkers who have been appointed adjunct instructors for the semester.
Upon successful completion of their semester in New York, which costs about $10,000, the equivalent of a semester's tuition at Duke, the students earn four course credits, which counts as a full semester of study. They live at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn, commuting to Manhattan by subway.
Victoria Engelhorn, a third-year economics and French major who makes her home in London, said of the living arrangements: "Here you live with closed doors, like apartment living, and my next door neighbor is an elderly woman. In the dorms, we usually have our doors open, know everyone and we're all the same age. I like living in a New York landmark, but everyone keeps telling us about the pool at the St. George and we were a little disappointed to find that it's no longer open."
Nearly all the students described it as a chance to explore a city and culture seemingly worlds apart from the ivy-covered campus they left behind in Durham, N.C.
"I find Duke itself very constricting," said Carla Murphy, a junior who was raised in Queens and has family roots in Barbados. "Most of us are 20-year-olds trying to find ourselves, and this is the kind of experience that helps make you a complete person."
But the program has a mission beyond its stated educational purpose: to whet the appetites of tomorrow's patrons, corporate donors, board members and policy makers. In the view of those whose business it is to fill the big houses on Broadway and Lincoln Center as well as regional theaters and repertory workshops, there is a need to develop knowledgeable audiences.
"It's what we used to call connoisseurship," said William Robert Bucker, dean of the School of Fine Arts at the University of Minnesota at Duluth and former director of education for the Metropolitan Opera. "It used to be related to the visual arts and to developing students with the potential to become great collectors or the potential to go to museums and see what was best in the art of past and present.
 
Future Decisions About 'Quality'
"We're trying to develop that same kind of connoisseurship with the performing arts," he added. "We want students to come away and be able to make thoughtful, intelligent decisions about quality, about what is good. Because ultimately, as leaders in their communities, they will be responsible for making decisions that have an impact on those very issues as they relate to arts organizations in their communities."
The curriculum includes two public policy courses, "Leadership and the Arts" and "Policy, Philanthropy and the Arts," both taught by Mr. Payne. Dr. Bucker returns from Duluth once a month to teach a third course, "Music and Drama, Performance and Politics."
The Duke program relies on the kindness of artists and arts institutions like Lincoln Center and the Shubert Organization, both of which provided teaching space, discount tickets and guest lecturers, the support of Duke alumni in the New York area and a bevy of F.O.B.'s -- "friends of Bruce."
Barbaralee Diamonstein-Spielvogel, an author and the chairwoman of the Historic Landmarks Preservation Center, who taught a course at Duke with Mr. Payne on philanthropy and the arts, invited the students to her Park Avenue apartment for a lecture on landmarks preservation, followed by lunch and a tour of her art collection. The SoHo penthouse loft of Andy King, a caterer and corporate concierge, was the site of a dinner and a discussion on the differences between leadership and management with Richard J. Caples, whose interest in dance led him from a job as a corporate lawyer to the position of executive director of Lar Lubovitch Dance Company.
Molly Ringwald and the cast of "How I Learned to Drive" spoke with students after they attended an evening performance, and Douglas Carter Beane, the author of "As Bees in Honey Drown," gave a lecture on the Drama Dept., the repertory theater Mr. Carter Beane cofounded.
"Gee, I wish I had a class like this when I was a college student," said Mr. Carter Beane, echoing sentiments voiced a few nights earlier by Ms. Ringwald.
Classes are regularly held at Mr. King's loft, the Met's Guild Board Room and Sardi's, which offered its space after Mr. Payne got in touch with Jack Thomas, director of sales development for the Shubert Organization, the restaurant's landlord. Mr. Payne often asks for and receives the keys to friends apartments and private offices on a moment's notice.
"The arts, whether for profit or nonprofit, thrive on mutual aid," Mr. Payne told his students "People in New York's arts community are thrilled to help out because they want bright people to care, to share their enthusiasm."
To help students understand that experience of volunteerism, Mr. Payne had them work as clerks stuffing envelopes, selling T-shirts and working backstage with wardrobe at a fund-raising benefit for the Doug Varone Dance Company.
Mr. Payne acknowledged that one of the "ulterior motives" of the program was to encourage students to broaden not only their horizons but their career paths as well. Which explains the lecture by Mr. Caples, the corporate attorney turned dance company executive.
Indeed, Ms. Billinghurst of the Met says the next generation of art administrators will come from "all sorts of different backgrounds" rather than from the traditional pool of fine arts majors and scions of wealthy families.
"Who knows," she said. "Some of the students in this class could work for a ballet company or theater company."
Tom Sowers, a senior in the R.O.T.C. who is headed for the Corps of Engineers after graduation, still seemed committed to his goal halfway through the semester. But the discussions of relevance and leadership in the arts were not lost on him. Before the semester began, Mr. Sowers had had some difficulty trying to persuade his military science professor of the relevance of his decision to study arts in New York City.
"Bruce shows us how you can see leadership not only in a general's command on a battlefield, but in Wynton Marsalis's approach to jazz," Mr. Sowers said. "As an officer I will be responsible for leading a command, and it's a compelling argument that you can find leadership within a dance company as well as in a 40-troop platoon."

HEADLINE: A Dash Past Rush?

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
Rush Limbaugh, the talk-radio personality whose flair for political bombast helped revitalize AM radio, is no longer the most listened-to person on the airwaves, at least according to one survey.
Talkers magazine says that Mr. Limbaugh has been eclipsed by a pair of polar opposites: Dr. Laura Schlessinger, whose knack for concise put-downs and an unswerving moral compass have helped her tap into a culture impatient for accountability, and Howard Stern, whose locker-room antics help that culture stay in touch with its seamier underbelly. 
 Experts on radio say the ascent of Dr. Schlessinger and Mr. Stern over Mr. Limbaugh reflects a broader shift away from political talk radio as the strong economy and weariness with scandal dull the public's interest in Washington.
And with the Beltway news often resembling celebrity gossip -- another favorite subject of talk radio -- there is less fodder for the left-right debates on which shows like Mr. Limbaugh's have thrived.
"The trend has been to more well-rounded talk programming," said Eric Weiss, a Los Angeles radio agent. "Political talk is clearly not as popular as it was several years ago. A whole slew of right-wing talk shows were launched."
According to the survey by Talkers, a trade-journal of the talk radio circuit, Dr. Schlessinger's show has a weekly national audience of 18 million, followed by Mr. Stern at 17.5 million and Mr. Limbaugh with 17.25 million.
Stephen C. Lehman, president and chief executive of Jacor Communications Inc.'s Premiere Radio Network, which carries Mr. Limbaugh's show, disputes Talkers' findings that Mr. Limbaugh's audience is shrinking and contends that Mr. Stern's audience is closer to seven million. "The big discrepancy is with Stern," he said. "Something's off."
In any case, industry experts say it is clear that political shows are losing some of their luster. Other radio personalities with a political bent, drawn into the medium by Mr. Limbaugh's long success as host of a call-in show, are seeing a decline in listenership, according to Talkers.
"There's been a slowing in the growth of political talk since 1996," said Michael Harrison, publisher of the journal, based in Longmeadow, Mass. That year, Mr. Limbaugh's popularity peaked at 21 million listeners. "Limbaugh's decline is now at a point where there is a trend," Mr. Harrison added.
G. Gordon Liddy, Michael Reagan and Oliver North also saw declines in listenership in the fall survey. Last month CBS radio canceled the show of Mary Matalin, the former Republican campaign official. Previous pink slips went to Mario Cuomo, Gary Hart and Joycelyn Elders, also short-lived talk-show hosts whose political hard knocks proved inadequate training for the demands of keeping a daily show current.
"To go into talk radio in the 90's and think they can succeed by taking someone with marquee value isn't going to cut it," Mr. Harrison said. "Radio is not oratory. It's conversations."
No one knows that better than Mr. Limbaugh. "It isn't his politics; he's a great entertainer," said Walter Sabo, a talk-radio programming consultant. "Rush's audience couldn't have gotten any bigger," Mr. Sabo said. "If he slips a little, everyone else has a long way to go."
Dr. Schlessinger, who has a doctorate in physiology and is a licensed marriage and family counselor, has mastered the art of summing up anecdotes and spewing confrontational opinions with lightning quickness.
She is heard on 450 stations that have a nationwide audience of 18 million. Stations in the Los Angeles area carried her three-hour show for two decades before it was syndicated in 1994 and its popularity took off. In September, Jacor paid $71.5 million for the show. Industry executives estimate it generates about $30 million in advertising revenue.
Last year, as part of a move to establish itself in radio programming and syndication, Jacor paid $50 million for Mr. Limbaugh's show, which is carried on 600 stations. Its revenue is estimated at close to $38 million by industry executives.
Mr. Stern's show is independently controlled, and is unusual in the syndication business for demanding a licensing fee from stations, which then can sell advertising on the show. Under most programming arrangements, a station gives up some commercial time, which is sold to advertisers by the syndicator, in exchange for obtaining the programming.
Dr. Schlessinger's appeal to adult women indicates how the talk format, like music, is beginning to splinter as programmers seek to appeal to different demographic groups, Mr. Sabo said. Mr. Limbaugh is typically tuned in by older men, while Mr. Stern draws younger males. All-talk formats aimed at younger audiences are also moving to FM, such as WTKS in Orlando, Fla., and WRKO in Boston, in part because it is more profitable, airing 18 minutes of commercials an hour compared with 14 minutes on music stations, he said.
If there is unanimity among radio executives over Dr. Schlessinger's ascent, there remains quibbling in some quarters over the rest of the results in the Talkers survey. There is room for dispute because unlike television ratings, radio ratings are not based on a single show but cumulative listening to a station over a week or in a particular time slot.
Counting listeners tuning in to syndicated programming with certainty is difficult because audiences can be counted twice, when syndicated shows are broadcast more than once by a station, or missed entirely if shows are carried in cities too small to be surveyed by traditional ratings services like Arbitron.
Because syndication companies keep their list of affiliates secret, Talkers compiles its findings through focus groups and research with individual stations, Mr. Harrison said.
But he disputed the assertion by Mr. Lehman of Jacor that the survey's figures for Mr. Stern's and Mr. Limbaugh's audiences were incorrect. "Its credibility is based on our reputation. We have more to lose than anybody."
To try to settle the dispute, Arbitron, at Jacor's request, is conducting a more definitive market survey, which is expected to be completed this week.
