HEADLINE: A Victim of a New Economy, The Corner Bank is Fading

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
They are the ghosts of banking in New York City.
The former New York Bank for Savings, a 19th-century Beaux-Arts landmark at Eighth Avenue and 14th Street, took its last deposit in 1981 and is now a rug store. 
 Another city landmark, 55 Wall Street, was vacated by Citibank in 1993 and is being renovated as a hotel. And at 33d Street and 10th Avenue, a building where Chase and Citibank employed hundreds of data-processing workers until 1995 is now home to The Daily News, WNET and other media companies.
The recycled buildings, with their newly chiseled or painted facades, are not the only signs of a passing era of banking in the city. A wave of consolidation and restructuring has caused dozens of banks to vanish in the last decade, and their once-familiar names -- Richmond Hill Savings Bank, Crossland Savings, Manufacturers Hanover Trust, Chemical -- are quickly fading in the city's collective memory. Along the way, thousands of jobs have been eliminated and more than 200 neighborhood branches closed.
The wave has crested in recent days with the proposed $70 billion merger of Citicorp and the Travelers Group, both based in Manhattan, and two other huge mergers that are expected to be announced today -- one of which would create the nation's first coast-to-coast bank. The Citicorp-Travelers deal would create a monolith engaged in stock trading, insurance and high-technology financial services, pushing the neighborhood bank teller further toward the status of an artifact in American commerce, like the village blacksmith.
These changes have generated no small amount of pain: in addition to the layoffs, advocates for the poor warn that the disappearance of bank branches will only worsen a chronic lack of banking services in neighborhoods outside Manhattan.
But despite the retrenchment, industry experts say New York City is coming out ahead, maintaining its status as the national epicenter of the new financial services industry, from venture capital to mutual funds to risk arbitrage. And they insist that the city stands to benefit as regulatory barriers break down between traditional banking, securities trading, insurance and other businesses.
"If I were worried about New York City's future, it would only be because I was worried about financial services as a whole, and I'm not," said Roy C. Smith, a professor of finance at New York University. "It has all become an interconnected circle, with people moving from one sector to the next."
Indeed, last week's merger proposal has simply accelerated a trend that has been reshaping the city's banking industry for years. According to the New York State Department of Labor, employment at the city's commercial banks -- not including brokerage houses or investment banks -- plummeted by a third between 1988 and this year, to 112,300 from 177,600.
The drop in the number of banks doing business in the city, and their branches, has been almost as steep. Federal data show that there were 85 banks and 1,200 bank offices in the city at the end of last year, down from 120 banks and 1,545 bank offices in 1988.
Economists say the impact on employment, although severe, has not been as catastrophic as the state figures might suggest, since many of the companies that have been taking away bank business are also providing jobs for bank workers.
"We were an overbanked city," said Carol Parry, the executive vice president for community development at Chase, the city's largest private employer. Perhaps more than any other, her bank represents the changes that have reshaped the industry: it acquired Chemical in 1995, only two years after Chemical had taken over Manufacturers Hanover Trust.
In reorganizing its new holdings, Chase closed more than 100 branches, but Ms. Parry said that it had found ways to deliver consumer services more efficiently. "We do not abandon communities," she said. "But having branches across the street or right next door to each other was not necessary."
Industry analysts say the shake-up has its roots in New York City's historic role as the nation's center of finance, which has made it a magnet for banks from around the world and led to duplication of many customer services. Beginning in the 1980's, with the introduction of conveniences like automated teller machines and banking at home by computer, they say some of the most routine bank branch services became redundant and unprofitable.
And growing competition from other financial service companies has carved deeply into bank profits. The biggest blow has come in the shift of people's assets from bank deposits to mutual funds, retirement accounts and other investments. Other competition has come from credit card companies and home loan brokerage concerns, which have cut into the banks' consumer business, and from investment banking houses, venture capital concerns and others that have lured away the business of corporate finance.
It is against that backdrop of an industry splitting into competitive pieces that experts say the surviving New York City banks will benefit if Federal regulations, which now limit their ability to diversify, break down. And they say the proposed marriage of Citicorp and Travelers, more than any other, will put pressure on Congress to change the rules.
"This merger is great for the city," said Mitchell Moss, an economist and urban planner at New York University. "It means the rest of the world is going to buy financial services in New York."
Whatever benefit may eventually flow to the city from its bank industry shake-up, the immediate results have been grim. Government figures show that employment gains at brokerage houses, financial consulting firms and other related businesses have fallen far short of making up for the banking cutbacks.
"The losses have not been remotely offset," said Rae Rosen, senior economist of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. While shrinking in importance to the city economy, she said, the New York commercial banks are also continuing a long downward spiral in their share of the nation's banking business, commanding less than 7 percent last year compared with more than 13 percent in the 1960's.
Executives say many of those being displaced from bank jobs are being helped by the region's strong economy and high demand for workers, if not at other banks or financial services companies, in other fields.
"Even though the number of banks that people can go to has gotten dramatically smaller, we are seeing very little overhang of chronic unemployment," said Lee Pomeroy, an executive search consultant who specializes in financial services. A former vice president at Chemical Bank, he said he left in 1987 "when I realized banking was the land of shrinking opportunities."
Mr. Pomeroy said workers being eliminated by banks now have much better prospects than in the early 1990's, when they faced the combined problems of a weak regional economy and a glut of laid-off bankers. Banking executives and managers are turning to a broad spectrum of other fields, including financial consulting and insurance, he said.
Since most entry-level bank workers receive at least rudimentary training in word processing, data entry or other computer skills, they are also in demand by companies in other fields, he said.
Still, the retrenchment of commercial banking poses problems that have less to with layoffs than with the level of banking service. A particular worry is the number of branches in poor neighborhoods far from the commercial core of Manhattan. Advocates for the poor, immigrants and elderly people say these areas have always been underserved. Now, with the elimination of many small banks and the branches of larger ones, they say the problem may be growing worse.
"Historically, there would have been a local savings institution that people could go to with their projects, but today they find themselves walking the halls of Chase or Citicorp," said Kathryn S. Wylde, president of the New York Investment Fund, a business-sponsored philanthropical organization, who has spent more than 10 years leading a program to build housing in poor areas.
"The banks that are left are being expected to do more, and for the most part they are stepping up to the plate," she said. "But there has to be a limit to how many people and much of their resources they will devote to community development lending."
And even where banks have retained branches in poor areas, they have provoked repeated criticism for offering fewer services in those offices than in wealthier areas. Automated teller machines, in particular, have been the focus of complaints, with Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate, charging that banks have installed fewer of them in sections of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens than in Manhattan.
Still, bank executives and some analysts say the only way to maintain many of their traditional services amid the industry's retrenchment will be through technology -- not just in the form of automated cash machines, but through a growing assortment of bank transactions that can be conducted over the phone or home computers. "While we are processing fewer transactions in the branches, people are becoming much less dependent on them," Ken Herz, a spokesman for Chase, said.
Because of the pressures on New York City banks to continue their retrenchment and reorganization, Mr. Moss said customers would have no choice but to rely more on electronic bank services.
"Banks used to be the equivalent of financial temples, putting people close to God," he said. "Now the marble of the temple is becoming less important than its phone line to the outside world."

HEADLINE: For Gay Soldiers, Service Means Lying

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Trouble With 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' " (editorial, April 8), on the Defense Department report showing that the number of homosexuals being forced out of the military under the policy is higher than when the policy was adopted in 1993: 
 You say the "Pentagon spin is that service members are voluntarily declaring themselves gay to get out of the military." You go on to ask, "But if that were true, wouldn't discharge numbers have stayed roughly the same from year to year?" This ignores several realities.
There is less stigma associated with homosexuality today, so new recruits who find the military tougher than expected can claim to be homosexual and get an honorable discharge with taxpayer-financed transition benefits. Veterans use the same excuse to gain their freedom to pursue careers in a robust economy, and a growing number escape obligations after expensive taxpayer-financed legal and medical schooling. Meanwhile, military recruiting and retention are severe problems.
 
ROBERT L. MAGINNIS
Director, Miltary Readiness Project
Family Research Council
Washington, April 8, 1998

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices of the 30-Year Treasury Issue Decline in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday, hurt in part by speculation that the Bank of Japan had sold Treasury bills to raise cash for its efforts to support the yen.
The weakness in the market, however, also stemmed from comments made by a Federal Reserve governor, Laurence H. Meyer, on Thursday. Mr. Meyer said that the economy's "performance is exceptional but unsustainable," suggesting that any slowdown generated by Asia's financial crisis may have arrived too late to ward off an increase in interest rates by the Fed. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 21/32 yesterday, to 102 25/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.93 percent, from 5.88 percent on Thursday. The Treasury market was closed on Friday in observance of Good Friday.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at J. W. Charles Securities Inc., in Boca Raton, Fla., called the market "a little vulnerable because we have not been able to go up on good news, instead the market is focusing on yen-dollar trade."
Trading volume was up in the shorter maturities but thin in the longer-maturity coupons, Mr. Pugliese noted, leaving bond prices susceptible to sharp fluctuations. One large seller or one large buyer can move the market on days like yesterday, he said.
With reports expected today on March consumer prices and retail sales, "tomorrow will be a pivotal day for bonds, depending on how the market reacts to the monthly retail and Consumer Price Index numbers," Mr. Pugliese said.
"Market participants have been growing accustomed to friendly numbers," he said.
Rates at yesterday's weekly Treasury bill auction were higher in what was described as a weak and sloppy auction. The bid-to-cover ratios were poor, with some analysts attributing the outcome to activity by the Fed, which was in the market selling securities for a customer.
The average rate for the three-month bill was 5.035 percent, up from 4.960 percent last week, while the six-month bill was awarded at the average rate of 5.130 percent, up from 5 percent.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN BANKING: THE CONSOLIDATION;
Big Mergers: Economies That Could Break the Scale

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The old American financial system -- with banks unable to cross state lines and barred by law from getting into some other financial businesses -- was a messy and inefficient one. But it encouraged a diversity that may have helped the economy.
The new system, cemented by mergers and takeovers that are coming in a wave, is hailed by Wall Street for its efficiency as economies of scale reduce costs. But the presence of fewer substantial competitors also means that the remaining ones are more likely to make the same mistakes if the financial environment again turns hostile. 
 Some of today's big players got to be big precisely because they avoided the mistakes of their larger competitors. But there will be fewer midsize players in the future with the ability to move up to the front ranks.
To see just how much the financial landscape has changed in a generation, consider the lineup of large banks a quarter of a century ago, at the end of 1972. Then there were 10 commercial banks in the United States with assets of more than $10 billion.
Today, with all the mergers that have transpired in recent years -- and the ones announced in the last two weeks -- just three of those banks are to be owned by the same companies that controlled them a quarter of a century ago.
The amazing change in banking leadership in this country is a result of several factors. Some banks faltered in the 1970's and 80's because of bad loans. Others were able to grow because of more friendly regulatory treatment in their states as interstate banking became possible. Others merged as banks faced intense competition from other financial services providers.
As this year began, five of the top 10 of a quarter century ago were still owned by the same owner, or by a successor whose name reflected a reorganization, not a takeover.
But Citicorp, the company that owns Citibank -- then called First National City Bank of New York -- agreed last week to be acquired by Travelers, the insurance and brokerage giant. And yesterday, BankAmerica agreed to be merged into Nationsbank, the successor to a North Carolina bank that ranked 33d in size a quarter of a century ago.
The three remaining are all New York banks -- Morgan Guaranty, Chemical Bank and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation. Chemical Bank is no longer around, but its parent corporation, the Chemical New York Corporation, is, having been renamed the Chase Manhattan Corporation when it acquired that bank a few years after absorbing another of the top 10, Manufacturers Hanover. J. P. Morgan still owns Morgan Guaranty, but has indicated it would consider a merger if it is unable to become an investment banking powerhouse on its own. Bankers Trust has expanded into investment banking and has shown no signs of wanting to be bought, though there has been speculation that it might become a target.
Outside New York, there were four banks in the top 10, as compiled by American Banker based on data from the end of 1972. All but BankAmerica had already gone the takeover route before the latest wave. Security Pacific, based in Los Angeles, was taken over by BankAmerica. Chicago's Continental Illinois, a victim of bad lending in the 1970's, had to be rescued by the Government and was eventually acquired by BankAmerica. First Chicago was taken over by a Detroit bank in 1995, only to have the merged entity agree to be bought yesterday by Banc One of Columbus, Ohio. A quarter of a century ago, that company's predecessor, First Bank Group of Ohio, was the third-largest banking company in Columbus. It was nowhere near the top 100 in the nation.
The fate of the Chicago banks reflects the fear in which they were held back home. For decades, Illinois law barred them from expanding to other parts of Illinois. That was supposed to protect downstate banks. In the end, it merely left them open to acquisition by banks from outside the state and assured that the headquarters of big Chicago banks would no longer be in Illinois.
During this great period of consolidation, Wall Street has fallen in and out of love with the banks several times. There have been worries over bad loans, over the costs of all that branch-bank real estate in an increasingly computerized age, and of deteriorating market share for banks as mutual funds have come on strong.
But lately, there has been an intense love affair. In the 1990's, interest rates have come down -- and the biggest reductions have come in what banks pay for deposits, not what they charge for loans. With the economy healthy, relatively few bad loans have appeared, and Wall Street has come to expect good profit increases for the banks that survive, with each merger meaning the elimination of redundant costs and opportunities to sell more products to more customers.
Of the four banks in yesterday's deals, the stock in three rose. Banc One shares rose in early trading but settled back to end unchanged at $61.75.
Part of the problem there was that in a meeting with analysts yesterday, John B. McCoy, chairman of Banc One, said his goal for annual profit increases now was 13 to 15 percent. He tried to hint that he really didn't mean to imply the figure could be as low as 13 percent, but some analysts immediately noted that the old figure had been 15 percent, and the stock soon weakened.
Eight years ago, when bad loans were bringing banks down and analysts were vying to predict failures correctly, the idea of banks as growth vehicles would have seemed quaint. If and when the credit excesses of this era appear in earning reports, it may again seem odd.
The old system that kept banks within state lines, and out of other financial businesses, may have been inefficient. But it meant that when the biggest players stumbled, there were others who could grow to take up the slack. And the huge number of banks meant that banks were likely to pursue differing strategies, some wiser, or luckier, than others. Contrast that with European countries, which tended to be dominated by a few large banks that were likely to make similar mistakes.
The consolidation phase of American banking is continuing, and there is no sign of an early end. The resulting behemoths may be better at squeezing out costs and at marketing the most products. But they are less likely to be nimble in the way that smaller institutions could be, and that fact -- in the next economic cycle or the one after that -- may prove to be very important, and the source of disappointment to investors.

HEADLINE: Test Census Is Attracting Few Workers

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: CHESTER, S.C., April 8

 BODY:
Only five people three unemployed workers, a member of the volunteer fire department and a clerk at the local motel -- showed up one evening at the public library for the test to be census takers. But officials from the Census Bureau were thankful for the few who did come. Some nights, the turnout is even more disappointing.
"For every 10 calls we get from people who say they want to take the test, 50 percent don't show up at all," said Jackie P. Shaw, chief recruiter for the Census Bureau's regional office in Charlotte, N.C. 
 As the Census Bureau begins a critical dress rehearsal in South Carolina for the 2000 Census, it is encountering the same problem that has bedeviled private industry across the country. The bureau cannot find enough workers.
In an effort to attract more workers, the bureau has recently raised the pay by 50 cents an hour for workers at the South Carolina test site. Now, census takers can earn as much as $10.50 an hour, while some supervisors can make as much as $14 an hour for the temporary jobs that last six weeks and pay no benefits.
With the jobless rate the lowest since the early 1970's, welfare rolls plummeting and the American work force radically changed over the last 30 years, census officials have been scrambling to hire enough people to perform the critical work of knocking on the doors and counting members of those households that have not mailed in their census form.
"Every place you go into in this area, especially the type of people who in the past we have been able to recruit from -- namely the fast food industry, places with high turnover and fairly low wages -- they are all looking for people," said Ms. Shaw, who is supervising recruiting in the 11 counties in South Carolina that make up one of the three test sites.
No one can predict the shape of the country's economy two years from now, but South Carolina's hiring difficulties could be compounded by an even older problem of finding temporary employees when the traditional source of such workers, stay-at-home wives, has been shrinking.
By the end of last week, officials here had recruited fewer than 4,369 people, or roughly less than 38 percent of the workers needed to canvas the test area starting on May 16. Officials hoped that by the end of April they would have hired 80 percent of the 11,575 employees who they will eventually need. But now they are afraid they will fall far short.
Unemployment is so low in some areas where the bureau is trying to recruit -- it is 2.3 percent in Richland County, home of Columbia, the capital of South Carolina and one of the counties in the test -- and welfare rates have fallen so fast that bureau officials are concerned about the quality of some of the applicants. "Frankly, the people who are unemployed in a market like this -- my eyes have been opened -- are, for the most part, unemployable," Ms. Shaw said.
As a result, the bureau has embarked on a new strategy, focusing its recruiting efforts on retirees and on people who are already working, but who want to earn some extra money in the evenings and on weekends. "I stress to all my recruiting assistants: do not spend all of your time; in fact, do not spend the majority of your time on the unemployed folks," Ms. Shaw said.
The bureau is even running into resistance from local businesses. Recently, the bureau asked a number of local plants if they could place recruiting posters on company bulletin boards, advertising the opportunity for part-time work. The companies, fearing the loss of workers, refused.
"There are not really a lot of companies we have found who are enthusiastic about their employees working another 30 hours," said Peter Iwema, assistant manager for recruiting for the South Carolina test site.
The Census Bureau's problems in South Carolina underscore how difficult the next census will be. Currently Congress is squabbling over the bureau's plans to use statistical sampling to estimate the population in the year 2000. That method, which is loosely similar to public opinion polls, is opposed by Republicans who say it is unconstitutional and prone to manipulation for partisan political purposes.
Census Bureau officials say they are attempting to get a change in Federal rules to allow employees in other Federal agencies to do the census work part time.

LENGTH: 400 words

HEADLINE: Ukraine's Dangerous Decline

 BODY:
Last year, Ukraine and Turkmenistan were the only former Soviet republics to see their official economies shrink. Ukraine's steady decline is the main reason that voters abandoned the relatively reformist governing party in parliamentary elections two weeks ago. The big winner was the Communist Party, a group so troglodyte that it favors "voluntary reunification" with Russia. The vote practically insures that Ukraine will see none of the reforms the country needs.
Since its independence in 1991, Ukraine has had some limited economic success, largely thanks to the skill of the central bank governor, Victor Yushchenko. Inflation, 10,000 percent five years ago, has fallen to around 10 percent today. About half the economy is now in private hands, compared with 70 percent in Russia. 
 But privatization has not generated economic growth. Important areas, like agriculture, have yet to be touched. The tax system is arbitrary, burdening legitimate businesses and driving them into the shadow economy. Regulation is stifling -- setting up a construction company requires some 50 different licenses, virtually all of which must be accompanied by bribes. President Leonid Kuchma and his allies in the Parliament introduced an important package of reforms more than a year ago, but it died, a victim of the pervasive corruption that is choking modernization and driving away investment.
Ukraine's economy also suffers from the country's uneven progress in democratic reforms. Ukraine is one of a handful of former Soviet republics that have had relatively clean parliamentary elections and changed their presidents. The country's treatment of national minorities is also good, and it has shown the political maturity to give up its nuclear weapons. But Ukraine's newspapers and especially its television stations are politicized and controlled to the point where they cannot keep an eye on the Government.
Ukraine is the fourth-largest recipient of American aid, but that assistance may be cut in half under a misguided new law requiring the Administration to certify that the country is making progress on the problems of a few American investors. The World Bank and International Monetary Fund should condition their assistance on changes like tax and regulatory reforms designed to speed economic growth. Ukraine's politicians need a clear message that economic reform cannot wait.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN BANKING: THE NEW BANKAMERICA;
Hands in a Lot of Markets And a Foot on Each Coast

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
As expected, the Nationsbank Corporation and the BankAmerica Corporation announced a $60 billion merger yesterday that would create the nation's largest bank in terms of deposits and would have relationships with 30 percent of the nation's households.
The combined company, to be called BankAmerica, would catapult ahead of the Chase Manhattan Corporation and would have a truly national reach, stretching from Nationsbank's headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., to BankAmerica's home in San Francisco. It would be second in assets only to Citigroup, the proposed $70 billion combination of Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc. announced just a week ago. 
 Nationsbank and BankAmerica aim to be the biggest consumer bank in the nation and expect to achieve significant economies of scale, temporarily putting aside the notion that banks need giant securities firms, insurance companies and asset management units to compete in the increasingly global marketplace.
"This is going to be the best franchise in the country, both in terms of their retail and wholesale businesses," said Robert Albertson, a Goldman, Sachs & Company analyst.
The proposed merger could lead to 5,000 to 8,000 job cuts, an undetermined number of which would involve layoffs, and is expected to result in expense reductions of $2 billion in the two years after the merger. The companies said they expected the merger to close at the end of the year. Unlike last week's merger agreement between Citicorp and Travelers, which involves few overlapping business, the BankAmerica transaction with Nationbank would permit the merged company to reduce back-office costs as it combines similar businesses like investment banking and credit card operations.
The new BankAmerica would have $570 billion in assets, compared with $697 billion for Citigroup. In market capitalization, it would also be second, with $133 billion to Citigroup's market capitalization of roughly $140 billion. Most important, it would have branches in 22 states coast to coast, with little overlap. There are only two states where both NationsBank and BankAmerica now have branches: Texas and New Mexico. BankAmerica had previously announced that its retail operations in Texas were for sale but reversed that decision yesterday.
Hugh L. McColl Jr., 62, would be chairman and chief executive of the merged company, which would be based in Charlotte. Over the last decade, Mr. McColl has gobbled up banks at a rapid clip to create a giant franchise out of the once small North Carolina bank known as NCNB.
David A. Coulter, 50, of BankAmerica, would be president of the combined company and Mr. McColl's designated successor. But the board will favor Nationsbank, with 11 of the new board's 20 members coming from that institution.
The leadership issue was not contentious, Mr. McColl said in a news conference yesterday. "We figured out which one of us was the oldest and who would get out of the way the quickest," he said, "and I won."
This is not the first go-around for the two companies. Merger discussions were held in 1995 between Nationsbank's Mr. McColl and the former BankAmerica chairman, Richard M. Rosenberg, who retired in early 1996 and was replaced by Mr. Coulter. At the time, though, the deal faltered because they could not decide who would run the combined company, where it would be based and what it would be named.
This time both companies' executives set aside egos to get the deal done. In late March, Michael O'Neill, the chief financial officer for BankAmerica, and James Hance, his counterpart at Nationsbank, held initial meetings in San Francisco, said a person close to the talks. Meetings in San Francisco followed on April 2, with Mr. McColl and Mr. Coulter joining the discussion. There, along with Edward Herlihy, a lawyer at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz who had advised Nationsbank on its acquisition of Barnett Banks and had counseled BankAmerica on other deals, the two companies outlined the basic merger terms.
The four bank executives flew to Phoenix for the Bankers Roundtable, an industry conference, after their meetings in San Francisco. There, Mr. McColl and Mr. Coulter hammered out the last of the details.
To keep the deal quiet, executives from both companies met secretly in Dallas last week to conduct due diligence far from the watchful eye of employees, analysts and reporters, said the person close to the talks. On Thursday, BankAmerica's board approved the merger. Nationsbank's board approved the merger the next day.
The transaction is a stock swap that involves BankAmerica's shareholders exchanging their existing stock for 1.1316 shares of the new company. Nationsbank shareholders will retain their existing shares.
The stocks of the two bank companies soared in early trading before settling back at the end of the day. BankAmerica finished at $91.375, up $4.625, while Nationsbank gained $4.1875 to close at $80.625.
Merrill Lynch and Montgomery Securities provided investment banking advice to Nationsbank, while BankAmerica was advised by Goldman, Sachs. Nationsbank received legal advice from Wachtell, Lipton and Smith, Helms, Mulliss & Moore. BankAmerica's counsel was Wachtell, Lipton.

HEADLINE: 3 Large Securities Firms Post Strong Earnings Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Three big securities firms -- Merrill Lynch & Company, the Paine Webber Group and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. -- reported strong earnings gains yesterday for the first quarter, helped by the booming stock market.
The companies' stocks rose after the reports and amid speculation, set off by mega-mergers in the financial industry, that more securities firms will become takeover targets. 
 Merrill, the biggest securities firm, said its profits rose 11 percent. Paine Webber, which is the seventh- largest firm, said profits were up 20 percent, and Donaldson, at No. 8, said its profits rose 55 percent. All the results handily beat analyst forecasts.
Wall Street firms are benefiting from the healthy economy and rising corporate profits, which are enticing millions of individuals to put their money into stocks and other investments. This has encouraged many companies to raise cash by selling both stocks and bonds -- businesses that earn securities companies hefty underwriting fees.
Meanwhile, consolidation in many industries also continues to generate significant revenues for Wall Street firms that provide advice on corporate mergers.
The booming business on Wall Street has caught the eyes of commercial banks and other companies looking to diversify as Depression-era restrictions that have separated financial services in the United States continue to crumble. Merrill Lynch, Paine Webber and Donaldson have all maintained their independence. But the three companies all have been mentioned as ripe targets by analysts and have been the subject of takeover speculation.
The speculation was heightened -- and the shares of the three firms surged -- yesterday after the Nationsbank Corporation and the BankAmerica Corporation announced a giant merger and the Banc One Corporation said it would combine with the First Chicago NBD Corporation. The two deals followed last week's planned union of the banking giant Citicorp and Travelers Group, the financial services giant.
Merrill Lynch, Paine Webber and Donaldson credited their strong performances to healthy gains in asset management fees, brokerage commissions and investment banking, which includes underwritings and corporate mergers advice.
Merrill, the leading American underwriter of stocks and bonds during the quarter and No. 1 in advising on corporate mergers, earned $518 million, or $1.30 a diluted share, compared with $466 million, or $1.17 a share, a year earlier. Revenues after interest expenses rose to $4.6 billion from $3.8 billion.
The results beat Wall Street expectations of $1.11 a share, according to Zacks Investment research. Merrill's stock was up $4.125, to $99 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Asset management and portfolio service fees rose 50 percent, to $970 million. Brokerage commissions increased 23 percent, to $1.4 billion. Trading revenue rose 16 percent, to $951 million. Investment banking revenue was up 32 percent, to $810 million.
Meanwhile, Paine Webber earned $120.7 million, or 77 cents a diluted share, compared with $100.8 million, or 62 cents a share, a year earlier. Net revenues rose to $1.11 billion from $984.8 million.
The results exceeded analysts' forecasts for earnings of 64 cents a share. Paine Webber's stock was up $2.125, to $48.9375 on the Big Board.
Donaldson, the brokerage subsidiary of the Equitable Companies Inc. earned $134.2 million, or $2 a diluted share, up from $86.4 million, or $1.37 cents a share. Revenues minus interest expenses rose to $1.1 billion from $763 million. The results were much stronger than the $1.32 a share Wall Street expected. The company's shares were up $7.375, to $101.25 a share on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: This Year in Argentina, Two Brothers Build an Empire;
Outsiders, They Bet on Future of a Global Breadbasket

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
Moments after taking off from an airport here, Alejandro Elsztain peered out at the verdant patchwork of family farms spreading over the Argentine horizon.
"At the beginning of the century, the land is what Argentina was known for," Mr. Elsztain told a group of investment fund analysts on an airborne tour of farms he manages. "And in the future, Argentina will once again be known for its agriculture. We are just beginning." 
 When Mr. Elsztain (pronounced el-STINE) speaks of "we," he is referring not just to Argentina, but also to himself and his older brother, Eduardo, whose fortunes are increasingly intertwined with the fortunes of their nation. With a vision of Argentina awakening from six decades of economic slumber to become a dominant agribusiness power in the next 15 years, the two brothers are quietly building Latin America's newest real estate empire before either has reached the age of 40.
Though their gamble that Argentina will become the next big breadbasket in an increasingly integrated global economy is only beginning to pay off, they have already emerged from obscurity. Since Eduardo talked his way into George Soros's office in New York City eight years ago and came away with a $10 million check, they have become darlings of Wall Street's emerging-market gurus and Argentina's free-enterprise revolutionaries intent on smashing the nation's quaint tradition of inefficient, underfinanced family farms and ranches.
The history of Latin America is full of wealthy "hacendados" and "rancheros," powerful figures who pulled the strings from behind the scenes. Not the Elsztains. They are outsiders, third-generation Jews from Eastern and Central Europe now in a thoroughly Roman Catholic country, whose vision is nourished by a mystical Orthodox faith usually associated with the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn.
With an audacity that has stunned many in the Argentine business community, the Elsztains doubled their rural land holdings to 1.1 million acres in the last year -- a vault that suddenly made their farm company Cresud Argentina's largest landowner and biggest producer of beef and grain. Meanwhile, their separate real estate company, IRSA, headed by Eduardo Elsztain, is remaking the skyline of Buenos Aires and pushing the city's development south and east.
"There is a tremendous amount of capital going into the developing world," Eduardo said in a recent interview. "That pool of money is translated into increases in salaries. People who have a jump in salary first begin to eat a little better. That creates a demand for food, and that's where Argentina will grow."
Cresud is bringing about big changes in Argentine ranching and agriculture with biotechnology, extensive irrigation of marginal land and one particular innovation that horrifies most gauchos and Argentine beefeaters who shun fatty meat. Cresud recently entered into a joint venture with the Texas-based Cactus Feeders to begin fattening 100,000 head of cattle a year with corn rather than traditional Argentine grass to increase yields and produce cuts of beef marbled with more fat to appeal to American and Asian tastes.
Believing that the Argentine middle and upper classes can only expand and grow richer, the Elsztains' real estate arm is buying up shopping centers, office buildings and hotels around Argentina at a dizzying pace. It is also helping restore the capital's shabby river waterfront to splendors not seen in 60 years. Abasto, a sprawling neighborhood known until recently for muggings and seedy tango bars, is suddenly gentrifying as the Elsztain brothers begin to build a giant high-rise middle-class housing project abutting an even larger shopping center complete with a dozen movie theaters and a children's museum.
IRSA last year swallowed up its biggest competitor and acquired assets worth more than $350 million, bolstering its real estate portfolio to an estimated value of $800 million, according to a recent Bear, Stearns report. And now, with local partners in Venezuela and Brazil, the company is taking its mall empire outside Argentina. The cover of its last annual report displayed a key entering a lock in the shape of the entire South American continent.
The Elsztains say the economic upheaval in Asia is little more than a speed bump. In the long term, they contend, the sprawling pampas of Argentina will feed a growing Brazil, a Europe that must cut its immensely expensive agricultural subsidies and an Asia that will continue to move away from an agrarian production system as it industrializes.
In recent years, as the Argentine Government slashed farm export taxes, land prices have rapidly appreciated. Nonetheless, they remain considerably less expensive than comparable lands in Canada and the United States. The company stands to gain from a further escalation of land values, local and foreign analysts say.
"The Elsztains know that Argentina can produce meat, wheat and milk cheaper than the United States," said Osvaldo Cortesi, an agricultural economist at Macroeconomica, a local research organization. "They know that as agribusiness expands in Argentina, land prices will rise."
Argentina's share of world beef exports has already doubled since 1993, in large part because of a 400 percent increase in exports to Brazil. With the United States last year opening its market to Argentine beef for the first time in six decades, and with Japan soon expected to follow, international experts say the future for Argentine beef growers looks even brighter.
Since 1990, the country's agricultural exports have climbed 80 percent, to more than $9 billion last year. Its current annual grain output of 60 million tons is expected to climb to 80 million tons in 2000, according to local and foreign analysts.
Nevertheless, the Elsztains are feeling at least a short-term chill from Asia. Jittery foreign investors have shied away from Latin stocks in recent months, jolting Cresud, which is traded as American depository receipts on the Nasdaq market, and IRSA, which is traded on the New York Stock Exchange. The companies' shares are well off their highs of $24.625 and $46 last year; Cresud closed yesterday at $20.25, down 12.5 cents, and IRSA, at $36.0625, down 43.75 cents.
Weak international commodity prices, particularly for corn, have been a drag on Cresud. Rental rates have slowed, and some analysts consider retail sales in IRSA's shopping centers vulnerable. Moreover, concerns that the last decade of political stability may not last hang over Argentine markets.
"There are two if's," said Hector R. R. Lawrence, Pioneer Hi-Bred International's manager in Argentina. "If there is no political change in the rules of the Argentine economy and if there is no international crisis that provokes capital flight from Argentina, these two brothers are going to be extremely successful."
Alejandro, 32, is the day-to-day manager of Cresud, while Eduardo, 38, is the top executive of both Cresud and IRSA. They both assiduously keep a low profile and refuse to answer any questions about their religion, family members or personal lives.
Alejandro is a trained agronomist with a love of the outdoors and riding horses gleaned from childhood visits to a family farm. Though he sometimes displays a quick temper, he also has a warm smile and a teasing, sometimes self-deprecating sense of humor. In the recent tour of his properties with analysts, he mixed dense statistical presentations with fun. He plied his guests with sizzling steaks and Argentine wines and humored them by leading a tour of his fields on horseback. He then encouraged them to milk the cows and feed the calves.
Eduardo is the dour, bearded brother. He is a man of few words, but by all accounts he is the real visionary of the family. He is an Orthodox Jew who seeks guidance from Lubavitcher rabbis, intellectual direction from the English philosopher Karl Popper and economic perspective from Mr. Soros, the financier. Visitors to his office in Buenos Aires leave with copies of the writings of the Grand Rebbe, the late Menachem M. Schneerson, and a sense that Eduardo finds a spiritual mission in his investments.
"I feel every person is born with a mission in life," Eduardo said. "So when you make a business, you are not only making a business but elevating something, and that is how the person grows and elevates himself beyond the material world."
For all his seriousness, though, he lets loose, too. On Purim, Eduardo joined in a service that was held in his office and attended by fellow executives and members of the local Lubavitcher community. At every mention of Haman, the evil Persian leader who plotted the destruction of the Jews, he whistled in a loud jeer and banged a double AA battery on the table. That night in March, at a boisterous Purim party, he danced in wild gyrations as he drank kosher wine straight from the bottle.
Eduardo was not always religious, associates said, nor did he always seem destined for success. As a high school student during the times of the military dictatorships, acquaintances said Eduardo sympathized with the leftist opposition. He did not graduate from college. He went to work in his father's small real estate company and gradually found religion, spending a year in Israel in 1980.
In 1990, as Argentina was beginning to emerge from a devastating fit of hyperinflation, Eduardo spent a year in New York City studying Jewish teaching in the mornings and lobbying Mr. Soros and other investors in the afternoons. In a single meeting, Eduardo convinced Mr. Soros that new policies of the Argentine Government intended to deregulate and privatize the economy were worth a gamble.
With Mr. Soros's $10 million, a partner and a secretary, Eduardo founded a portfolio management company. As the Argentine stock market exploded in 1991 and 1992, he took profits and turned his attentions to real estate. IRSA now has a market capitalization of about $697 million, and Cresud, about $252 million. Mr. Soros holds about one-quarter of the shares of both companies, and Eduardo has since made at least one other deal with him, investing with Mr. Soros in Apex Silver Mines Ltd.
Eduardo describes himself as a contrarian who saw values in properties and stocks driven down by decades of political instability and hyperinflation. When Argentina was left staggering again in the wake of Mexico's monetary crisis in 1994 and 1995, he became only more aggressive in his pursuit of both urban and rural properties. That paid off when the Argentine economy took off again, growing last year by 8 percent with only a slight slowdown so far this year.
"The companies are growing with the country," Eduardo said. "The more the country grows, the more we will grow."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Warns U.S. Markets Could Tumble

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund said today that while the United States was likely to ride out the remainder of the Asian financial crisis largely unscathed, the American stock and bond markets were increasingly vulnerable to a major fall.
The assessment was contained in a survey of world economies, published as finance ministers from around the world began arriving in Washington to assess the impact of the Asian crisis and debate how the world should react to such shocks in the future. The meeting comes as Congress is debating whether to increase the United States' contribution to the monetary fund by $18 billion, a step opposed by many Republicans and some Democrats. 
 In the survey, the fund lowered its projections for world economic growth for the second time in four months, predicting that it would slow to 3.1 percent from 4.1 percent a year ago.
The major drag on world growth, the report suggested, would come from Japan, which the fund's economists said in polite language would be lucky to post zero percent growth this year. Other economists are predicting that Japan could slip into a deep recession that might drag down much of the rest of the world.
Such projections will almost certainly keep Japanese officials on the defensive this week. Already they have been attacked by European and Asian nations for a slow and insufficient response to their country's financial slide.
Last week, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan announced a $76 billion financial stimulus package in response to overwhelming international pressure.
"Everyone called the Japanese and put the screws to them," said a senior international financial official involved in this week's meetings. "And still, they came up with something the markets view as insufficient."
Predictably, the United States received the best marks for the management of its national finances over the last year, and the monetary fund projected that inflation would remain low through the rest of the year, in part because of a flood of low-priced Asian imports.
But the fund warned that American stock prices were currently "at or very near historical peaks." The fund's chief economist, Michael Mussa, said at a news conference that a sharp fall in the market was "a risk that should warrant concern at this point in time."
"There needs to be concern about the possibility of an equity market correction," he said, "but I don't have any reason at this stage to fear that there would be large adverse consequences from such a correction."

HEADLINE: 1,500 Executions Cited for Iraq In Past Year, Mostly for Politics

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 13

 BODY:
The Government of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has executed at least 1,500 people in the last year mostly for political reasons, a former Dutch Foreign Minister has concluded in a report to be presented on Tuesday to the United Nations Human Rights Commission.
Most of the deaths occurred during a "prison-cleansing campaign" in November and December ordered by Mr. Hussein's younger son, Qusay. He directs Iraq's Special Security Organization, one of a number of armed intelligence agencies that sustain an atmosphere of terror in Iraq, diplomats based there say. 
 The report says that after Qusay Hussein's visit to one prison, Abu Gharib, large numbers of prisoners condemned to death or to sentences of 15 years or more were shot, hanged or electrocuted there and in other prisons. The families of those shot were forced to pay for the bullets used before they could claim the bodies.
The report was prepared by Max van der Stoel, former Foreign Minister of the Netherlands, for the Human Rights Commission. It is in line with charges that Iraq exiles have been leveling against President Hussein's administration in recent months.
Reporting on human rights issues is virtually nonexistent inside Iraq, where the news media are controlled and opposition to the President and his family is met with draconian measures -- including assassination and imprisonment without fair trial.
This report follows a separate study for the United Nations in March that concluded that Iraq leads the world in forced disappearances, with 16,000 people reported missing in the last decade.
The Clinton Administration has made an improvement in Iraq's human rights record a prerequisite to the lifting of economic sanctions imposed in 1990, after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait -- along with a demonstrable end to prohibited weapons programs.
The United States is likely to face pressures in the United Nations Security Council, though, by the end of this month to reward Iraq for what appears to be a new spirit of cooperation with arms inspections.
Mr. Van der Stoel, who holds the title of United Nations Special Rapporteur on Iraq, has been refused entry to the country since 1992. His survey, completed last month, is based on reports and documents smuggled out of Iraq as well as on information compiled from a number of sources by exiled Iraqi opposition groups. He also collected information in Turkey because information reaches that country through Iraqi Kurds in the border area.
His report paints a picture of persistent persecutions of the Kurds, of the Shiite tribes in the southern marshes and Turkomans and other ethnic or religious groups. It describes a relentless pursuit of all political critics or would-be critics.
Among the instances of summary executions that he cited were the killings in October of 14 military officers and politicians who were accused of planning an attempt on President Hussein's life.
In another instance he cited, 23 people were sentenced to death, among them three military officers charged with "maneuvering" against the Government.
He received reports of the executions of army deserters, Islamic activists, Shiite tribe members and people connected with opposition groups that maintain offices in exile -- including nine people with ties to a group called the Iraqi National Council and seven people associated with another group, the Supreme Council for Islamic Revolution in Iraq.
As with other United Nations human rights investigators, Mr. Van der Stoel guards his sources of information to protect them from retaliation. His work is given considerable credibility because he has been reporting on Iraq since the Persian Gulf war.
"Iraqi law imposes life imprisonment and, in certain cases, death on anyone insulting the President," the report says. It notes that the Iraqi Government explanation is that officials distinguish between criticism and insult, reserving death for the latter.
Mr. Van der Stoel said he found this distinction "neither convincing in theory nor reflective of the factual situation in Iraq."
Membership in political parties not officially working with the governing Baath Party is punishable by death, the report says. And crimes against property can also bring the death penalty or in some cases disfigurement. Iraqi thieves may be branded, or limbs may be amputated, or both. In December, Iraq executed four Jordanian students who had smuggled $850 in auto parts into the country.
In addition to information about executions, the report details a continuing Iraqi policy of forcibly resettling people belonging to ethnic minorities -- especially Kurds and Turkoman people in Kirkuk, north of Baghdad -- and of moving Arabs into that region. Mr. Van der Stoel says Arabs are given incentives of money and apartments to settle in Kirkuk.
"Families who are perceived to be opposed to the regime, families who have relatives outside Iraq or in southern Iraq and those who have relatives in detention or executed are said to be the first targets of forced displacement," the report said. It added that officials from the Baath Party are given the power to move targeted families, often with as little as 24 hours' notice.
Today in Baghdad, the official Government newspaper Al Qadissiya called Mr. Van der Stoel an agent of American intelligence and Zionism who had been ordered "to spread lies and put out idiotic reports that no one will take seriously."
Iraq has told United Nations committees that it is fighting a rising crime wave brought on by sanctions. The Van der Stoel report challenges that explanation and also criticizes Iraq for not accepting for more than four years a Security Council plan allowing the limited sale of oil to raise money for food and medicine.
"Instead, the Government of Iraq decided to rely only on domestic production to meet the humanitarian needs of its people -- preferring to let innocent people suffer while the Government maneuvered to get sanctions lifted," the report says.
In another document issued today, the International Atomic Energy Agency submitted a six-month report on investigations into Iraq's nuclear program that found "no indication of prohibited materials, equipment or activities."
The Atomic Energy Agency's report said its monitoring activities would not only continue but would also be expanded and upgraded with new technology.
But the lack of any damaging new findings is likely to lead to another attempt by Russia and possibly by France and China as well to close the file on Iraq's nuclear case. Under requirements of the Security Council, all prohibited Iraqi nuclear, chemical and biological weapons must be destroyed or accounted for, along with long-range missile delivery systems.

HEADLINE: 1998 Candidates Advertise Early And Expensively

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Taking a lesson from the 1996 Presidential campaign, an array of candidates in this year's midterm elections has begun buying television advertising months earlier than usual, promising another election year likely to break spending records.
Gone are the days when candidates husbanded their resources for pre-primary or post-Labor Day advertising blitzes. Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a Connecticut Republican who eked out a victory in 1996, spent close to $100,000 around New Year's on a television spot on her sponsorship of a health care bill. 
 Senator Harry M. Reid, Democrat of Nevada, went on the air a month ago with $350,000 worth of television advertising. And Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican whose popularity dropped with his stewardship of the Senate's Whitewater hearings, began broadcasting commercials upstate and on Long Island in May 1997, a full year and a half before Election Day.
The early commercials are not confined to the traditional big-money states with major television markets like California, New York and Illinois. Nor is it just the candidates who are taking to the airwaves. The Arkansas Democratic Party, for example, broadcast two television commercials in January attacking Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican, on education and parole issues.
Strategists in both parties attribute the trend to President Clinton's decision in 1995 to mount the earliest, most intensive television campaign ever by an incumbent President. The Republicans never responded to the barrage of advertisements in the fall of 1995, which were paid for by the Democratic National Committee and focused on the budget battle between the President and the Republican Congress.
The cost of those advertisements led the Democrats into frenzied fund-raising that came back to haunt them amid accusations of questionable practices. Factions in the Clinton campaign argued over how successful the commercials were, but many consultants now believe that Mr. Clinton locked in his re-election victory during that period in 1995 by defining the Presidential race on his terms.
Now, in contests across the nation, candidates and their strategists are trying to duplicate that success.
"People do think that they are reading the Clinton playbook," said Rachel Gorlin, a Democratic consultant. "And it's also fueling a great deal of fund-raising because people think they need to get the money early to get the ads done early. And that does not mean that you don't have to have the ads on late. It means you have to have the ads on early and late."
Fergus Cullen, the deputy campaign manager for Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, a Republican, said, "We certainly did notice the Clinton campaign's tactics of using early media to help solidify an early lead."
Mr. Rowland made his first television advertising purchase, worth $200,000, last October -- more than a year before Election Day -- for a spot on his proposal to provide health insurance for uninsured children.
For another set of wealthy challengers this year, the role model is less President Clinton than Steve Forbes, the magazine publisher who became a major force in the early Republican primaries through his television advertising. "There's definitely an 'if you have it, spend it' rule," said Evan Tracey of the Campaign Media Analysis Group, which tracks political and issue advocacy campaigns.
In California, Alfred A. Checchi, the former co-chairman of Northwest Airlines who is a candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, began television advertising just before Thanksgiving for a June primary, the earliest of any candidate in the state's history. The standard Mr. Checchi set promises to lead to the most expensive state election campaign in the nation's history, with an estimated $20 million in television ads already purchased racked up in that one race alone.
In Illinois, John Schmidt, a losing contender for the Democratic nomination for governor, as well as Peter Fitzgerald, who won the Republican Senate primary, both put vast amounts of their own money into sustained television campaigns.
In several cases, those using television early are the incumbents, who traditionally have an easier time raising campaign money. The commercials showcase particular votes or initiatives or reintroduce themselves and their records.
"When an incumbent does media early, it's rather like sending out newsletters rather than running for office," said Dick Morris, the strategist who pushed Mr. Clinton to mount his own early television advertising. "He's shaping the perception of his incumbency."
Senator Reid of Nevada, in one of two commercials that first appeared a month ago, focused on the Federal Government's plan to create the nation's only high-level nuclear waste disposal site in Nevada. "I used my seat on the Appropriations Committee to help cut $30 million from the waste site budget," he says in the spot.
Governor Rowland's second television spot, "A Better Connecticut," was broadcast at the end of January and said the state's economy had improved under his stewardship.
Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the University of Pennsylvania's Annenberg School of Communication, said that the appearance of year-round campaign commercials raised the question of whether "campaign advertising has become a form of governance."
Another old truth of television advertising -- that when you go on the air, stay on the air -- is not always being followed this year.
"You can't go on the air nine months before the election and stay up -- unless you are Warren Buffett or Bill Gates," said Dave Karvelas, chief of staff to Representative Johnson of Connecticut. Instead, candidates are planning periodic bursts of commercials unless, like Mr. Checchi, they have fortunes to spend.
Some consultants are still dubious about the whole trend, particularly during an election cycle when the public seems tuned out of politics. "The fact that candidates want to run commercials early doesn't mean that voters want to watch them early," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster. "There's a risk of people just not paying attention."
Charles E. Cooke Jr., the editor of a nonpartisan political newsletter, noted that early television commercials were also in vogue in the 1986 midterm elections. "The fad then was to go on the air early and define yourself before your opponents defined you," Mr. Cooke said.
"A lot of people who did that in '86 became nonmembers in '87," he said, "because they spent their money too soon."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

In Banking Mergers, Big Enough Doesn't Exist
The $60 billion BankAmerica-Nationsbank merger and $30 billion Banc One-First Chicago NBD merger that roiled the United States banking industry yesterday illustrate the intense pressure on the top 50 domestic banks to increase their size and reach.
It also suggests that the biggest banks believe the only way to flourish is to create an operation with a nationwide customer base. News Analysis. Page A1.

The Nationsbank-BankAmerica combination would create the nation's largest bank in terms of deposits and would have relationships with 30 percent of the households in the country, from Charlotte, N.C. to San Francisco. D10. 

In the credit card world, the Banc One-First Chicago NBD merger was the big headline because their combination will create the No. 2 credit card business behind Citibank. D10.
 
The investment banking subsidiaries of Nationsbank and BankAmerica are rivals. Now, Robertson Stephens and Montgomery Securities face the prospect of working together, which may not be easy. D11.
 
Gains at 3 Big Wall Street Firms
Merrill Lynch, Paine Webber and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette all reported healthy gains in quarterly earnings on the strength of the booming stock market. The share prices in all three securities firms rose, partly on speculation they are prime targets in the current wave of mergers reshaping the financial services industry. D2.
 
Stocks Struggle to End Mixed
Despite two new huge bank mergers and a rally in the financial sector, stocks struggled to a mixed finish. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.44 points, to 9,012.30, its second close above 9,000. Some broader market indicators ended with slight losses. D13.
 
Treasury securities fell, hurt by speculation that the Bank of Japan had sold some of its holdings. The 30-year Treasury bond yield rose to 5.93 percent from 5.88. D13.
 
I.M.F. Sees Mixed Outlook
The I.M.F., in an assessment of world economies, said that while the United States was likely to ride out the remainder of the Asian financial crisis largely unscathed, the American stock and bond markets were increasingly vulnerable to a major fall. A9.
 
Gillette's New Shaving System
Gillette is expected to announce its largest product introduction ever today, its first new shaving system in nearly a decade. D8.
 
Betting on Better Food
Burrill & Company is investing in start-up companies trying to create healthier or faster-growing crops through biotechnology. Market Place. D12.
 
Anti-Smoking War of Words
An ambitious advertising campaign to discourage smoking among teen-agers begins this week in Florida, financed by the tobacco industry as part of a settlement reached last year with the state. The broadcast, print, outdoor and interactive campaign, which declares "Their brand is lies," is meant to counter pitches by tobacco companies. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D8.
 
Italy's Business Ambassador
The Italian financier Giovanni Agnelli and the staid business world with which he has long been synonymous face big changes as Italy prepares to join the European monetary union next year. A4.

Report Says 1,500 Iraqis Were Slain in Prison
The Government of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has executed at least 1,500 people in the last year for political reasons, a former Dutch Foreign Minister has concluded in a report to be presented to the United Nations Human Rights Commission. Most of the deaths occurred during a "prison-cleansing campaign" ordered by Mr. Hussein's younger son, Qusay, left, who directs one of Iraq's armed intelligence agencies, diplomats based there say. HEADLINE: Economics All-Star Says He Will Stay With Home Team, After All

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
One of the nation's most prominent economists, Robert J. Barro, has decided to back out of a highly publicized, exceptionally lucrative deal he had negotiated with Columbia University and will instead remain at Harvard University.
It is not clear what motivated Dr. Barro, 53, to change his mind weeks after he had, in a very public fashion, accepted Columbia's offer, which involved a pay package of nearly $300,000 and a wide range of benefits. 
 But according to colleagues and friends with whom he spoke yesterday, it appears to be just a question of cold feet.
"'My sense is that it was emotionally a big problem to make this move," said Elhanan Helpman, referring to Dr. Barro's earlier decision to leave Harvard. Dr. Barro, after all, had always professed to being quite happy there.
Professor Barro did not return telephone calls and E-mail seeking comment yesterday.
The mood at Harvard, which had not suffered a successful raid at a senior level from a rival university since 1979, was one of quiet vindication.
"Better a broken engagement than an unhappy marriage," Harvard's dean of faculty, Jeremy R. Knowles, said.
Dr. Barro's colleagues at Harvard, who had been stunned by his earlier decision to leave their top-ranked department for Columbia's department, which is ranked 14th, found themselves surprised by the professor once again.
"Robert is a very unusual guy," said Professor Helpman.
Professor Helpman recently left the University of Tel Aviv to join the Harvard department. "Everybody's happy here," he said.
Columbia, meanwhile, had just made its official announcement of Dr. Barro's arrival on the front page of The Columbia University Record, the official house organ.
Dr. Barro is a Chicago conservative with a libertarian streak who has written scholarly articles that are cited by other researchers as often as those of economists like Paul Samuelson, Milton Friedman and Robert Lucas. He has also written for The Wall Street Journal and Business Week.
After Columbia spent months to engineer a deal attractive enough to lure Dr. Barrio to its campus on Morningside Heights in Manhattan, Harvard had made a counteroffer involving some sweetening of his contract and a new research center for him to direct.
At the time, Dr. Barro said that the counteroffer, presented to him personally by Harvard's president, Neil L. Rudinstine, was, if not too little, then too late. "If he had offered me in November what he did in February, I probably would have stayed," he said.
Still, Dr. Barro's last-minute change of heart was not a result of Harvard's making an 11th-hour effort to win him back. The terms of his deal to remain at Harvard are expected to be the same as they were in February.
At the same time, despite the storm of criticism of Professor Barro's deal from Columbia professors in departments other than economics, there is no sign that that Columbia had in any way begun to back away from the commitments it was making to lure Professor Barro.
Officials at Columbia University did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
But Professor Barro's decision to jilt the school is clearly a major embarrassment.
Professor Barro's rich deal with Columbia have been the subject of gossip within the economics profession since it was struck in mid-February and details were disclosed in The New York Times last week.
Columbia's administration has been besieged by complaints and inquiries from people in other departments who reacted not just to the record-breaking salary but also to the news that the economics department, as part of the deal, was getting five permanent tenured positions and one visiting professor at a time when salaries and positions were frozen in other departments.
Yesterday, the senior faculty members in the Harvard economics department were forwarded the following E-mail from Dean Knowles to the department chairman, Jeffrey G. Williamson:
"I am happy to let you know that Robert Barro has decided to remain at Harvard ("absolutely and unequivocally") on the terms that he and I had discussed in February. I have reported Robert's change of heart to the President. Please share this surprising and happy news with each of your colleagues."
Dean Knowles expressed sympathy for his counterparts at Columbia, saying, "I'm very glad, of course, that Professor Barro has decided to stay, even though I'm sorry that the departments at two institutions should have been on such a seesaw."

HEADLINE: Will Mayor Exit? Washington Wonders

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
For the last 20 years Washington has been consumed with the political fortunes of its artful Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr.
But rarely has speculation over his viability in office grown as intense as it has this spring. 
 Mr. Barry, 62, who has served four terms since 1974, has not said whether he intends to seek a fifth four-year term this year, a delay that is fueling speculation that he will not challenge the four other Democrats who have entered the September primary.
The surest sign that Mr. Barry is seriously considering other options is his increasing willingness to acknowledge a life after governing, something he never did publicly before this year.
"A number of people are looking for opportunities for me," Mr. Barry said last week in his weekly news conference, discussing one of them, a college teaching job. "I've got two or three solid offers in six figures."
To the ears of many local residents and political analysts who have long followed Mr. Barry's career, that sounded like a retirement speech.
"He has never toyed with the public like this," said Mark Plotkin, a local political analyst. "I think he has decided that there is nothing left to prove. He came back, rising like the phoenix, in one of the greatest political comebacks of all time, and he could go out on a high -- although that's an unfortunate choice of words."
The reference is to the one interruption in Mr. Barry's colorful career as Mayor of the District of Columbia: a drug conviction and six-month prison term. The incident forever tarnished his image, and many residents, business leaders and Federal lawmakers now view him as the biggest obstacle to the return of power to locally elected officials and continuing economic growth.
Since its creation three years ago, a control board has in effect managed all aspects of city government, answering only to Congress. The Mayor has been left with nominal authority over city agencies, most of which are now run by a chief manager appointed by the control board.
The shift in power was a critical factor in turning chronic deficits into a $348 million surplus this year and a projected surplus of $196 million for next year. The control board is to shut down after the city has balanced its budget for four consecutive years.
Beyond the budget, other signs are just as encouraging for the future of Washington. Crime rates are falling. Housing sales are picking up.
But whether the trends continue once the control board shuts down could depend as much on a mayor's image and relationship with Congress as on policies. And some Federal lawmakers contend that someone other than Mr. Barry would give the city new advantages with Congress, including a long honeymoon.
"It could make all the difference in the world," said Representative Thomas M. Davis 3d, the Virginia Republican whose subcommittee on the District created the control board. "There is no question that a new mayor with a different agenda could achieve positive results in dealing with Capitol Hill. I think you would see a restoration of democratic rights to the city sooner and the likelihood of more money invested in the city."
"Ultimately," Mr. Davis added, "the control board is just a substitute for a bad mayor. It's a very ineffective way to do things."
John Tydings, president of the Washington Board of Trade, said many of the region's business leaders also predicted better times for the city under a new mayor.
"It goes back to the economic development aspect of the job," Mr. Tydings said. "A new mayor would improve the image of the city as the national capital and strengthen relations with Congress."
For his part, Mr. Barry remains unfazed by criticism and images of a city without him leading it. He contended last week that if he chose to run, he would have enough financial support and voters to prevail in a crowded primary.
"The winning part is not a factor," Mr. Barry said. "I know I could win."
As the Democratic nominee, he would probably face Carol Schwartz, a Republican member of the City Council whom he defeated in 1994.
And for those who say he would not run, "that's their problem, not mine," Mr. Barry said in a brief interview today. "I have plenty of time to decide." Rather, he said, his deliberations center on how best he might serve the city in the future. But that, too, is something he has never said openly before.
"He reminds me of longtime House Democrats who were committee chairmen and all of a sudden Republicans are in charge," Mr. Plotkin said.
"They don't find it fun anymore," he said. "I don't think the Mayor is having fun anymore, and I don't think he's going to run."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. at work yesterday in his mobile city hall in northwest Washington. Mr. Barry was not saying whether he would seek a fifth term this fall, but Washington has seized on hints that he may not. (stin Lane for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Indonesian Currency Gains Against Dollar

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
The Indonesian rupiah climbed to its highest level against the United States dollar in two months during Asian trading yesterday as the market cautiously welcomed Indonesia's latest pact with the International Monetary Fund. The dollar was sold at 7,550 rupiah, its lowest level since Feb. 13. 
 The strengthening of the rupiah followed the publication last Friday of Indonesia's new 117-point I.M.F. program. After three weeks of negotiations, the two sides agreed to a plan to restructure Indonesia's private debt and a tough requirement to consolidate the nation's crippled banking sector. Given progress on carrying it out, the way is now clear for the I.M.F. to release to Indonesia its next portion of assistance funds.
