HEADLINE: In the Rockies, Culture Knows How to Survive;
Intellectual Life on a Small Scale Gets More Attention Than Money

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: BOZEMAN, Mont.

 BODY:
One Saturday night at the Willson Auditorium on Main Street, a creaky 1,100-seat theater in a school that is the busiest entertainment venue in this growing Rocky Mountain town, the attraction was the Chord Rustlers, a local singing group that, with 44 members, represents Montana's largest chapter of S.P.E.B.S.Q.S.A.
The initials, of course, are those of the Society for the Preservation and Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America. And as the Chord Rustlers, ages 12 through 85, estimably harmonized their way through "Chattanooga Choo Choo" and "Wait Till the Sun Shines, Nellie," it seemed as if Bozeman itself was expressing its artistic heart: simple, consonant, old-fashioned. 
 But Bozeman's cultural life is not quite as wholesome and uncomplicated as all that. Indeed, in a state where the arts receive scant support from the government, where private philanthropic foundations hardly operate and where there is not a single Forbes 500 company to stand behind its local arts organizations, this city of about 35,000 residents (including the 10,000 or so students of Montana State University) is home to a vibrant arts community. It may be small but it is stubbornly prominent.
And perhaps most significant, artists here of every stripe speak of a regional voice, of art that is Bozemanesque, characterized by a reflection of Montana's vast landscape.
"When I came here I was writing in a more compressed manner," said Eric Funk, a composer who moved here from Portland, Ore., in 1986 and whose opera "Pamelia" had a concert performance at Carnegie Hall three years later. "Now my sonorities are more spread out. I'm writing over six and seven octaves.
"It's the land, I think. Two years ago I did a residency in Brandenburg, Germany, and the people there said to me: Your music, it's just so slow-moving. And I think that pace, too, comes from living here."
Unlikely as it sounds, in a place where ranching and outdoor tourism are the primary economic forces, Bozeman offers a good example of the survivalist mentality that one finds among artists in cities throughout the country, where, like desert flowers, the arts manage to bloom without the presumed-to-be-necessary life-sustaining elements of a national spotlight and available money.
"If you put all the arts organizations and activities together, you'd have the fifth largest employer in town," said John Barsness, the executive director of Montana Arts, a nonprofit group that provides administrative services to seven arts organizations in Bozeman.
"The arts are alive and well here, flourishing in spite of the politicians, and in spite of the fact that we live on the edge of the fund-raising universe. There are 50,000 private foundations in the country, half of them significant. Of those, fewer than 40 fund in Montana in any given year, and that covers social services and the environment, not just the arts."
Indeed, Bozeman is far better known as a gateway to the outdoors. The Big Sky ski area is nearby, and Yellowstone National Park is less than a two-hour drive away. And it is growing largely because it has been discovered by wealthy second-home buyers from California and elsewhere, people who tend, Mr. Barsness said, to support the arts where they've come from but not where they've just arrived. The most prominent example, he said, is Ted Turner, whose huge ranch is within an hour of the city. "He's been very generous about the environment. But I can't tell you anyone in the arts who's received a dime from him. So that's our challenge locally, to develop new audiences in a seasonal population that has its allegiances elsewhere."
Nonetheless, with much of the philanthropic support coming from local businesses, the ballet company, in its 14th season, runs a school with 150 students. The Intermountain Opera is set to stage "La Traviata" next month, its 20th anniversary production. The Bozeman Symphony, with 75 professional and amateur musicians (and an equivalent-size choir) plays a season of five concerts with nearly 800 subscribers. And all have survived in spite of having to perform at the Willson.
 
Acoustics Frustrate Strings and Soloists
"Acoustically it's pretty miserable," said Marilyn Traez, executive director of the symphony, which is in its 30th season. "The strings and soloists can't hear each other. Without a new hall, we're limited as to how much better we can get. But raising the funds for a performing arts center has never been done in Montana, and I don't know that we're all that close."
At the Museum of the Rockies, Bozeman boasts a world-class collection of dinosaur bones. The city is home to dozens of painters and sculptors (including Deborah Butterfield), musicians (including the baritone Pablo Elvira) and writers (including the novelist and naturalist David Quammen).
Two independent bookstores sit within a block of each other on Main Street. The Vigilante Theater, a nonprofit company now in its 17th season, produces only original work, typically on regional themes, and often tours the state. Its most recent production, "Wuf!," a musical about the controversial program of reintroducing wolves into Yellowstone Park, played six performances in Bozeman and is to be performed in Missoula, home of the University of Montana, and smaller towns.
Bozeman also provides an enthusiastic audience for pop music, fueled by KGLT-FM, one of the nation's few remaining free-form alternative music stations; Vootie Productions, a local presenter since 1991, put on 45 shows last year, including Phish and the Indigo Girls, for more than 3,000 people at the University Field House.
And in contrast to the practice in many more urban places, the schools continue to maintain substantial programs in art and music. "There's just a tremendous number of kids involved in music programs," said Mr. Funk, the composer, who supplements his income by conducting the Helena Symphony, two hours away, and by teaching piano.
"This is a great place to write," Mr. Funk continued. "The thing I miss is the collegial interaction, being among people who really understand how to read a score and can talk about it. But it's not a bad trade-off for the wide open spaces."
The trade-off is one that many artists in Bozeman acknowledge.
"It's not art about people here so much as it is about place," Steve Kelly, a painter, responded when asked if there was a vision that united local artists. "It's a landscape-based esthetic. I don't think you can make art here without having that as your focus."
Clarice Dreyer, a sculptor who operates a combination coffeehouse, flower shop and art gallery with Mr. Kelly, agreed. "The land is more important to me than having museums to go to," she said. "I used to go to New York to see shows a lot more. Now I'd just rather take a drive and look around."
Even nonvisual artists find the terrain inspirational.
"That's what sustains the arts activity -- the artist's relationship to nature," said Mary Overlie, a dancer and choreographer who grew up here and has just returned after living in New York and Europe for three decades. "My choreographic work is extremely spatial. A lot of slowness and silence. No throwing things at the audience but making them observe. That's very much Montana, which kind of turns everybody into a tourist."
But vast spaces and isolation have their drawbacks. Audiences, for example, are harder to gather. Conservatism is the rule. (A year ago a billboard by Mr. Kelly in downtown Helena criticizing the slaughter of buffalo who wander out of Yellowstone became a local political issue.) Ann Bates, artistic director of the Montana Ballet, laments that it is almost impossible to find male dancers.
"It's so hard for artists here because the population base is so small," Ms. Overlie said. "I don't know if I can say that the population around here is friendly to the arts."
 
Anonymous Donor Finances a Haven
And for artists there is limited opportunity for the kind of society that often fosters intellectual creativity. One solution was the Emerson Cultural Center, established in an old school building off Main Street, when a community group raised the money to buy it from the city in 1992. The cost was not quite $500,000, more than half of which was provided by an anonymous community donor. The center now sponsors educational programs, presents music and dance performances from visiting troupes and has a 700-seat theater, as well as work space for more than 40 artists, a couple of cafes -- including Mr. Kelly and Ms. Dreyer's -- and a handful of galleries.
One gallery houses the work of artists sponsored by Montana Indian Contemporary Arts, a nonprofit organization that promotes painting and other artwork on the state's seven Indian reservations and by members of its 10 tribes. The state itself is not exactly diverse -- few Indians live in Bozeman, which is overwhelmingly white -- and MICA, as the organization is known, has obstacles other than the normal ones faced by Montana artists.
 
'A Little Better Than Most Places'
"Living here is a challenge," said Susan Stewart Medicine Horse, the executive director of MICA. "It can be pretty racist, and we live with that. Bozeman's a little better than most places, but it's there."
The one-room gallery contains both traditional and abstract contemporary work by Indians from the Gros Ventre, Blackfoot, Oglala Lakota and Crow tribes, including paintings by Mrs. Medicine Horse. She and her husband, Tyler Medicine Horse, whose specialty is the re-creation of traditional Indian art objects with contemporary materials, plan to create a performance and installation piece in New York City on April 17, at 6 P.M. at the American Indian Community House Gallery, 404 Lafayette Street, near East Fourth Street in the East Village. They will also speak about their work at the National Museum of the American Indian.
That Bozeman accommodates a wide range of artistic expression is evident every Tuesday night, when, almost next door to the MICA gallery at the Emerson, the Chord Rustlers rehearse. It's an occasion resembling a lodge meeting, where men like Russ Ludeman, a charter member of the group, which was founded in 1975, come for camaraderie. Mr. Ludeman, 61, sings in two quartets, the Doodle Dandies and the Par Fours.
"The Par Fours are a bunch of old guys," he said. "Our cumulative age is 270. But we put on a good show and people like it." Of course, anyone doubting that the Chord Rustlers are hip in Bozeman need only speak to another member, Jake Bloxham, an 18-year-old movie projectionist who wears a bandanna on his head and three earrings in each ear. "I'll tell you one thing," he said. Since I started doing this I haven't had any trouble finding a date."

HEADLINE: Guggenheim Announces Record Gift, $50 Million

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum announced yesterday that it had received a cash pledge of $50 million from Peter B. Lewis, the chairman and chief executive of the Progressive Corporation, a Cleveland-based insurance company. It is one of the largest cash gifts made to any visual arts institution and the largest the Guggenheim, founded in 1937, has ever received.
"This is a huge amount of money," said Thomas Krens, the Guggenheim's director. "It sends a signal that the trustees are supporting this museum in an impressive way." 
 Mr. Lewis, who has been a Guggenheim trustee since 1993, had already committed $10 million of the $50 million he is giving to the museum two years ago when the Guggenheim began its $200 million capital campaign. He is to give the museum $10 million each year for the next four years.
Mr. Lewis's initial $10 million gift paid for the restoration of the theater under the museum's famous Fifth Avenue rotunda, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. Work was completed in 1996, and it has been named the Peter B. Lewis Theater. The rest of his initial gift helped establish an endowment for educational programs related to the use of the theater.
The $40 million that was pledged to the Guggenheim yesterday will be used solely for the Guggenheim's endowment, which will now be nearly $100 million, museum officials said.
"I think the Guggenheim is a fascinating and important dream," Mr. Lewis said in a telephone interview yesterday. "It's now a worldwide institution, and institutions of this kind should be fostered."
His generosity toward the Guggenheim has helped encourage other trustees to increase their giving too. Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of Revlon and president of the Guggenheim's board, had committed $20 million to the capital campaign and just increased his gift to $25 million. Since Mr. Lewis's gift, other trustees have followed, with a total of $8 million in new pledges. Mr. Krens said that the Guggenheim had pledges in hand totaling $144 million.
The latest promised gifts are going into the endowment. "Any great institution has to have a solid endowment," Mr. Krens said. "It gives you a level of security and makes you feel stronger all the way around." Mr. Lewis said he became involved with the Guggenheim in the early 1990's when he was working on the design of a house with Frank Gehry, the Los Angeles architect who designed the new Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain. It was Mr. Gehry who introduced Mr. Lewis to Mr. Krens. "Frank wanted me to meet Tom because he thought we were kindred spirits," he said. "And that's how it all started."
Mr. Krens's vision of creating an international network of Guggenheims initially drew more criticism than praise. Since arriving at the Guggenheim in 1988, he has been accused by some of treating the museum as if it were a global corporation, with little regard to exhibitions.
Back then there were only two Guggenheims, the famous Fifth Avenue building and the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice. Under Mr. Krens's direction, the museum opened a branch in the heart of SoHo in 1992. He is responsible for the $58 million renovation and expansion of the Fifth Avenue building and he masterminded the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao, which opened in the Basque region of Spain in October and has drawn crowds ever since. Attendance has already reached a half a million visitors, more than doubling the museum's expectations. In November the Guggenheim also opened a 7,000-square-foot exhibition space in Berlin on the ground floor of the newly renovated Deutsche Bank on the Unter den Linden, near the Brandenburg Gate.
With these new museums has come new art for the Guggenheim's permanent collections. The Guggenheim Bilbao recently acquired Robert Rauschenberg's "Barge," from 1962-1963, which it bought in a 50-50 partnership of the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao and the Guggenheim Foundation in New York. Meanwhile, Deutsche Guggenheim Berlin has shown its first site-specific work, James Rosenquist's "Swimmer in the Econo-mist," a room-size mural that will be owned by the Guggenheim Foundation and Deutsche Guggenheim Berlin.
"It's one thing to say you're going to do something; it's another thing to do it," Mr. Krens said. "This gift should remove any doubt people had about the Guggenheim."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Securities Rise Slightly As Inflation Remains in Control

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday, after another report showed that inflation remained in check.
The gains were constrained, however, by the lingering concerns prompted by recent remarks from a Federal Reserve official who suggested that the Asian economic turmoil, which had been expected to help keep inflation under control by slowing growth, might have less effect on the United States than originally expected. 
 The 30-year bond rose 11/32, to a price of 103 5/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.90 percent, from 5.92 percent on Monday.
Bonds were lifted by the Labor Department's report that the Consumer Price Index was unchanged in March and that even the so-called core rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, was up only one-tenth of 1 percent.
Donald Fine, the chief market analyst for Chase Asset Management, noted that even on a year-to-year basis, the overall index was up only 1.4 percent, with the core rate up only 2.1 percent.
Investors in the bond market are encouraged by signs of lower prices because inflation erodes the value of their holdings.
The data point to growth with low inflation, a scenario that suggests that the Fed may continue to be able to keep interest rates at current levels.
Still, the market continued to have jitters from comments last week by Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor, who said that the economy's "performance is exceptional but unsustainable," suggesting that any slowdown generated by Asia's financial crisis may have arrived too late to ward off an increase in interest rates by the Fed.

HEADLINE: More Merger Mania

 BODY:
BankAmerica of California proposed this week to merge with Nationsbank of North Carolina to form the country's largest bank chain, spanning the continent and serving almost half the states. Banc One of Ohio proposed to join with First Chicago. These colossal marriages, which follow last week's proposed union of Citicorp and Travelers, raise two questions. Are small banks doomed and, if so, need anyone care?
One potential problem bears watching -- whether the mergers will threaten service to low-income neighborhoods. The outcome is within the control of regulators. The Community Reinvestment Act requires banks to serve poor neighborhoods. To the extent that mergers make banks profitable, mergers also make it easier for banks to meet their C.R.A. obligations. 
 Otherwise, there seems little reason to worry. The three mergers pose no threat to most consumers because none would dominate any financial product or region. Even BankAmerica-Nationsbank will control about 8 percent of bank deposits, not nearly enough to dictate interest rates.
The economics of installing computerized information and other administrative systems mean that big banks will outclass small banks in important ways. But community banks say they charge lower fees for many services and still turn a profit. If so, they have nothing to fear. Customers will search out low-cost providers. If it turns out that the boast is idle, or that bank customers crave the no-fee national A.T.M.'s and other services that large banks can provide, then small banks will disappear.
What the mergers do suggest is that the C.E.O.'s of major chains are itching to test whether bigger is still better. After Congress legalized interstate banking, regional banks gobbled up statewide chains. Then regional banks expanded further into superregional giants like Nationsbank. The next logical step is to create a national customer base over which to spread huge administrative costs. If profitable, then a half dozen or so national bank chains will before long fight for business across the country.
It is possible that merger mania in banking may turn out to be as evanescent as the merger mania that hit industrial America in the 1980's. Customers should now sit back and watch the games unfold, confident that they have nothing to fear from huge banks as long as there are other huge banks lurking in the same neighborhood.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Tough Workfare Rules Used As Way to Cut Welfare Rolls

SERIES: DOES WORKFARE WORK?: Last of four articles.

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
By restoring the luster of the work ethic and providing a path to real jobs, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani often says, his workfare program has played the central part in the dramatic reduction of New York City's welfare rolls. The numbers he cites are stark and indisputable: the rolls have dropped more than 30 percent in the last three years, to 797,000 from 1.16 million.
But an examination of workfare shows that the program's role in that decline often has little to do with offering a route into the job market. In many ways, workfare has become welfare's back door, allowing the city to trim thousands of people from the rolls each month for violating its work rules. 
 In the first eight months of 1997, about 16 percent of workfare participants -- or an average of 6,100 out of 36,000 people each month -- were cut from the rolls for infractions that ranged from showing up late to refusing a work assignment.
Precisely how much of the overall drop in the rolls can be attributed to such sanctions is not known. The city does not track the fluid movement of individuals through the system -- on and off the rolls and often back on again, sometimes more than once in the space of a single year.
Even so, welfare experts in and out of the administration agree that the sanctions have had a significant downsizing effect. Underlying the numbers, though, is a fierce debate over interpretation:
To the Mayor and his aides, sanctions are used sensibly and appropriately. Even so, the process is meant to be tough: a big stick is needed, they say, to teach the discipline of work, of getting up in the morning, every morning, and showing up at a job on time.
But advocates for the poor argue that the city has overzealously enforced often technical rules without sufficient regard to the lives and dignity of the truly needy -- but with considerable attention to the political benefits of trimmer welfare rolls. The sanctions process, they say, has created a sizeable churning of the rolls, in which thousands of people are dropped each month, only to return later.
The advocates point out that when recipients get state hearings on their sanctions, they win two-thirds of the time. This means that while most remain off the rolls, about a quarter of the nearly 6,100 sanctioned each month -- about 1,400 -- were reinstated after filing appeals. And many more reapplied at the end of their punishment periods -- generally three months but as many as six -- though the number who actually returned to the rolls is not known.
The aggressive use of sanctions is hardly limited to New York's workfare program, which Mr. Giuliani vastly expanded three years ago. Whether they use workfare or, more commonly, programs that stress job training and placement in private industry, welfare officials across the country have stepped up their use of sanctions as pressure to move people off the rolls has increased.
"In general," said Demetra Smith Nightingale, director of welfare research at the Urban Institute in Washington, "caseworkers are using sanctions more than they used to because time limits mean that there's now more at stake if they don't get people into the job market."
Of course, the reasons for the drop in New York's welfare rolls go beyond sanctions.
Some who leave welfare do get real jobs, but available evidence indicates that they make up a small fraction. A recent state survey found that fewer than a third make more than $100 on the books in the first three months after leaving the rolls. The survey did not distinguish between full- and part-time jobs, nor did it take into account people who were working off the books, were self-employed or moved away.
At the same time, workfare -- or, more precisely, the prospect of having to participate in workfare -- has driven many people off welfare without finding jobs. To these people, it is more appealing to rely on off-the-books jobs, to move in with friends or relatives or to otherwise turn to others to get by, say city officials and advocates for the poor.
Not only has welfare become easier to lose, it has become harder to get. Since the city adopted a tough new screening process, the rejection rate for those applying for aid has doubled, to 54 percent in 1997 from 27 percent in 1994.
The Mayor says the new screening procedures have helped weed out thousands of welfare cheats who would give false addresses or hide other sources of income. But some advocates say that, for many people, the new admissions rules and the sanctions have turned public assistance from a full-time program into a part-time one -- with part of the year spent on the rolls and part spent trying to get on or waiting out a penalty.
"It's like musical chairs, where there are 9 chairs but 12 people," said Liz Krueger, associate director of the nonprofit Community Food Resource Center. "The real number of people needing welfare is still 12, but the caseload is only 9."
 
The Sanctions
Penalties Increase As Workfare Grows
Enrique Segarra Sr. was told he would lose his benefits about a year ago because he was half an hour late on the first day of his workfare assignment. He said he thought he had allowed enough time for his three-fare trip -- from bus to subway to another bus.
But when he arrived at the Bronx Sanitation Department garage at 7:30 A.M., the supervisor wouldn't listen to his explanations and sent him home with instructions not to return. Two weeks later, he was notified that the process to cut off his welfare benefits had begun because he had violated workfare rules by arriving late without a written excuse.
At a state appeals hearing, Mr. Segarra produced bus schedules proving he could not have gotten to the garage any earlier, and the city withdrew its plan to cut him off.
City officials argue that the penalties are a tool for teaching the importance of work and for rooting out those who are unwilling to work for their benefits.
"We have a basic social contract that says that for people who are going to seek benefits, the government has the right to ask for something in return," said Anthony P. Coles, a senior adviser to the Mayor. "So if someone is not willing to participate, then the government's obligation to provide benefits is released as well."
That philosophy led the city to expand the use of sanctions as it expanded workfare in early 1995. City statistics for years prior to 1996 were not available, but since the vast majority of New York State residents on workfare live in New York City, a rough calculation can be done with statewide figures. Those figures, from the State Department of Social Services, show that the number of workfare sanctions doubled in the first fiscal year of the expansion, 1995, to 28,119, from 14,856 the previous fiscal year.
In the calendar year 1996, for which city figures are available, there were 82,538 sanctions issued in New York City alone. The number appears to have decreased slightly in 1997: in the first eight months of the year, 49,568 sanctions were issued; extrapolated for the whole year, that would work out to about 75,000.
To advocates for the poor, the number of participants who get their benefits restored on appeal suggests that the sanctions are often issued unfairly.
Even as the overall number of sanctions dropped in 1997, the number of appeals filed in the entire year went up 17 percent, to 45,239 from 38,431, according to the state. And of the 24,845 appeals in which a hearing was held in the entire year, more than two-thirds -- 16,673 -- went against the city, roughly the same percentage as the year before. (The rest of the cases never got to a hearing; some people simply disappear from the system, while others opt to wait out the penalty period.)
For single adults, sanctions range from three to six months without any benefits. After the penalty period, they must undergo the newly rigorous application process. But mothers are treated differently: They lose only their share of the welfare check, while their children's benefits continue. And they are given a chance to get a first-time sanction lifted by complying with the work requirement; subsequent sanctions result in an automatic three to six months without benefits.
The opportunity to cancel a first-time sanction by complying was intended to be more lenient than a fixed penalty. But the policy has actually left more than 20,000 welfare mothers in what city officials call "sanction limbo." For while single adults can reapply after a penalty period, mothers must comply or face an open-ended penalty.
To advocates for the poor, this imposes an unequal burden on the mothers who have good reasons for avoiding workfare. To the Giuliani administration, though, many of these mothers are taking unfair advantage of the system, since they continue to receive benefits for their children. That's why the Mayor is pushing Gov. George E. Pataki to toughen the penalties by cutting off the children's checks as well.
The reasons for punishment vary, but city officials and welfare advocates agree that most sanctions are meted out to workers who never show up, show up late or call in sick without providing documentation. Some workfare participants have been cut off because their school schedules, or their children's, have interfered with workfare assignments or because they say they misunderstood the city's procedures or notices.
Workfare handbooks and assignment sheets plainly state that workers can lose their benefits if they do not call a supervisor before their reporting time if they will be late or absent. Workers are told that acceptable excuses for absences include holidays, illnesses, a family emergency, jury duty and employment interviews. They are also told not to bother to return to work without a written excuse.
The city contends that these work rules are fair, and that it enforces them evenhandedly.
"If people have a good reason to be excused, they are excused," Mr. Coles said. "And if there are instances of sanctions that are inappropriate, we try to correct it right away."
But welfare recipients and advocates for the poor say that some people lose their benefits because supervisors enforce work rules so rigidly that they would be unusual in the private sector or elsewhere in the public sector.
Ian F. Feldman, a Legal Aid Society lawyer in the Bronx who has represented scores of workfare participants, said medical documentation was a common problem because welfare recipients seldom have regular doctors.
"If you were sick and you didn't go to the doctor that same day and get a note, you're finished," he said. "But not even a person with the best health care goes to the doctor for everything little thing."
At the same time, the advocates say, others are cut off because the system cannot deal with the complicated realities of their lives.
Kathleen Parks, for example, lost her benefits when she stopped showing up at her workfare assignment as a clerk for the Parks Department in March 1996 because, she contended, an ex-boyfriend was stalking her at work.
Ms. Parks, who is 43, said in an interview that co-workers had tried to protect her from the ex-boyfriend, who screamed obscenities and hurled bottles at her when she left work. But with time sheets showing her absences, the city quickly closed her case.
She lost her first appeal because she had nothing but her word in her defense. At a second hearing, she was represented by a lawyer, who got her an order of protection and presented it to the judge along with her conscientious work record. Nine months after Ms. Parks was dropped from the rolls, the judge reinstated her, with back benefits, writing that the documents proved "her refusal to participate was not willful or without good cause."
She has not been reassigned to workfare since she was reinstated.
 
The Alternatives
Avoiding the Stigma By Leaving the Rolls
Workfare has also had a less direct effect on the size of the welfare rolls: It has contributed to what welfare experts call a "smoke-out effect," pushing people off welfare whether they have jobs or not.
In some cases, welfare recipients who were already working off the books have decided to leave the rolls, experts say. There are no reliable estimates of how many people fall into that category, but welfare experts say that because it is virtually impossible to survive on welfare benefits alone, a significant number of welfare recipients probably rely on other sources of income.
Many others have either gone out and found work or have turned to friends and relatives for help rather than deal with the stigma of welfare or a city bureaucracy that they believe to be hostile.
For instance, Alexa Perez, a sophomore at Hunter College and mother of two little boys, decided she would go without her share of her family's benefits when the city told her she had no choice but to report to a maintenance job at a housing project on the Lower East Side. She decided that a workfare assignment that lasted from 9:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. five days a week would interfere with her school and child care schedules too much to be worth the $80 a month she would lose.
Since then, she has started working 30 hours a week at a clothing store near school, where she makes $200 a week.
"My grades have suffered a little, but you have to do what you have to do," she said, adding that she would not consider reapplying for welfare.
Not only has the Giuliani administration's welfare message pushed large numbers of people off the rolls, some experts say; the strong economy has allowed some of those who have left welfare to either find work or rely on acquaintances who have benefited from the good times.
But Irv Garfinkel, a professor at Columbia University's School of Social Work, said the economy had probably been less of a factor in New York than elsewhere in the country because the city's 9.2 percent unemployment rate is still relatively high.
The Giuliani administration has not cooperated with Dr. Garfinkel's request to study what happens to people when they leave welfare. (City officials have also refused to provide information on former welfare recipients to The New York Times. The Times sued, and last week, a State Supreme Court justice ordered the city to release the information; the city is expected to appeal.)
Dr. Garfinkel, though, has a theory that falls somewhere in between the Mayor's and the advocates' versions of reality.
"My guess is that about one third of the people already had jobs and are managing fine without welfare," he said. "Another third are getting jobs, which is the Mayor's story, and the other third can't get it together and the changes have made it impossible to function in the system, and that's the advocates' story."
 
Does Workfare Work?

HEADLINE: Consumer Price Index Flat in March

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Consumer prices were unchanged last month while the value of retail sales fell unexpectedly, the Government reported today.
Consumer prices have been flat in two of the last three months. The tame inflation rate affected the sales data because "businesses can't raise prices -- and in some cases they're cutting them," Mark Vitner, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., said. That cut into the value of retail sales even though the volume of goods being sold is rising about 3 percent monthly, he said. 
 Price growth was held in check during March by the fourth consecutive monthly drop in energy prices, the Labor Department said. The core inflation rate, which excludes often-volatile food and energy costs, rose one-tenth of 1 percent in March.
In February, prices had increased one-tenth of 1 percent over all and three-tenths of 1 percent after food and energy costs were removed.
As for the retail report, the Commerce Department said that sales fell one-tenth of 1 percent in March. At the same time, though, it revised February's sales increase to seven-tenths of 1 percent, up from the gain of half a percent reported initially.
Low unemployment and rising incomes suggest people have money to spend, so March's sales decline might have been nothing more than a "natural pause" for the economy, said Gary Thayer, an economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
The biggest news in the consumer price report was a 1.2 percent drop in energy prices, which account for about 10 percent of the price index over all. Energy costs may begin rising, however. Gasoline and other energy prices have been increasing so far in April.
Food prices were unchanged last month and tobacco prices declined 2.6 percent following a rise of 2.9 percent in February. Transportation service costs fell six-tenths of 1 percent, housing costs rose two-tenths of 1 percent, recreation costs grew four-tenths of 1 percent and the cost of medical care rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
Prices for personal computers and supplies fell 2.8 percent in March.
In its retail report, the Commerce Department said sales of big-ticket goods, including autos, appliances and furniture, fell four-tenths of 1 percent during March.
When auto sales were excluded, March's sales increased one-tenth of 1 percent. Sales of cars and light trucks fell 2.8 percent in March from a year earlier, as bigger discounts from auto makers did little to bring consumers into showrooms.
An unusually late Easter may have also caused some consumers to postpone holiday purchases until April, said William Sullivan, an economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Home-Grown Giant Of Central America

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR

 BODY:
Inside, the main terminal at Comalapa Airport here is crowded with business people, tourists and visiting Salvadoran-Americans scrambling to make their flights. Out on the tarmac, TACA airline workers are busy painting new planes with the company's new logo: five golden macaws flying in unison.
These are boom times for commercial aviation throughout Latin America, and TACA is one of the main beneficiaries. Already the dominant force in a Central American market that is growing 8 percent a year, El Salvador's energetic flag carrier is expanding into the Caribbean, seeking Washington's approval of a code-sharing agreement with American Airlines and increasing its presence on lucrative routes to and from the United States, where capacity has been struggling to keep up with demand. 
In 1997, in fact, air traffic between North America and the rest of the hemisphere surpassed that on routes to Europe for the second consecutive year. Airline executives think that explosive growth will continue for several years: since President Clinton signed a regional open skies agreement in Costa Rica last May, the number of seats on flights between the United States and Central America has increased 40 percent.
With the end of the wars that racked the region in the 1980's, tourism is resuming and the large numbers of Central American immigrants in the United States are able to visit their homelands safely. In response to that growing demand, Delta Air Lines this month started daily nonstop service from Atlanta to four Central American capitals and United has begun a daily nonstop flight from Chicago to Guatemala City.
For TACA -- shorthand for Transportes Aereos Centro Americanos -- that means more head-to-head competition with some of the giants of the industry on what could be less than favorable terms. As a relatively small carrier, the company benefits from neither the economies of scale nor the name recognition of United States rivals.
Until now, "we've been fortunate to be in the right place at the right time," Roberto Kriete, TACA's board chairman, said in an interview at company headquarters here. "Continental, Delta and United are all aiming their heavy guns at Central America, but I think we have a formula and a strategy that can make things work and enable us to survive in what promises to be a time of tremendously intensified competition."
Less than two decades ago, amid wars in much of Central America, TACA International Airlines was a tiny carrier, with revenue of $18 million and initials that were said to stand for "take a chance airlines" because of its irregular schedule and suspect equipment. Today, the privately held company generates $600 million a year in revenue and has earned a reputation as an efficient and scrappy carrier.
"You've got to give these guys credit," Robert C. Booth, director of Aviation Management Services, a Miami-based consultant, said. "They're not from the old school -- air force generals trying to run an airline. They're very bright businessmen who know what they are doing and were quick to jump on the privatization bandwagon when Central American governments moved that way."
Founded in 1931 by a pilot from New Zealand, TACA has over the last decade bought controlling stakes in competing airlines in Costa Rica, Guatemala and Nicaragua and opened a subsidiary in Honduras. They are, respectively, Lacsa, Aviateca, Nica and TACA de Honduras.
The resulting five-carrier alliance has permitted Grupo TACA to centralize management, maintenance, purchasing, reservations, insurance and accounting, and to provide a common logo and uniforms. The group, which has nearly 5,000 employees, flies to more than 40 cities in 19 countries from Canada to Chile.
On April 20, the airline will take another step forward when it begins daily nonstop service from New York City and Washington to San Salvador. TACA's larger United States competitors, however, predict that their upstart rival will find it harder to maintain a foothold in the American market.
"They're a nice little regional carrier, run by very good people," said Greg Brenneman, president of Continental Airlines, which plans to begin daily nonstop service from Newark to San Jose, Costa Rica, this summer. "But they're small, and their product quality is largely not the same" as that of the big United States carriers.
Ben Baldanza, TACA's managing director, said, though, that the airline sees itself as "the real Latin American carrier," offering "the sort of warmth, sensitivity and hospitality" that the growing number of Latin Americans traveling to and from the United States often complain is lacking in their big northern rivals. "We understand the culture because we are the culture, not because we have gone to training classes," Mr. Baldanza added.
TACA has been adept at finding and exploiting new niches in which to operate. Late last month, for instance, the company's new joint venture, Inter-Cuba S.A., began operations, flying routes among six Cuban cities and offering domestic passengers an alternative to the state-run Cubana Airlines.
TACA officials are also planning to expand flights elsewhere in the Caribbean, with service on the lucrative New York-Santo Domingo route, in which American Airlines faces no competition from a Dominican carrier. It is to begin as soon as a Dominican subsidiary can be organized. TACA already flies to Santo Domingo from Havana and Caracas and, since the fall, to Havana from Toronto.
In anticipation of increased service, TACA and two South American partners signed a multibillion-dollar purchase agreement with Airbus Industrie last month. Joining forces with Lan Chile and TAM, a Brazilian airline, TACA ordered 88 A320's and put in an option for 87 more, at what Mr. Booth describes as "a substantial discount off the sticker price."
But the outcome of another crucial element in TACA's plans, the proposed code-sharing deal with American, is not so clear. Other carriers have objected to the arrangement, arguing that it would give TACA and American a combined market share of 65 to 80 percent to every Central American destination. After more than a year, the United States Transportation Department has yet to approve the tie-in.
"It's like Coke and Pepsi coming together, and all of a sudden it costs two bucks to take a drink," Mr. Brenneman of Continental said. "We definitely believe it's anticompetitive and in the end hurts the customer, and we are stringently opposing it."
TACA officials argue that the delay sends a discouraging message to other Latin American countries that are trying to negotiate open skies agreements with the United States. As they see it, established carriers like American, Continental and United already have broad access to the Latin American market, and their Latin American competitors merely want reciprocity.
"I view it as a mistake for the United States to have made TACA a guinea pig," Mr. Kriete said. "In order for us to compete in a global market, we need strategic alliances. All the other Latin American carriers are looking at our experience and saying 'be careful.' "
Additional open skies agreements are important not only to TACA but also to relative newcomers like Delta, which has acquired a 35 percent stake in Aeroperu to bolster its advance into Latin America. "Open skies marks a turning point for us because it allows us to fly to cities where we can see that the profit margins are very good at a time of phenomenal growth," said Rudi Forster, general manager of Delta's Latin America division.
On its home turf, TACA has also faced recent criticism. Legislators and travel agents hoping to stimulate tourism complain that TACA, the largest private employer in Central America, is able to keep fares at an artificially high level and benefits from a cozy relationship with the Salvadoran Government.
Last month, for instance, Copa, the Panamanian airline, complained when Salvadoran officials withdrew permission for it to add a second daily flight here. The reason given was that increased competition "puts in danger the millions that TACA is investing in El Salvador," according to Government documents supplied to reporters.
"It's hard to see where TACA ends and the Government begins," a diplomat here said. "There are very close ties between the two."
TACA executives dismiss such complaints as jealous carping that "goes with the territory," as Mr. Baldanza puts it. More important, Mr. Kriete argues, is TACA's commitment to the region in good times and bad, its ability to thrive despite the fact "there is no equity market in Central America," in contrast to recent arrivals who could just as easily withdraw if a downturn comes.
"We can't go anywhere else," Mr. Kriete said. "We're here to stay. Our future depends on it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Airlines serve families as well as business. Passengers await flight departure at Miami International Airport, a big U.S. hub for TACA. (Susan Greenwood for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Old Tax Dodge;
While the Affluent May Lead the Way, Others Eagerly Follow

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
You cheated a little on your taxes, right? Join the club.
As millions of Americans prepare to drop their tax returns in the mail tonight -- 11th-hour filers make up perhaps a fifth of the nation's 174 million taxpayers -- there are mounting questions about just how much fibbing is going on. 
 While there are no official data, a number of economists and tax preparers say that tax cheating is on the rise. And, significantly, the Government trusts ordinary wage earners far less than it does wealthier people who earn significant income from selling investments at a profit.
Since 1994, in fact, affluent taxpayers have had powerful incentives to cheat on capital gains taxes, but Congress has begun no research or enforcement initiatives to make sure those taxes were properly paid.
Not that it stops there.
The tax on capital gains, experts say, is just one of many that are widely ignored, underreported or evaded, often with increasing frequency. These are among the others:
*Taxes on self-employment work, especially jobs usually paid in cash, like house painting and gardening, and income from flea markets and other cash businesses. The I.R.S. estimates that only about one dollar in five is reported.
*Taxes on mail-order goods from out of state, an obligation so widely ignored that tax returns show that one taxpayer in 100 pays in Connecticut and only one in 500 in New Jersey.
*Income taxes on gambling winnings and tips.
*Gift taxes on transfers of more than $10,000 annually to a relative or friend.
*Estate taxes on people who die leaving more than $625,000 for individuals and $1.25 million for couples, the amounts not subject to tax.
*State and local taxes on investment property like stocks and bonds.
*The "nanny tax," owed on wages paid to child-care providers, house cleaners and other in-home workers. This was paid by 314,000 or so households in 1996, down from nearly 500,000 in 1994, when paying it was much more complicated.
"The primary reason some taxes are not paid is that your chances of getting caught are so low," said Daniel Mitchell, a tax policy expert at the Heritage Foundation in Washington.
Anne M. Magro of Rutgers University, who teaches tax and has studied the behavior of accountants, said: "Minor cheating on tax returns is a lot like speeding -- most people do it, but very few have a crisis of conscience when they do. The penalties are low, the law seems excessively restrictive, the chance of getting caught is small, so what's the harm?"
The harm, of course, is that other people's taxes must be higher to support the Government. Many taxes get little enforcement attention, and Congress has been steadily whittling away at the I.R.S. budget to enforce tax laws. Only about 1,000 people a year are indicted for tax crimes.
The maximum tax rate on long-term capital gains is now 20 percent, essentially half the top rate on earned incomes. And that difference, combined with a disclosure system that reports only one side of asset sales or requires no reporting, makes it irresistible for many people to understate gains or to claim that earned income is a gain subject to the lower rates.
This problem vexed the tax system in the three decades after World War II, spawning a whole industry of tax lawyers and accountants who, because of the wide gap in tax rates, specialized in devising ways to convert earned income into capital gains. That industry was seriously undercut in 1986 when the top rate on both incomes and capital gains was cut to 28 percent.
But starting in 1991 and then in a further move in 1993 the Democratic-controlled Congress raised the top income tax rate, ultimately to 39.6 percent on earned income -- still a far cry from the 91 percent rate under the Eisenhower Administration. Last year, with Republicans in charge, lawmakers reduced the top long-term capital gains rate to 20 percent.
Capital gains, income that overwhelmingly flows to the most affluent Americans, are subject to far less reporting than wages and generally are not subject to withholding. For example, when an individual sells stock, the brokerage firm reports to the I.R.S. the gross proceeds, not the stock's cost, leaving that to the taxpayer.
And when an item that has risen in value -- like a small business or an artwork -- is sold privately, there is seldom a report filed with the I.R.S.
"I suspect there is a lot of not reporting of capital gains transactions," said William Gale, who studies taxes for the Brookings Institution, a nonprofit research organization in Washington.
Several tax preparers said they saw little risk in overstating a stock's cost, even in a sale in which the gross proceeds are reported to the I.R.S., because fewer than 1 percent of returns are audited.
"If you calculated your basis as $100 a share and it was really $50," said one tax preparer in Manhattan, who insisted on anonymity, "it would be wrong, it would be a crime, but even if you got caught you would never be prosecuted if the rest of your return was clean because you could argue it was just a mistake, that you forgot about the stock split."
The I.R.S. has no data on how many people have been charged with capital gains tax evasion, said Larry Blevins, an agency spokesman.
Alan Auerbach, a University of California economist who studies taxes, said the rhetoric from Capitol Hill about the I.R.S. gives comfort to those who cheat.
"These attacks on the I.R.S. are just a disaster," he said. "I can't think of anything more irresponsible than going after the I.R.S. in a world in which we depend on self-assessment and the perception that others are paying their taxes fairly."
The I.R.S., at the direction of Congress, has since 1995 zeroed in on low-income taxpayers who understate their income to qualify for the earned income tax credit, a form of negative tax, and on people who file no returns.
Still, some experts warned that the risks of cheating were greater than many people believed.
"You have to assume," said Julian Block, a former I.R.S. criminal investigator and now a tax lawyer in Larchmont, N.Y., that "the agent assigned to the audit of your return will be the equivalent of Eliot Ness and not Li'l Abner."
Sometimes tax professionals cheat and the I.R.S. does not notice. Charles Davenport, a Rutgers University professor of tax law and an editor of Tax Notes, a weekly magazine on tax policy, said he was once astonished to find himself working with lawyers who refused to report an estate of more than $1 million -- far above the tax threshold.
He said the lawyers thought his insistence on reporting the estate was bizarre, one of them telling him it was common practice not to in the city where the law firm was situated. Mr. Davenport resigned from the case.
Vicki Abt, a Pennsylvania State University sociologist who has studied gamblers for two decades, said she had yet to meet one who reported winnings. The only winnings the I.R.S. learns about, she said, are those of people who win big jackpots or walk away from the blackjack, craps or baccarat tables with more than the $1,200 of slot-machine winnings on which Federal reporting is required. Table games are exempt.
Verenda Smith, spokeswoman for the Federation of Tax Administrators, is one of many tax policy experts who worry that the debate is disheartening to honest taxpayers.
"I get increasingly irritated," she said, "with debates that leave me feeling like I have been called an idiot for caring how my government is funded and wanting to participate in my government."
Tax experts say the kind of two-sided reporting that is done on wages and salaries, together with a perception of tough enforcement, is critical to compliance.
Mr. Gale said "the three most important things to avoid evasion are withholding, withholding and withholding, because where there is withholding, compliance is very good."
Such reporting makes it difficult to cheat and explains why Tom Burger, chief of employment taxes for the I.R.S., estimates that it collects 99.5 percent of taxes due on wages with payroll withholding.
The I.R.S., though, guesses that it lost close to $12 billion in 1992 from unreported capital gains, or 8 percent of the total.
The I.R.S. generally favors more reporting but has had a hard time persuading Congress to expand such requirements, because they involve more paperwork for business and individuals.
The agency likes to tell what happened when Congress first required a Social Security number for each child: the number of children claimed as deductions fell by seven million. And in the years since, the numbers have not bounced back, indicating that many people were claiming children they did not have and that some divorced couples had counted the same children twice.
Outside the Federal system, the most widely ignored tax is undoubtedly the levy on mail-order goods from out of state.
Richard Pomp, a professor at Connecticut College, often orders from catalogues because "I hate shopping, I hate driving to the mall and fighting crowds and being mistreated by some surly clerk who doesn't know the inventory and, of course, I avoid the tax."
Most of the tens of millions of Americans who buy clothing, toys and books from catalogues do so at least in part to avoid sales taxes, experts say. What few people know is that in most states they are formally obligated to pay a "use" tax, at the same rate as the sales tax.
Only 1 percent of Connecticut residents pay it, state Revenue Department figures show, even though the state income tax form requires individuals to report use taxes they owe.
Sometimes, when a tax goes unpaid, government is partly responsible in encouraging misreporting.
In recent years, Connecticut, Maine and some other states have added a line to their income tax forms for people to report their use tax obligation. But the forms do not explain the use tax, or even mention mail-order purchases.
Falsely writing "zero" on the use tax line makes the taxpayer subject to enforcement action, but as a practical matter states do not prosecute people for small underpayments. After all, given the widespread view that mail-order taxes are avoidable, it would probably cost them more to collect the tax than they would generate in additional revenues.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Little White Lies That Add Up"
When it comes to taxes, economists and tax preparers estimate that most people cut a few corners. Here are a few examples.
 
CAPITAL GAINS -- Not just stocks, it also includes collectibles and underreported income from the sale of a business.
 
INDEPENDENT CONTRACTORS -- Underreported income from nannies, house painters and others who are paid in cash.
 
MAIL-ORDER GOODS -- State taxes on these items are almost never paid.
 
GIFTS -- Transfers over $10,000 are taxable but are often not reported.
 
CIGARETTES AND LIQUOR -- Many people stock up on them in states with no sin taxes.
 
ESTATES -- Taxes on estates of more than $625,000 for individuals, or $1.25 million for couples, are often circumvented.
 
SMALL-BUSINESSES -- Those which handle a lot of cash, like bars and hardware stores, may underreport their income.

HEADLINE: U.N. Arms Inspector Fears Baghdad May Erect New Barriers

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 14

 BODY:
Less than two months after Secretary General Kofi Annan won an agreement from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to allow unfettered weapons inspections of presidential properties, there are signs that Iraq intends to curtail access to the sites.
In a report that is expected to go to the Security Council in the next few days, the arms expert who led an inspection of the eight sites after the agreement was reached says his Iraqi counterpart told him the visits were not part of an "indefinite" process. Iraq had previously contended that presidential sites should be off limits. 
 "It is quite clear that there is a difference in view here, and I reflected that in this report," the deputy chief inspector, Charles Duelfer, who led the inspections and wrote part of the report, said in an interview today. "This issue will ultimately have to be addressed by the Security Council."
Iraq's initial refusal to allow inspectors in the presidential sites, including one large palace complex in Baghdad, played a major part in leading the United States to the brink of a military attack on Iraq early this year.
For the first time the inspectors were accompanied to sites by diplomatic observers, as the accord stipulated, and the main body of the report was written by Jayantha Dhanapala, Under Secretary General for Disarmament Affairs and leader of the diplomatic delegation that accompanied the inspectors.
His summary is generally positive, saying the Iraqis were willing to compromise when differences arose.
But Mr. Duelfer says he met resistance from the leader of the Iraqi arms negotiating team, Gen. Amir Mohammed Rashid, when Mr. Duel fer asked for a written agreement that changes would not be made at the sites without at least 24 hours' notice.
General Rashid balked, telling Mr. Duelfer that any such promise would prejudice the Iraqi position that the inspections were "a finite process, not an indefinite process." Mr. Duel fer wrote in his report that General Rashid made it clear that Iraqis considered the right of access limited to perhaps no more than short follow-up visits in the very near future.
The presidential sites collectively cover nearly 19 square miles and more than 1,000 buildings. Officials say they could be used to hide documents, research material and weapons components, if not the actual weapons. Iraq is suspected of hiding biological and chemical arms programs and cannot account for all of its delivery missiles.
United Nations arms inspectors and the Security Council have assumed, despite doubts about Iraqi pledges, that the recent tours of the once-closed sites could be "base line" visits to lay the groundwork for future inspections.
Several Security Council members had pressed Mr. Annan in February, on his return from Baghdad, for assurances that there were no hidden ambiguities in the Iraqi promise. For example, until the last minute in Mr. Annan's talks, Iraq had demanded a 60-day limit on visits to presidential properties. When Mr. Annan's mission to Baghdad was at a critical point, the deadline issue was described by his aides as a potential "deal breaker."
Now, some officials fear, Iraq is trying to reinstate the deadline.
But Nizar Hamdoon, Iraq's representative at the United Nations, said in an interview today that there would be absolutely no back-tracking on the agreement negotiated by Mr. Annan. "We're still committed to that," he said. "There's been no change in our position."
Other officials say the Secretary General is withholding the report from the Security Council until Iraq explains the stand taken with Mr. Duelfer, an American. He is the deputy chairman of the United Nations Special Commission, which has been assigned the elimination of Iraq's chemical, biological and nuclear weapons technology and production.
The visits to the presidential sites did enhance the inspection process, officials said, and those gains are reflected in the report. Officials said they had finally proved that they could have access to prohibited areas in Iraq and construct a data base from what they saw.
The team inspected hundreds of buildings during eight days of visits that began on March 26. Even the brief visits could have given them a sense of what the areas might contain -- what spots needed a second or third look and what areas could be eliminated from suspicion, at least for now. It was in Iraq's interest to make the inspections run smoothly despite a few disagreements over boundary markers, photography or the use of helicopters over Baghdad.
The Special Commission says inspections must continue until they have answered all outstanding questions about weapons that have not been accounted for.
The inspectors place great importance on Mr. Annan's assurances that their work will not be circumscribed now that Iraqis have direct access to the Secretary General's office and they are not confined to dealing with the Security Council, which imposed sanctions on Iraq after its 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
"It is essential to note," Mr. Duelfer wrote in his portion of the new report, "that the fundamental issue of continued access is by no means solved and has only been postponed to the future."
Iraq has high hopes that the crippling economic sanctions will be lifted by the end of the year if it follows the script laid down by the Annan mission. President Hussein has run up large construction costs on extravagant palaces and monuments to himself, and the Iraqi people have suffered from a shortage of food and medicine. A resumption of oil sales would meet both needs.
Iraq faces two other potentially troublesome reports this week.
A team of international oil experts has been in Iraq assessing its ability to produce more oil under a plan that allows limited sales to meet civilian needs. Iraq says it cannot meet the expanded $5.2 billion in sales permitted every six months by the Security Council unless it can repair its oil wells and pipelines.
Also this week, Richard Butler, executive chairman of the Special Commission, will submit a crucial six-month report on the entire inspection process. This period has been the most tumultuous to date, and the report will form the basis of a review of the sanctions by the Security Council.

HEADLINE: MCI Has Stopped Pursuing Local Residential Customers

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
When the MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance company, began offering local residential telephone service on Long Island and in New York City and some of its northern suburbs last summer, the move was hailed by consumer advocates as an alternative to Nynex, now Bell Atlantic.
But earlier this year and with much less fanfare, MCI, which had long sought access to local telephone markets, quietly stopped seeking customers for the service in the New York metropolitan region, as well as in other parts of the country. It will, however, keep marketing local service to businesses. 
 The setback for MCI illustrates the unusually contentious war the company has been waging with the Bell Atlantic Corporation. It also shows the regulatory difficulties and legal uncertainties that many telecommunications companies face when entering a marketplace that was, until recently, a monopoly. "Rather than lose money, we decided to stop selling the service," Brad D. Burns, an MCI spokesman, said.
Mr. Burns said the trouble with MCI's local residential service in the metropolitan region stems from a court ruling in January. The decision struck down a Federal Communications Commission order that would have forced Bell Atlantic and other regional phone companies to sell their service to new competitors, like MCI, at a more substantial discount than they already do.
The ruling, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in St. Louis, is being appealed to the Supreme Court, but a decision there is not expected until next year.
Mr. Burns said that under the existing rate structure, MCI cannot profit by reselling the time it buys in bulk from Bell Atlantic. MCI is also unable, he said, to offer customers discounts on their long-distance bills as a reward for signing up for the company's local service, a move that might have attracted enough customers to make local residential service more financially feasible. "It's called bundling, and bundling is something we can't do," he said.
Currently, MCI charges $6.30 a month for basic service in the city, compared with Bell Atlantic's rate of $6.60. Both companies also charge a small amount per call, depending on the time. MCI also offers a flat rate of 10 cents a minute, offpeak (7 P.M. to 7 A.M. and on weekends), and 20 cents a minute, peak (7 A.M. to 7 P.M. on weekdays), for all toll calls within the metropolitan area, rather than the sliding scale used by Bell Atlantic, which charges different rates based on the time and day.
In addition to its service in New York City, MCI offers local residential service in Westchester, Putnam, Rockland, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and in parts of California, Michigan and Illinois. The company refuses to say how many customers signed up for local service in the New York region, but it has about 100,000 residential customers nationally.
Current MCI residential local customers will not be affected by the decision to stop expanding the service, Mr. Burns said. He added that the company hopes to resume offering local residential service, but he would not predict when. "The economics are pitiful," Mr. Burns said, adding that the company is losing about $3 a month for each of its local residential customers and stopped offering the service in January.
He also conceded that that there have been problems with MCI's local residential service, including delays in having additional lines installed in homes and confusion over switching long-distance carriers. He blamed the problems on "strategic incompetence" by Bell Atlantic and other regional carriers.
"They are holding up the process," Mr. Burns said. "Bell Atlantic gets an order and drags its feet."
A Bell Atlantic spokesman, Jack Goldberg, disputed MCI's assessment. "We have had this ongoing debate with MCI for some time," he said. "The only obstacle facing MCI is their own lack of interest."
Mr. Goldberg added that service orders that reach Bell Atlantic are processed within 24 hours and any delays are because of MCI. He noted that he personally tested an MCI local residential line and experienced service problems. "I live on the Upper West Side, and one evening I called their 800-number to convert a second line, and I got a rep in Colorado who didn't know Manhattan," he said. "And from the moment we placed that order that evening, it was more like two to three weeks before MCI conveyed that order to my operations center."
He also said that MCI, which is based in Washington, was deliberately providing poor service in local residential markets as a ploy. He said that MCI was disingenuously trying to claim that it was being hampered by regional carriers, like Bell Atlantic, from entering local markets in the hope that regulators would retaliate against regional carriers by blocking them from entering long-distance markets.
"They will do enough in a half-hearted, underfunded way to try to create some evidence that it is someone else who is stopping them," he said. "MCI is totally uninterested in providing local service, and they can't say that."
Maureen Flanagan, a spokeswoman for Bell Atlantic, also noted that several dozen small companies, like RCN Telecom Services of Princeton, N.J., have established local residential service in New York City. "They are succeeding and they are doing quite well," she said.
Mr. Burns scoffed at that assertion. "That's a typical monopoly response," he said. "Just because they are offering local service and growing fast doesn't mean they are making a dime. In fact, most are losing their shirts."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Ends Over 9,100 Despite Mediocre Earning Reports

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Investors decided to be cheered yesterday.
Maybe it was that any actual earnings news looks good after company analysts have forecast the worst profits growth in seven years for the first quarter. Or maybe it was just that the investors still think stocks are the best bet in a low inflation, low interest rate environment -- even if earnings are mediocre at best. 
 What else could explain why lower-than-expected earnings from International Paper and just as-expected earnings from Eastman Kodak and several other companies helped send the Dow Jones industrial average up almost 100 points to a new high and its first close over 9,100.
"It is a market that has a momentum of its own," Byron Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said.
And investors could be even happier today because they will actually have a positive earnings surprise. After the stock market closed, Intel reported that despite a sharp fall in profits last quarter, earnings were still better than expected. That is the kind of surprise -- even if it was contrived with company jawboning -- that investors like.
Intel earnings were 81 cents a diluted share before charges, while analysts had forecast 72 cents a share, according to First Call. But that 72-cent forecast is down from 93 cents at the beginning of the year and it was warnings from the company that helped send those analyst estimates lower. Intel's stock jumped as high as $79 in after-hours trading.
"The analysts are terrified to have an estimate out there that the company can't beat," Mr. Wien said. "As a result, companies are going to come though better than expected."
The Dow rose 97.90 points, or 1.1 percent, to 9,110.20 while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks climbed 6.06 points, to 1,115.75, a smaller percentage gain that left this broader index still below its recent record high. The technology-heavy Nasdaq index climbed 18.08 points, or 1 percent, to 1,843.03. Advancing stocks led declines on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,899 to 1,103.
Almost 30 points of the Dow's climb came from the surge in Kodak, which rose 3 13/16, to 70 13/16, and International Paper, which rose 3 3/8, to 54 3/8.
Kodak reported earnings that met analysts' estimates, but said that worldwide film sales were still declining. Hugh Johnson, the chief investment officer of the First Albany Corporation, said that the Kodak analysis at his firm saw positive news in the report because "the reduction in costs was impressive." But Prudential Securities' Kodak analyst, B. Alex Henderson, cut his forecasts for 1998 and 1999 after the report.
International Paper had earnings of 25 cents a diluted share, which was 2 cents below the consensus estimate from First Call. At the beginning of the year, the earnings estimate was at 44 cents a share.
J. P. Morgan slipped 5/16, to 147 5/16, after reporting lower earnings that met expectations. But the stock is still up 11 percent in the last two weeks because of the speculation about mergers among big financial concerns.
Gillette was a big loser yesterday after it introduced its new shaving system. The stock dropped 4 1/8, to 120 1/4.
Surely, the economic data reported yesterday morning supported the view that inflation remains low while the economy continues to perk along at a pace that is just right -- strong enough to support profits but moderate enough to keep the Federal Reserve from raising short-term interest rates to slow the economy down. The Consumer Price Index for March was unchanged while retail sales slipped one-tenth of 1 percent after rising strongly in the first two months of the year.
"People are not forgetting the pretty good news that came out this morning," Mr. Johnson said. This environment, he added, "is enough to encourage all that money that is flowing into stock mutual funds." And once investors put it there, money managers have to put it to work by buying stocks, even if they think they are too expensive or overvalued.
"There is an urgency to put the money to work in stocks," Mr. Johnson said, so that managers do not risk being outperformed by a rival.
