HEADLINE: Screen Test for Main Street;
Suburbs Put Faith in Multiplexes for Economic Revival

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, April 10

 BODY:
First, New Rochelle trumpeted the news a year ago that it was building a 20-screen movie theater to reinvigorate its ragged downtown.
Then, White Plains announced in February that it, too, would build a theater for its anemic downtown, only its theater would have 24 screens. Then Yonkers got into the act, promising to crown the revival of its tumbledown waterfront with a 14-screen theater. 
 Suddenly, people around here began toting up the score for Westchester County and realized that 148 new screens were being planned or seriously considered in settings like Mount Vernon, Port Chester, Tarrytown, Cortlandt, Elmsford and Ossining. If all 148 go up, the largely suburban county would have 213 movie screens, more than triple the 65 the county has now.
Whether Westchester, population 875,000, has enough devotees of the cinema to support each one of those movie screens is a question that may well be asked by local officials and bankers, who will have to approve and finance some of the deals. But what is happening in Westchester mirrors what is happening around the nation.
More than 2,000 screens were opened across the country last year, the most ever in a single year, giving the United States 31,865 movie screens. In New York City, at least four theater chains have plans for multiplexes, including a 25-screen AMC Entertainment theater on 42d Street that will embrace part of an 85-year-old burlesque hall.
The driving force behind this wave of new movie screens is the country's extraordinary appetite for films, with Americans going to the movies 1.4 billion times last year and buying $6.4 billion in tickets. The teeming offspring of the baby boomers, although raised on videos and cable, seem to relish sitting in front of a communal screen. And they are reaching their teen-age years, the prime moviegoing age. At the same time, older boomers whose children have taken off for college have time on their hands and, in a robust economy, the money to spend.
"People are going to the movies in numbers we haven't seen in decades," said Jim Kozak, communications director of the National Association of Theater Owners. "More people went to the movies in 1997 than any other year since 1959."
Also taking place is a serendipitous convergence of the yearnings of local government officials, theater owners and real estate developers.
Mayors of struggling cities like New Rochelle covet multiplexes because they draw people downtown at night, bringing new life to restaurants and bars and attracting new merchants like ice cream parlors. Government officials in more rural areas like them because, unlike malls, they give people something to do besides shop and eat.
"Entertainment seems to be the way to go to bring back cities of New Rochelle's size," said Mayor Tim Idoni of New Rochelle, which has 67,000 residents. "There's a lot of retail out there, the office development industry is in a lull, so the way to bring people back to Main Street is to entertain them."
Developers love the multiplexes because they create a stream of patrons for shops on their properties. The theaters also fill mall parking lots at idle times and use interior space, like basements, that is otherwise wasted.
Theater owners love multiplexes because the ability to offer a variety of films allows them to fill seats that would be empty with a single moderately popular film. When a movie like "Titanic" is shown, a theater manager can project the film in several screening rooms at staggered times to maximize the audience, yet know that people who have been closed out can be served in the same theater with a second choice. Meanwhile, the cost of projectionists, ushers and insurance is spread out among many screens.
There are, of course, skeptics and outright detractors. Fay Dolnick, a research associate at the American Planning Association, warns that with too many multiplexes feeding on the same cheek-by-jowl audience, "multiplex mania may become multiplex cannibalism."
Beth Peterson, executive director of Downtown New Jersey, a nonprofit advocacy group for revitalization of older business districts, says she dislikes multiplexes that kill off cornfields and replace them with "a sea of asphalt." From her office in Somerville, she can travel five minutes in any direction and find a multiplex on the drawing boards. Statewide, the number of screens has grown to 828 from 559 in 1990.
"Desirable places to live are malling themselves to death and entertaining themselves to death and you wonder, 'Does the population exist to support all of them?' " she said.
Others lament the passing of another cornerstone of American life, the village or neighborhood theater like the one in Larchmont, where neighbors can gather in front of a single screen and chuckle or weep at the same movie. Clearview Cinema Group, the Larchmont Theater's new owner, is thinking of converting it into a triplex.
Almost nowhere does the multiplex trend seem to be as voracious as in Westchester. It combines some of the nation's most prosperous villages and a half-dozen struggling cities. The multiplex industry sees opportunity in both.
In the last decade, White Plains has received a number of wounding blows to its reputation as the City of a Thousand Stores. The shuttering of entire office buildings in the real estate slump of the late 1980's was followed by the opening of an upscale mall, the Westchester, that diverted customers from downtown.
After that, two linchpins of the main thoroughfare, Mamaroneck Avenue, were closed -- a 47-year-old Macy's and a cavernous Woolworth's. Dozens of storefronts on Mamaroneck Avenue are now empty.
But several theater chains have expressed interest in White Plains, a city of almost 50,000 people with populous towns nearby that does not have a single theater. The Macy's site, flanked by two large municipal garages, lured a developer, Tishman Speyer Properties, and Loews Theaters, which operates 1,020 screens nationwide. Loews will enter Westchester for the first time.
"We'll not only have a revitalized Mamaroneck Avenue, we'll have a different look," said Mayor Joseph Delfino. "I can see ice cream parlors, restaurants more active than they are today and stores that don't exist today."
Similarly, New Rochelle's efforts to resurrect its downtown had been blocked by a dead mall. Wrecking balls have just torn that mall down and work crews are beginning to build an entertainment complex that is to include a multiplex operated by Regal Cinemas, the nation's second-largest chain with 2,337 screens, as well as a supermarket and two ice-skating rinks. Mayor Idoni says he hopes that once the theater is open people will begin drifting one block down to Main Street and patronizing its long-suffering shops.
Port Chester, a heavily blue-collar village at the crossroads of two interstate highways, 95 and 287, is so eager to build a multiplex alongside a Costco shopping-club warehouse that it is willing to arrange a second relocation of its largest private employer, Nadel Industries, a plastics factory that provides 200 jobs. Just two years ago, the village loaned Nadel $5 million to move to its current location.
Officials in more pastoral towns like Somers and Cortlandt are also happily anticipating multiplexes in shopping centers.
"People want to be able to go to a single place and have a choice of 11 different theaters," said John Felt, director of planning for Cortlandt, where an 11-screen theater is under construction. "It's analogous to television. We once had three channels and now we have 104."
Right now, Westchester probably has too few screens. Like other moviegoers, Peter Graff of Briarcliff complains that to get into the most popular films at the All-Westchester Saw Mill, a 10-screen multiplex in Hawthorne, he has to arrive an hour early. On Saturday nights, the parking lot is a madhouse.
"It would be nice if there were more screens," said Mr. Graff, a journalist. "You wouldn't have to get here so early."
But a tripling of screens may be just too many. "Someone may go in with a 12-screen and be knocked down to 10 or 8 because of parking," said Albert Annunziata, director of research for the Westchester County Planning Department.
The newest player in the multiplex game in Westchester demonstrates how the business, which sprouted 36 years ago when a Kansas City, Mo., theater was split in two, has mushroomed relatively overnight.
Ten years ago, A. Dale Mayo was an investment banker trying to start his own business with a mini-mall in Tenafly, N.J. Tenafly's leaders persuaded him to build a theater instead. His company, Clearview Cinema Group, now operates 37 theaters with 169 screens, including newly acquired theaters in Bronxville, Larchmont and Mamaroneck, where Clearview hopes to add screens.
Recently, Mr. Mayo announced plans to build a 15-screen theater in Carmel, Putnam County, and he has also been asked to build the 14-screen theater on the Yonkers waterfront, which he envisions as an art house like Manhattan's Angelika theater that will show foreign and independent films.
Mr. Mayo says his multiplexes will show films like "Deconstructing Harry" and "Wings of the Dove" that appeal to more mature audiences -- "especially senior citizens, empty nesters and people with small children." That is why his theaters stock treats craved by aging yuppies, like Perugina chocolates, bottled water and cappuccino.
In the new age of theaters that suit a multiplicity of tastes, even the popcorn at his theaters is customized, made with canola oil, which is better for cardiovascular health than corn oil.

HEADLINE: A Nasty Family Fight Breaks Out Among Democrats in the Race for Governor in California

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 14

 BODY:
With candidates spending record amounts to buy television advertising in a tight race, it was only a matter of time before the Democratic primary campaign for governor of California turned into a nasty family feud, and in the last few days, it has.
First, one candidate, Al Checchi, the former co-chairman of Northwest Airlines, ran a commercial attacking a rival, Representative Jane Harman, for voting to raise Social Security taxes. Since Ms. Harman cast that vote -- to raise taxes on only the wealthiest recipients -- as part of approving President Clinton's landmark budget package in 1993, she struck back, accusing Mr. Checchi of distorting her record. 
 Then Mr. Checchi, who has spent more than $18 million of his personal fortune, most of it for television advertisements that never mentioned his party affiliation, began broadcasting an advertisement last weekend that promotes him as "a leader for President Clinton," and shows him shaking hands with the President. That drew a pro forma scolding from the White House -- which is officially neutral in the primary -- and an agreement from the Checchi campaign to stop using the President's image.
"Those photos belong to Al Checchi and there's no legal ban on their use," said Mr. Checchi's manager, Darry Sragow. "But in deference to the White House, we'll either change the photos or change the ad."
The sparring reflects the closeness of the race, the tightest Democratic primary fight in the state since 1974, when Edmund G. Brown Jr. won the nomination in a field of seven. The latest Los Angeles Times poll, released over the weekend, shows Mr. Checchi and Ms. Harman, both newcomers to statewide politics, virtually tied for the nomination, trailed by Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis, a two-decade veteran whose campaign has faltered in the face of his rivals' heaving spending. All three led the presumed Republican nominee, State Attorney General Dan Lungren, in hypothetical fall matchups.
"We're seeing a spending spree extraordinaire, the likes of which we've never seen before," said Leslie Goodman, a former senior aide to the Republican Governor, Pete Wilson, and now a communications consultant in Sacramento. "The question is, through all the clutter, what cuts?"
Mr. Checchi, who has never run for office before but is worth perhaps three-quarters of a billion dollars, has tried a bit of everything. Last year, his support in the polls stood at just 1 percent, but his ad blitz has raised that to the low 20 percent range.
Because the June 2 primary will be the first in the state's history in which candidates of all parties will appear on a "blanket" ballot, Mr. Checchi has taken pains to cast himself as a moderate businessman who would cut bureaucracy and automobile insurance rates, without emphasizing his party affiliation.
But after Ms. Harman's own $4 million advertising blitz brought her swiftly within striking distance, Mr. Checchi adopted a more traditional approach, and is running a commercial in which his friend and fellow Northwest board member, the historian Doris Kearns Goodwin, attests to his "commitment to basic Democratic ideals of fairness, equality and economic success."
In the advertisement that pictures Mr. Checchi with Mr. Clinton, a narrator says of Mr. Checchi, "As a teen-ager he was inspired by J.F.K. and marched with Martin Luther King for civil rights." Mr. Sragow said that that was a reference to how, as a 15-year-old growing up in suburban Maryland, Mr. Checchi went to watch the 1963 march on Washington with his father, an official at the Food and Drug Administration.
Mr. Checchi's claim to be "a leader for President Clinton" is based in part on his having contributed the maximum $1,000 individual donation to the President in 1996 and $100,000 to the Democratic National Committee, but the Harman camp notes that he also gave $1,000 each to Bob Dole and Steve Forbes that same year, contributions that Mr. Checchi says were based on old friendship.
The campaign wrangling also reflects the tangled web of relationships, rivalries and old feuds among the candidates' aides and advisers, many of whom were allies in various California or national campaigns in the past and now find themselves not only divided but well aware of each other's quirks, faults and playbooks.
The media advisers for the three campaigns -- Bob Shrum for Mr. Checchi, David Doak for Mr. Davis and Bill Carrick for Ms. Harman -- were all once allied in support of candidates like Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts. But in the 1990 California Democratic gubernatorial primary, Mr. Carrick worked for Dianne Feinstein, while Mr. Doak and Mr. Shrum worked for State Attorney General John Van De Kamp. Later, Mr. Doak and Mr. Shrum's partnership, based in Washington, broke up.
Similarly, Mr. Sragow, the Checchi campaign manager, worked for Ms. Feinstein in her unsuccessful 1990 campaign for Governor, and Ms. Harman's campaign manager, Kam Kuwata, worked on Ms. Feinstein's successful Senate race two years later.
Mr. Carrick, who handled California strategy for Mr. Clinton's 1996 re-election campaign, engineered the White House's rebuke of Mr. Checchi this week. Meanwhile, Senator Feinstein, who declined to enter the Governor's race this year because she said she had no stomach for attacks from Mr. Checchi, this week took the unusual step of attacking Mr. Checchi's advertisements as "grossly misleading" and "dreadful."

HEADLINE: U.S. Treasury Chief Offers Plan to Avoid Crises Like Asia's

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin today outlined an American initiative to avoid future economic convulsions of the kind roiling Asia, declaring that the international financial systems set up at the end of World War II need drastic updating "to be as modern as the markets."
In a speech opening three days of talks in Washington focusing on the Asian economic crisis, Mr. Rubin proposed new rules that would all but compel nations to disclose embarrassing financial data that many governments have routinely withheld. 
 In a proposal that Mr. Rubin developed with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, the Treasury Secretary also said the United States should consider new rules that could bar foreign banks from operating in the United States unless their home countries imposed strong regulation on their financial institutions.
Such a drastic step could limit the ability of fast-growing nations to conduct business in the United States. Indonesia, Thailand and Korea all lacked such systems before their banks began to crumble under the weight of bad debt and plunging currencies last year.
Mr. Rubin's speech contained echoes of the cold war era of arms control: In effect, he called for more international inspection and monitoring of national economies that could pose a potent threat to their neighbors. And he urged an end to the traditional secrecy that has cloaked many vital economic statistics that provide tip-offs of impending trouble. Thailand and South Korea, for instance, refused to disclose last year how much their foreign currency reserves had dwindled -- so investors would not know how vulnerable they were to attacks by currency speculators.
"The most powerful source of discipline we have around the world," he said, "is the power of the markets."
But Mr. Rubin's proposals are bound to meet objections around the globe, and he acknowledged today that it would take years before many of them were in place. Already, several nations are resisting Washington's efforts for American-style rules of disclosure and regulation; in recent weeks some members of the International Monetary Fund have even blocked publication of a recently completed study by the fund's staff about the causes of the Asian crisis.
In making his proposals today, Mr. Rubin seemed to be aiming his message at several audiences: world leaders, investors who Mr. Rubin suggested were not suffering heavy enough losses for ill-judged investments, and Congress. His efforts to convince Congress to provide $18 billion in additional financing for the Monetary Fund has run into heavy opposition. Some Republicans say they regard the fund as a menace to the world economy, and others insist that it become far more open -- and publicly critical of some of its member countries -- in return for American support.
Today Michel Camdessus, the director general of the I.M.F., shot back at Congressional critics who have denounced his institution as a huge bureaucracy of overpaid economists who dictate economic strategies to countries around the world. At a news conference, Mr. Camdessus argued that the fund is "the most magnificent bureaucracy in the world."
"I do not apologize at all," said Mr. Camdessus, whom the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, recently called a "Socialist from France" who should not be running the fund. "I am proud to be here."
In Congress the argument over the future of the I.M.F. has become wrapped up in abortion politics, the debate over paying arrears to the United Nations, and other unrelated issues. What is largely forgotten is how to avoid financial shocks that sweep around the globe faster than they did even a decade ago.
The Clinton Administration began raising that issue after the collapse of the Mexican economy in late 1994, and there have been modest efforts to strengthen international rules about what kind of data countries and companies should disclose. But none of that information was sufficient to provide a tip-off of the impending collapse in Asia.
It is possible that none could. Financial collapses are like tornadoes; forecasters can find evidence of atmospheric disturbance and predict that a twister will appear, but rarely can they say exactly when and where. Mr. Rubin's initiative seems aimed at breaking up the storm clouds before they turn into something more dangerous, by giving the markets better warning signs.
But Mr. Rubin acknowledged today that many big investors ignored the warnings altogether. Before trouble struck in Asia last year, he said, the "lack of data meant that no one had a true understanding of this buildup of economic vulnerabilities." But he also said many international investors -- including major banks and brokerage houses -- did not assemble "the appropriate expertise and and knowledge" about the risks of the markets where they were investing.
Perhaps the most controversial issue Mr. Rubin raised is whether Washington should prohibit foreign banks from operating in the United States if their home countries fail to supervise their activities. This has already happened in half-secrecy; the Federal Reserve, for example, has deflected efforts by banks in China and Mexico to operate in the United States.
After his speech today, however, Mr. Rubin said that he was simply "raising a subject for discussion," and that he did not know if the United States would decide to move ahead with such regulations on its own.
He also said today that he expected that he would remain in his post "for some time to come." One of the members of President Clinton's Cabinet who has often been mentioned as a potential successor to Mr. Rubin as Treasury Secretary, Franklin D. Raines, resigned today as director of the Office of Management and Budget to take the top post at Fannie Mae, the Federally chartered mortgage institution.

HEADLINE: Budget Director Quits to Head Fannie Mae

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Franklin D. Raines, an architect of the balanced-budget agreement and a supporter of the Clinton Administration's plan to reserve budget surpluses until Social Security's future is secure, said today that he was stepping down as the White House budget director to become chief executive of Fannie Mae.
Mr. Raines, 49, will have served as director of the Office of Management and Budget for less than two years before returning to Fannie Mae, the nation's largest provider of home-mortgage financing. He served as vice chairman from 1991 to 1996. 
 The O.M.B. director's salary is $151,500 a year. In 1997, the current chairman of Fannie Mae, James A. Johnson, received compensation totalling about $7 million, company officials said.
When Mr. Raines assumed the budget post in September 1996, the Federal budget deficit was $107.5 billion. He said today that the budget surplus for the current fiscal year, ending on Sept. 30, would be more than the $18 billion estimated by the Congressional Budget Office. He would not be more specific, but many private economists have predicted that the surplus would exceed $40 billion, if current economic conditions hold until fall.
Mr. Raines said in an interview that he had expected to remain in the Administration for the duration of Mr. Clinton's second term, but the lure of running one of the world's largest financial institutions was too great.
Mr. Raines said that when Mr. Johnson unexpectedly told him that he was leaving the chairmanship at the end of the year, he had to readjust his thinking.
"This is sooner than I ever thought of leaving," Mr. Raines said. "This was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. I wanted to stay in Government for the Social Security debate, but my real life's ambition is to run a major company, and you only get asked a very few times to run a company like this one."
He said that he could have stayed in the Government to become the White House chief of staff, or perhaps even Treasury Secretary, but that he could not pass up the chance to run the 33rd largest corporation in America.
Before President Clinton left Washington today for a forum on race relations in Houston, he formally announced Mr. Raines's departure, which takes effect on May 21.
"He has earned the trust of Democratic and Republican members of Congress alike," the President said of his budget chief.
The President also declared today that he intended to nominate Jacob J. Lew, currently the deputy budget director, to move into Mr. Raines's position. Mr. Lew, 42, has been a White House policy aide and associate director of O.M.B. for legislative affairs. His nomination requires Senate confirmation.
Mr. Lew served as a senior adviser to the late Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and as executive director of the House Democratic Steering and Policy Committee.
He was Mr. O'Neill's chief policy adviser on Social Security the last time the Government tackled the nation's largest entitlement program, in 1983. He will again have a chance to frame the restructuring of the system as Congress and the Administration debate Social Security's future over the next two years.
Mr. Johnson's planned departure from Fannie Mae is a major development in its own right. He has presided over a period of unrivaled growth at the lending institution. Its assets rose to more than $400 billion during his tenure, from $133 billion in 1991, when he became chief executive.
Mr. Johnson plans to remain at Fannie Mae through 1999 as chairman of the executive committee.

HEADLINE: Foiled Drug Pursuit of a Mexican Bares a System Rife With Graft

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON and CRAIG PYES 

DATELINE: CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico

 BODY:
For nearly a decade, the United States Government has been trying to prosecute a Mexican multimillionaire who is accused of running a cartel that smuggled tons of cocaine into California several years ago.
When American drug agents raided one of his warehouses, it was the largest single drug bust in history and it remains so today. American agents thought it was an open and shut case against the suspect, Rafael Munoz Talavera, because several traffickers who were arrested after the drug seizure identified him as their leader. 
 But despite two trials, one conviction, and what American prosecutors say is overwhelming evidence against him, Mr. Munoz is free. Mexican and American authorities say he is directing a violent campaign to seize control of a major part of the Mexican drug trade.
Neither Government has ever publicly explained the collapse of the lengthy effort to convict Mr. Munoz. But a history of the investigation, based on interviews with law enforcement officials, judges who tried Mr. Munoz, and an examination of documents, shows a Mexican criminal justice system in chaos, rife with corruption and mismanagement.
In the first trial, the police and prosecutors, who were later accused of accepting bribes from the drug cartel that officials say was run by Mr. Munoz, steered a watered-down package of evidence to a friendly judge. A second trial, bolstered by stronger evidence from investigators in the United States, ended in a conviction. But a Mexican appeals court freed Mr. Munoz, ruling that he had been illegally tried twice for the same crime.
During the trials, Mr. Munoz was lodged in comfortable suites in Mexican federal prisons, including one with a bar.
"We knew he was going to walk from the date of his arrest," said an American official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "In Mexico the guy with the biggest pocket book always wins."
Now Mr. Munoz has been reported back in Ciudad Juarez, just across the border from El Paso, Tex., and American prosecutors are working to assemble yet another case against him.
Mr. Munoz did not respond to requests, left at his Juarez restaurant, to discuss his legal fight. But in December, in a newspaper advertisement, he denied any involvement in drug trafficking and described himself as a "simple and hard-working man." The lawyer who defended him in his seven-year legal battle, Sergio Roldan Ramos, was slain in Ciudad Juarez last October. Mr. Roldan's partners and other lawyers who have worked for Mr. Munoz did not respond to requests for interviews.
Mr. Munoz's release, and criminal comeback, dramatize the legal crisis threatening Mexico's modernization. The economy has opened up and opposition political parties are finding a voice. But criminal syndicates are casting a widening shadow and the justice system is riddled with graft and incompetence, mired in archaic procedures and shielded from accountability.
Mexicans hold every element involved in disrepute, from the police and prosecutors to judges and jailers. A 1996 United Nations survey asked Mexicans how much confidence they had in their judicial system and 80 percent responded "little" or "none," the worst showing of any Latin American country.
"We have a justice system immersed in the routine violation of every basic principle," said Eduardo Lopez Betancourt, a law professor at the national university. "Nothing is respected. Prosecutors rig evidence and judges sell verdicts according to the highest bidder, without delay, favoring every kind of criminal from drug traffickers to car thieves."
Confronted with this crisis, American prosecutors routinely press to extradite traffickers for trial in United States courts. Although the extradition of Mexicans is constitutionally barred, officials in Washington say that Mexico has recently vowed to honor future extradition requests. Still, the United States Government has never successfully extradited a major Mexican drug dealer.
Four years ago, President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico replaced the entire Supreme Court and set up a Judicial Council to attack corruption. By requiring competitive examinations, the reform cleaned up the system of judicial appointments, based on cronyism. But otherwise the council has been timid.
Mario Melgar, a council member, said that of 1,538 complaints filed against federal judges, only 8 had been forwarded to prosecutors. Not one Mexican judge has been punished for accepting payments from traffickers, he said.
"I don't see any way to know if a judge receives a bribe," Mr. Melgar said. "It's practically impossible."
 
The Justice System
Bribes Can Blind Judges to Crime
Many of the forces that foiled the prosecution of Mr. Munoz are embedded in the nation's justice system.
*Graft is considered rampant. In the Munoz case, only the police and a prosecutor were accused in American testimony of corruption, but many judges are also suspect. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of the United States Congress, told a committee in March that a specially vetted Mexican police unit fighting organized crime trusts only one of Mexico's 500 federal judges and magistrates to authorize wiretaps without tipping off the suspects.
*Judges allow thousands of fugitives to avoid arrest. The police commander who led the arrest of Mr. Munoz was later charged with taking bribes from the drug cartel. But he was never arrested because he obtained an amparo, or writ, barring his detention. For thousands of dollars, corrupt officials and accused traffickers can easily buy an amparo, amounting to what one American official likened to a "Get-out-of-jail-free card."
*Court papers are secret, inhibiting accountability and independent scrutiny. Officials at the five Mexican courts that heard the various stages of Mr. Munoz's case refused to allow reporters to read the trial record, citing laws that keep documents from scholars and journalists.
*The system is poorly managed. The judge in the second trial of Mr. Munoz found him guilty, only to be reversed on appeal because he was tried twice on the same charges. Communications are so poor that the judge said in an interview that he had never even heard of the previous trial.
*The Mexican Attorney General's office was in such disorder that 10 successive federal attorneys were assigned to oversee the second, 30-month, trial of Mr. Munoz. Some were on the job just weeks. Few stayed long enough even to read the thousands of pages of documents.
 
The Suspect
A Huge Drug Hoard Spotlights Mexicans
Until late 1989, Mr. Munoz, who is 45, was known in Juarez as a sober, even taciturn, restaurateur from a leading local family. Agents for the United States Drug Enforcement Administration were suspicious of a $3 million estate he had built in El Paso, but he was not known as a major trafficker.
"There was information on him, but not anything where you hit the button and lights go off," one American official said.
Then drug agents received a tip about suspicious comings and goings at a warehouse in the Los Angeles suburb of Sylmar. They obtained a search warrant, sliced off a $5 padlock, and discovered 36 wooden pallets stacked with boxes of cocaine. The hoard, weighing 21.4 tons, was the size of two school buses.
Ledgers showed that billions of dollars of cocaine -- hundreds of tons -- had passed through the warehouse. The seizure caused what the the American Embassy in Mexico described in a cable as "an earthquake" that redefined Washington's understanding of the drug war by highlighting the growing role of Mexican smugglers.
Not only was it clear that Mexican smugglers were significant new players, but a dozen traffickers arrested at Sylmar identified Mr. Munoz as their leader.
"We knew the dope came from Munoz Talavera," said James P. Walsh, the assistant United States attorney who supervised the investigation. As a result, the clamor for Mr. Munoz's detention became intense.
Five weeks later, Mexico's Federal Police arrested him in a dingy Ciudad Juarez hotel in possession of several rifles and handguns. The police said they had seized a small bag of cocaine during a raid on one of his houses. He was initially arraigned on charges of drug possession and weapons violations, which were broadened to include drug trafficking. Mexican prosecutors announced triumphantly that he was facing 60 years in jail.
But his case went before a judge with a reputation for leniency.
From the beginning, the circumstances of Mr. Munoz's arrest aroused suspicions among American officials that the prosecution was rigged.
First, the authorities announced his arrest in advance, inviting reporters to film him as policemen escorted him handcuffed out of the hotel. Then the hotel manager said that the room in which Mr. Munoz was arrested had been rented not by Mr. Munoz, but by the police a week earlier.
"This was one of those deals that appeared to be prearranged," said a Texas lawyer involved in related proceedings who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "There was pressure on the Mexican Government to do something, and so they did something. Why arrest him in a hotel? It smacked that he made an appointment with the authorities so they wouldn't arrest him in front of his children."
Later, more disturbing information emerged. Two Mexican officials involved in the arrest and trial of Mr. Munoz were accused in American court testimony of receiving huge bribes from his drug organization.
The police officer who orchestrated Mr. Munoz's arrest and assembled the initial evidence was Elias Ramirez Ruiz, the powerful Federal Police commander in Chihuahua, the state in which Ciudad Juarez is situated. Javier Coello Trejo was the Mexican Deputy Attorney General, based in Mexico City, who channeled evidence received from American officials to Mexican prosecutors in Ciudad Juarez and supervised the Munoz case.
Late in 1990, even before Mr. Munoz's first trial ended, Mr. Ramirez and Mr. Coello were driven from office by a barrage of corruption charges. Since the resignation of Mr. Coello, several witnesses in at least three Federal trials in Texas have detailed how he received suitcases of cash from the Ciudad Juarez and other drug cartels.
Mexican press reports accused Mr. Ramirez of staging several phony cocaine seizures as window dressing for Mexico's antidrug effort. And two years later, Mr. Ramirez was charged with narcotics smuggling and racketeering. Federal prosecutors sought his arrest, but he obtained an amparo from a judge and has never been detained.
 
The First Trial
Extradition Is Foiled By a 'Masquerade'
A year ago in a Houston courtroom, Cesar Dominguez Becerra, a former police officer who worked for Mr. Ramirez in Ciudad Juarez at the time of Mr. Munoz's arrest and trial, testified that both Mr. Ramirez and Mr. Coello were working with Mr. Munoz's organization. Mr. Dominguez was asked to describe his duties.
"Sometimes it was to pick up money, and on other occasions it was to pick up drugs," he testified. "Sometimes it was to help with the sacks that we got off the planes."
"Did you also do police work?" he was asked by Jesse Rodriguez, an assistant United States attorney.
"Sometimes," Mr. Dominguez said.
"On whose orders were you operating?" Mr. Rodriguez asked.
"Elias Ramirez Ruiz," he said.
Later Mr. Dominguez testified that he had personally delivered bundles of cash from the cartel to Mr. Coello.
"Where did you deliver this money to Mr. Coello Trejo?" he was asked.
"Sometimes in the Federal Police office itself," he said.
In an interview, Mr. Coello denied that he had accepted drug bribes, saying "no trafficker has ever paid me one cent." He scoffed at assertions that American officials suspected him of corruption, reeling off names of American agents with whom he had worked closely, and expressed outrage at accusations that he and his prosecutors had sabotaged the case against Mr. Munoz.
"Why say that only prosecutors are corrupt?" Mr. Coello asked. "Don't you think some judges are corrupt too?"
Mr. Ramirez did not respond to interview requests made to him through his Ciudad Juarez lawyer, Francisco Pena Gonzalez.
Mexican and United States officials said that American evidence in the Sylmar investigation was channeled to Mexico for use against Mr. Munoz, although what was provided has never been made public.
Recently, however, a Mexican official who took part directly in the first prosecution of Mr. Munoz described the Government's management of the case as a deliberate farce.
"It was a masquerade," the official said. "It was arranged ahead of time. They orchestrated a trial in Mexico so that Munoz Talavera couldn't be extradited to the United States" for prosecution.
The official said that while the charges linked Mr. Munoz to the drugs seized at Sylmar, the evidence presented in the first trial failed to prove the tie.
"The idea was not to present strong evidence," the official said.
A second official on the Mexican Attorney General's staff who has studied the Munoz case also acknowledged its weakness. The reason, he said, was that American officials became so suspicious of Mr. Coello's ties to the cartel that they broke off cooperation. The United States Justice Department, however, has refused to discuss the proceedings.
Judge Librado Fuerte Chavez, who presided over the first trial, acquitted Mr. Munoz of all charges in January 1991. Mr. Munoz's release illustrated the blatant corruption surrounding the justice sytem in another way. The Mexican authorities had seized several Munoz properties, including two ranches and a mansion. During the trial, prosecutors and their families had squatted in the homes. With the acquittal, the judge had to order them out.
A year later, a grand jury in El Paso indicted Mr. Munoz on trafficking and money-laundering charges, and American authorities later requested his extradition. The Mexican police, acting on a tip from the Drug Enforcement Administration, re-arrested him in September 1992 in Tijuana.
Instead of delivering Mr. Munoz to United States authorities, however, Mexico mounted a new trial, again on Sylmar-related charges, this time before a Federal judge in Sonora, the state south of Arizona. The second trial lasted nearly three years.
Two assistant United States attorneys and a team of Drug Enforcement Administration agents helped gather evidence, prepare testimony, and translate documents. Half a dozen American officials traveled to Sonora to testify.
 
Street Wars
Rivalry Threatens 'A Real Blood Bath'
But it was a waste of time. Although the second judge found Mr. Munoz guilty in 1995 and sentenced him to 24 years in jail, an appelate tribunal overturned the conviction, ruling that Mr. Munoz had already been tried and acquitted in Ciudad Juarez on the same charges.
Freed from prison, Mr. Munoz returned to Ciudad Juarez, but another trafficker, Amado Carrillo Fuentes, had taken control of the cartel based there. Mr. Munoz seemed for a time to administer his restaurant quietly. But when Mr. Carrillo died last year, Mr. Munoz moved into action, officials from both countries said.
Francisco Barrio Terrazas, the Governor of Chihuahua, said in an interview that Mr. Munoz forged an alliance with exceptionally violent traffickers from Tijuana, hoping to seize control of the Ciudad Juarez drug trade from Mr. Carrillo's followers. Months of narcotics killings have followed. One grisly slaughter that Mr. Barrio attributed to Mr. Munoz and his Tijuana henchmen came last August when gunmen sprayed a Ciudad Juarez restaurant with gunfire, killing six.
In recent weeks, Mr. Munoz has appeared to retreat from Ciudad Juarez, a Mexican official said. But Thomas L. Kennedy, the D.E.A.'s special agent in charge in El Paso, recently told an Austin television station, KTBC, that he expected the street wars between Mr. Munoz and his rivals to continue. "It's liable to end up in a crescendo of violence, a real blood bath, before somebody backs down," Mr. Kennedy said.

THE CRIME
Sept. 29, 1989
Authorities raiding a ware-house in Sylmar, Calif., seize 21.4 tons of cocaine, the largest cache of narcotics ever found in a single location. Those arrested in the seizure identify Rafael Munoz Talavera as their boss.
 
THE FIRST ARREST
Nov. 1, 1989
The Mexican police arrest Mr. Munoz in a hotel in Juarez and later charge him in con-nection with the Sylmar seizure. The arrest appears staged.
 
THE ACQUITTAL
Jan. 17, 1991
Judge Jose Librado Fuerte acquits Mr. Munoz, saying the Government presented a weak case that failed to prove any tie between the defendant and the Sylmar drugs.
 
THE SECOND ARREST
Sept. 20, 1992
Mr. Munoz is arrested in Tijuana and brought to Hermosillo, Sonora, to face new Sylmar-related charges, based on evidence collected in the United States.
 
THE CONVICTION
PUB-DATE: March 20, 1995
Judge Otoniel Gomez Ayala in Hermosillo con-victs Mr. Munoz and sentences him to 24 years in prison.
 
THE APPELLATE REVERSAL
PUB-DATE: March 2, 1996
An appellate panel orders Mr. Munoz freed, ruling that he was tried twice for the same crime.
 
THE CORRUPTION CONNECTION
PUB-DATE: March 11, 1997
In a Houston narcotics trial, a former Juarez police officer testifies that the Federal com-mander who arrested Mr. Munoz in 1989 and the Deputy Attorney Gen-eral who pros-ecuted him were taking bribes from Mr. Munoz's drug cartel. (pg. A14)

Stocks Rise to Records Despite Weak Earnings
The stock market surged into record territory again yesterday and propelled the Dow Jones industrial average to its first close above 9,100, despite weaker-than-expected earnings reported by some leading companies.
The Dow average rose 97.90 points, or 1.1 percent, to 9,110.20. Broader market measures rose as well. An unexpectedly strong earnings report from Intel, announced after the market had closed, could provide further reason for investor optimism today. Page D7. 

Commerce Hurt by Network Crash
A breakdown in a national high-speed data network of AT&T seriously disrupted the flow of data for transactions involving credit cards, bank accounts, travel reservations and the like. The network was back to nearly normal operation by yesterday afternoon. D2.
 
5,000 Job Cuts at Ameritech
Ameritech said that it would eliminate 5,000 jobs, or nearly 7 percent of its work force, as part of a plan to reduce costs. D4.
 
Earnings Fall, But Shares Rise
Kodak reported its sixth consecutive quarterly decline in profits, a 17 percent drop from a year ago before the effects of a one-time charge. Analysts said results illustrated the photography giant's enduring problems, but its stock rose sharply, as investors apparently believed that Kodak was making progress reducing costs. D4.
 
Inflation Low; Sales Weaken
Consumer prices were unchanged in March for the second time in three months, while the value of retail sales fell unexpectedly, the Government reported. D4.
 
Healthy Bank Earnings
J. P. Morgan reported a 44 percent drop in first-quarter earnings, largely a result of higher costs from building its investment banking business. First Union and other big regional banks posted strong gains. D2.
 
Strong Quarter for 2 Drug Giants
Pfizer and Johnson & Johnson reported double-digit gains in earnings on the strength of some of their top-selling drugs. D5.
 
Warner-Lambert was ridiculed in the pharmaceutical industry a few months ago. Nobody is laughing now. Market Place. D8.
 
Insurance Relief for Drivers
Insurance premiums have fallen for millions of drivers across America and are expected to keep declining -- or at least hold steady -- for the next few years. The change reverses a 20-year trend of rising costs. A1.
 
Russian Turmoil Lifts Metal's Price
Palladium, used in catalytic converters, computers and cellular phones, shot up to an 18-year-high, making it more expensive than gold. Traders blamed political turmoil in Russia, the biggest producer. D7.
 
BankAmerica's Hometown Jolt
It was nearly a century ago that A.P. Giannini founded BankAmerica, setting up shop in the ruins of the San Francisco earthquake and later becoming a corporate patriarch of the City by the Bay. But with BankAmerica's planned $60 billion marriage to Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C., many San Franciscans fear the bank's beneficence and economic power in California will fade, costing jobs and betraying the founder's legacy. D2.
 
Big Pay Package at Ford
Ford Motor said it had paid Alex Trotman, its chairman and chief executive, a salary and bonus of $9 million last year, the most it has ever paid its leader. D3.
 
Bright Lights, Big Egos
Not only are Michael Ovitz and Michael Eisner set to compete on Times Square -- after Mr. Ovitz's investment in Livent Entertainment -- but a third Hollywood mogul, Jeffrey Katzenberg, may focus on Broadway. E1.

HEADLINE: AT&T Data Network Fails And Commerce Takes a Hit

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
From Monday afternoon until yesterday afternoon, companies and consumers across the United States were given an unsettling lesson in just how dependent on vast computer networks the commerce of everyday life has become.
A few million people found that their credit cards were useless and automated teller machines at banks were dead because a national high-speed data network of the AT&T Corporation had crashed. The network breakdown did not affect the conventional or cellular telephone service of customers of AT&T. Nor did it interrupt Internet access. But the flow of data for transactions involving credit cards, bank accounts, travel reservations and the like were seriously disrupted. 
 AT&T is the nation's largest supplier of data network services to companies. The data network was restored to nearly normal operation by yesterday afternoon, but its collapse was the worst such failure ever, industry experts agreed. They said it was the data network equivalent of the breakdown of AT&T's long-distance switching system in January 1990, when about half of the nation's long-distance calls ended in busy signals or recorded messages for nine hours.
"This sort of thing is going to happen infrequently, but more and more in the future," said Howard Anderson, managing director of the Yankee Group, a technology research firm. "And it makes you realize how vital to the lifeblood of the economy these complex computer networks have become."
Mr. Anderson had firsthand experience with the problem. In a telephone interview yesterday afternoon, he said he had just emerged from a Tower Records store in San Jose, Calif., where there had been a long line of frustrated customers, whose credit card transactions could not be processed. "I had cash, so it was great for me," Mr. Anderson said. "I went straight to the front of the line."
The impact of the network breakdown was uneven. Some businesses and institutions noticed slowdowns. These included Northwest Airlines, in its processing of reservations, and the American Red Cross, in the tracking of its blood supply. At the Wells Fargo Bank the automated teller machines at 1,023 branches in California went dead for several hours, but 520 other branches in the state were unaffected.
By late yesterday, Wells Fargo had enlisted the help of MCI Communications, Roseville Telephone and 3Com to hastily patch together a backup network.
"We've never had a failure like this before, but we were able to restore service in about seven hours," said Sherry Nash, Wells Fargo's senior vice president in charge of data networks.
There is no way to estimate just how much business was lost nationwide because of the data network breakdown. But the losses are likely to be big, since thousands of companies were affected and many of those do business in hundreds or thousands of locations.
Tele-Communications Inc., a leading cable-television system based in Denver, was one of the few companies that had estimated its losses by last night. Rex Mammel, a network administrator, calculated them at as much as $5 million. The losses, he said, resulted from the inability of TCI representatives who field requests for pay-per-view services, installation and repairs at 500 offices to log in to the company's central data base to get access to billing information or to process orders.
The AT&T network that went down is known as a frame relay network -- named for the method it uses to handle data at high speeds. The data packets are sent almost instantaneously over fiber optic telecommunications lines and complex switches nationwide.
AT&T's frame relay network has 145 switching hubs, or nodes. The company executives said yesterday that the exact cause of the breakdown had not been determined. But one executive said that the problem began with a data transmission between two hubs on the network -- one in Albany and another in Cambridge, Mass. The problem cascaded uncontrollably to the other hubs in the network, for some as-yet-undetermined reason.
Frank Ianna, AT&T's vice president for network and computer services, said it would probably take two to three days to pinpoint the precise cause of the breakdown. He said the cause was most likely "some combination of hardware and software" failure.
In a conference call yesterday, C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of AT&T, told reporters, "Frankly, these outages have let our customers down, and I want to apologize to each and every one of them."
Until the cause of the network breakdown is found and solved, Mr. Armstrong said, AT&T frame relay customers will not be charged. For AT&T, frame relay services are a $1- billion-a-year business, growing at more than 30 percent annually.
Indeed, throughout the telecommunications industry, data transmission services -- far more than voice services -- are the high-growth business for the future.
And as these networks grow and handle more traffic, industry experts predict, all the suppliers will inevitably experience breakdowns.

HEADLINE: The Waiting Game

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
For the last few years, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has assumed the role of an expectant suitor, twirling a corsage in his hands and waiting for George M. Steinbrenner 3d to appear at the door with an answer to the overriding question:
Will the Yankees' owner keep his team in the Bronx, demand that a new stadium be built in Manhattan, or move to some meadow in New Jersey? 
 Mr. Steinbrenner has played coy with so many others -- including two previous New York City Mayors, two New York governors and three New Jersey governors -- and has demurred so often that many have lost patience. But not the lifelong Yankee fan named Giuliani; he knows that if the Yankees leave the city under his watch, the future will remember less the dramatic reductions in crime and more the loss of a beloved baseball team.
And so Mr. Giuliani has sat, eager to please, awaiting word.
"The Yankees have been a cherished institution in this town for many decades," said Deputy Mayor Randy M. Mastro. "It's worth a little patience and a lot of effort to keep them here."
But now, the crash of a chunk of steel and concrete from the aged ballpark's rafters Monday afternoon may drastically change the prolonged flirtation between Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Steinbrenner, and the Mayor may soon face the prospect of having to persuade the city that it has to build a new stadium. A person involved in the Yankees' strategic planning said yesterday that Mr. Steinbrenner was intent on leaving the Bronx once his city lease expires in 2002, and saw the chunk that fell from the ceiling as a convenient sign from the heavens.
The insider, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity, said team officials believe that the 75-year-old stadium is not worth refurbishing. It would cost as much as $850 million to provide the amenities that the team says are needed -- the luxury suites, the additional parking, the connection to the Metro North railroad line -- and that money, team officials feel, could be better spent elsewhere.
Namely, the West Side of Manhattan.
There, the Yankees could enjoy the flow of fans that have boosted revenues for other teams with new stadiums -- like the Baltimore Orioles and the Cleveland Indians.
In truth, Mr. Steinbrenner has favored leaving the Bronx for many years. He has practiced the curious marketing strategy of describing the stadium's neighborhood as unsafe to visitors and impractical for cars, and ignored evidence that on game days the area is flooded with police officers and is about the safest in the city. He has also been largely unreceptive to talk of building a new stadium near the old one, which would salvage some historic connection between the team and the Bronx.
If indeed Mr. Steinbrenner plans to deliver an ultimatum to the city, then Mr. Giuliani will be faced with one of his greatest challenges as Mayor.
He knows that New Jersey business leaders are often seen in the owner's box at Yankee Stadium, and that a private consortium could come up with a tantalizing package for Mr. Steinbrenner. Some officials dismiss the New Jersey option as nothing more than a bargaining ruse. If that is so, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman played along yesterday by saying that if Mr. Steinbrenner expressed interest, she would welcome the Yankees "with open arms" and provide them with various economic incentives.
"There are all sorts of places we could point to that would lend themselves to that kind of a facility," she said. "We have some excellent sites, well within the reach of the current New York fan."
The Mayor also knows that like himself, most city residents want the Yankees to remain in the Bronx. Even though Mr. Steinbrenner describes the borough as being somewhere in New England, a subway trip from midtown Manhattan to the stadium takes only 20 minutes. But the Mayor has signaled that the only hope for the Bronx is a new stadium.
"The question with the Yankees is where, not whether, they're going to have a new baseball field," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday. "They should have a new baseball field. And before this incident occurred, the justification for that was economic."
Given Mr. Steinbrenner's apparent distaste for the Bronx, the Mayor has one final, controversial option: to help finance the construction of a stadium on a concrete platform over rail beds along the Hudson River, between 30th and 33d Streets. Unfortunately, when the Mayor announced this option two years ago, he did so without first gathering the support of the Pataki administration, various West Side politicians and other affected parties.
Now, if the Manhattan plan is the only option for keeping the Yankees in New York, the Mayor has to counter the opposition of community boards and environmentalists west of Sixth Avenue. He also would have to persuade the city to see beyond the $1 billion cost and recognize the larger picture -- of families strolling down glamorous Eighth Avenue toward the House That Steinbrenner Wanted and Giuliani Built.
For now, the Mayor and his aides are deflecting any potential criticism by blaming Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, for creating an environment so hostile that Mr. Steinbrenner could be forgiven for wanting to leave. "His inflammatory rhetoric and personal insults of the Yankee owner cannot possibly help keeping the Yankees in the Bronx," Mr. Mastro said. "It's an unbelievable approach."
Mr. Ferrer disagreed, and continued to taunt Mr. Giuliani for trying to placate a businessman who has maligned his borough for so long. Here is his simple solution to negotiations that have become so complicated:
"Let's repair what needs to be repaired, jump-start these talks, and forget about these plans for the West Side," he said. "Let's finally come to grips with the reality of the situation."

HEADLINE: American Airlines' Chief To Step Down

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Robert L. Crandall, the combative chief of American Airlines who helped develop many of the modern airline industry's most significant innovations, including frequent-flier programs and sophisticated computer reservation systems, will retire as chairman and chief executive next month, an executive close to the company said yesterday.
Mr. Crandall, 62, will announce his decision at a board meeting today, the executive said, and will leave his post in mid-May. He will be succeeded by Donald J. Carty, who is the airline's president and has been Mr. Crandall's heir apparent since he was named to that post in 1995. A spokesman for American declined to comment. 
 While Mr. Crandall was expected to retire within the next few years, his decision to do so now still came as a surprise.
But analysts said that even though he was so closely identified with the airline, his early departure would not have a significant effect on the carrier, which, along with other airlines, is enjoying a fourth straight year of record passenger traffic and profits.
The shares of the AMR Corporation, the airline's parent, have risen sharply during that time, closing yesterday at a 52-week high of $147.25, up $3.3125 from Monday.
"AMR has the deepest management pool in the industry," said Brian Harris, an airline analyst at Lehman Brothers. "To that extent, it is well positioned to absorb a significant management change."
But American Airlines without Mr. Crandall is hard for many followers of the industry to imagine. His intensity saw American Airlines through one of the industry's most tumultuous periods, after deregulation in 1978. Many of the best-known carriers -- Braniff, Eastern and Pan Am among them -- did not survive the shakeout.
A fearsome, chain-smoking workaholic with slicked-back hair and a gravelly voice, Mr. Crandall was the definition of a demanding executive. He scheduled meetings at 5 A.M. and was known for comparing the airline industry to war.
Indeed, his combative nature extended to the airline's relationship with its unions. There were several strikes under Mr. Crandall's watch. The most recent, last year, involved the pilots' union. That strike, which threatened the nation's travel system over the busy Presidents' Day weekend, was halted by President Clinton minutes after it started.
In 1993, the airline's flight attendants went on a five-day strike, also before a busy holiday period -- this time, Thanksgiving. And as in the later strike, President Clinton played a key role, nudging both sides toward a settlement.
But Mr. Crandall also leaves a legacy of innovations in the airline industry. Since he joined the airline in 1973 -- he took over as president in 1980 and became chairman and chief executive in 1985 -- American's innovations have ranged from frequent-flier mileage to computer reservation systems to sophisticated software for setting fares. When discount carriers started appearing in the wake of deregulation, American's reservation system gave it an edge in the battle for market share.
AMR sold a minority stake in the reservation system, called Sabre, to the public in an initial offering in 1996.
More recently, the airline has entered into a broad alliance with British Airways, a plan that is still awaiting regulatory action. And in February it announced an alliance with Japan Airlines that gave American a much stronger presence in Asia.
There have been strategic miscues, too.
In 1992, his effort to get the industry to adopt a simplified fare structure -- called value pricing -- to streamline the Byzantine system that evolved in the wake of deregulation ended in failure. Competitors, instead of following American's example, upped the ante in a series of fare wars that deepened the industry's heavy losses over the next few years before its recent recovery.
American ranks alongside United as one of the biggest United States commercial airlines, serving 349 destinations with 3,700 daily departures using a fleet of more than 850 aircraft.
Like other carriers, it has benefited enormously in recent years from a strong economy, rising demand for travel and lower fuel prices. Its parent company's 1997 earnings excluding one-time items totaled $972 million, up nearly 14 percent from $854 million the year before.
Mr. Crandall joined American in 1973 as senior vice president for finance and later was named head of the airline's marketing operations.
Last year, he received a base salary of $790,000, up from $750,000 the previous year, according to a company filing last month. Those figures did not include his bonus, which was $851,250 in 1996 but had not been determined for last year as of the time of the filing. He also received large grants of stock options in each year.
His retirement leaves only Herb Kelleher, the chairman and chief executive of Southwest Airlines, and Stephen Wolf, the chairman and chief executive of U S Airways, as the industry's remaining larger-than-life executives.
In an interview last year, Mr. Crandall hinted that he might not stay at American until the normal retirement age.
"I have no immediate plan to retire, but I probably won't stay until I'm 65," he said at the time. "There will be a graceful time to leave."

HEADLINE: Should Social Security Be Fairer?;
Remove the Salary Cap

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is astounding that in all the debates about fixing Social Security (Economic Scene, April 9) we have yet to hear a simple solution: remove the salary cap of $68,400 for paying Social Security taxes. The contribution of 6.2 percent amounts to $4,240.80. This amount represents 4.7 percent of a $90,000 salary and 3.9 percent of a $110,000 salary. It is not difficult to observe that such a cap is regressive.
 
LEON W. ZELBY
Norman, Okla., April 13, 1998

HEADLINE: Albany Lawmakers Pass Budget Only 2 Weeks Beyond Deadline

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 14

 BODY:
Breaking with its traditions of closed-door negotiations and budgets that are finished months after the deadline, the State Legislature today produced an election-year spending plan that provides far more money than the Governor had sought for state colleges, public education, child care and environmental programs.
The Legislature finished the budget for the 1999 fiscal year only two weeks after the previous fiscal year ended, a striking contrast to the 18 weeks beyond the deadline that the negotiations took last year and the 15 weeks the year before. In fact, the last time that the Legislature finished a budget this early was in 1993. 
 But the budget, the most generous in a decade, still requires the approval of Gov. George E. Pataki, who was largely excluded from this year's negotiations after rank-and-file members of both houses of the Legislature held public budget talks for the first time ever. In past years, the budget was the product of secret three-way negotiations among the Governor and the leaders of the State Senate and the Assembly.
"We have changed the budget process this year so that we will never, ever return to the old ways," said Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader of the Senate, who in previous years helped keep a tight rein on budget talks.
Over the last two weeks, the Legislature had passed two of the eight bills that comprise the state budget. Today, it passed the other six bills.
Mr. Pataki said nothing about the budget today, but he has repeatedly warned that he was prepared to veto all or parts of any budget that spent more than the budget he proposed in January. But the situation creates something of an election-year quandary for Mr. Pataki. He must choose between accepting a budget that spends far more than his own and vetoing a host of popular programs as he seeks re-election.
His main rivals in the Legislature, the Democrats who control the Assembly, have said they would not try to override any vetoes that he makes, suggesting that they would be happy to let him take the political heat for cutting cherished programs.
This afternoon, the Governor's office released a terse one-page statement saying that administration officials would have nothing to say until they had completed a full review of the Legislature's budget. "We will not comment on any specific aspect of the package until this overall budget analysis is complete," Robert L. King, the Governor's budget director, said in the statement.
Despite spending increases totaling more than half a billion dollars, legislative leaders from both major parties insisted that their budget does not spend more than the $71.6 billion budget that the Governor proposed in January. That is possible, they contend, because his budget greatly overestimated the cost of welfare and health care expenses by hundreds of millions of dollars.
Even so, the budget passed today, which legislative leaders estimated to total $71.46 million, clearly exceeds the spending targets in many categories in Mr. Pataki's original proposal. The budget increases spending on schools by $960 million, to about $11.9 billion, an 8 percent increase over the preceding year. Over all, the Legislature's plan calls for $400 million more for schools than the Governor proposed. New York City stands to receive more than $4 billion for its schools.
The plan also provides an additional $500 million for school construction and repair projects that would begin as early as April of next year. That would be on top of the nearly $900 million a year that was included in the Governor's original budget.
The plan was hailed as a victory by an assortment of educational groups, from the teachers' union to school board members and administrators. "If ever there was a year to make education a funding priority, this was it," said Alan B. Lubin, president of New York State United Teachers. "Legislative leaders have shown tremendous leadership in directing resources to public schools, which are facing daunting challenges."
The Legislature also provided significantly more money than the Governor had sought for child care. The legislative plan triples the amount that Mr. Pataki sought for child care, to more than $200 million. The bulk of the money would be spent to subsidize free slots in child care for low- and moderate-income families.
The plan also provides $20 million to finance after-school programs for schoolchildren, and an additional $100 million for public colleges and universities. And it calls for the state to issue $25 million in bonds to build day care centers across the state.
"This budget will help kids and families all over New York," said Michael Kink, the legislative coordinator for the Children's Defense Fund. "All of our kids will benefit from these much-needed improvements."
The plan also includes about $40 million that the Governor did not seek to replace dirty coal furnaces in some schools and clean up hazardous waste sites and municipal drinking-water systems.
The budget passed today does include many of the Governor's original proposals, including the acceleration of a scheduled property tax cut, only for the low-income elderly, at a cost of $537 million. It also includes an array of tax cuts that the Governor did not seek, costing the state $743 million by the year 2002 when fully in effect. The bulk of them are business taxes, the largest being a drop in the top corporate income tax rate to 7 1/2 percent from 9 percent.
The budget package also includes a slew of tax cuts for individuals, including an expansion of the earned-income tax credit for poor and middle-income families and an increase in the child care tax credit at a cost of $50 million to the state.
But the Legislature rebuffed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's request to eliminate the sales tax for clothing. Instead, it eliminated the tax for clothing items that cost $110 or less.
Fiscally conservative groups warned that the Legislature's plan would create huge fiscal problems for the state in the coming years because it assumes that the state will continue to benefit from an upswing in the economy that is largely driven by the boom on Wall Street.
They also criticized the Legislature's decision to borrow an additional $200 million to pay for a variety of programs, including $40 million to build apartments for homeless mentally ill people in New York. They said the borrowing was irresponsible and would add to the already huge debt load of $34 billion.
"It's clear that the legislators don't know what to do with taxpayer money other than to spend it as fast as they can," said Brian Backstrom, vice president of Change-NY, an anti-tax group. "Despite all the posturing, the spending additions in this budget spell only fiscal disaster. They have locked in long-term spending and long-term debt based on a one-time upturn in the economy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: State senators and their staff members gave their attention yesterday to the Senate's Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, standing center, as he spoke in Albany. The Legislature later passed its budget plan. (David Jennings for The New York Times)(pg. B5)

HEADLINE: The City by the Bay Holds Its Collective Breath

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 14

 BODY:
For almost three decades the BankAmerica Corporation's 52-story headquarters has been a dominating presence on this city's skyline, but in the aftermath of the bank's planned $60 billion merger with the Nationsbank Corporation many people here are wondering if that presence will fade to a shadow.
Word that the largest bank merger in history might remove a financial institution intertwined with San Francisco's rich history dating to the 1906 earthquake has rocked the city. 
 Reports that the merger might cost 5,000 to 8,000 jobs nationally were interpreted here to mean that San Francisco was particularly vulnerable. The bank's middle-management jobs are obvious candidates for relocation from San Francisco, one of the nation's most expensive cities, to Nationsbank's headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., where the cost of living is much lower.
Still, today nobody could state with authority what the actual job impact of the merger would be.
When he was awakened with the news Monday morning, Mayor Willie Brown called the deal an "economic disaster" for San Francisco. By the afternoon, however, after speaking with the BankAmerica chairman, David A. Coulter, the Mayor had changed his mind and suggested to reporters that there was a potential for new jobs.
The combined bank's vision as it was announced is a formidable power with twin centers, in which Charlotte will be the headquarters and San Francisco will serve as the hub of an expanding international presence. Indeed, Mr. Coulter said he planned to remain in San Francisco, and most analysts consider him the leading candidate to succeed Hugh L. McColl Jr., who will become the merged banks' chairman.
However, many San Franciscans view the city's almost century-long relationship with the bank as intricate and intimate, and the symbolic departure of its headquarters to the East Coast was cause for alarm.
Indeed, the bank's founder, A. P. Giannini, had twin visions of creating a bank that was national in scale but attentive to the needs of the "little people," reflecting San Francisco's blue-collar roots.
"In one sense he'd be thrilled and in an another sense he'd be spinning in his grave," said Warren Hellman, chairman of Hellman & Friedman, a private equity fund and a descendant of the family that created the Wells Fargo Bank, BankAmerica's main California rival.
Indeed, the city has been transformed from its origins as a seaport and manufacturing town at the turn of the century into the financial center of the Pacific Rim.
But San Francisco has maintained a love affair with the image of Mr. Giannini setting up his bank outside on a rough-hewn desk in the ruins of the 1906 earthquake and fire to help finance the rebuilding of the city.
The banker took that passion to finance the state's agricultural, movie and oil businesses in the first half of the century.
"When grandpa started the bank he went up and down California's Central Valley telling the farmers, 'Put your money in my bank and you'll make money,' " said Virginia Hammerness, who is Mr. Giannini's granddaughter.
The merger represented a betrayal of Mr. Giannini's dream, she said. "They sure sold out San Francisco," she said. "I'm hung up on loyalty and there isn't any here."
A number of the city's leaders expressed similar concerns about losing a powerful financial institution and corporate citizen -- BankAmerica contributed $5 million to San Francisco organizations in 1997. The bank has been a significant contributor in areas from the American Conservatory Theater to the city's welfare-to-work program, from financing projects ranging from the Golden Gate Bridge to the Hetch Hetchy water project.
"I'm pessimistic," said Michael Yaki, a member of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors. "I'm worried that those decisions will be relocated to Charlotte and have an impact on the health of our civic and social institutions."
BankAmerica's magnet effect has created a financial climate that will be difficult to duplicate, he said.
"Their corporate headquarters has meant mega-jobs and mega-deals and has made the city a financially hip place to be," he said. "That's something you can't replace."
Despite San Francisco's anxiety over BankAmerica's future, its relationship with the bank has in recent years become more strained. The main reason is a whistle-blower lawsuit brought by more than 250 cities and the State of California accusing the bank of defrauding the public by taking more than $1 billion from Government bank accounts to pay for salaries, consultants and other expenses.
"It was like finding out that your best friend has been cheating with your wife," the deputy city attorney, Marc Slavin, said. He attributed the change to a modern economy in which corporations lose touch with their home communities.
"It's a symptom of the globalization of the economy," he said.
That fact struck home directly with Tom Lieser, the executive director of the University of Los Angeles at California Anderson Forecast, a regional economic forecasting group. As a teen-ager in 1956, Mr. Lieser opened a passbook savings account with Home Federal Savings in Tulsa, Okla. On Monday, after that bank was merged for the sixth time, Mr. Lieser's account was finally taken over by BankAmerica.
"It's a microcosm of what's happened in this industry," he said. 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 17, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the impact of a planned merger between BankAmerica and Nationsbank on BankAmerica's home, San Francisco, misstated the university affiliation of Tom Lieser, an economic forecaster who was quoted on such consolidation. It is the University of California at Los Angeles (not the University of Los Angeles at California).
