HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Thai Troubles Drive a Dynasty To Sell Its Crown Jewel Bank

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand

 BODY:
Photos of the Thai King adorn the walls of most local companies and homes. But at the Wanglee Company, that honor is reserved for the sage, sepia-toned likeness of Tan Siew-Wang, forefather of one of Thailand's most famous business clans.
Mr. Tan sailed to Thailand from southern China more than 130 years ago, and he died early this century. But his portrait is not all that remains. The family dynasty he started, known by the Thai-Chinese name Wanglee, is now in its fifth generation. With interests that span manufacturing, agriculture, real estate and banking, the Wanglees are as well known here today as the Carnegies or the Rockefellers were in America a century ago. 
 They have kept their sprawling empire intact through loyalty to Mr. Tan's conservative business philosophy, the canon of which can be summed up in four words: Thou shalt not sell. The Wanglees still own every parcel of land Mr. Tan bought, and they have never offered outsiders large stakes in their companies.
"What belonged to our family 100 years ago still belongs to us," says Vuttichai Wanglee, a fourth-generation heir and managing director of Wanglee, which still uses the riverside trading house where Mr. Tan worked. "It is our culture not to risk what great-grandfather built."
This all-in-the-family rule has served the Wanglees well through several wars, the Japanese occupation and a dozen military coups. But it will not survive Asian financial crisis.
Faced with an ultimatum by the Thai central bank to raise fresh capital, the Wanglees are reluctantly preparing to sell a controlling stake in Nakornthon Bank, the family's crown jewel, for a fraction of the price it would have brought a year ago. "Our ancestors could never have imagined that it would come to this," said Thamnu Wanglee, the bank's president, slowly shaking his head. "But they also could never have imagined such a crisis."
The sale will do more than embarrass a member of the Thai business aristocracy. The collapse of Asian financial markets has struck a blow -- a fatal one, some economists say -- at perhaps the most outstanding feature of Thai business: the domination by a few wealthy Chinese families, and the cozy network that nurtures them.
As in Indonesia, Chinese represent a small fraction of the Thai population, but straddle every line of business. Nowhere is that as true as in banking. Twelve of the 15 commercial banks are Chinese family operations. The Wanglees' Nakornthon Bank is relatively small, with about $2 billion in assets. But shareholdings in even the largest banks, led by Bangkok Bank and the Thai Farmers Bank, are structured to insure family control.
Even in diverse family empires, banks are the prized possession. Thailand has not granted a new full-service banking license in 40 years, creating a family-directed plutocracy of 15 that rivals the Finance Ministry in their power. "Owning a bank is one step removed from royalty," a longtime banker here said.
But today, many blame that insular system for the nation's financial trouble. Family banks often make loans based on relationships -- so-called name lending -- giving more weight to a company patriarch's reputation, and the collateral he offers, than to business plans and cash flow. Critics say such practices allowed Thai companies to rack up too much debt and pumped air into real estate and stock market bubbles.
The Thai Government is determined to change the system, clearing a path for Western banks in this long-cloistered market. The International Monetary Fund has made an overhaul a central condition of its $17.2 billion bailout package.
The changes are already striking. The central bank has nationalized four banks this year, wiping out founding-family shares. Two other banks have fallen into foreign hands, one to the Dutch banking giant ABN Amro, and the other to the Singapore Development Bank. The rest are scrambling to raise funds in a way that insures long-term family control, but few see that as likely for more than one or two of them.
"The era of family banking is over," said Amaret Sila-on, head of a Government body overseeing disposal of bad bank assets. "Whether the families like it or not, Thailand now needs professionals at the helm."
The Wanglees customized their businesses to avoid just such a fate. Mr. Tan, the founding father, insisted on self-sufficiency. He bought land along the Chao Phraya River in Bangkok so that his company could handle rice and silk cargo ships on its own jetties. To this day, it owns more than half a square mile of prime riverside property. Wanglee rice mills also sat on Wanglee land.
In his final days, Mr. Tan established the Wanglee Company as a perpetual corporation, making all his descendants -- there are about 200 today -- equal shareholders, the better to prevent infighting that might splinter the company.
As if to stress continuity, the Wanglee Company remains where it was a century ago, on a pier by the river. The tarmac is made of cobblestones shipped from China as ballast on silk ships. Inside, vault-like teak doors and wood-cage cashier windows have been faithfully maintained. A Chinese scribe on the payroll drafts handwritten company reports for relatives living in China.
Big business decisions are said to be communal. A foreigner whose company had a joint venture with a Wanglee-run firm said that on his arrival in Bangkok he was introduced to 10 elders of the family, most of whom had no real links to his business. "I felt like an ambassador being introduced at court," he said.
Still practicing primogeniture, the oldest member of the oldest generation serves as family umpire. Sukit Wanglee, 68, the de facto headman who also serves as chairman of the family's agricultural trading company, calls regular Sunday meetings at a Wanglee compound in downtown Bangkok, a green oasis walled off from the city center.
The bank was founded in this conservative tradition. When it was registered in 1933, Thailand had only one other commercial bank. And the Wanglee Bank, as it was called then, had modest ambitions. It financed the family's exports and took deposits from relatives and a coterie of Chinese friends.
When the family sought to expand the bank's horizons in the 1970's, it changed the name to the more generic Nakornthon and entered a seven-year alliance with Citibank. The American bank installed credit and accounting systems, while Wanglees remained in control.
The family sends its future executives to train abroad. Vorawee Wanglee, the bank's current chief executive, studied at Duke University and worked at the Bank of New York and Citibank before returning to the fold. Thamnu, the president, spent 15 years climbing the corporate ladder at Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank before joining Nakornthon.
The bank just moved into a plush new head office, a chrome-and-glass tower with duplex executive floors decorated in desert hues, blond wood and frosted glass. But following tradition, the tower was built on a spot where Mr. Vorawee's branch of the family once lived.
None of that innate caution, it turns out, prepared the Wanglees for Thailand's financial trouble. A few weeks after the baht was driven off its peg to the United States dollar last July, the bank's main clients -- almost half in manufacturing -- began delaying loan payments, Mr. Vorawee said in an interview.
"We have tried to be patient, to work with them on restructuring," he said. "But the situation keeps getting worse."
It did not help that the bank's most promising client turned out to be its biggest burden. Nakornthon cultivated a relationship with the Thai-Chinese businessman Charn Asawachoke, founder of a high-flying chip maker, Alphatec Electronics. But Alphatec is now on the verge of bankruptcy, with Mr. Charn facing suits charging misappropriation of company funds. Mr. Thamnu, reflecting Nakornthon's standing as key lender, was appointed chairman of the ill-fated semiconductor company after shareholders ousted Mr. Charn.
Other failures have piled up. Once, only a tiny percentage of the bank's loyal clients failed to pay back loans on time. Now, the percentage of nonperforming loans has risen into the high teens. Some analysts expect that it will soon reach a third of the bank's loan portfolio, a level considered crippling.
Amid general bloodletting on the Thai stock exchange, the market has savaged Nakornthon. The bank would have commanded a purchase price of about $600 million early in 1996. Today, shares trade at one-tenth that level. The value of the Wanglee's controlling stake, estimated around 40 percent, has tumbled in tandem.
But the body blow came from Thailand's central bank. After years of loose regulation, it has required local banks to begin adhering to the most stringent international accounting standards. The terms, like capital adequacy and accrual periods, are technical, but the results for the Wanglees are personal: The standards require that they put up capital in excess of their current stake in the bank, or risk losing it.
Late last year, the Wanglees moved to shore up control. Sukit Wanglee, acting as family head though he has no direct bank role, called emergency meetings. The elders prevailed on relatives in Thailand, Hong Kong, Canada and the United States to contribute the equivalent of $17 million to keep the bank in family hands.
No sooner had the money been raised than it turned out to be woefully inadequate: The central bank made it known that it would require compliance with even tougher accounting standards sooner rather than later, forcing Nakornthon and other banks to raise more capital than they expected in less time.
However congenial by nature, the Wanglees do not disguise their contempt for the Government's actions. "I do not oppose the new rules in principle," Mr. Thamnu said. "But when they push all these new requirements on us all at once, well, you are simply pushing all the Thai banks into foreign hands."
When it became clear that the family needed to raise more money, Mr. Sukit called a new meeting. According to people present, the majority agreed that it was not prudent to invest any more in the bank. The decision made a sale inevitable.
"My feeling was that we should not sell off other businesses to support just one business," Mr. Sukit said. He hinted at a subtle difference of opinion with some other family members, saying that his heart was in farming, not banking. "In this kind of crisis, we should return to our roots," he said.
To save face during their first sale of a family business, the Wanglees are seeking a trusted foreign partner who will keep Mr. Vorawee and Mr. Thamnu as top executives. But many analysts doubt that the Wanglees will remain in management past a transition period.
Most family members say they are resigned to the sale. "It is a loss of face," Mr. Vorawee said. "But wouldn't it be an even bigger loss of face if the bank were confiscated by the Government?"
Mr. Thamnu concurs, arguing that international competition and free capital flows are drawing the curtain on Thai-style relationship banking. "If we put up lots of fresh money," he said, "we can survive for a year to two -- but that's all."
But for Mr. Vuttichai, keeper of the family flame at the old Wanglee headquarters, the bank sale is nothing to be proud of. "You have to wonder where we will stand among our friends, when something we have held in the family so long goes," he said.
Mr. Vuttichai recently organized the family's Ching Ming ceremony, on the Chinese holiday to remember ancestors. Almost no one came. "They said the traffic is bad, too busy to come," he said. "But really, I think people have lost interest."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Pennzoil and Quaker State Plan a Combined Company
Pennzoil and Quaker State, the leading companies in the nation's motor oil market, plan to combine into a dominant force they likened to Procter & Gamble. The company would command 36 percent of the market for automotive lubricants, waxes and additives.
Pennzoil would spin its motor oil operations, Jiffy-Lube chain and related businesses into a new company, which would merge with Quaker State in a stock swap, but their brand names would remain distinct. Page D4. 

Records Set on Technology Rally
I.B.M. and Hewlett Packard led the Dow Jones industrial average to its second straight new high -- 9,162.27, up 52.07 points. A technology stock rally also lifted the Nasdaq composite to a new high, 1,863.26, up 20.23 points. D9.
 
Compaq Computer met analysts' lowered forecasts. Earnings fell 96 percent, as the company worked to cut inventories, but Compaq shares rose 68.75 cents, closing at $26.75, as investors focused on the company's outlook for the longer term. D9.
 
Inventories and Sales Advance
Business inventories jumped six-tenths of a percent in February, the biggest increase in five months, while sales rose eight-tenths of a percent, the best in three months. D22.
 
Loss at Time Warner
Time Warner reported a first-quarter loss, primarily because of a weak performance at its music division and losses at the WB television network. D6.
 
American From Famine to Feast
Robert L. Crandall's 18-year record at American Airlines is a tough act to follow. He put the carrier at the forefront of virtually every innovation in the industry. Still, Wall Street is bullish on his successor, Donald J. Carty. Market Place. D10.
 
Technology Policy Called a Failure
The Clinton Administration's attempts to control encryption technology have failed and are forcing American software makers to lose ground to foreign competitors, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said. D2.
 
Lockheed-Martin Trial Delayed
A judge set back Lockheed Martin's proposed $12 billion acquisition of Northrop Grumman, delaying the trial in the Government's suit to block the deal until Sept. 8. D5.
 
Radio Show's Host Is Charged
Jerome M. Wenger, the host of "The Next Super Stock," a radio program aired in New York on WEVD-AM, was charged with taking thousands of dollars in secret payments from companies to promote their stocks. B3.
 
Disney C.F.O. Joins Starwood
Starwood, the world's largest hotel company, hired Richard D. Nanula, the senior executive vice president and chief financial officer of Disney, as president and chief executive. D4.
 
Coca-Cola Net Falls 13.2 Percent
Coca-Cola reported a 13.2 percent drop in first-quarter earnings, sending its stock down $1.188 a share to close at $76.6875. The company attributed the decline to devalued currencies in many countries where it does business. But analysts were cheered by a 12 percent rise in operating earnings. D2.
 
Shifting Economic Power in Thailand
The crisis that has ravaged Asian financial markets has struck a blow at perhaps the most outstanding feature of business in Thailand: domination by wealthy Chinese families. A1.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Group of 7 Has Words but No Action for Japan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
Finance ministers and the heads of the central banks of the world's largest industrialized nations said today that the yen had fallen too far as Japan struggles to pull out of its worst financial straits in years.
But in a daylong meeting, the ministers offered little explicit help to Tokyo in bolstering the yen, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said the United States was not retreating from its view that a strong dollar is in America's best interest. 
 "I continue to support a strong dollar," he said, carefully stepping around the question of how the yen could rise in value without the dollar falling.
The dollar, which had been weakening against the yen before Mr. Rubin spoke, stabilized afterward. In Asian trading early Thursday, the dollar rose to 131.05 yen from 129.36 yen in New York late on Wednesday.
Mr. Rubin's comments appeared to have been interpreted on foreign exchange markets as a sign that while the yen may be allowed to rise modestly, the United States will not let the dollar decline much against the yen.
That was also the message last week, when Mr. Rubin said he welcomed Japan's intervention in the currency markets to bolster the yen but made clear that the United States did not spend a penny to do the same.
Once again today, the Group of Seven nations pressed Japan to do more to improve its economic prospects. In a discussion that went on longer than expected, participants in the meeting said they were unimpressed by the presentation made by Japan's new Finance Minister, Hikaru Matsunaga, about a $75 billion stimulus package that Japan announced last week.
"The world still hasn't seen the details," Mr. Rubin said this evening, doing little to hide his disappointment in Mr. Matsunaga's repetition in private of vague plans released last week. "The final proof will be whether it affects the economy."
A communique issued by the Group of Seven tonight said: "The challenges facing Japan are serious and have intensified in recent months. What is crucial is to implement quickly a strong program of effective fiscal measures and structural reforms."
While that wording seems benign, in the arcane language of finance ministers it represents a public reprimand -- in this case that the Japanese Government, having neglected serious economic problems for years, no longer has the luxury of time to stop a downward spiral of its economy, the world's second largest.
"Japan got itself into this problem," one senior American official said last week, "and it's going to have to get itself out."
The yen's value has become an embarrassing indicator of the country's weakness and its dim prospects for imminent recovery. While Japanese industry benefits from a weak yen -- because it makes the country's exports less expensive and thus more competitive abroad -- Japanese officials are clearly concerned that the slide has gone too far.
They also know that a weak currency is a political hazard. The weak yen has kept Japan from importing more goods from Southeast Asia, which is struggling to overcome its own crisis. That has created considerable tension with its neighbors. And the flood of Japanese imports coming into the United States, fueled by the weak yen, is greatly increasing the size of Japan's trade surplus with the United States. American officials have warned that the widening trade gap could reignite a political outcry on Capitol Hill.
As soon as today's meeting was over, the participants were already putting their distinctive spin on its conclusions, hoping to influence the markets to their advantage.
For example, Japan's Vice Minister of Finance, Eisuke Sakakibara, noted that considerable time was spent on the question of whether stock markets around the world, particularly in the United States, had gone too high. And he told a news conference that the Group of Seven's statement suggested that the seven countries -- Japan, the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Canada and Italy -- could decide to intervene in the currency markets simultaneously to drive up the value of the yen.
Mr. Sakakibara, regarded as one of Japan's most powerful financial officials, said that the communique "is indicating the possibility of coordinated intervention." He clearly hopes the possibility of such action will dissuade investors from betting on further yen weakness.
But at a news conference at the Treasury this evening, Mr. Rubin said coordinated intervention in the markets was not discussed.
The meeting came after weeks of tension between Washington and Tokyo over Japan's economic strategy. The Japanese Government has been reluctant to run up huge budget deficits to bolster the economy, because Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto came to office promising austerity and balanced budgets.
But the pressure became too great last week and he announced a plan -- though it lacked critical details and seemed to include billions in spending on real estate and other transactions that have little chance of spurring economic activity. While Mr. Hashimoto announced tax cuts, they were relatively small and may be temporary.
Even top Japanese officials who attended today's meeting said in private that they were still uncertain what shape the plan would take.
But Mr. Rubin insisted that the meeting today did not include much heated criticism of Japan.
"Heated?" he said. "These are finance ministers and central bankers. Our idea of heated is somebody has an extra glass of water. I wouldn't call it heated."

HEADLINE: Talking Business With: Fran Reiter;
Head of Tourism Unit Sees Plenty of Room for Growth

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Deputy Mayor and campaign manager, Fran Reiter earned a reputation as a smart, aggressive lieutenant who got things done. A lifelong New Yorker and alumna of the public schools, Ms. Reiter can talk a blue streak about the greatness of New York City.
But Ms. Reiter's bulldozing style has caused some problems. She clashed with some of the other deputy mayors in her years at City Hall. And she angered community leaders at times. In 1996, for example, neighborhood organizations and politicians in Harlem blamed her for holding up their federally financed empowerment zone there by refusing to cede greater control of the zone's board of governors to New York State. 
 She was named president and chief executive of the Convention and Visitors Bureau in December, after a little arm-twisting by Mayor Giuliani, but business and civic leaders applauded the appointment. As head of the city's official tourism marketing agency, Ms. Reiter leads a private nonprofit group with more than 1,100 members. Its mission is to bolster an industry that employs 131,000 people and funnels $18 billion a year into the city's economy. Half of its $7.5 million budget is provided by the city, while the other half comes from members. LISA W. FODERARO
 
Q. You're taking over the Convention and Visitors Bureau at a time when tourism is at an all-time high. Can anything be done to push the numbers even higher or has New York City reached its maximum potential?
A. We haven't come close to reaching the kind of visitor levels we'd like to see.
Right now, we're suffering from a shortage of hotel rooms. There are more people who want to come to New York than we can sometimes accommodate. What we're very happy about is that between now and the year 2000 we expect to have another 5,000 hotel rooms in New York City. Most of them are slated to be moderate-priced, which is really where the shortage is.
Having said all that, there are still times of the year, like January and parts of February, when tourism numbers aren't nearly as high as we'd like. This year February was better because of the N.B.A. All-Star game. That's a perfect example of the kind of thing we're trying to do to encourage visitors during times of the year when they otherwise might not be here.
Q. In the recession of the early 1990's, a number of hotel developers were hurt as projects conceived in the 1980's opened as tourism sagged. Are you concerned that there are too many hotel plans on the drawing board?
A. No, I'm not. Economic downturns are cyclical. What we don't want to see repeat itself is this industry's inability to withstand those downturns.
Some of that downturn is due to economic downturns not here in the city but in other places around the world. Over the next year or two, we expect to see fewer people coming from Japan and other countries in Asia, and we have to make up for that somewhere. You can do it by always being alert to where the emerging markets are. Brazil is an example. You will see increasing numbers of tourists coming from Brazil and other parts of South America.
Q. What are some of the ways in which you're going to sell New York beyond public relations, brochures and advertising?
A. Well, that's actually a big part of what you need to do. In the last couple of years, there have been some limited advertising campaigns. But they haven't been global. Starting in 1999, we are planning to do some major print campaigns in valuable markets to New York City around the world.
We're also doing a major promotion in London this June called "The New York Experience." We will do it in Frankfurt as well. We are taking what is best about New York and are literally going to re-create it in venues in those cities -- four of the great restaurants in New York, entertainment from Broadway and exhibits from cultural institutions. In essence, we're going to entertain the travel industry. Why those two cities? They're the two largest feeder markets of tourists in New York City in all of Europe.
Q. Business leaders and government officials say the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center can't handle the largest conventions. What do you think should happen there and how should the bureau be involved?
A. The one thing everybody agrees on: it's too small. And it is totally inadequate in a particular way, and that is with respect to conference space. The only way to hold a decent sized conference is to put it on the exhibition floor, and that's not a good use.
So it needs to be bigger. But how much bigger? How should it expand? The state has come up with a plan. We've taken a look at it. There are aspects of it that look right. There are also land use issues that are very complicated. Coming out of government, I understand how hard it is to move three blocks anywhere in New York. So I think the role we can play is being the honest broker between a lot of competing interests that exist around the Javits Center.
Q. You have said that you would like the bureau to take over bookings at the Javits Center. Why?
A. It's the long-term bookings that I would like the Convention and Visitors Bureau to play a much more active role in.
Different kinds of events reap different benefits for the city. An event like the auto show is the most extreme example of one that has very little economic impact. Why? Because most of the people who attend it live in the city. The Convention Center is booked. But the hotels aren't. The restaurants aren't. Which doesn't mean you don't do them. You just don't want to do too many of them. It's a balance that we're looking for.
Q. The bureau's focus is understandably on Manhattan. But what are you doing to promote the other boroughs to tourists?
A. The single biggest challenge that we have is getting people to leave Manhattan to experience the fabulous things going on in the rest of the city.
It's important to get people knowledgeable about institutions in New York before they arrive here. If we can get them excited about the American Museum of the Moving Image in Queens or the Brooklyn Museum, they're less likely to be put off by the fact that they need to take a subway to get there. I'm going to be meeting with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to talk about how we can get visitors used to the idea of using the Metrocard on the subway or bus.
We need to bring institutions in other boroughs together with tour operators to make them part of tour packages. There are some great things going on in Harlem, for example, and we can replicate that kind of historical and cultural tourism in other neighborhoods of the city.

HEADLINE: As Idaho Booms, Prisons Fill And Spending on Poor Lags

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho

 BODY:
Come to fast-growing Idaho, the people behind the prosperous new economy here like to say, and you will find a nearly crime-free state with no visible poor people.
With little patience for investing in social welfare or giving criminals time off for good behavior, state leaders here have charted a course that fits Idaho's political personality. And if they are filling up prisons at an exceedingly high rate while reducing welfare rolls to an astonishing level, that is the plan and goal. 
 But beneath the sheen of the Gem State are statistics that no one is bragging about. Some social historians say Idaho is in danger of becoming another Mississippi, which consistently ranks near the bottom of states in spending for children, education and the poor.
Over the last three and a half years, Idaho has reduced its welfare rolls by 77 percent, the steepest cut in the nation. Only South Dakota spends less per capita on child welfare. But by a huge margin, Idaho's proportion of abused or neglected children leads the nation.
Crime is low, but prisons are filling faster than ever. Idaho locks up people for crimes that most states do not even consider felonies. Among the states, its rate of incarceration is growing faster than all but two. Its prisons are filling so quickly that Idaho has to fly people out of state to find cells for them.
Experts caution against making connections too directly between low public investment in children and in the poor and high rates of abuse, neglect and incarceration. But they say the trends in Idaho bear watching by other states that have reduced spending on basic welfare and education needs of poor children while pouring dollars into new prisons.
"Idaho has effectively made itself the worst place in the nation to be poor," said John Cook, the research director at Tufts University Center on Hunger, Poverty and Nutrition policy. A recent study by the center ranked Idaho as the state whose policies were most likely to worsen the economic condition of the poor.
People on both sides of the political spectrum say that what is happening in the nation's most Republican state is the consequence of its relatively recent move toward one-party rule. In a state where Democrats may have been lulled into complacency by 24 years of Democratic governors, there is only a single, statewide Democratic officeholder, the controller. In the Legislature, there are only 16 Democrats among the 105 members of the House and Senate.
"This is the problem with living in a monarchy," said the editor of Boise Magazine, Alan Minskoff. "The monarchy is tough on the poor, it's tough on education, it's tough on the environment. It loves prisons. In order to have some balance, you need two political parties."
Idaho's Governor, Phil Batt, is a Republican who generally supports the course his state has chosen. The poor who leave Idaho's welfare rolls have more self-esteem, he said.
But Governor Batt, who considers himself as conservative as any mainstream Republican, has recently warned that perhaps the state is being too hard on children and the poor, and too quick to put people in prison. He cannot explain his state's high rate of child abuse and neglect, which is more than three times the national average. And he says he is perplexed by the huge drop in the welfare rolls, as well as by recent studies that show reading levels falling for grade-school pupils.
"Food bank usage has gone up, no doubt about it," Mr. Batt said. "And we are deeply concerned about child abuse in this state."
On the welfare drop, he said it was too early to draw conclusions, but he suggested that Idaho's two-year limit on benefits might be too harsh.
Idaho is something of a statistical anomaly. It is much more rural than the rest of the United States, though its economy has gone from one based on agriculture and natural resources to one, especially in the south, built around high technology. Its small population -- 1.2 million -- is 95 percent white. It has a deep-seated distrust of the Federal Government, and a tradition of self-reliance. An often heard refrain is that Idaho is what the United States used to be.
But Idaho's isolation, and its homogeneous political and racial makeup, is hurting the state, Stephen Lyons wrote in a recent essay in High Country News, a Western weekly. "That isolation has led to xenophobia, a fear of strangers or, perhaps more precisely, a fear of anyone not white," Mr. Lyons wrote.
Others say that Idaho is more tolerant than it is portrayed outside the state, but that it could use a second strong political party.
A retired state Supreme Court Justice, Bob Huntley, just announced that he would run for governor as a Democrat this year. His main reason, Mr. Huntley said, was the lack of a two-party system.
But beyond political philosophies, some experts say that Idaho, in limiting welfare benefits while expanding prisons, is simply making a bad investment for taxpayers. The state spends only $17 per person on overall child welfare. It spends five times that much on each prisoner.
"There are good reasons for building prisons," said Professor Robert Marsh, chairman of the Department of Criminal Justice at Boise State University, "but our one solution to everything -- drugs, alcohol abuse, minor offenses -- is prison, and that is simply not cost-effective."
In 1996, the last full year for figures, 78 percent of those Idaho sent to prison were nonviolent offenders -- more than 50 percent higher than the national average. Yet Idaho's overall crime rate ranks it in the lower fifth among states.
Idaho's prison population, at more than 4,000, has grown tenfold in the last 25 years. Simple drug possession, writing a bad check, drunken driving and driving without a valid license can land a person in prison, though the Governor just signed a bill that raised the thresholds for those felonies.
In addition, 10 years ago Idaho became one of the few states to eliminate parole for good behavior. "The average time served now, for any crime, doubled in 10 years from 22 months to about 44 months," Professor Marsh said.
The state is now spending $200 million to build a new, privately operated prison for 1,250 inmates. Its spending for the poor totals only about $15 million a year, at the bottom among all states.
Welfare payments are no more than $276 a month for a family, regardless of size, and there is a lifetime limit of two years for receiving aid. Some critics say the predominant attitude toward the poor is punitive. Some of those who used be on welfare certainly feel stigmatized.
"I find myself sometimes going for days without food so my kids can eat," said Krista Ziebart, an epileptic mother of two from the Boise area. Ms. Ziebart lost her welfare benefits when Idaho became one of only three states that count Social Security disability payments as income that would disqualify someone from welfare.
Ms. Ziebart is one of hundreds of people in Idaho who have left the welfare rolls, but have not necessarily been lifted out of poverty. Though they are uncertain, state officials attribute the drop to the new time limit of two years and a host of new requirements.
"A lot of these families that the state kicked off welfare have had to move in with other families or relatives, so it's not unusual now to find 9 to 12 people living in a single trailer," said Mikey Krajcer, director of the Hunger Action Network, a private nonprofit agency that works with the poor here.
A number of researchers and educators from Idaho have joined national critics in arguing that the state's investment in welfare and early child education is too low.
One recent study, financed by the state, found that nearly 60 percent of fourth graders were reading at a level below their grade. Another survey echoed national studies in establishing a direct link between failing grades for poor children by the fourth grade and the likelihood that the children will commit crimes as a juvenile or young adult.
"The message our state seems to be sending is that if you're going to be a kid, don't be a kid in Idaho," said Robert Barr, dean of the College of Education at Boise State.
"I have tried to convey to the state Legislature the most chilling information that I've ever seen," Dean Barr said in a interview. "If a child is poor, is held back at least once and is not reading at grade level, you can predict with better than 90 percent success that the child will never graduate from high school and may end being a burden on the system, in prison or elsewhere."
Earlier this year, the Legislature turned away Federal money that would have provided health insurance for more than 10,000 poor children, at only a small cost to the state.
After a furor, and lobbying by Governor Batt, some of the Federal money was restored last month, but not the full amount to which the state was entitled. State budget writers said they did not want to become dependent on Federal largess.
"Idaho is rock-solid, good families," Dean Barr said. "Unfortunately, people are very suspicious of Government schools or Government help."
They have become even more suspicious in recent years, as Idaho lost its Democratic office holders. The party's decline can be traced to the disappearance of its strong union base in the north, where minimum-wage service workers have replaced industrial labor. The last Democratic power in the state was Cecil Andrus, a four-term Governor until 1994.
A decade-long surge of newcomers, primarily from California, also changed the state's politics. Most experts now think that the new residents were fleeing more racially and politically diverse states, and are perhaps more conservative than many Idaho natives.
Governor Batt said there would seem to be ample jobs for the poor.
Asked why they could not get jobs, some mothers with families who have been forced off welfare said it was too hard to live on the minimum wage while trying to take care of young children.
What is more, some Idaho officials have indicated they do not want too many well-paying jobs to come to the state, because it would raise wages for others. Last year, the president of the Boise Area Chamber of Commerce, Jay Clemens, said he opposed a company's plan to bring 500 jobs to the area because it could "unrealistically drive up wages."
The state has a strong private welfare tradition through the Mormon church, to which about a third of Idaho's population belongs. But the church welfare system generally applies only to Mormons.
If you are poor and non-Mormon, there are few places to go, said some people here. "They just want us to disappear," said Sherry Meschler, a disabled mother of three who lost her welfare benefits last year.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
In Wildwood, Bets Are Still On Gambling

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: WILDWOOD, N.J.

 BODY:
FRED WAGER is getting impatient with all the nattering naysayers. As Mayor of this great little resort, he promised to give tourist-chomping Atlantic City a poke in the eye. He told voters he would try to bring a casino here, and, three years later, by golly, that's just what he's going to do.
The statistics that help fight the good fight against the snickering politicians, not to mention the press, gush out. "Three to one," Mr. Wager says. "Three to one, the voters said yes to a casino. I mean, we got 26 percent unemployment! Kids graduate from high school and have to move away. Twenty six percent unemployment! We got no jobs for them." 
 These, of course, are the same grave statistics Mr. Wager trotted out three years ago when he brought Chief Larry Snake of the Delaware Tribe of Anadarko, Okla., to town to declare a city parking lot sacred ancestral land. Wildwood, once the wildest Jersey Shore resort of them all, had fallen as Atlantic City's boomed, and the Delaware Indians were going to help bring it back. The city would deed the parking lot to the Delawares, who would open a casino that would stanch the flow of tourists who bypass Wildwood for the gambling mecca 30 miles to the north.
But while the politicians thought they had ridiculed this idea out of existence, Fred Wager and Wildwood (pop.: 5,000) may get the last laugh.
WILDWOOD, which looks like it's in mothballs nine months of the year, is in the process of settling a lawsuit recently filed by the Delaware tribe that claims the city as ancestral land. But Jeffrey April, a lawyer for the tribe, says the litigation is simply designed to expedite a casino.
Negotiations are under way to settle the land claim by giving the tribe the two-acre parking lot the city had originally proposed for a casino, or a tract of similar size. The tribe would then ask the Federal Government to place the land in trust, creating in effect a mini-reservation.
And then: Bingo! The Delawares would be able to open a high-stakes bingo hall on their "reservation" without having to get state clearance.
The sneaky plan sidesteps the approval process the tribe would have to go through with the state for a full-fledged casino with slot machines and baccarat tables. Since the Governor has already said that casinos outside of Atlantic City are not an option, this provides the only way for Wildwood to open the casino it has decided is its best bet for the future.
While it may sound like a cockamamie scheme, it wouldn't be the first time an Indian gambling hall has opened without state approval. And while a high-stakes bingo hall, which has some card games and lottery-style ticket games, could hardly hold its own against a Caesars or Trump Plaza, its proponents see it as a start.
MR. APRIL said that it was quite possible that the Delawares would be able to obtain a full casino license without state approval by petitioning the Bureau of Indian Affairs. Congress is considering an amendment to the 1988 Indian Gaming Regulatory Act that would allow the Bureau or the attorney general to approve complete casinos when tribes and states can't agree on a compact.
So this old seashore hangout may have a casino one block from its fabled boardwalk after all. Obviously, it is desperate for something.
The city's other big scheme, to bring back the tourists by promoting its large cache of motels with plastic palm trees and neon signs, may be more inventive and less of a gamble. Wildwood has other attributes, too: some of the most interesting, old-fashioned amusements on five piers, and clean water where dolphins and whales are known to romp. But these, apparently, are minor, fair-weather assets.
Right now, Wildwood looks like the victim of a brush fire, boarded and empty. The other day, a pedestrian mall in the heart of downtown was being used by boys practicing tricks on their bikes. Of the more than 100 pubs in town, only a few are open.
One is Phil and Eddie's, which is next to the parking lot where the new casino might stand. The manager, who would not give her name, sounded about as hopeful for a new casino as everyone else, despite the drawbacks of gambling. "Listen," she said. "It couldn't be worse here than it is now."

HEADLINE: State Legislature Approves $950 Million Increase in Spending for Education

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 15

 BODY:
In what is by far the steepest spending increase in this election-year state budget, the Legislature has approved raising the allocation for public schools to $11.9 billion, a $950 million increase over last year.
Lawmakers are crowing about the unprecedented level of aid that would flow into their districts, saying it will provide everything from computers to property tax relief. If Gov. George E. Pataki does not veto any of the school spending, state aid to local districts will have risen 14 percent in just two years. 
 But the recent increases do not make up for years of cutbacks during the last recession. When adjusted for inflation and increased school enrollment, the education aid proposed for fiscal year 1999 is more than 4 percent lower than it was a decade ago. That fact, obscured by talk among legislators of a historic new commitment to education, underscores just how shaky the state's finances were in the early 1990's, and how aggressively Mr. Pataki sought to cut education spending early in his term.
"We fell way behind in education spending and we're just now catching up," said Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat who is the chairman of the Assembly Education Committee. "Nobody can deny that the state contribution to education had to get much higher."
The budget passed Tuesday by the State Legislature pays about 42 percent of the total cost of public education in New York State, up from 39 percent in 1994, the year Mr. Pataki was elected. It contains $11 billion in general operating aid for the state's 4,000 public schools, an increase of $740 million over last year. More than 100 of the state's 730 school districts are to receive a total of $67 million for prekindergarten classes as part of a multiyear agreement that also provides money for building repairs, full-day kindergarten and technology.
The budget also authorizes $500 million for a school construction program, $200 million of which is to go to repair and build schools in New York City. That investment comes five months after voters rejected a bond act that would have provided $2.4 billion for statewide school construction.
But in an effort to keep overall state spending below the $71.6 billion proposed by the Governor, the Legislature will not make the money available until the start of the next fiscal year, in April 1999. The delay is also an acknowledgment that districts cannot plan how to use so much money in time for the coming school year.
Although the Legislature's education budget is about $430 million higher than what Mr. Pataki proposed, lawmakers said they did not think the Governor would veto any school spending in an election year. For one thing, they said, the money was more carefully focused on specific programs than in the past.
"This was not a case of taking a lot of money and throwing it against a wall to see how much will stick," Mr. Sanders said. "It would be politically foolish and substantively indefensible for the Governor to veto any piece of this spending."
Under the Legislature's spending plan, New York City's school system, which has 37 percent of the state's public school students, will receive an increase in state aid of more than $300 million, bringing its total to more than $4 billion. The budget also calls for the city to receive more than $30 million for new prekindergarten classes, enough to double the enrollment in the program to 24,000 pupils. But Steven Allinger, a lobbyist for the New York City Board of Education, said the city would first have to find the space for dozens of new classrooms.
"Providing additional money specifically for prekindergarten was extremely important for us," Mr. Allinger said. "But it will be a great challenge securing the extra seats."
As the state spends substantially more on education this year, local districts will be spending less of their own money, which is raised primarily through property taxes.
The districts will be reducing their contributions to the pension fund for teachers by a total of $200 million because the fund's investments in the stock market did exceptionally well last year.
Mr. Pataki, who has remained silent on the budget so far, has 10 days to decide whether to veto any parts of it.
A veto on education spending could anger not only voters but also powerful teacher unions, which have enough money and numbers to exert considerable influence over this year's gubernatorial campaign.
While Mr. Pataki wanted to eliminate a spending category known as Teacher Support Aid, which helps poor urban districts pay teachers' salaries, the Legislature's budget not only retains that category but also increases spending on the program, to $77.5 million from $67.5 million. It also adds $10 million for Teacher Centers, which help schools develop new instructional methods.
Richard P. Mills, the State Education Commissioner, said a steep increase was necessary this year to help school districts meet new curriculum standards adopted by the State Board of Regents last year. The budget includes $82 million specifically for programs to help the state's 2.8 million schoolchildren meet the new standards. Mr. Mills said schools could spend the money on reading programs, tutoring, teacher training and curriculum changes.
"There has been a tremendous effort across the state to meet a very clear set of expectations," he said. "Now here is a budget that invests very heavily in that work. The expectations are clear, the resources are here, so now it's time to press on."

HEADLINE: Need Engineers? Try Paying Them

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, April 14) quotes T. J. Rodgers, the founder of Cypress Semiconductor, as saying that every high-tech engineer he can employ (even if a foreigner) can generate five local jobs. This is a succinct expression of job creation in a global marketplace. Foreign examples abound. Citizens of European Union countries can live and work in any other member country, allowing European companies to reconcile European manpower across country borders. 
 Nokia, the Finnish cellular phone company, has expanded its operation to Britain to take advantage of a freer economy that uses the lingua franca of high tech. Another example is finance workers in London and the business they generate for hotels, pubs and construction. If labor protectionism returned to Britain and other European workers were sent home, the British working in the support industries would see a return to 11 percent unemployment.
 
GARY L. DARE
Evanston, Ill., April 14, 1998

HEADLINE: The Road Ford's Taken;
Auto Maker Places Biggest Bet Yet on the Behemoths

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

 BODY:
After years of cranking out low-profit heavy-truck tractors through a maze of conveyor belts and robot welders covering more than 100 acres here, North America's largest auto factory has a new product. And it is beginning to earn a fortune for the Ford Motor Company.
When Ford sold its heavy-truck business to Daimler-Benz A.G. last year, the company began building Super Duty pickups here instead. The profitable new pickups, which are taller than Michael Jordan, with front seats that are nearly four feet off the ground, have been an instant hit since they went on sale in February. To keep them selling, and the profits rolling, Ford has brought in a thousand workers from unprofitable car factories in Ohio and has just begun operating the factory here around the clock. 
 "This truck plant has gone from producing low-volume, low-margin vehicles to much higher-volume and certainly much higher-margin vehicles," Jacques A. Nasser, Ford's president of worldwide automotive operations, told thousands of cheering workers recently after driving one of the first big pickups off the assembly line.
Ford is betting more and more on its stars -- ever-bigger vehicles that turn ever-bigger profits -- and turning its focus away from what was once its heart and soul, even scrapping some passenger car models.
"I think much more of the quality of the sales than the number of wheels we drive across the curb," said Alex Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive, using an industry phrase for the number of new vehicles leaving dealerships.
This is a radical departure in Detroit, where auto makers have traditionally kept selling every model possible to squeeze out the last ounce of market share. The General Motors Corporation has stuck valiantly to this costly strategy, keeping alive dozens of slow-selling cars.
Ford's strategy carries risks. If gasoline prices rise or the sport utility mania fizzles, cars might become popular again, hurting auto makers like Ford and the Chrysler Corporation that have bet their futures on light trucks. Federal safety regulators have strongly criticized the industry in the last two months for producing bigger, taller light trucks that inflict far more damage during crashes, and the industry may be hurt if new rules are issued.
Environmentalists and some Federal regulators also want manufacturers to improve the average fuel efficiency of their light trucks. That could crimp sales of the biggest and most profitable gas-guzzlers, which barely manage double-digit gas mileage, but would be less likely to affect the Super Duty, which is so big that it is now exempt from fuel-economy rules.
"It's these luxury trucks that are carrying the profits around here, and everybody's holding their breath for whether that will fall apart," said Ronald Harbour, a Detroit-area industry consultant.
Ford is betting that sport utility vehicles and pickups will stay popular, that any regulatory changes will be gradual and that gas prices will not rise much. Mr. Trotman predicts "an extended period of low at-the-pump prices."
A string of successes like the Super Duty, the Ford Expedition and the Lincoln Navigator -- combined with sharp cost reductions across the board -- have produced steeply rising profits and a soaring stock price for Ford. Its net earnings rose 56 percent last year, to a record $6.92 billion, the fourth-highest of any American corporation, trailing only Exxon, General Electric and Intel. After years as a laggard, Ford's stock has more than doubled in 12 months. The shares closed on Wednesday at $49.875.
All the big auto makers, of course, have cashed in on the public's insatiable demand for pickups and sport utilities, but Ford has zeroed in on this trend most decisively. Just in the last year, it has jettisoned its heavy-truck business and dumped a half-dozen unprofitable cars, including the Thunderbird, Probe and Aspire; another, the Lincoln Mark VIII, will go out of production this summer.
Yet Ford has held on to its 25 percent market share in the United States, with sales of larger vehicles taking up the slack.
Some buyers of canceled models appear to have switched to the Mustang, whose sales were 42 percent higher in this year's first quarter than a year earlier. The Mustang makes money because its strong brand name allows Ford to charge a premium for the car.
Wall Street is delighted by all this. "Ford's running the business better and management is more interested in maximizing shareholder value," said John A. Casesa, an analyst at Schroder & Company.
Ford has been No. 2 in the Big Three for half a century, but the gap by which it has trailed G.M. is narrowing as G.M. continues to struggle.
Neither auto maker earns much in Europe, although the introduction of sleek small cars like the Ka have made Ford's operations there more profitable than G.M.'s for the first time in years. In Latin America, sales of Ford's popular new small cars have been affected relatively little by the recession in Brazil. And in the crumbling economies of Southeast Asia, Ford has been proved right after building a small, but expandable, factory in Thailand, while G.M. has found itself stuck with a huge operation.
Ford's success shows how an industrial giant can lift profits even in a flat market. With G.M. and most Japanese auto makers spinning their wheels, Ford has a cash hoard of more than $20 billion. And while rebates and other incentives on cars and light trucks have been growing, Ford has cut costs even faster.
The company's success has surprised Wall Street, especially because Ford has achieved big cost savings while laying off only a few workers. It sold 4.4 percent more vehicles last year, while its costs rose only four-tenths of 1 percent. If its costs had increased in line with vehicles produced, after-tax profits would have dipped slightly. Instead, they rose by $2.47 billion. Ford estimated that if the number and type of vehicles produced had stayed the same, automotive costs would have dropped $3 billion.
Some analysts have attributed as much as half of the falling costs per vehicle to lower commodity prices. The price of rubber for tires, for example, has dropped by a third because the currency of Thailand, a big rubber producer, has plunged.
But John M. Devine, Ford's chief financial officer, said commodity price shifts were a tiny factor. Ford, he said, buys a lot of parts under long-term contracts not directly linked to raw-material prices.
Mr. Devine and other Ford executives attributed the savings to greater budget discipline and streamlined manufacturing. Under the variously designed sheet metal, more and more Ford models share just a few common engines, transmissions, suspensions and underbodies. "It's just amazing how a few million here and a few million there adds up to serious numbers," Mr. Trotman said.
Just two years ago, many on Wall Street and in the financial media were questioning whether Ford had designed new models, including sport utilities and pickups, so luxurious that few Americans could afford them. The main evidence lay in weak sales of the Taurus sedan, which rose $1,000 in price when Ford redesigned it in 1995 and which has since lost its leadership in midsize car sales to the Toyota Camry.
But big, high-priced vehicles have turned into the hottest segment of the market. Despite price tags of $30,000 to $40,000 or more, Ford's light trucks now account for almost three-fifths of the company's domestic sales. Its most expensive sport utilities, the huge Expedition and the similar Lincoln Navigator, have also been its most profitable, with the Navigator nearly outselling the once-popular Lincoln Continental and Mark VIII combined.
While auto makers do not release profits by model, analysts estimate that Ford is earning a pretax profit of $2.2 billion on annual sales of $9 billion worth of Expeditions and Navigators. And Scott Merlis, an automotive investment banker, predicted that the new Super Duty would add more than $600 million a year to Ford's pretax profits.
Ford faced criticism from efficiency experts two years ago for installing costly features like overhead-cam engines in the F-150 pickup and its offspring, the Expedition and Navigator. But customers have been flocking to the upscale behemoths, while G.M. has accumulated large supplies of unsold Chevrolet Suburbans, a slightly larger model with a less sophisticated design.
"It's really remarkable how in this market, a few good models can make such a difference," said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst at Furman Selz, a New York investment bank. "The Expedition was a brilliant stroke of genius -- it makes a fortune."
When environmental questions arose last year about the contribution these vehicles make to urban smog, Ford's sophisticated engines helped make it the only large auto maker able to promise that its full range of sport utilities would be roughly as clean as cars by this fall. And while Federal regulators are examining the dangers that these oversize vehicles pose to other drivers, Ford also appears to be further along than its rivals in working on solutions, announcing, for example, that it would offer side air bags in all its cars within three years.
Ford's shift from low-profit cars to high-profit sport utilities has also insulated it from Asian competition. While the dollar has soared against the Japanese yen and Korean won, making it far cheaper for foreign auto makers to import vehicles to the United States, overseas production of full-size pickups and sport utilities is negligible. High taxes have driven up the price of gasoline to $4 or $5 a gallon in most industrialized countries, so the main market for huge vehicles is the United States.
"We don't compete head to head with Japanese imports on a large piece of our production," Mr. Trotman said. Japanese auto makers also seem to have shown restraint in cutting prices on their cars, perhaps because of concerns about a political backlash in the United States.
Ford also has a big advantage in competing with G.M., its primary domestic rival.
G.M. has suffered a series of crippling strikes in the last four years and appears close to another big strike this spring. Ford has not suffered a strike at a single factory in more than a decade. It has also been allowed considerable flexibility by the United Automobile Workers to move workers around.
Ford's success has been partly the result of continuity of management: Peter J. Pestillo, an executive vice president, has overseen the company's labor policy since 1980 and is close to the U.A.W.'s leadership. But Ford also continues to benefit from sharp cuts in staffing that Mr. Pestillo negotiated with the union in the early 1980's, when Ford was struggling for survival.
Despite all this, Ford has some serious vulnerabilities. Few of its car models other than the Mustang have produced much enthusiasm in the marketplace. That could prove to be a serious problem if gas prices rise or if sport utilities go out of favor.
Profits slipped last year at the Ford Motor Credit Company, which provides auto loans and leases, when cars coming off lease could not be sold for as much as expected. And after five years of strong sales, the nation's driveways are so full of late-model vehicles that any economic slowdown could prompt millions of families to defer their next trips to dealerships. Mr. Trotman said that while Ford was well positioned to weather a recession, whether it would remain profitable in a downturn would depend on how deeply its rivals discounted prices.
Yet over all, Ford is prospering. Most analysts predict -- and, in an interview, Mr. Trotman agreed -- that Ford's earnings will be up again in the latest quarter, the eighth straight year-to-year rise.
Ford's strength has also benefited the 4,600 workers at the Super Duty factory here, who earn at least $19.50 an hour. They are already speculating on the styling of the world's largest sport utility vehicle, which Ford plans to build here next year. It will be nearly two feet longer than the Expedition and will use the underbody and other features of the Super Duty pickup.
The employees are also looking forward to a lot of overtime pay. "It's hard work," said Kenny France, a 28-year-old worker on the line, "but the money's the best."

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 38; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Shades of Meaning From a Black Modernist

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK 

 BODY:
In the sacred, all-white pantheon of first generation Abstract Expressionists, the name of Norman Lewis (1909-1979) is not enshrined. A black artist who was based in Harlem, he is hard to find in chronicles of the New York School. Nor did he appear in the defining photograph of the group, identified as the Irascibles, that ran in Life Magazine on Jan. 15, 1951, and included the usual suspects: Jackson Pollock, Robert Motherwell, Mark Rothko, Willem de Kooning, Barnett Newman, Ad Reinhardt, et al., along with one female painter, Hedda Sterne.
Yet for a good while Lewis was a presence among them; close friends with Reinhardt and others. He showed his work at important museums and expositions; he got grants from prestigious foundations, he was represented, from 1946 to 1964, by the well-regarded Marian Willard Gallery. But as the luster of Abstract Expressionism dimmed in the 60's, his own reputation faded. "Norman Lewis: Black Paintings, 1946-1977," at the Studio Museum in Harlem, is part of an ongoing attempt to restore his work from near oblivion to public and historical attention. 
 Presenting some 60 oils and works on paper, the show moves from Lewis's beginnings as an Abstract Expressionist in the mid-1940's to his last endeavors, paintings that reflect his interest in the phenomena of nature. Like many exhibitions that expose a broad range of work, this one is uneven. There are wonderful things in it, for instance, "Metropolitan Crowd" of 1946, a dense, rhythmical all-over web of multicolored linearities on a black field that, strobelike, seems to track the movements of city pedestrians. Another gem is "Woman," a small but dynamic oil from 1948 -- a time when de Kooning was wrestling with his "Women" series -- in which sharp, jazzy geometric forms in red and beige meld exuberantly with the painting's black ground. But curatorial zeal has kept in too many weaker works, particularly his muddy "Atmospherics" of the 1950's.
Why, since Lewis was known primarily as a colorist, does the selection of paintings here focus on black? It's complicated. Like his colleagues in the first-generation New York School, Lewis did not approve of art as a forum for political statements. With Abstract Expressionisism, he had turned away from the prevailing Social Realism movement of the 1930's toward more esthetic adventures: exploring the potential of color, line, gesture, form. To him, as to the others, the most meaningful "message" a work could convey was the glorious act of painting itself.
Yet Lewis was by no means unaware of social issues; on the contrary, along with most of his artist friends, he leaned to the left. And he was deeply concerned with the battle for black equality. During the civil rights struggles of the 1960's, that concern got into his work. Black-and-white paintings like "America the Beautiful" from around 1960, and the 1961 "Klu Klux" mock the boobyish activities of Klansmen. But this was really the only time after the early 1940's that polemics -- however mild -- appeared directly in his paintings.
Aside from these, like his white artist friends, Lewis produced many paintings in which black was the prevailing hue. He used it, as they did, not only as a credo of modernism, but for the richness of shade and tone it offered. (Black-dominated works by Pollock, de Kooning, Motherwell, Kline, Reinhardt and Robert Rauschenberg are included in the show to provide historical context.) Lewis valued black, he said, as a way of "arousing other colors," and traced his interest in it to a painting he had made of rhododendrons, using the dark pigment to "convey the form." He added, "Just manipulating the paint was exciting to me."
But in their catalogue essays, the show's organizers -- Ann Eden Gibson, associate professor in the department of art at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and Jorge Daniel Veneciano, curator of exhibitions at the Studio Museum -- present labored arguments to the effect that even in paintings other than the "Klansmen" compositions, black served Lewis as a metaphor for the African-American experience, allowing him to make political and social references without specifics.
One example, cited by Mr. Veneciano: the 1948 painting "Tenement." A vertical rectangle of black, on which occurs a random arrangement of tiny multicolored rectangles, it strikingly represents the facade of an apartment building at night. There is no word from the artist about his ambitions for this simple, almost celebratory composition. But Mr. Veneciano deduces that Lewis's choice of the word "tenement" is "loaded with social and economic insinuations." While the painting "cannot be considered a critique of certain New York City living conditions," he allows, it can also be seen as "emblematic of such a critique." The title gives the painting a relationship to "a socially articulated issue." Such freighted post-mortems do little to bolster the work's importance.
As for the show itself, it is divided into several areas, Postwar Abstractions, Rituals and Atmospherics, with subplots in each division. Linearity and a kind of nighttime light (Lewis enjoyed the dark and liked to keep wee-morning hours) dominate the early postwar paintings. The nervous calligraphic line of Mark Tobey, a gallery mate of Lewis's, seems to have affected some, including the impressive "Metropolitan Crowd" mentioned above. And so has the work of the Afro-Cuban painter Wifredo Lam, at least in "Untitled" of 1949. Reminiscent of Lam's Surrealist-influenced jungle paintings, the jostling vertical elements of "Untitled," suggesting attenuated human figures, radiate light and color that shade into dense greenish-black forest at the painting's perimeters.
The "Ritual" paintings translate Lewis's interest in street people and musicians into stylized groups of tiny figures involved in varied, sometimes dancelike movements around and across the canvas expanse. Besides the Klan paintings, a powerful example -- also in black and white -- is "Processional" of 1964, in which a crowd of calligraphic figures marches militantly in a broad, hard-edged band across an all-black field. Protesters, warriors, civil-rights marchers, whatever, they make a striking apparition.
In the 1970's, the decade of his death, Lewis's work seems to take on new vigor, especially in paintings like the spare, Minimalist "No. 2" of 1973, an all-black abstraction randomly scored with thin, vertical lines of white, and "Blue and Boogie" of 1974, a knockout of a painting in which a dynamic whir of bright blue patches -- like a Coney Island Cyclone ride -- animates an all-black field. Similar whorls, strung together across an otherwise empty black canvas, are used as wave forms in a group of energetic paintings that relate to the sea.
Was Lewis really in a league with the powerfully inventive major Abstract Expressionists, as his supporters suggest? Based on this presentation, with all the strengths and weaknesses it exposes, one would have to say no. But the exhibition should help to re-establish a place for him in the arbitrary, market-driven annals of 20th-century American art. Lewis does not deserve to be cast aside, and this show compels attention.
"Norman Lewis: Black Paintings, 1946-1977" is at the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, through Sept. 20.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "America the Beautiful," a painting by Norman Lewis (circa 1960). (Studio Museum in Harlem)

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Big ESPN Deal Means Certain Cable Rate Hike

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
When ESPN decided that it had to acquire the entire Sunday night National Football League package that it used to split with TNT, it elected to escalate its annual rights fee from $131 million to $600 million.
How would ESPN pay for $469 million a year in added costs? Certainly, more games mean more advertising to sell. Being able to market an 18-game schedule, not just the final 9 games, might provide additional sales incentives. 
 But in a conference call with reporters on Jan. 14, Steve Bornstein, the ESPN president, seemed to assure cable subscribers that they would be spared major increases. The increase would be "modest," only "a range of a few pennies" more than was paid for the shared ESPN-TNT package, he said.
Although he was not specific at the time, Rosa Gatti, a spokeswoman for ESPN, said Bornstein was referring to the first year.
But given the new model ESPN has erected, it was hardly surprising this week to see the The Wall Street Journal and Variety report that ESPN will hike its rates 20 percent on Aug. 1, and it wants 20 percent annual increases through 2006.
Much of that would very likely be passed on to consumers.
Gatti would not confirm the Aug. 1 increase and denied that other subsequent increases had been established. "Anything else would be speculation," she said.
But one major cable operator, who asked for anonymity, said, "It's 20 percent now and forever. We're being handed this to eat. Their rationale is we'll get more commercial time and we should get a giveback from TNT."
Greg Hughes, a TNT spokesman, said: "Why should we underwrite ESPN's outrageous overpaying for the N.F.L.?"
TNT has increased costs of its own, doubling its National Basketball Association fees and adding other programming.
Yes, it makes sense for ESPN to charge more for the full package. It only charged for half before.
ESPN anticipated buying the formerly shared property in deals made with cable systems in 1994.
But those deals were signed when there was no idea ESPN would pay $600 million a year -- $50 million more than Fox and ABC paid to retain their packages.
"We're troubled by this," said Lela Cocoros, a spokeswoman for Tele-Communications, the giant cable system owner. "The N.F.L. deal is excessive."
"There's an impression that sports rights fees are going out of bounds but nobody has the guts to do anything about it," said Dick Aurelio, an executive with Time Warner, which owns a 1.1 million-subscriber system in New York City.
When TNT bowed out of the bidding in January to keep half of the package, it did so because it would not drastically alter its economic model with cable systems.
ESPN is the most expensive basic cable service, costing an average 62 cents per subscriber, according to Paul Kagan Associates, the media analysis firm.
Gatti said ESPN offers enormous value, and will try to offset any possible rate increases by offering cable systems more advertising time to sell than was available on the combined ESPN-TNT games; oodles of commercial time to sell on its ESPN and ESPN2 studio shows, and further incentives being discussed.
But the cable operator who asked for anonymity, said:
"The N.F.L. is more valuable to ESPN than it is to us. Having more commercial time doesn't create one new advertiser for me or increase the budgets of existing advertisers. What will happen is local advertisers will have to pay higher rates from us."
He added: "How did cable end up having to pay the most money for the least valuable games? Sunday night games are like the last on the list."
Well, it's obvious: Paul Maguire has joined ESPN's telecasts. Surely he's worth a rate increase, isn't he?
Gatti noted any increase is for all of ESPN, not just the N.F.L. games. But no other sport on ESPN is costing three or four times more than in the past.
 
Seifert's New Job
 George Seifert didn't coach last season after leaving the San Francisco 49ers and won't coach this year either, having agreed yesterday to a multiyear contract to become CBS's third studio analyst for the revived "N.F.L. Today."
"I go into this with the idea that this will be my profession," Seifert said.
"I've been described as professorial, but I'm very passionate about the sport and the emotional insights I've developed."
Did he say professorial? Bill Walsh, Seifert's predecessor as the 49ers coach, was dubbed "The Professor" during his disappointing stint as a game analyst for NBC.
At least Seifert has one wacky entry on his resume Walsh lacks: singing in a karaoke bar in a Visa commercial.
"If you saw that, then you know I have a zany side," Seifert said.
Sean McManus, the CBS Sports president, had targeted Seifert and Mike Ditka, the New Orleans coach and former NBC studio grizzly, for the show.
"Mike was on our list but he made it clear he wanted to stay in New Orleans," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Securities Post Gain On the Strength of the Dollar

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of United States Treasury securities posted gains for the third consecutive day yesterday on the strength of the dollar and a report that suggested that manufacturing was slowing, easing concern that inflation could accelerate.
The 30-year bond rose 4/32, to a price of 103 19/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.87 percent, from 5.88 percent on Wednesday. 
 The market took comfort from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's regional report on manufacturing, which suggested that activity was slowing. The index of economic activity fell to 13.4 from a revised 16.1 in March, while the index of new orders dropped to 16.6 from 18.8. And the prices paid index, viewed as a gauge of inflation, dropped to 6.6 from 12.
Other data released yesterday provided mixed signals on the economy, and investors largely ignored them. Housing starts fell slightly during March, for example, but still remained strong. And first-time claims for unemployment benefits fell sharply last week, dropping by 22,000, to 289,000, but that number may have been artificially held down by the fact that it was a holiday week.
Market participants have been taking some of their cues from the dollar, with bond prices up when it rises and weaker when it declines. Overnight yesterday, the dollar regained some of the ground that it had lost in recent days, rebounding after central bankers and finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrial nations opted not to signal a joint effort to support the sagging Japanese yen.
A stronger dollar makes assets denominated in it, like Treasury securities, more attractive.
But even with market-friendly numbers, investors may still be concerned that the Bank of Japan might take action on its own to keep the yen from sliding too low.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Fell in March, But Not Much

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
Starts of new homes fell less than expected in March after having risen strongly during previous months, the Government reported today, while the number of people collecting unemployment benefit checks at the start of April fell to nearly a nine-year low.
"This is an economy still on a roll," Tim O'Neill, chief economist at the Bank of Montreal in Toronto, said. 
 The Commerce Department said housing starts declined 2.8 percent last month, to 1.59 million units at a seasonally adjusted annual rate. That was just the first decline since November and still left starts at their second-highest level since January 1989. Housing starts had risen 5.8 percent in February.
Analysts had expected a larger decline during March because construction activity in January and February was bolstered by unseasonably warm temperatures.
"Housing is still being driven by low interest rates, full employment and very good levels of consumer confidence," said Robert J. Strudler, chairman and chief executive of the U.S. Homes Corporation in Houston. "Put those three things together and you have a superb housing market."
Mark Vitner, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., said, "The continued strength in home building will reverberate throughout the economy, lifting the fortunes of everyone from builders, bankers and realtors to carpet, furniture and appliance makers."
In another report today, the Labor Department said the number of people on the unemployment benefit rolls decreased by 55,000 in the week ended April 4, to 2.12 million, the lowest level since the week ended July 1, 1989. The department also said that first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 22,000 last week, to a seasonally adjusted 289,000, the lowest level since the week ended July 26. The number might have been held down by the Good Friday and Passover holidays, which could have prevented some discharged workers from seeking benefits, analysts said.
Nonetheless, "the labor market is still humming," said James Padinha, an economist at Briefing.com in Jackson Hole, Wyo.
