LENGTH: 360 words

HEADLINE: Roger Murray 2d, 86, Economist Who Was an Adviser to Congress

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
Roger F. Murray 2d, an economist whose financial acumen made him a frequent adviser to members of Congress and business leaders during the 1950's and 60's, died on Monday at his home in Wolfeboro, N.H. He was 86.
The cause was cardiac arrest, according to the Lord Funeral Home in Wolfeboro. 
 As a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company and later a business professor at Columbia University, Mr. Murray helped untangle some of America's most frustrating problems. In 1962, Mr. Murray, an originator of the individual retirement account concept, worked for passage of the Keogh Act, which enabled self-employed people to have tax-deferred pension accounts.
Some of Mr. Murray's other opinions were particularly forward thinking. In 1952, he warned banks to pursue aggressive equity portfolios, noting that "timing wasn't everything" when trading stocks. That same year, he opposed a plan by Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, to tax executive stock options, contending that salaries were not enough to lure executives away from established companies. Stock options remain a vital part of executive compensation to this day.
Roger Franklin Murray 2d was born on Oct. 11, 1911, and grew up in Manhattan on West 95th Street. He graduated from Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., in 1928 and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Yale in 1932. Mr. Murray then earned M.B.A. and Ph.D. degrees from the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration. In 1934, he married the former Agnes M. McDede of Jersey City.
Mr. Murray had wanted to join J. P. Morgan & Company, but a family friend who was a Morgan executive warned him that the company was retrenching and that advancement was likely to be slow. Mr. Murray joined Bankers Trust instead.
At Bankers Trust, Mr. Murray quickly found his specialty in investment strategy. In 1956, he carried that specialty to Columbia University, where he retired in 1965.
Besides his wife, Mr. Murray is survived by his son, Roger F. Murray 3d, and a daughter-in-law, Linda T. Murray, all of Wolfeboro; three grandchildren, and a sister, Mary M. Westcote of Glen Ridge, N.J.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Doses of Bad News Push Stock Market Down
Stocks dropped sharply, reversing two days of strong gains, on a selloff in drug and technology shares, a new whiff of weakness in Asia and ripple effects of a crash in Cendant stock after the leading franchiser disclosed possible accounting abuses. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which hit its second consecutive record Wednesday, fell 85.70 points, to 9,076.57. Broader market indicators also retreated. Page D8.
 
Treasuries rose for the third day, pushing yields lower. The 30-year bond yield fell to 5.87 percent from 5.88. D8.
 
Merck Profit Below Forecasts
Merck said that its profit rose by a lower-than-expected 14 percent in the first quarter, prompting a decline in most of the major American pharmaceutical stocks, including Merck. But the shares of Pfizer rose, buoyed by strong prescription volume for the company's new impotence drug, Viagra. D4.
 
Ford Earnings Improve
Ford reported a 15.1 percent gain in quarterly operating earnings, reflecting strong sales of trucks and sport utility vehicles and lower costs at the auto maker. D2.
 
Hughes Electronics, a G.M. subsidiary, said earnings more than doubled. D6.
 
More Signs of Economic Resilience
Government reports showed starts of new homes fell less than expected in March and the number of people applying for unemployment last week fell to nearly a nine-year low. D9.
 
Healthy Results for Chip Maker
Texas Instruments said quarterly profit before charges rose 28 percent on strong sales of its specialty communications chips. D4.
 
Sun Microsystems' earnings met expectations but revenue growth fell short, which the company attributed to unfavorable exchange rates and Asia's economic problems. D2.
 
A Race Gap in Cyberspace
At a time when the Clinton Administration is promoting the Internet as an engine of commerce and a tool of democracy, a new study has found that black Americans are far less likely to use the global computer network than are whites. A1.
 
A Blow for Former Archer Officials
A judge ruled that tapes secretly recorded during a price-fixing investigation at Archer Daniels Midland could be used as evidence at the trial of three former executives. D6.
 
F.A.A. Wants to Change Boeing 737
The F.A.A. said it would propose changes in wiring and in fuel vents on the Boeing 737 to cut the risk of fuel tank explosions. A18.
 
Apple in Asia: Advertise Different
Apple Computer has removed images of the Dalai Lama from an advertising campaign in Asia for fear of offending China. Apple has used the image of Tibet's exiled spiritual leader in the United States, where he appears as part of its "Think Different" campaign. A6.
 
The Lawyers in the Mega-Deal
For two lawyers, the proposed merger of Travelers Group and Citicorp was Mount Everest at a time when Himalayan deals are routine. The deal was unusual for its lack of investment bankers, if not lawyers. B2.

HEADLINE: Pork-Barrel Spending Alive and Well in Albany, Report Says

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 16

 BODY:
They advertised it as the end of back-room deals and furtive agreements between powerful politicians. This year, legislators conceived the state spending plan in public meetings, opening the wonder of budget-making for all to see.
But still there were deals: There was $2,000 for the drum and bugle corps of the Bronx Youth Sports Club. And $18,000 to build a playing field for the Lady Lumberjacks softball team at North Tonawanda High School. Chautauqua County will get $150,000 for a methane digester, otherwise known as an electricity generator fueled by cow manure. And so it is spent, hundreds of millions of dollars in "member items," otherwise known as old-fashioned pork. 
 According to a report issued today by an antitax group called Change-NY, lawmakers approved more than 5,000 pet projects, at a cost of $350 million -- up from last year's $175 million.
No one here was particularly surprised by such legislative largesse, coming as it does in a year when legislators are up for re-election, the economy is healthy and the state is awash in cash. But while the open process was supposed to hold lawmakers more accountable for their spending practices, fiscal conservatives said that when it came to pork-barrel spending, it had the opposite effect.
"Unfortunately, involving more legislators meant involving more spending," said Brian Backstrom, vice president of Change-NY. "This open process took the form of everyone getting together, thinking of as many projects of possible and deciding to fund them all."
Despite their reputation, many member items provide an economic shot in the arm for communities of all sizes. Most listed in Change-NY's report are for libraries, schools, fire departments, arts programs and centers for the elderly. But even spending that appears to have only honorable intentions often has purely political roots.
Take the $100,000 to teach students around the state about the Irish potato famine. The Legislature passed a law in 1996 requiring social studies curriculums to include a modern historical view that the famine resulted not just from a blighted potato harvest but also from Britain's policy of exporting other crops that could have kept its Irish colonial subjects alive. The legislation was sponsored by Assemblyman Joseph Crowley, who represents a largely Irish section of Queens and whose constituents may well remember his effort on Election Day.
Several community groups and local government agencies contacted today said they had not been expecting the money the Legislature decided to give them, and had no idea what it would be used for. For instance, Chuck Cornell, executive assistant to the Chautauqua County Executive, did not know what a methane digester was or why the county needed one.
"I could spend all afternoon trying to figure out why we're receiving it," he said. "Someone will have to get back to you."
That someone turned out to be Assemblyman William L. Parment, a Democrat from Ashville, who explained that a dairy farmer in Clymer had written him asking for state funds to purchase a methane digester so he could reduce the amount of cow manure polluting the water and soil around his farm. If the system works, it might be expanded to dairy farms across the state to curb pollution, said Mr. Parment, who added that he did not know the farmer receiving the grant.
"He's just a constituent who wrote to me and said, 'Hey, I've got a problem,' " Mr. Parment said. "We just want to show this is an effective way of managing manure."
But if budget negotiations remain open to the public, and especially if the economy slows, the public might start protesting pork-barrel spending, Mr. Backstrom of Change-NY said. Before that can happen, legislators need to be far more forthcoming about which member items they want to include, long before they pass a budget, he said.
"Legislators still believe that the more bacon they deliver, the more they will be loved," he said. "But the average taxpayer is sick of that thinking. It wasn't evident in the brief open process that took place this year. But it will become apparent in the coming years, when there won't be enough money to go around."
As it turns out, legislators spent less on pork last year than Change-NY expected, Mr. Backstrom said. The group had predicted that pork-barrel spending would reach a record $600 million in 1997-98, including $450 million set aside by Gov. George E. Pataki and the leaders of the Republican-controlled Senate and Democratic-led Assembly for community projects of their choosing. But none of the $450 million, which was to be raised through borrowing, was spent. Mr. Pataki has the power to veto member items, but he may be loath to do so in a year when he and all the legislators are up for election.
Legislators defended the member items included in this election-year budget, saying it was by no means frivolous to spend $10,000 on road signs that would lure tourists to the National Warplane Museum at the Elmira-Corning Regional Airport, for example, or $3,000 on a surveillance camera for a park in Athens.
Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, said the antitax group was being unreasonable. "I think they were critical of the Governor's original budget, too, so they were never happy," said Mr. Silver, a Democrat from Manhattan. "The fact is that the economic plan that was put out to meet the needs of the people is consistent with the needs of the state."
Mr. Parment, the Assemblyman responsible for the methane digester, agreed, saying he did not understand why fiscal conservatives assailed member items year after year. His items include $25,000 for three public libraries and $15,000 for basketball courts in his district, projects that are "pretty mundane" but important to the average citizen, he said. "I don't know why my items always show up on their list," he said. "It's not like this stuff is exotic, like palm trees swaying in the breeze."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Developer Plans to Build Rental Apartments in Historic Chelsea

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
For nearly three decades the Getty gas station stood on the southeast corner of 20th Street and 10th Avenue in Chelsea. But now a Manhattan developer who has leased the land is advancing plans to build a rental apartment building on the site.
The plan is to construct an eight-story building with up to 70 one- and two-bedroom apartments, ranging in size from 500 to 750 square feet, on the first seven stories. Two penthouse units, each with 1,000 square feet, would share the eighth floor, and the ground floor would provide 10,000 square feet of retail space. 
 The developer, Ashkenazy Acquisition Corporation, secured a 99-year lease on the site at 460 West 20th Street last month and started razing the gas station two weeks ago.
The $10 million project marks the company's entry into the Manhattan housing market. It owns three million square feet of commercial properties in the Northeast and the Southwest, including one million in the metropolitan New York region, said Ben Ashkenazy, president of the company.
"The market is demanding and justifying new housing and this is the best underutilized corner in Chelsea," Mr. Ashkenazy said, noting that the site is in a primarily residential neighborhood and is two blocks from the Chelsea Piers recreation complex. He said the company would use its own money to start the project and then seek bank financing.
Monthly rents at the building are expected to average $35 a square foot, or $1,750 for a one-bedroom apartment and $2,625 for a two-bedroom.
The rental market is "extremely tight" in Chelsea, said Evie C. Scocos, rental manager of the Bellmarc Brokerage in Manhattan. Her firm puts the vacancy rate at about 1 percent. The scarce supply pushed rental prices up by 10 percent over the last year, she said.
Monthly rents in comparable buildings with units of similar sizes range from $1,850 to $2,000 for one-bedroom apartments, and from $2,300 to $2,600 for two-bedroom units, Ms. Scocos said.
The current zoning does not include specific height restrictions for a building at the site.
But because the property is in the Chelsea Historic District, which encompasses parts of West 20th, 21st, 22d and 23d Streets between 8th and 10th Avenues, any new buildings must receive a certificate of "appropriateness" from the Landmarks Preservation Commission. That means, among other things, that the facade and scale of proposed buildings must complement those of neighboring buildings.
The area includes the Gothic-style General Theological Seminary, an Oxford-like oasis set on a block bounded by 9th and 10th Avenues and 20th and 21st Streets. The land for the seminary was donated by Clement Clarke Moore, a theologian who is the author of "A Visit from St. Nicholas" and is considered Chelsea's founding father. In the 1830's, he reluctantly began developing the estate his grandfather had bought 50 years earlier and had named Chelsea.
Opposite the seminary is the Greek Revival Cushman Row group of town houses at 406-418 West 20th Street, which were completed in 1840. On the westernmost corner of that block is the gas station site.
To further preserve the neighborhood the local Community Board 4 devised a plan, which was adopted two years ago by the City Planning Commission and City Council as an advisory document to guide development in the area. The plan, among other things, limits the height of new buildings in certain areas of Chelsea. The height of new buildings in most areas in or near the historic district, for example, would be a maximum of seven stories, said Edward Kirkland, chairman of the Chelsea Preservation and Planning Committee of Community Board 4.
The city is now preparing zoning changes to carry out the plan. The zoning proposal then must undergo a review during which the public will have an opportunity to comment on the proposal and the City Planning Commission and the City Council can adopt the changes.
Mr. Kirkland said the 20th Street site was important to the historic district. "The gas station was likely to be replaced," he said. "But we were hoping that wouldn't happen until the plan was in place, insuring that a new building would conform with the neighborhood's historic scale."
Though Mr. Kirkland has not seen Mr. Ashkenazy's plan, he said the building as proposed appeared to be higher than the community board and nearby residents would like.
Five months ago the company submitted a plan for a nine-story building, which the staff of the Landmarks commission recommended be reworked "to be more appropriate," given the buildings nearby.
The new plan lowers the height by one story and Mr. Ashkenazy said the project could still work economically by eliminating the penthouse floor and having a seven-story building.
Though the building's final design has yet to be determined, Mr. Ashkenazy said it would be done "with the existing and new zoning in mind and would fit into the neighborhood." He said he expected to present the new plan to the Landmarks commission in the next two months and to start construction in the fall, with completion a year later.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Heavily Laden Black Chips;
Empowerment Deals Thrive In South Africa, but Sniping And Skepticism Mount

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
When does a "black empowerment deal" truly empower blacks? And when is it just another example of what Jimmy Manye calls "the Irish coffee problem" -- blacks on the bottom, whites on top, with a sprinkling of black faces like cinnamon on the foam to lend respectability?
These are some of the hardest questions in South African business today. 
 Black empowerment is the rage in the private sector and the law in the public sector. In the last four years, so many empowerment deals have been struck that blacks now control 28 companies worth a total of more than $13 billion, about 6 percent of the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, according to Business Map, a consultancy that tracks business trends.
In general, blacks and whites are surprised and pleased that it has gone so well. The leading "black chip" companies outperformed the Johannesburg Stock Exchange last year.
But there is growing dissatisfaction with mega-deals that enrich only a few fortunate and well-placed blacks. That came to the fore in January with the collapse of Johannesburg Consolidated Investments Ltd., one of the country's oldest mining houses.
The sale of the company by the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa to the African Mining Group, headed by Mzi Khumalo, was hailed as a historic moment -- the first time a black man gained control of part of the mining industry. But a falling gold price and Mr. Khumalo's mismanagement so shattered the mining company that it is being broken up and sold off. And critics are saying that Mr. Khumalo, who effectively owned less than 1 percent of JCI's shares, was really a front for white mining executives and bankers who wanted to own a valuable Anglo American spinoff that had been reserved for black buyers.
By contrast, the earlier sale of another Anglo American division, Johnnic, is considered an empowerment success. Cyril Ramaphosa, the former secretary general of the African National Congress and head of the mine workers' union, is the new chairman, and the company is doing well. Hundreds of thousands of black union members are shareholders through their pension funds, and tens of thousands of black small investors were recruited, too. Johnnic has interests in newspapers, automobile plants, beverages and other industries, and the subsidiaries are under pressure to show affirmative action results.
More recently, the head of the broadcasting authority that just awarded Midi TV a license to start the first privately owned free television channel said Midi's 80 percent ownership by black groups had given it the edge. The chairwoman of Midi is Nomazizi Mtoshotshisa -- who, coincidentally, was once married to Mr. Ramaphosa -- and its owners include the pension funds of the mine workers', metal workers' and textile workers' unions, the black chamber of commerce and bodies representing youths and the disabled. Midi also has a powerful foreign backer: Time Warner Inc., which owns 20 percent.
Midi had six rivals for the television license. A recent race for casino licenses drew 23 bidders. Most of these bids for Government licenses are similar: each inevitably has a black spokesman, at least a small group of black investors and a huge local or foreign backer. Cynics sneer that in some cases the blacks are merely window dressing.
Both the private sector, through the Black Management Forum headed by Mr. Manye (pronounced MAHN-yeh), and the Government are inventing ways to test the legitimacy of such bids.
This country has about 33 million nonwhites, counting those formerly classified as African, colored or Indian. All are now, in empowerment jargon, P.D.I.'s -- "previously disadvantaged individuals." And all, when it is politically advantageous to do so, call themselves "black." Most are poor and know little about the stock market. A few are talented entrepreneurs or well-connected politicians in a position to take repeated rides on the empowerment juggernaut. And a few are simply opportunists willing to, in effect, sell their skins to unscrupulous white business executives.
Some white-run companies are taking advantage of empowerment either to qualify for minority contracts or to buy political good will.
"We're sick and tired of companies who do what they want and call it empowerment," Mr. Manye said. "We're going to make it our business to investigate these deals."
As Phinda Madi, the author of "Black Economic Empowerment in the New South Africa," put it, some companies think that having a minority black stake and "a well-known black personality with struggle credentials" as chairman will "serve as protection against the transformation barbarians at the gate."
"It is an open secret," he added, "that some organizations with dreadful industrial relations track records get into empowerment deals as a labor relations shield. The new chairman becomes the fire-eater, the magician to calm the marauding masses on the shop floor."
As more and more black empowerment consortiums -- with names like African Harvest, Kuyasa Mining and Dynamo Investments -- have emerged to compete for the attention of lenders, skepticism has set in. Jenny Cargill, director of Business Map, says bankers and executives are questioning exactly what constitutes "black empowerment."
"One can't belittle black ownership -- it's important," Ms. Cargill said. "But it's usually been achieved with very high debt levels. All the dividends go back to the institutions that backed the deal. Now the companies need to get scrutinized more on their internal policies -- management training, affirmative action. There are these enormous glass ceilings over black staff."
Even in companies owned by the early black consortiums, affirmative action may go slowly. New Africa Investments Ltd., formed in 1994 by President Nelson Mandela's physician, Dr. Nthato Motlana, owns African Merchant Bank, "which is still a very white institution," Ms. Cargill said.
Paradoxically, the company with the best reputation for bringing along black middle managers is South African Breweries, which has white executives and no significant black shareholding.
Mr. Manye wants to create a sort of Black Empowerment Seal of Approval. He is gathering a council of executives, union leaders, church leaders and others to write a checklist by which to measure proposed deals that say they are black-empowerment exercises. It will probably include these provisions:
*How much equity will blacks have?
*How much management control will blacks have?
*Do the blacks named as managers actually have management skills?
*How much training will blacks get?
*Once trained, will they be promoted?
*What will the company do for the poor and for small black businesses?
*Are the assets for sale actually worth the price?
*Do the white partners have the same plans for the company as the black ones do?
The Black Management Forum, which is not rich, expects deal makers to pay to have their proposals investigated. Then, he said, "if you get our stamp of approval, you'll be in good shape." He added, "Nobody will be able to doubt it's black empowerment."
In the public sector, the process is already being formalized by law.
Edward Lalumbe, the legal adviser to the Gauteng Gambling and Betting Board, in the province that includes Johannesburg, had to sort through the 23 long applications for casino licenses. By law, each had to have a black empowerment component. But all were backed by big investors, some by South African companies like Anglo American or the Stocks and Stocks real estate development company, some by Malaysian or other foreign investors. The Black Management Forum, not entirely a disinterested observer, was itself a partner in some of the bids, he noted.
If an applicant said it had a large percentage of black shareholders, the board's auditors would look into who the lenders and the casino manager were. If the projected loan interest or management fees were so large that the shareholders would not see dividends for years, the auditors would question the sincerity of the deal.
Applicants tried different tacks. Some promised to meet quotas for hiring black croupiers, pit bosses and managers. Others promised to buy supplies from black businesses, hire black contractors for construction or set up trusts to lend money to small black businesses. One promised to build a stadium nearby and train black athletes.
For the winners of the four licenses awarded, those promises will become conditions of their licenses. "Our inspectors will check up on them," Mr. Lalumbe said. "If they don't do what they promised, they'll pay penalties or have their license withdrawn."
To spread ownership down to small black investors, many empowerment deals now try to do what Midi TV did: bring in the pension funds of traditionally black unions like the miners and food industry workers. Some approach church groups, women's groups and other organizations and ask them to flog shares to their members.
And two events are in the works that should markedly increase black share ownership in South African society.
The first is that the country's two biggest life insurers, Old Mutual and Sanlam, with combined assets of almost $70 billion, have announced plans to demutualize and list on the stock exchange. All their policyholders, many of whom are black, will automatically become shareholders.
The second is that the Government, which is slowly selling off assets like the national phone company, national airline and the like, will set aside 10 percent of the shares in each deal for small black investors.

HEADLINE: Bank Mergers Pose Challenge To Regulators

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
With a sudden flood of multibillion-dollar bank mergers rapidly changing the financial landscape, some legislators have begun to wonder how well equipped banking regulators are to supervise the new corporate giants.
As the new behemoths adopt the guise of enormous vending machines, spitting out everything from credit cards and savings accounts to insurance, stocks and bonds, the regulatory network that oversees them is splintered among several powerful and turf-conscious Federal agencies that often butt heads when it comes to deciding who is in charge. Those turf wars are only magnified when mergers heat up in an industry like banking. 
 Even so, many bankers and regulators consider a fragmented regulatory system a safeguard against the possible closed-mindedness of one, all-powerful financial chieftain. But short of creating a super-regulator -- an idea that has repeatedly foundered in Congress over the last few decades anyhow -- there are still those who think that the wave of mergers requires some changes in how regulatory agencies oversee financial services concerns, particularly banks.
Yesterday, Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the House Banking and Financial Services Committee, said he would hold hearings April 29 to address, in part, the regulatory challenges posed by the merger boom.
"The financial firms involved in the recently announced mega-mergers are well-respected companies that are acting under current law and regulation," Representative Leach said. "A critical question that the committee will want to address is whether legislation is needed to insure that management and regulators are equipped to prudently administer and supervise institutions of such dimensions."
The challenges facing the nation's banking supervisors are about to grow far more complex than they were in the earlier, bygone era of plain-vanilla banking, largely because of the ramifications of one event -- the merger agreement struck early last week between Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc.
That merger aims to create a new company, Citigroup Inc., that would stand like a financial colossus astride such varied businesses as banking, insurance underwriting and stock brokerage. Insurance powers are the new fly in the ointment when it comes to bank regulation. Banks are permitted to sell insurance, but most cannot underwrite policies. Citicorp is one of a handful of banks that can underwrite life insurance and annuities, but it is still forbidden to underwrite risky property and casualty insurance indefinitely without dispensation from the Federal Reserve.
As that clock begins ticking after the Citigroup merger takes effect, it is likely that other banks will test the insurance waters as well, forcing Federal banking regulators to don yet another hat -- that of the insurance analyst. Banks are also expanding more aggressively into other new activities, such as the sale or underwriting of stocks, making the regulatory web even more complex.
The officials primarily responsible for keeping tabs on banks include the Federal Reserve, which oversees bank holding companies, has great sway in determining whether major banks can pursue new lines of business, has final approval over mergers, and opens and closes the money supply spigot; the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which charters national banks and examines their books; the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which guarantees the deposits of its member banks, and the Office of Thrift Supervision, which charters and examines savings and loan companies.
There is no single Federal insurance regulator. Rather, there are individual insurance regulators in each of the 50 states. Since so many commercial banks have also moved into investment banking and brokerage businesses, the Securities and Exchange Commission gets to play its regulatory role in the banking industry as well. To date, the derivatives business has been only loosely regulated, despite banks' heavy involvement in trading those complex financial hybrids in a booming international market. Exactly which Government agency has primary authority for regulating derivatives is still a matter of debate, as the S.E.C. and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission are engaged in a turf war over those powers.
What all of this means is that the types of risks major banks are undertaking as they pursue new lines of business are far different and more complicated than ever, yet there is a snarl of regulators assessing those risks. Moreover, the current regulatory brew produces a hodgepodge of rules that can make for some odd inconsistencies in the way big banks in the same markets operate.
"It has always seemed bizarre to me that our financial system is subject to four separate Federal regulatory agencies for banking," said Robert Tortoriello, a lawyer with the New York firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton. "There are four separate supervisors who don't say the same thing on every issue for every bank."
For example, the Comptroller permits subsidiaries of national banks to underwrite municipal bonds, while the Fed forbids state-chartered banks to do the same thing. National banks are forbidden to own real estate investments under the Comptroller's guidelines, while the F.D.I.C. permits some state-chartered banks to own investment property.
One outcome of all of this is that banks regularly shop new business ideas to different regulators in the hope that one agency will sign off on something another opposes. And many regulators think that is a healthy thing for the economy.
"It's been fundamental to the history, development, and strength of the U.S. banking system to have nationally chartered banks and state-chartered banks with different powers," said Julie Williams, the Acting Comptroller of the Currency. "What it has produced over the years is innovation at the state and national levels."
To be sure, no one is arguing that every merger of the last several days is cause for regulatory alarm. A pair of huge merger agreements on Monday, between the BankAmerica Corporation and the Nationsbank Corporation and the Banc One Corporation and the First Chicago NBD Corporation, were noteworthy for their unusual size, but they are just much larger versions of mergers that have been going on for several years as banks attempt to expand their national or regional reach.
"I don't see why some of these big bank mergers would require a change in the regulatory scheme," said H. Rodgin Cohen, a lawyer specializing in banking law with Sullivan & Cromwell. "There are no antitrust issues here with the big mergers, and Federal regulators have already been moving expeditiously to address mergers of great size in the banking industry."
But the Citicorp merger with Travelers is a unique event in the financial world and it is the main reason some legislators want to readdress the contentious issue of regulatory reform.
Although so many new financial activities are now being swept under the banking umbrella, it is unlikely that it will result in any mega-mergers among Federal regulatory bodies. A bill sponsored by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, and introduced in February of last year, seeks to create a commission that would merely coordinate the activities of disparate agencies. But the fact that Senator D'Amato's idea has not caught fire in Congress illustrates how little enthusiasm there is for giving any overarching supervisory powers to one body.
Merging the operations of big bank supervisors has not sat well with the heads of any of the regulatory agencies currently overseeing banking. Some of this has to do with a desire to protect administrative turf. Yet many, including bankers themselves, see diffuse regulatory powers as a boon to the banking industry. One of the chief proponents of this view is the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.
"A consolidated single regulator would deprive our regulatory structure of what the board considers to be the current invaluable restraint on any one regulator conducting inflexible, excessively rigid policies," Mr. Greenspan said in 1994, when the idea of a super-regulator was floated unsuccessfully in Congress. "The dual banking system and multiple Federal regulators have facilitated diversity, inventiveness and flexibility in our banking system, so important to a market economy subject to rapid change. A single Federal regulator would effectively end the dual banking system."
Legislation intended to overhaul banking laws was recently withdrawn in the House of Representatives, but is to be reintroduced shortly. It calls for clearly breaking down regulatory authority by function. In that plan, the S.E.C. would get first crack at regulating securities activities by banks, insurance czars in each state would oversee insurance operations and so forth. The bill also tilts in favor of the Federal Reserve as the principal regulator of banking activities.
Representative Leach said he saw that bill as a potential model for how regulatory snags might be resolved, although he acknowledged that the Comptroller was unlikely to defer to the Fed as a first among equals when it comes to banking regulation.
"The question with the Citicorp merger with Travelers is how it fits within the current construct of the law," Representative Leach said. "You need a precise locus of responsibility for overseeing each of the parts."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Who Watches the Banks"
A look at the Federal agencies that oversee bank regulations and activities.
 
FEDERAL RESERVE BOARD
Governing board of the Federal Reserve System and the primary regulator of bank holding companies. Sets reserve requirements for financial institutions and serves as a lender of last resort through its discount window. Also responsible for monetary policy: loosening or tightening the availability of credit and regulating the purchase of securities on margin. Its seven members are appointed by the President to 14-year terms and are confirmed by the Senate.
 
FEDERAL DEPOSIT INSURANCE CORPORATION (F.D.I.C.)
Guarantees funds on deposit for member banks.
Lends money or buys assets of those banks to facilitate mergers or prevent failures.
 
OFFICE OF THRIFT SUPERVISION
Agency of the Treasury Department that is responsible for savings and loan associations and savings banks. It regulates, supervises and charters these institutions.
 
OFFICE OF THE COMPTROLLER OF THE CURRENCY
The Comptroller's office charters, examines and supervises all banks with national charters. Banks can be declared insolvent only by the Comptroller, who is appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Foreigners Buy Korea Stock but Not Companies

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
While foreigners have been buying South Korean bonds and pouring cash into the country's resurgent stock market, direct foreign investment in Korean companies remains sluggish.
Since the nation flirted with default on its international loans in December, only two outright acquisitions of South Korean companies by foreigners have been confirmed: BASF's purchase of the Daesung group's lysine business for $600 million last month, and the impending acquisition of Samsung Heavy Industries' construction equipment unit by Volvo for $765 million. 
 While foreign investors complain about sketchy accounting and legal barriers, many of the negotiations under way here are bogged down over the fundamental issue of price. Even acutely troubled Korean companies are expensive, their ability to survive bolstered by easy availability of capital.
South Korean banks, saddled themselves with bulging nonperforming loan portfolios, are finding ways to prop up favored corporations that are technically insolvent, and the result, in the eyes of many foreign investors, is that valuations are unrealistically high.
"There are lots of active negotiations and due diligence going on, but all are running into the very significant difference between buyers' and sellers' perceptions of value," said Gary L. Clinton, co-chairman of the foreign investment committee at the American Chamber of Commerce in Korea. He noted that many of the deals coming to fruition now began before the country was forced to go the International Monetary Fund for financial help.
To be sure, many foreign companies have moved to protect their stakes in joint-venture operations by buying out their partners.
Intel has pledged $1 billion to help support small and midsized companies in the computer business.
And foreign investors purchased the bulk of $4 billion of South Korean Government bonds that sold recently at far lower rates than even optimistic analysts had expected.
Foreigners are largely responsible for the rise in the Korean stock index, a more liquid form of investment than direct acquisition of companies.
But the fire sale that many investors anticipated has not developed, at least not yet. The Government has moved swiftly to eliminate regulations on foreign investment, and officials from President Kim Dae Jung on down have devoted themselves to selling corporate South Korea to the rest of the world.
The country does need investment. "There are no domestic sources of capital available on remotely the scale that's needed," said Wilbur Ross, senior managing director of Rothschild Inc. in New York and adviser to the Halla group, one of South Korea's troubled conglomerates.
In an effort to prop up companies that in many cases were its best customers, Korean banks have been providing financing to weak corporations at below-market rates, a practice euphemistically labeled "cooperative financing." It takes different forms, ranging from outright new loans to rolling over existing debt at lower interest rates.
Often the beneficiaries of such largess have debts outweighing their equity by four times or more, an astounding level by Western standards.
Critics say that this practice further imperils the already shaky banking system and deters the foreign investment South Korea desperately needs. "This is retrogression in the financial system," said Stephen E. Marvin, research chief at the Ssangyong Investment and Securities Company. "And it is the financial system that is most vulnerable at this point because the financial system is highly exposed to large numbers of companies with huge amounts of debt and no way to service it. Let's face it, these cooperative loans are gone; they're never going to be paid back."
Take the Hanwha group, South Korea's ninth-largest conglomerate, which is struggling to restructure itself, so far to little avail. "The most difficult part of restructuring is implementation," said Lee Jae Moo, head of strategic planning at Hanwha. "This is taking a long time, longer than we expected."
Hanwha has put a number of its businesses -- petroleum-refining operations and gasoline stations, a precision ball-bearing machinery company and some real estate holdings -- on the market. The ball-bearing company is being examined by prospective buyers, and the energy businesses have attracted several interested parties despite a debt-to-equity ratio of 10 to one.
Hanwha's banks have extended cooperative financing twice since December to keep it afloat. The energy business relies on short-term commercial paper to purchase oil imports, and making payments was difficult in the period immediately after South Korea went to the I.M.F. for loans, Mr. Lee said.
All told, at current exchange rates, Hanwha has received $286 million in additional financing at preferential market rates, and its bankers have rolled over $244 million in debt. Over all, the company has a debt-to-equity ratio of seven to one
No wonder, then, that Hanwha must work hard to sell its assets: It has to get very high prices if it is ever to pay off its bankers.
Hanwha's desire for a high price for its energy businesses, despite the debt-to-equity ratio, has already driven away Royal Dutch/Shell, reportedly one of the contenders along with Caltex and Total, according to bankers.
"That kind of financing isn't great news," said Harry Van Dyke, head of Morgan Stanley's mergers and acquisitions business in Asia and adviser to the Daesung group. "It means less pressure on companies to rationalize their businesses."
President Kim has called for an end to cooperative financing, but Lee Chul Hwan, a director in the Economic Policy Bureau of the Finance Ministry, said there was probably no legal way to prevent banks from making whatever loans they chose. "We agree that it only delays reorganization," he said of the practice. "We're working to set some limits."
Business is fighting those efforts. Lee Yong Hwan, executive director of the Federation of Korean Industries, compared ailing companies like Kia, Halla and Hanbo to the Chrysler Corporation, which Washington bailed out in 1979 because it was deemed too big to be allowed to fail.
"The consequences of loans to insolvent companies should be left to market principles," he said. "The decision to extend cooperative financing is a decision reached between a bank and its client company, and so should not be stopped."
South Korea's bankers insist that such preferential treatment is given only after careful consideration of a client's future prospects. "The extension of cooperative financing always comes with a strong demand for restructuring," said Lee Seok Woo, assistant director of loans and loan evaluation at the Hanil Bank, Hanwha's lead bank, and the only banker willing to discuss the practice for the record. "If we see no positive results, then we stop providing cooperative financing and allow a company to go bankrupt," he said.
But if that were to happen too often, it would bring down the banking system, he said, adding, "We are taking such measures because if we allow insolvent companies to go bankrupt, this will lead to too many nonperforming loans."
On the other hand, said Rhee Namuh, chief of research at Samsung Securities: "If banks were willing to take the hit, it would make debt restructuring much easier and invigorate the whole liquidation cycle. But so far, though, restructuring has been very disappointing, especially in terms of the reform of banking practices, which is crucial."
Paradoxically, those companies that do not receive cooperative financing seem to be restructuring the most quickly. The Daesung group, which sold its lysine manufacturing operations to BASF, had to put its golden egg on the market to survive, but it was rewarded when a bidding war broke out and the price ended up at a remarkable 2.8 times revenue.
The lysine business represented one-fifth of Daesung's revenue, but its sale will lower the group's debt level to 2.5 times equity compared with four times equity before.
"The few firms that have cut their prices and agreed to terms that they wouldn't have considered realistic a year ago stand to reap the greatest benefits," said Richard Samuelson, executive director of SBC Warburg Dillon Read in Seoul. "They're going to end up getting the higher prices in the long run and be in better shape to go forward faster."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Earnings Setbacks and Asia Fears Send the Dow Sliding

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Disappointing earnings from the drug maker Merck, a reversal among technology stocks and a wisp of trouble in Asia helped send the stock market lower yesterday.
The crash of the stock of the Cendant Corporation after it announced that accounting irregularities would force it to restate earnings also helped pull the broader market lower. Cendant, which owns or controls brands that include Avis, Howard Johnson and Coldwell Banker, tumbled 16 9/16, or 46 percent, to 19 1/16. 
 "The trend is positive, but we will continue to see this volatility because there is so much uncertainty" about the immediate outlook, said George Cohen, a principal at Cohen, Klingenstein & Marks, a money manager.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which set a new high Wednesday, fell 85.70 points, to 9,076.57, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 11.15 points, to 1,108.17. The Nasdaq index, which also hit a new high Wednesday, finished down 5.02 points at 1,858.24.
Overnight, stocks in Asia fell sharply, led by a 2.9 percent drop in South Korea and a 2.6 percent fall in Japan. The finance ministers of the Group of Seven nations meeting in Washington indicated that they would not move to support the weak yen, saying that it is the Japanese Government's job to get the economy moving again. In South Korea, labor tensions rose as workers threatened a strike at Kia Motors, a bankrupt auto maker.
While the outlook for Asia -- and its impact on the American economy and corporate earnings -- has been better than had been expected several months ago, the market declines were a reminder that there could still be trouble ahead.
Stocks were also pressured by Merck & Company, which announced before the market opened that its first-quarter earnings rose 95 cents a diluted share, just below the estimates of analysts. Considering how much some drug stocks have rallied this year, the underperformance led to a selloff. Merck fell 4 1/16, to 119 7/16. Johnson & Johnson, which just met analysts' expectations when it reported earnings Tuesday, dropped 1 9/16, to 70. Eli Lilly was off 1 1/2, to 63 1/4, and Warner-Lambert fell 1 15/16, to 168 13/16.
The only major drug stock that rallied was Pfizer, up 3 1/8, to 100 11/16. Pfizer has jumped 35 percent this year on optimism about its new impotence drug, Viagra.
Technology stocks had risen sharply Wednesday. But yesterday, even after the surprisingly strong earnings from Apple Computer, a lot of big technology stocks fell.
One negative factor in the Apple report may have hurt: its revenue was down 12 percent, meaning that all the strong earnings came from cost-cutting and better profit margins. But some analysts feel that it is getting harder to improve results this way, given the price cutting in the industry and the pressures on wages. This means sales are the way to higher profits, and Apple and other computer companies still face problems on this front.
Intel, which reported better-than-expected earnings late Tuesday but said the second-quarter outlook is not strong, fell for the second day, finishing at 74 3/8, down 1/2. Amgen fell 2 1/8, to 53 13/16, and Cisco Systems, which rose sharply Wednesday, slipped 1/2, to 70 3/16. Microsoft was down early in the day but rallied to close up 5/16 at 91 11/16.
Ford rallied at the opening, after reporting record earnings that were better than expected. But it then slipped, a fall that may have been spurred by its announcement that it had no immediate plans to repurchase more stock, a maneuver popular with investors. It fell 3/16, to 49 11/16. The companies involved in the three big financial mergers announced over the last two weeks all fell again, led by BankAmerica, down 3.4 percent, and Nationsbank, down 3.1 percent. J. P. Morgan, which hit a 52-week high Wednesday on speculation that it might merge, dropped 3.9 percent.
On the positive side, Internet stocks surged. Excite jumped 8 1/8, to 91 1/8, before reporting that its losses had narrowed during the first quarter.
Oil company stocks shot higher as the price of crude oil moved up sharply for the second day. Exxon, up 1 5/8, to 70 5/16; Chevron, up 3 11/16, to 83 3/4, and Mobil, up 1 5/8, to 77 1/8, gave both the Dow and the S.& P. 500 their biggest lifts.
So far, 149 companies in the S.& P. 500 have reported quarterly earnings. Of the total, 50 percent have reported a positive earnings surprise, below the range of 55 percent to 65 percent of the last two years, accorrding to I.B.E.S., a firm that tracks analysts' estimates.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Giuliani Threatens to Oppose Kennedy Rail Link

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday that it had awarded a contract of nearly $1 billion to build a long-delayed rail line linking Kennedy International Airport to nearby subways and trains. But hours after the announcement, the Giuliani administration warned in a blunt statement that the city had not yet formally approved the plan.
The total $1.5 billion project, a scaled-down version of what has been a long-frustrated dream of city planners, would for the first time link the airport by rail to Manhattan and other points. The Port Authority said yesterday that it planned to break ground on the light-rail line within months and have it running in phases in 2002 and 2003, but such hopes were immediately tempered by the city's reaction to the annoucement. 
 "This project cannot begin until a final agreement is reached with the city," Anthony P. Coles, a senior aide to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said in a statement. "A final agreement has not been reached and by making this announcement prematurely the Port Authority, once again, is placing its own priorities over the priorities of New York City."
Administration officials said they wanted explicit written assurances that the city would not end up paying $200 million in construction costs that are not covered by an airline passenger tax. The city also wants to be sure that the Port Authority will carry out a planned study of a separate link to La Guardia Airport.
The Mayor had originally favored a far more ambitious plan to provide a rail link from Manhattan to Kennedy that would not require passengers to change trains in Jamaica, Queens. He finally eased that stance last year, but has continued to take a tough line in negotiating with the Port Authority, which he has long accused of favoring New Jersey over New York. The Giuliani administration has also vowed to seize control of New York's airports from the Port Authority.
If the Mayor chose to, he could stall the project through the city's land use review process. Before the light rail project can begin, it must gain approval from the City Council and the city Planning Commission, a majority of whose members the Mayor appoints.
Port Authority officials announced the awarding of the $930 million construction contract during an elaborate news conference in which they presented miniature models of the train and showed renderings of the futuristic light rail cars traveling in the middle of the Van Wyck Expressway. The construction contract and a $105 million, five-year contract to run and maintain the line was awarded to a team of companies: Skanska USA, the American division of a Swedish heavy construction company; the Bombardier Transit Corporation, a Quebec train manufacturer, and the Perini Corporation of Framingham, Mass., a construction company.
The line, officials said, would allow for rail trips between Pennsylvania Station and Kennedy Airport that would take only 45 minutes and involve one transfer. The trip from Manhattan to Kennedy can now take more than two hours by car or bus, or subway and bus, along sometimes congested routes.
The dispute was just one in a series of instances in which the Mayor has taken issue with projects backed by the state.
Last summer, Mayor Giuliani said he would block the sale of the Coliseum site in Manhattan only days before the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was to announce the selection of a developer.
The Mayor has also turned a deaf ear to the state's $750 million proposal to expand the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
"Obviously, there are disagreements between the city and the state," Charles A. Gargano, the state's Commissioner of Economic Development, said yesterday. "There is no question these things have to be worked out. But it's hard to understand the criticism about spending $1.5 billion on light rail to Kennedy Airport."
The current disagreement stems from a crucial ruling by the Federal Aviation Administration in February. In an advancement for the plan, the agency ruled that $1.3 billion of the project could be paid for mainly through revenue from a $3 charge already added to every ticket sold for flights from Kennedy. But the Federal agency ruled that the ticket fees could not be used to cover as much as $200 million in project expenses.
A Giuliani administration official said the city would not give final approval to the project until it had been guaranteed it would not have to pay the additional $200 million.
"We have to make sure that if there is a shortfall, the city is not liable for it," the official said.
The stance was one in a series of tough negotiating positions the Giuliani administration has taken.
The city and the state were close to an agreement last June, but it fell apart when the Mayor learned that the Port Authority planned to deduct its $300 million share of the construction cost from the rent it pays the city on the airports, effectively passing on the cost to the city.
During later negotiations in September, the city refused to approve a $23 billion plan for Federal transportation aid, stopping the flow of Federal money for hundreds of projects in New York State and the city. The state eventually agreed to provide the $300 million shortfall and finance a $100 million study of a direct subway line between Manhattan and La Guardia Airport.
The 8.4-mile project is about one-fourth the price of a proposed 22-mile railway linking Manhattan, Kennedy and La Guardia airports that was deemed too costly in 1995, one of 20 previous proposals that have stalled over the last three decades.
Officials have long said that easier access to Kennedy is one of the region's most pressing transportation needs.
Port Authority officials said that under the plan a two-mile rail line would link Kennedy's nine terminals to each other. A 3.4-mile line would link the terminals to parking lots, rental car agencies and the Howard Beach subway station. A three-mile elevated line running up the center of the Van Wyck Expressway would link the airport at Jamaica Station in Queens to the Long Island Rail Road, the E, J and Z subway lines and the bus lines.
Port Authority officials said the shuttle around the airport would be free and other prices were not set.
Karen Antion, the Port Authority's chief technology officer, said the new rail system would attract anxious passengers by allowing them to avoid erratic traffic congestion. "Even if it's a fairly quick trip," she said, "it's more important that it be reliable, that you know how long it will take you."
Port Authority officials said a big part of the potential ridership in the new system would be Kennedy employees. People working at the airport make up about half of the people traveling to and from the airport each day, they said.
Currently one million of the 18 to 20 million passengers who travel to and from Kennedy each year use the subway to arrive there, according to Patty Clark, airport access program manager for the Port Authority. She said that Port Authority officials project that four million people will use the subway and train for travel to Kennedy during the new system's first year.
The plan still faces hurdles. The Air Transport Association, the trade association of the major airlines, vowed to pursue a lawsuit it has filed in Federal District Court in Washington questioning the F.A.A. ruling that $1.2 billion in passenger taxes could be used for the project.
Critics of the plan, who include dozens of Queens community groups opposed to the Jamaica station link, say it is a glorified version of the failed "train to the plane" express subway that was abandoned in 1990 because of low ridership. Lugging heavy luggage into subway stations and making transfers, one of the main complaints of the train to plane, are part of the new system.

HEADLINE: Warsaw Journal;
Trying to Make the Twain of East and West Meet

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW, April 10

 BODY:
Bronislaw Geremek, the Foreign Minister of Poland, is an ineffably polite man and a practiced listener. But there are occasions that try his patience.
After hearing some platitudes over a copious lunch from his counterpart in neighboring Belarus about how the authoritarian Government there held no political prisoners, Mr. Geremek, a dissident during Poland's Communist era, replied crisply, "That's what they used to say in Poland when I was in prison and being called a hooligan who spied for the United States." 
 Such passion in public is unusual in the highly scripted world of foreign ministers. But in many respects -- for instance, as a Jew in a country that during the 20th century has shown little tolerance toward Jews, and as a distinguished historian -- Mr. Geremek is different from his well-rehearsed colleagues who dominate diplomacy in Europe.
Appointed last fall by the new Solidarity-based Government, Mr. Geremek, 66, is Poland's public face at a critical juncture: as the deal to join NATO is all but done, and negotiations on what promises to be a tortuous path to the European Union are just beginning. As Poland seeks to anchor itself in the West -- to regain "our natural place," Mr. Geremek says -- it must foster relations with its old foe, Russia.
In short, Poland is trying a delicate balancing act as it strives, with its 40 million population and spirited 6 percent annual growth, to become a mid-size European power.
On its western border, relations with Germany are close to "a miracle," says Mr. Geremek, who survived the Nazi occupation of Poland during World War II. His father died at Auschwitz, and many of his relatives, he said, were also killed at the death camp.
"I'm astonished in the change of attitude of Polish society toward Germany," Mr. Geremek said during a conversation at the Foreign Ministry here. Surveys show that Poles feel steadily less threatened by Germany, even as they remain uneasy about the territorial designs of Russia. For Mr. Geremek, the reconciliation with Germany has been a personal journey, as well.
"I couldn't imagine I would become a defender of Polish-German rapprochement and that I would receive the Karls Prize," he said, referring to a prestigious award he will receive next month in Germany. "With my biography I could not forget the war. I had to learn how deep was the sense of responsibility of Germany society for the last war. I will never forget the past, but I think it is a closed chapter."
With Russia it is not so easy. First, there is Poland's membership in NATO. On his first visit to Moscow as Foreign Minister, Mr. Geremek said he found the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, sincere. "He said: 'You have to understand we are not glad about the enlargement of NATO. But we know it will happen. Just don't ask us to be happy about it.' "
Then there is the question of Poland's eastern border; once Poland becomes a member of the European Union, this will become the frontier between Western Europe and the former Soviet Union. As a price of admission to the European Union, Western Europe is demanding that Poland create strict controls on its 1,000-mile-plus border, through which hundreds of thousands of Russians, Ukrainians and Belarussians pour monthly.
In Germany and France, some argue that by wanting to join the European Union but still maintain warm trading ties with Russia, Poland wants to have its cake and eat it, too. "The European Union has quite good cake by having Poland," said Mr. Geremek, forever the Polish patriot.
But aware that Western Europe still needs to be convinced that Poland can manage its borders, Poland has introduced paid visas for some visitors from the east. In essence, though, Mr. Geremek is in favor of openness.
"I don't think at the end of the 20th century we should think in terms of closed borders and repressive means," he said. "One can't create barbed wire; that period is over. I'm a former dissident, and I can't forget that for us, the possibility of going abroad and getting a visa easily means freedom."
After escaping the Warsaw ghetto at age 11 with his mother, Mr. Geremek spent the last two years of the war in western Poland under the protection of a Christian man who later became his mother's husband. He returned to Warsaw and graduated in history from the university and took postgraduate studies at the Sorbonne in the late 1950's.
He speaks impeccable French and is treated like a national treasure when he arrives in Paris. One of the reasons, perhaps, is that his specialty as a historian is medieval France. His postdoctoral thesis was on prostitutes and outcasts in medieval Paris, a subject that he warmed to, he said, because it dealt with the weak and the poor.
In 1968, when the Communist Party ran an anti-Jewish campaign and many of the remaining 30,000 Jews in Poland emigrated, Mr. Geremek stayed put. He never considered leaving. "It's my country," he said. "If I don't like the policy in my country, I have to change it."
Later that year the Warsaw Pact countries invaded Czechoslovakia, and Mr. Geremek left the Communist Party. "That was the last chapter of the illusion that Communism can have a human face," he said.
When the Solidarity trade union movement coalesced around the shipyard worker Lech Walesa, Mr. Geremek became one of a handful of intellectuals who devised a strategy to outwit the regime. During martial law, he was interned for a year.
In the last few months, Mr. Geremek has been out of Poland more than at home, visiting hot spots as chairman of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, the 55-nation group that includes the United States and works on conflict prevention and resolution. He flies, with only a modest retinue, in the Polish Foreign Ministry's small jet. This month he was in Central Asia, in part because as a leader who feels his country was kept outside the pale of normalcy for too long, he believes that smaller nations must be heard from.
But overwhelmingly, his eye is on the main chance for Poland, and there his sense of Realpolitik far outweighs his patience. He is not a Pollyanna who believes that Poland will be part of the union by the millennium. But waiting until 2010, as has been suggested, is out of the question.
"If the expansion of the European Union is to be a factor of stability, it should happen in the next three or four years," he said. "In 10 or 12 years, anything can happen."

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Latin America to 'Be Patient' on Free Trade

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 16

 BODY:
President Clinton pleaded with the leaders of Latin America today to be patient with the United States as it conducts a painful internal political debate over the merits of free trade throughout the hemisphere.
Mr. Clinton, in Chile for a Latin American summit meeting dedicated to creating a hemispheric duty-free shop from the Yukon to Tierra del Fuego, felt compelled to explain Congress's refusal last fall to grant him unlimited trade negotiation authority, known as "fast track." 
 In a speech to an international business audience here today, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that he had so far failed to persuade a majority in Congress of the benefits of free trade with the other nations of the hemisphere. The United States currently has a free-trade pact with Mexico and Canada.
Mr. Clinton said that ultimately the United States would not walk away from the "colossal opportunity" presented by the so-called Free Trade Area of the Americas, which is supposed to be in place by 2005.
Mr. Clinton quoted Winston Churchill, who said, "The United States invariably does the right thing, after having exhausted every other alternative."
The President said: "So be patient with us. So just stay with us. We'll get there."
Mr. Clinton's remarks set the tone for this visit, which American officials said marks a maturation of the United States' relations with its neighbors, which have veered over the decades from military intervention to not-always-benign neglect. By opening the trip with an explanation and implied apology, Mr. Clinton hoped to establish a dialogue of equals, officials said.
Mr. Clinton said he would continue to press for approval of fast-track authority, under which Congress can approve or reject proposed trade treaties negotiated by Mr. Clinton, but cannot amend them. The Presidential authority is considered crucial to achieve trade breakthroughs because other countries will be reluctant to negotiate trade deals with the United States if they feel Congress will change the terms after an agreement is reached.
A bill granting Mr. Clinton fast-track authority was withdrawn last November after Democrats in Congress said they were not persuaded that the trade deals the President is proposing would provide adequate protection for workers and the environment.
The start of the complex seven-year trade negotiations is the centerpiece of the President's four-day visit to Chile.
The first two days of the trip are dedicated to a state visit to Chile and talks with President Eduardo Frei. This weekend, 34 of the 35 countries of the hemisphere, with the exception of Cuba, which was not invited, will convene in a hemispheric summit meeting to celebrate the spread of democracy and an era of exceptional economic expansion.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Frei, at a joint appearance today, announced that they would work together to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases that lead to global warming. They also announced cooperative efforts on education, disaster preparedness and anti-drug programs.
Mr. Clinton is to speak to a joint meeting of the Chilean legislature on Friday. To the relief of American officials, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, a lifetime member of the Senate, signaled today that he would not be present. American officials had feared that the appearance of the 82-year-old general, who led an authoritarian regime here from 1973 through 1990, would be a distraction from Mr. Clinton's message of hope, growth and democratic development in Latin America.
Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, said Mr. Clinton would not alter his remarks on democracy and human rights, whether General Pinochet was in the audience or not. The operative theory of the trip appears to be that meeting and talking, even if with only modest achievements, are in themselves important benchmarks in the march toward hemispheric economic and political integration.
The official line is that the President does not need fast track to begin the negotiations for the Free Trade Area of the Americas, to which the democratic nations of the region committed themselves at the first modern Latin American summit meeting, in Miami in December 1994.
Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, said Washington had arranged the talks in its own interest, setting out their terms at the beginning, and had assured itself the co-chairmanship of the talks at the end stage of the negotiations five years from now.
In a briefing before leaving Washington, she brushed off concerns that in the interim Latin American nations will bypass the United States and form regional trade groups that will create economic ties with Europe and Asia and put American exporters at a disadvantage.
Ms. Barshefsky said those regional trade deals are not "an overly positive development" for the United States. But she said the Latin American nations would ultimately have to accommodate United States trade terms if they want unrestricted access to the immense American market for goods and services.

HEADLINE: A Rare Fish From Southeast Asia Is the Focus of a Smuggling Inquiry

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER 

 BODY:
Goldfish they aren't. Up to 36 inches long and with silvery bodies and colorful fins, the endangered dragon fish from Southeast Asia are prized for their exotic elegance -- not to mention their good luck, according to the Chinese.
So it was a bit more than curious when about 80 of them were found hidden in a warehouse atop a garment factory in Brooklyn and in shipping crates in Port Elizabeth, N.J. 
 But Federal investigators say this was no conservation effort. Rather, they announced yesterday, an employee of a Chinatown aquarium shop was selling the rare fish on the black market to collectors for up to $6,000 each.
On Wednesday, the authorities arrested the man, Zhi Lin Chen, saying they had uncovered a smuggling operation in which dozens of the fish were being imported in cartons labeled as containing goldfish and red-tail gouramies. The undercover investigation shed light on the little-known and lucrative trade in the dragon fish, otherwise known as the Asian arowana.
"It is probably the most expensive aquarium fish sold on the black market in the United States," said Dr. Dennis A. Thoney, general curator at the Aquarium for Wildlife Conservation in Brooklyn, who was asked by the investigating agency, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, to identify the dragon fish.
Now, Dr. Thoney said, about 30 of the confiscated fish are in large storage tanks in the aquarium, on Coney Island, until they can find new homes in other public aquariums once the Government closes its case.
Mr. Chen, 36, of Brooklyn was charged with one count of trafficking in an endangered species. He was released on $100,000 bond in Federal District Court in Manhattan, and if convicted, he could receive up to five years in prison and a fine of $250,000, prosecutors said.
Mr. Chen could not be reached for comment yesterday. It was unclear from court records whether he owned the Chinatown shop, 38 Aquarium, at 371 Broome Street. At the brightly lighted shop, where large goldfish swam in a tank in the window, an employee said he was not available.
His lawyer, Philip L. Weinstein, refused to comment, except to acknowledge that the charge was unusual. "It's obviously not a case that comes along very frequently," he said.
This fish tale began last fall, when Fish and Wildlife Service agents began investigating the trafficking in Asian arowana, said an affidavit filed in court.
The valuable fish is nearly extinct in the wild, although it is bred widely in Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and other parts of Southeast Asia, said Dr. Carl J. Ferraris, an ichthyologist at the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco whose specialty includes fish from Southeast Asia.
Dr. Ferraris said the arowana are bred for their color strains, and those with gold and red fins and scales bring the highest prices.
"They look very, very elegant," Dr. Ferraris said, "and they swim slowly and make a very stately presence."
During the Government investigation, agents found 59 arowana hidden inside 3 of 15 cartons that were shipped to Port Elizabeth on Oct. 8, the affidavit said.
The shipment was supposed to contain 472 goldfish and 72 red-tail gouramies from a fish farm in Malaysia and was addressed to 38 Aquarium.
Each of the arowanas was individually packed inside two plastic bags, while most of the goldfish and gouramies were dead or in poor condition, the affidavit said. It said another shipment, containing nine more of the rare fish, arrived the next day.
When undercover agents visited 38 Aquarium in November, they met with a man they now say was Mr. Chen. They asked him whether they could purchase Asian arowana and were given a price of $1,000 to $6,000 each, the affidavit said.
On April 2, they returned to the shop and were taken by Mr. Chen to a garment factory on 63d Street in Brooklyn.
There, they found numerous fish tanks and pools, containing about a dozen arowana, on the second floor, the affidavit said.
The document said the agents paid a total of $2,500 for two fish, one ruby red and one red-tailed gold.
The fish were later examined by Dr. Thoney, who confirmed that they were endangered.
Yesterday, at the factory where the fish were found, dozens of workers could be seen at sewing machines.
Asked whether there were any fish tanks in the building, a manager said: "This is a factory. There are no fish tanks."
